title: Four Pillars and a Base: The Structure and Interpretation of a Web NodeJS Project
abstract:
OK, OK, you get Microservices! I am not going to preach about the benefits of  Microservices. You can find hundreds of those.

What I am going to show is how we implemented a Microservice project. The nuts and bolts of creating a repo with all the microservices, the structure of the code of each microservice, and creating packages with the common code. Also how to build a docker image from these microservices, how we test the whole thing, how we build the project, how we deploy it in production, and how we monitor it.

Itâ€™s going to be a really boring talk, full of lots of tips we learned in blood in the last year of implementing this.

So be prepared to be bored! And, hopefully, educatedâ€¦
outline:
* Intro: this is a talk about the _structure_ of a Web project, not the technology, or not even the architecture.
* The four pillars: testing, small and loosely-coupled packages, monorepo, similar packages
* **Why** these four are important, and how they lead to frictionless development (the base)
* Why dynamic languages like JavaScript _encourage_ this kind of structure.
* Now come the pillars:
* Monorepo
* Uniform Packages
* Testing
* Small and loosely-coupled packages
* Summary

title: Egoprogramophobia, or fear of one's own code: how testing can change your life
abstract:
You fear your code. Once in production, you are afraid of changing it. A bug? You fix it using messy, yet surgical, hacks, rather than a refactoring that leaves your code better.

Admit it! You fear your code. But there's a way out: just write tests.
Writing tests is impossible! It makes my productivity tank! My boss doesnâ€™t leave me any time for writing tests!

These are all excuses for not writing tests. I will show you techniques that will force you to write those tests, and I will show you how they help you sleep better at night, make you more productive, and make you a much better developer.
outline:
Based on the following blog post: https://www.javascriptjanuary.com/blog/egoprogramophobia-or-fear-of-ones-own-code-how-testing-can-change-your-life

* The Young Developer: who needs tests, I'm not even in production!
* The Logical Developer: I'm in production. There's no choice: I have to test the code I write every time. I am afraid of changes to the code because manual testing is tough.
* The Questioning Developer: Is this it? Is this software development? Does everyone have Egoprogramophobia? The shakes? Isnâ€™t there an alternative way?
* The Testing Developer: I've decided! I'm gonna write tests!
* The End to End Developer: writing end to end tests for frontend apps
* The Unit Developer: writing unit tests
* The Integration Developer: writing integration tests
* The Strategic Developer: building a testing strategy
* Overcoming Egoprogramophobia: Nirvana!

(I know this looks like a lot. And it is. But I think I can do it in a fun and educating way.)

title: Tales of an open source library
abstract:
Most of us use open source libraries, but we don't write them ourselves. I'm sure some of you asked yourselves before if you can write a library yourself, and can it become popular.
In this talk I will take you through the journey I made writing angular-tree-component. I will cover both the technical sides of writing open source, versioning, bundling, etc. and the funny and joyful moments of writing for the community.
outline:
The talk is divided into 3 main concepts:
technical - versioning done right, maintaining docs, supporting different builds
community - supporting the community, how to be a better open source user, some funny stories
personal - why I decided to write open source and is it worth the time, and what my wife thinks about it

title: React Future
abstract:
React has announced some exciting new features, some of which are already usable today. It's exciting to see where the React team is taking the framework, and putting an emphasis on developer productivity and user experience.
In this talk, we will explore code splitting, data fetching and concurrent rendering, and of course hooks.
outline:
3m Intro
4m Code Splitting
2m Data Fetching
2m Concurrent Rendering
14m Hooks with a live demo!
5m Q&A

title: 5 unit testing facts I wish I knew 10 years ago
abstract:
Getting started with unit tests should be simple â€“ it is just a matter of writing code to test other code. If that is right why so many talented developers fail implementing unit tests in their daily job. I have started using unit tests 8 years ago and failed miserably. It took me 2 years and the right company to start over and learn how to use unit tests and TDD as development tools. However, it was not always clear sailing and as I progresses I found more than my share of pitfalls than blind alleys as well as a fair amount of successes.
In this talk, I will cover the non-trivial facts I learnt over the years about unit testing and the tips that I use to this day.
outline:
2m - introduction
2m - first try writing unit tests
5m - Having the correct environment
2m - 2nd try at unit testing
2m - Class != Unit
2m - Test classification and why it's important
2m - 3rd try at unit testing
5m - Code duplication is OK
5m - it's not about writing tests
2m - Summary

title: MobX - performance and sanity
abstract:
The 2 major challenges for frontend apps these days are maintaining a sane architecture, and good performance.
MobX introduces a very productive way to manage a reactive state with a single source of truth, using plain objects and decorators.
This talk will introduce the idea and concept behind MobX, and how it can completely turn your web development process around.
outline:
It's this talk, with more emphasis on the MobX side, less on the connection to React (I will adapt it to be cross-framework):
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0GF67B5H3dc

title: Legacy code - a horror story with a happy end
abstract:
This is the story of how a startup deals with an 8 years old code spaghetti. 
It's not easy and it sure ain't pretty - but it works and we have our path clear before us. 
If you are interested in how a startup gradually consolidates its 5 code bases and enforces code standards that enable reusability, testing and good architecture on production code - this talk is for you.
outline:
2m Introduction: Who am I and my professional background
5m The problem: About the problems most software companies face (legacy code)
8m The search: Our search for a solution (things that failed)
8-10m Our solution: The solution and its benefits + live examples
2m Summary
5m Q&A
Total time: 30-32 minutes

title: Work in Progress
abstract:
Weâ€™ve all been there, one moment you were enjoying writing a shiny greenfield application, and the next, without noticing it turns into a system that is a nightmare to ship. In this talk I'll answer how we get there.

Its a 4-year journey through the design evolution of a product Iâ€™ve been working on from its inception - Wix Bookings. Today, a complex application used by millions, that scaled both its team and its codebase within this period.  
 
I'll discuss design problems such as like code-sharing practices (aka why â€œcommonsâ€ are evil), API-first thinking in UI components, the importance of domain modeling and boundaries, how over-testing can be damaging and ponder about decision-making.
outline:
Background - 5 mins
Year 1 - 6 mins
Year 2 - 8 mins
Year 3 - 8 mins
Moving Forward 8 mins

title: Refactoring React code with Glean
abstract:
We will be examining an extension Iâ€™ve recently built for VSCode called Glean. Glean, is an open-sourced refactor toolkit for React apps, and has gained popularity lately, with over 24K downloads.
https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=wix.glean
Blog: https://www.wix.engineering/blog/finally-a-react-refactoring-tool-introducing-glean
outline:
Examination of a problem the extension solves 3 mins
Demo - 7 mins

title: Your IDE deserves better
abstract:
Web is a futuristic masterpiece, being written using stone age tools.  Javascript community erected fantastic frameworks and tools. However, we've mostly neglected sharpening their primary tool - our IDE!

While the editor vendors are working their magic to aid us, they stand no chance of keeping up with the evolution of the scene. And that's where I believe, we should step in!

In this talk, weâ€™ll learn how to build an extension for Your IDE using the knowledge You already possess. For demonstration, weâ€™ll be examining an extension Iâ€™ve recently built for VSCode called Glean. Glean, is an open-sourced refactor toolkit for React apps, and has gained popularity lately, with over 24K downloads
outline:
The problem - 7 mins
Introduction to Glean - 3 mins
The motivation for creating Glean - 5 mins
Demo - 4 mins
Building blocks of  VScode -  5 mins
Babel packages - 5 mins

title: Managing for dummies: Managing people smarter than you
abstract:
What if I told you that not all managers know everything?

This lightning talk shows my feeble attempts as a technical engineer manager to not be overwhelmed by my smart minions. In addition, the session talks about of how a manager can bring value even without taking a pause to get a P.hd in every field the team members are experts in.
outline:
* 30s â†’ whoami
* 1m 30s â†’ The problem (freaking smart people with domain expertise)
    * What do people really need from a manager?
* 1m 30s â†’ The solution
    * Contribute by enabling people - noise filter
    * Sharing is caring, concentrate on culture mentoring in addition to technical
    * Know thy context, contribute with completing the big picture for your engineers
    * One on ones => Venting and Ranting
    * Understand each team members pain
* 30s â†’ Summary + ending dad pun

title: SOLID Node Architecture
abstract:
I would explain in deep the SOLID principles as well as key insights from the book Clean Architecture by Robert C. Martin (Uncle Bob).
I would connect it to backend architecture in general, and explain how this can be implemented in node.js, which is very rare in the internet and in practice.
outline:
SOLID principle
Benefits
Architecture design
Node.js implementation for clean architecture

title: Hacking tools for web developers
abstract: Learn how to break it is the only way to learn how to make it. This is my agenda regarding security. If a web developer will know how to hack and how hackers work, the developer will know how to build secure applications and sites. In this session, I will teach and live demo real hacking tools that being used by black hat (and penetration tester) hackers to gain access to databases and code. This session propose is to allow developers to use those tools on their application and make it more secured.
outline:
5 minutes - legal information
5 minutes: type of tools: explained about reconnaissance, attack, and post-mortem. Burp suite.
10 minutes: reconnaissance tools and how to tackle those and mitigation.
10 minutes: attack tools and how to tackle those. Automated XSS, Automated SQLmap, Automated CSRF.

title: Continuous Integration for security: avoid security bugs for fun and profit
abstract: Continuous integration is the main key to scaled developing and deploying. Real, successful products must have continuous integration process to back them up. Good CI process helps us in maintaining a good code base and good product. You can also implement strong CI to implement security. In this session, I will explain and demo CI tools to ensure security on web products - from automated PT tests to headers scan. Implementation of those tools can be done in any CI process and will lead to better, safer products.
outline:
5 min - legal information.
5 minutes - static code to the rescue (and the limitation)
5 minutes- headers, headers importance, and headers tools. How to verify and why.
10 minutes - active PT testing: SQL Injection, XSS injection and how to automate those automatically.
5 minutes - closing the gap: how to make those CI in Jenkins\Travis\CircleCI real CI process.
Total time: 30 minutes.

title: Track all users! How to locate & track users and bypass all those nagging privacy issues
abstract:
Tracking users is not only IP recording. You can use a lot of tools to track and analyze users across platforms even without IP. In this session, I will explain how users try to conceal their identities and how to bypass those techniques.  How you can detect users and track them even if the use incognito mode. How to track them even if they use VPN or TOR. There are a lot of open source tools and code that is available to help us: from digital fingerprint to forever cookies. From WebRTC local IP detection to DNS cookies. 
You can use the information in this session to violate's users privacy, or you can use the session information to know how to defend your privacy. I use it for the latter.
outline:
5 min - legal and GDPR
7 min - Using digital fingerprinting to bypass incognito - demo. and how to mitigate.
7 min - Forever cookie - the dirty, dirty way to lock down any session.
7 min - WebRTC internal IP hack and how to use it. and how to mitigate it.
7 min - DNS cookie and how to get it and read it. How can we solve this issue?
Total 30 minutes

title: The hybrid rendering revolution
abstract:
The web began with server-side rendering, and with some extra help from jQuery, we were happy.

Then came the early 2010's, and a new generation of framework emerged, lead by AngularJS, and ushered in the client-side rendering revolution.

In the last 3-4 years, there's been another revolution, lead by ReactJS, but this one is silent - hybrid rendering.

In this talk I'll go through the benefits and pitfalls of both "classic" rendering techniques in historical context and nowadays, and showcase tools such as NextJS and Gatsby and how they allow any developer to improve their product in ways that seemed impossible just a few years ago.
outline:
2m Introductions, who am I, why am I qualified to speak about this.
5m 2000s web - A web dominated by server side rendering, and why that made sense in the year 2000.
5m 2010s web - The explosion of client side rendering techniques. Explain their benefits and why they make sense in the year 2010, contrasting with the things said about the 2000s web.
10m 2015+ AKA Best of both worlds - Hybrid rendering and how it takes the best parts from both aisles, : faster first meaningful paint/interactive, better SEO, progressive enhancement, and more.
4m This is accessible to any web developer, not just huge corps! Present example frameworks that exemplify these techniques.
4m Q&A

title: From an idea to production in one month
abstract:
You have a great idea for an app or an online service. You're going to be super rich and conquer the world, all the girls would want you and all the boys would want to be you, it's going to be so awesome and mom's going to be so proud, unless... someone have already done that before you.

Let's face it - right now, while you're wasting time reading this blurb, it's either someone have already implemented your idea, or they are in the the final process of releasing it. That's why apps, and digital products in general, need to be built and out in the market fast. Like lightning fast.
outline:
Slide 1: (1.5m)
It all start from an idea
So you have an idea for an app. And when I say an app I mean generally any online service. This is a great idea. Because itâ€™s yours, right?

Slide 2: (1.5m)
Hold your horses!

Hold your horses! We are not there yet. We are not scaling yet. We are bootstrapping, not even penetrating, just building skeletons and base concrete. And to be realistic here, someone probably already had this idea before you and heâ€™s already in the middle of the implementation process. 

Slide 3: (1.5m)
Iâ€™m Yonatan.
Nice to meet you.

My name is Yonatan. I am an entrepreneur, javascript developer, ux designer and a digital nomad. My recent experience with Spontix, a last minute events-tickets app, I co-founded, designed, built, launched and sold within a few month led me to make this talk.

Slide 4: (1.5m)
So letâ€™s look at what we have.
And what we donâ€™t.

So letâ€™s see what we have. We an idea, which is great. Hopefully we also have some sort of market research and business model. Because to be brutally honest with you, if you havenâ€™t done any of that your idea isnâ€™t worth much.

So how do we make this idea become a real product?

Slide 5: (2m)
Focus on the M in MVP.
This is probably the best advice I can give you. Keep things minimal. It doesn't matter if you are the one whoâ€™s actually building it, or you have a technical co-founder, or you have an digital agency to craft the product for you - Development takes time.
Therefor, take a good care white writing done requirement list and functionality for the app, then go over the list and remove 20-30% of the tasks youâ€™ve listed. Then go to sleep, wake up in the morning, and wind up another 20-30%. The first version of your app should be light and lean, which lead me to the next point.

Slide 6: (2m)
Make things lean.

Thereâ€™s so much been talked about lean startup philosophy and ways to implement it. For those who isnâ€™t aware of it - it base on a circular model of - Build, Measure, Learn. First you build, then you measure if what you measured made sense you learn what you can do to improve and then build more based on the conclusions youâ€™ve made.
If we take this into the scope of first version, keep in mind that every feature you build, might be obsolete after the first cycle - because it didnâ€™t make sense product sense or didnâ€™t drive traffic or what ever. Therefore - when you scope your first version - stick to the very base.

Slide 7: (2m)
Design is everything.

Focus on the flow and the UX, more than the UI. Get like a really good designer to look over your requirements list before starting any work. Good UX designer are able to look through logic and functionality from user perspective, and often theyâ€™ll tell you that youâ€™re requirement document doesnâ€™t make any sense. 
Make sure your design is modular and logic enough to be scaled up in time of need, which will save you a lot of time in the future, both for design and development.

Slide 8: (3m)
Focus on important tasks
Let others do the rest.

You are probably short of resources and canâ€™t do anything by yourself or by your small team. In order for you to focus on crafting a good product, try to figure out what do you need real team members and what could be done by an online service.
I wouldnâ€™t outsource core development or take a Fivrr designer. Because I think those two things relates directly to the product, and good product requires good and dedicated people. 
But for stuff that are not directly connected to the core product, for example, paying a little bit extra to get devop configuration sorted out for server by a SaaS service - I would definitely use these kind of shortcuts.

Slide 9: (1m)
To sum things up.

Minimal - keep your scope to minimum.
Lean - grow fast and in small chunks.
Design - design before build
People - people build product, all the rest is bonus.


Total Time: 15m

title: How we built a scalable end-to-end architecture for real-life machine learning
abstract:
Machine learning and AI received a lot of attention in the last few years, but very little was published on how to architect real-life ML-based systems.

In this session we present our architecture that supports an AI-based system with numerous live models handling multiple types of data (audio, speech, text, numeric data) with multiple training and inference lifecycles, and multiple approaches (supervised vs. unsupervised, traditional vs. neural networks).

We discuss how we created a cloud architecture supporting security and privacy, how we built a system architecture that supports training and inference at scale, and how we package software in a polyglot (Java/Python/...) environment.
outline:
- Quick introduction to machine learning concepts
- Overview of lifecycle for machine learning projects: data collection, training, analysis, inference
- Our cloud architecture (multi-account) to accommodate privacy and security, and researcher access
- Overview of our data flow for different type of machine learning projects: global projects, customer-specific, user-specific; unsupervised, supervised, lightly supervised
- Overview of our system architecture: Leveraging Python and Dockers within a Java environment, Standalone Microservices vs. Embedded Microservices, Scale via Cloud (short vs. long tasks). 
- (If time allows based on preparation) Persistency and data representation for ML based data, and why it matters.

title: Practical functional programming: How and why with examples (in Java)
abstract:
Functional programming has many advantages in writing clean, maintainable and scalable code but one major problem - people have a hard time understanding it.

I'll use my imperative background from writing Java for many years with my functional experience from Scala and Javascript to come up with motivation and implementation principles that anyone can understand and use. even Java developers (I use them myself).

I'll even manage to do it without any mathematical formulas or examples from Haskell

The lecture will be valuable for people that have zero experience with functional programming but also for people who have some sense and wants to understand it better
outline:
- 1m introduction: Who am I and my professional background
- 2m What is Functional Programming (FP)
- 10m Core principles: Declarative, immutability, pure functions
- 10m Building blocks: what are they and how to use them 
- 5m Examples for functional approach to few common patterns
- 2m Summary: motivation and guidelines on using functional programming everyday

Total time: 30m

title: Data Management - The Bad Parts
abstract:
Organizations depend on data to make informed decisions, however the quality of
data in most companies is ... not good. Data is also the foundation for data
science, and when the data is bad, everything that follows is also bad.

In this talk we'll share sightings of data found in the wild.  We'll then
discuss schemas and why they are not enough and raise questions about how can
we make our data pipeline (ETL) better. We'll cover error detection and
recovery, data versioning, data KPIs and more.
outline:
This is a guestimation, the talk is not fleshed out yet. However:
- 2min About me
- 5min Data war stories
- 5min Schemas & beyond
- 3min Causes for data error
- 5min Error detection
- 5min Data versioning
- 5min Data KPIs

title: Stop Writing Comments
abstract: I'll argue that you should stop commenting your code and will show how it'll make it better. We'll see examples in code with and without comments and notice the improvement. We'll also briefly talk about the special cases when it's OK to write comments in your code. Code examples will be in a programming language but apply to others as well.
outline: - 5min Why you should stop writing comments

title: From Clever code to Better code
abstract:
Part of the software developer job is to find new and better ways to solve problems. Writing code using his/her wits, intelligent and creativity.

However, sometimes being too clever can lead to hard to track bugs, maintainability issues and impossible to understand code.
Is all cleverly written code good code, or is it a problem just waiting to happen?

In this session, I will show you real world examples of cleverly written code. And show you how we can use clean code principles, refactoring and design patterns, to transform that code from clever code to good code, code one that your peers - and future self - would thank you for writing.
outline:
2m introduction
5m defining good code
15-20m examples of clever code and how to refactor them
2m summary

title: 4 Programming Languages You Should Learn
abstract:
In this talk we'll cover 4 families of programming languages you should learn. 

We'll discuss how each of them will affect the way you think about and solve problem and will show some code examples from each language.

We'll explore some project idea for you to learn each of these language.
outline:
The talk is not fleshed out, so hwere a guestimation

- 2min Who am I
- 3min How language affect our thinking
- 20min The 4 languages you should learn
- 3min Project ideas
- 2min Q&A

title: How to implement word morphing using AI and Machine Learning
abstract:
All of us have seen how image morphing looks like - how an image of a child is morphed into an image of a tiger.

Can you imagine what would word morphing be like?

In this talk I'll show you how you can use the combined power of AI and Machine Learning to implement word morphing yourself.
outline: I submitted this talk last year too, so I'd appreciate it if you could look at the outline I provided there :)

title: Lessons from the Field: Always On Availability Groups in AWS
abstract: In the process of reaching high availability we've been through all SQL server solutions, e.g. Log Shipping, Database Mirroring, Replication and Always On. In this meetup, we will demonstrate how to configure Always On Availability Groups in the cloud, and live through that (almost). We will talk about DC, listeners, failed failovers, and why Always On is not always onâ€¦
outline:
2m Introduction: Who am I and my professional background
10m Talking about mssql HA implementation that weren't working for us.
5m Explaining about always on solution in AWS environment.
10m Hands on example of the solution in a pre made test environment.
5m Explain the struggles we still face and why always on is not always on.
2m Q&A
Total time: 34m

title: Serverless ETL & data pipeline
abstract: AWS serverless is the new kid in town but lets not forget data which is also critical for your organisation, in this talk we will look at the benefits of going serverless with your data pipeline, but also the challenges it raises. This talk will be heavily loaded with demos so watch out!
outline:
1m  who am I 
2m What are we going to talk about and why data & serverless goes well together
1m set a goal: convert a "generic" data pipeline to be 100% serverless
5m describe a generic clickstream data pipeline
2m describe why it requires so much maintenance
8m * 3 - I'll introduce 3 different component (Kinesis, firehose, athena) where I'll explain which part in the pipeline it might replace and show how it works - total of 24 m
5m - another tool with less details which is aws glue
2m - summary 
5m Q&A
total of 40m

title: Mono vs Multi repo for microservices
abstract:
In this talk we will review the option out there to solve how do you manage your repo(s) in the microservices world. Would you go with multi repo? mono repo? what tools are out there to help you out? we will also review the difference between services and infrastructure packages
This talk will focus on NodeJS and NPM
outline:
1m - who am I
2m - set a goal: understand the benefit and challenges of mono and multi repo in microservices
5m - outline the differences between a service and a common code library and how it effects mono vs multi
10m - present how multi repo solution would work, from the developers workstation until production
5m - tools that helps you implement multi repo
10m - present how mono repo solution would work, from the developers workstation until production
5m - tools that helps you implement mono repo
8m - run a comparison between them
4m Q&A
total 40m

title: Deploy and Destroy: Testing Environments
abstract:
One of the critical factors for development velocity is software correctness. Our ability to develop and ship new features fast is bounded by our ability to validate several aspects of the change:

* Does the feature meet the requirements?
* How does the feature affect existing code, and how can it affect the production environment?

In this talk, Iâ€™ll focus on testing environments: why developers need a self-serve platform to create a full functioning environment on-demand, how such environments should be managed, and how can one restore part of the lost velocity. Iâ€™ll cover an internal system we use at AppsFlyer called â€˜Namespacesâ€™ that addresses the issue with the help of Mesos.
outline:
2-3m intro, 5m about the problem, 10m solution, 10m solution problems
total: 30m~

title: The Anatomy of a Click
abstract:
What actually happens when you click your mouse in your browser window?

In this talk we'll take a deep dive into how our web browser works and what actually happens when a mouse is clicked. We'll take a deep dive into what browsers do, how events work internally and why.

We'll go through how web automation tools like Puppeteer and Selenium simulate user actions, when that goes wrong and why.

Ideally at the end of the talk developers would have a much deeper understanding of how browsers dispatch events and could utilize that knowledge to write better front-end code.
outline:
- 2m introduction
- 5m the DOM event model, event propagation and what a mouse click is conceptually
- 15m stepping through the actual code handling events in Chromium
 - 5m presenting the flow Selenium and Puppeteer take for simulating events.
 - 3m summary and what we can do to be a better developer.

Total time: 30m

title: When Open Source gets Dark
abstract:
So, you have an open source project that's successful. Awesome!

You have millions of downloads, things are looking bright and it looks like everyone wants to get a piece of you. Just what you're you were hoping for.

Slowly, people start making demands about your project. You start feeling pressured. Working on the project isn't so fun anymore and you wish all the pressure would just stop. What happened?

In this talk I'll share my story and the story of other maintainers maintaining several open source libraries with 5M+ downloads a week.

I'll share my failures in keeping people I love engaged as well as my successes after learning what helps.
outline:
- 2m who I am, why this matters
 - 5m the stories of Petka (bluebird), Q (kris) vs. MobX (Michel) and Lodash JDD.
 - 2m what I learned from the Node.js moderation team and conflict management training about burnout and collaborator engagement.
 - 1m summary and tools for when you're in this situation.

title: Deno
abstract:
What would Node.js look like if it was written in 2019?

Deno is a new prototype project by the original creator of Node.js - Ryan Dahl.

It was created with lessons/mistakes learned from Node.js in mind.
In this talk weâ€™ll talk about the future of Deno, its philosophy and how to check it out.
outline:
- 2m who I am
 - 10m what Deno is going to do differently from Node.js
 - 10m what didn't work out since last year when Deno was annouced, changes in its architecture and where we are today.
 - 5m how can it help me
 - 3m Q&a
Total time: 30m

title: How to use Stack Overflow
abstract:
There are several practical tips that can make interaction with Stack Overflow much more pleasant.

In this talk we'll go through the common reasons people have a bad experience with Stack Overflow, how to avoid them and how to ask questions like a pro in Stack Overflow.

Hopefully, I will be able to save people the pains I had to go through when answering questions in Stack Overflow.
outline:
- 1m how I got started with Stack Overflow
 - 1m how Stack Overflow looks like from the perspective of someone answering questions
 - 1m why new questions get downvoted most often
 - 1m how to be kind and respectful in a somewhat toxic community
 - 1m the MCVE and how to get to 100K reputation in Stack Overflow painlessly.

title: Building your first malicious chrome extension ðŸ˜ˆ
abstract: Building chrome extension is so simple & fun. In this talk I will explain the basics of building your first chrome extension, in just a couple of minutes! We will then speak about the various ways to turn your awesome extension to a malicious one. The main purpose here is not to turn you into a hacker, but instead to understand the risks of extensions, and to increase awareness to these "small" and "harmless" plugins.
outline:
2m who am I & WIIFM
10m extensions architecture (building your first extension)
5m make your extension malicious 
5m risks of installing extensions
3m "protecting yourself" recommendations 
2m wrapping up
3m Q&A

title: Ethical questions in software engineering
abstract:
Software is eating the world. We, developers and architects, are a major force influencing software, technology, and the world it creates. We donâ€™t have the privilege of being unaware of our actions. If we really want to create a better world, we must understand the intersection of technology and humanity. We need to open our eyes to the link between ethics and software.
In this session weâ€™ll look at some examples of ethical questions involving software and algorithms. Weâ€™ll discuss technology, sense of self, politics, truth, and try to understand what we can do about it.
outline:
* Introduction to ethics, and why it's important in software development (5m)
* Examples - AI, automation, ML (10m)
* Examples - user choices, attention economy, media , social media and culture (6m)
* Examples - Industry ethos, unethical applications (5m)
* Examples - privacy and behavioral data (4m)
* Conclusions and call to action (6m)
Total - ~ 40m

title: The Ultimate Guide for Software Procrastination
abstract:
All our software is a bundle of decisions. But despite the fact that some decisions can have a long-lasting, crippling effect on our app, we make most of them based on guesses.

But what if the best decision is indecision? What if You could postpone most of your decision until you gather enough facts in order to make the optimal one?

In this talk, we will learn why deferring decisions can result in a much better, simpler code base. Weâ€™ll see examples of decisions we think we have to take on day 1 of the project, yet, can (and should) be postponed and see how practices like Spikes and the right design of your application will allow that to happen
outline:
Intro - 5 mins
Why defer decisions - 8 mins
What decisions can be deferred - 5 mins
Real Options - 5 mins
Enablers - 8
Costs and Summary - 3

title: The Freelance's Survival Guide
abstract:
The new gig economy caused an explosion in the freelances world, and more and more full timers are considering this move.
Problem is - being a freelance is not easy, and there are a lot of considerations and decisions to make.
In this session I'll discuss the most important aspects of being a freelance, based on my 4 years experience as one.

In this session we'll cover the following topics:
- Why do you want to be a freelance?
- Pros and Cons of being a freelance
- Financial management
- Being freelance in the competitive software world
- Tips & Tricks

If you're a freelance, or thinking about being a freelance, then this session is a must.
outline:
3m: Opening and intro
5m: Why do people want to be a freelance, and why they are wrong
5m: Motivations to be a freelance
10m: Finances: How to price your services and how to manage your tax payments so to avoid surprises at the end of the month
3m: Going above the crowd - how to get noticed in the competitive software world
5m: Tips & Tricks 
5m: Q&A

Total: 36m

title: The Journey to Adapt ML/AI Techniques in a Software Company
abstract:
Everybody talks about Data but very few do it and even fewer do it correctly at scale. During my personal experience in the transition from Software Development (C++) to Data Science (Python) and in working with several venues to move to Data Science techniques, I grepped some insights on how a company should approach the Data Science Challange.
At the talk, I will show how to perform the transition from being a software engineer as a person and as a company. The talk will include both a high-level overview of the process as well as some techniques and leads to start with.
outline:
* 2m Intro
* 5m Why your company needs to perform Data Science
* 5m Why moving to Data is so difficult - overshot and undershot scenarios
* 8m How to become a Data Scientist as a person 
* 8m How to add ML product to a Software company
* 2m Summary

title: (Still) Slaying the Monolith
abstract:
This talk describes a journey migrating our company's core product which is using old technology stack into modern reactive microservice oriented architecture.
You will learn how we use Giter8 in order to create microservices easily and encapsulate common behaviors in an Akka-HTTP based library.
We also implemented an update mechanism for applying template updates on existing microservices projects.
In order to generalize this process, we use JMH, Gatling, Metrics-Scala and other Scala compiler flags.
outline:
â€¢ 2m Introduction: Who am I and my professional background
â€¢ 5m background: Problem definition
â€¢ 2m Solution 1: What did we do in order to solve the problem and why did it fail
â€¢ 5m Solution 2: microservice solution
â€¢ 10m implementation: microservice template, working side by side with existing monolith, customer experience
â€¢ 5m Q&A

title: You Might Not Need a Components Framework
abstract:
Web development changed dramatically during the last years. With the enormous amount of JavaScript libraries and the HTML5 standard, today it is much easier to create web apps. But when you want to develop your web app what framework should you pick? React? Angular? Vue? 
In this session we will ask ourselves if we really need a components framework.
outline: I'll cover the concept of component driven development and how to build frontend infrastructure with Web Components. I'll also explain why it's necessary to understand that frontend development isn't about a framework such as Angular or React but rather about composing your app from components. The session will be created for the conference and I'll have an outline for it once I'll start writing it down.

title: Testing in Production
abstract: How do you know your feature is working perfectly in production? And if something breaks in production, how will you know? Will you wait for a user to report it to you? What do you do when your staging test results do not reflect current production behavior? In order to test proactively as opposed to reactively, test in production! You will have increased accuracy of test results, your tests will run faster due to elimination of mock and bad data, and you will have higher confidence before releases. You can accomplish this through feature flagging, continuous delivery, and data cleanup. Only when your end-to-end tests pass in production will you know that your features are truly working.
outline:
5 min - problem with testing in staging environments
5 min - examples of problems from personal experience
10 min - solution, intro to testing in production
(By email: Here I will talk about the way to run tests in the production environment of a system, and how we did it at Meetup, how to do it without disrupting real end users, and how to exclude testing data from data and analytics. I will also talk about the tools that help in this process, like feature flagging.)

5 min - benefits, why it works
(By email: Here I will talk about the benefits of testing in production and why the pros outweigh the cons, over doing it in staging or other testing environments, why its more reliable, and sometimes even easier.)
5 min - Q&A

title: Debugging (with) your mind
abstract:
Discussing the tools we use as software developers is a normal part of  software developer culture. It is normal to dissect the inner workings of a debugger, a compiler or the framework of choice of the moment for the purpose of learning to get more from it. This session is devoted to doing just that to the one tool we ALL use, regardless of programming language or environment but hardly give it any thought - our own mind.

We will discuss the cognitive process of debugging, turning debugging unto itself and gain a glimpse of what we do mentally, emotionally and cognitively when we debug. In the process we will learn how to be better debuggers, programmers and maybe, better human beings.
outline:
- 2m Introduction: about me and my background
- 4m When and why debuggers are bad for you
- 4m Debugging as a mental activity, computer program as a cognitive construct
- 4m Historic perspective: Tom Knight and the Lisp Machine - an MIT labs AI koan
- 8m What cognitive science can tell us about reality and how we experience it
- 4m Implications for debugging - how being aware of the cognitive process can help debugging
- 2m Implications about programming and interaction with other programmers
- 2m Some final words for conclusion

title: The ULTIMATE data processing pipeline with Apache Airflow and Kubernetes
abstract: Processing data is the bread-and-butter of most if not all technology companies. Plenty of tools, conventions, and terminologies were developed around this topic in the last 10 years but looks like a new winner, a tool that is here to stay surfaced: Apache Airflow. In this short lecture, I'll be talking about what it is but will mostly present what I believe is the ultimate setup and approach to running Airflow in production - utilizing the power of containers and Kubernetes. The lecture will contain practical examples and additional goodies that we at MyndYou learned from using it in production.
outline:
â€¢ 2m Introduction: Who am I and my professional background + where I work
â€¢ 7m Airflow and it's basic concepts: DAGs, Operators, Sensors, Usage of Jijna and more
â€¢ 3m The challenges we encountered in moving from model development to production - which led us to our solution.
â€¢ 5m Architectural overview of a sample pipeline 
â€¢ 5m diving into the code (segments)
â€¢ 7m Step by step walkthrough (probably images) of launching a managed Airflow cluster (GCP Composer), uploading our sample pipeline and running it.
â€¢ 5m Q&A
Total time: 34m

title: Unleashing Your Data Scientists: Towards Building Self Service Research Infrastructure
abstract: Creating secure Data exploration infrastructure is not easy, especially in GDPR era. "Productionisation" of algorithms developed by your Data Science team is not a trivial task either and usually requires involvement of Data Engineers. In this talk we're going to see how existing open source tools can be used for building a self-service infrastructure allowing researchers develop in a secure way, and deploy their models into production as is, thus reducing time to market dramatically.
outline:
5m Problem statement
-------------------------------------
* Typical problem a researcher works on
* What researcher working environment looks like
* "Missing" engineering skills - should we achieve them?
* How data privacy requirements make it all harder

10m Existing tools overview
-------------------------------------
* Legacy architecture - bird's eye view
* Does "productionising" mean "rewriting"?
* Everything is broken, or making your work environment secure is hard
* CI/CD is not for everyone

15m Building a unified research infrastructure
------------------------------------------------------------
* Implementing secure data access layer
* Unified API for exploration and for use in production
* Abstracting out ETL process
* YAML based workflow (Airflow DAG) declarations
* Jupyter Notebook deployment implementation
* Testing and monitoring

3m Final thoughts
-------------------------
* Extending the infrastructure for real-time data
* Lessons learned

title: We talked about your salary, now let's talk about your career
abstract:
So, you are 27 years old and already "at the top of your career."
Awesome! But, what are you going to do for the next 40 years until you retire?

Oh and wait, we all know there are almost no >50 year old people in this industry, does it mean that you only have ~20 years of career left?

Your salary is great and you like going to work every day, but is staying where you are the right decision for you in the long term?

Are there any steps you can take to make sure your career is moving in the path which is right for you?

Of course!

In this talk I'm going to offer my perspective on how you can handle these decisions to get your career on the right path.
outline:
Well, I will need to build this talk almost from scratch, same way I did my other talks in Reversim.
Top of my head:
 - What are you optimising for when making decisions that affect your career (Salary, skills, title, resume, WLB, etc)
 - Other parameters in your life (making a difference, being rich, have free time, conquer one mountain at a time)
 - The tips
 - examples

Not anything more than that, only 30 minutes and I want to focus on the examples to practice the tips

title: Surprise song!
abstract: It's going to be a surprise this year, it's going to be.... interesting... ;)
outline: - song

title: Welcome, to the Real (Time) World
abstract:
A few months ago, I've worked on a POC, where I needed to find an appropriate API for implementing an infrastructure for Push notifications, which has direct relation to the Real-Time application arena.
Due to a tight schedule (it always is), we needed to consider whether to use tentative solution using the well known Polling mechanisms...or to take the Red pill and - go deep to the rabbit hole. Wanna guess which one I took?

In this talk I'll cover the Real-Time apps evolution, the common underlying technologies to create Real-Time web applications today and then...giving a deeper glimpse into our Web-Sockets solution.
Join me for helping you take the right choice yourselves.
outline:
1. (5m) Introducing Real-time apps evolution
2. (5m) Underlying Technologies to implement Real-Time Web Applications
3. (10m) WebSockets solution to the rescue! How it works and what is it good for.
4. (4m) Performance sneak peek between web-sockets and HTTP
5.  (5m) Demo Time!

title: A Whole New World: Taking your app global and living to tell the tale
abstract:
So youâ€™ve launched your first service and all your customers in the US love it - great!
Now comes the hard part - how do you make the entire world love it too.

In this talk, Iâ€™m going to share what from my experience building the PayPal Mobile app and expanding WeWorkâ€™s systems to span the globe.â€¨Iâ€™m going to cover it all: from encodings, translations, UGC, CATs, i18n, g11n, l10n, LQA, money, dates, names, and taxes.
So that you can expand your app and reach new customers in London, Beijing, Tel-Aviv, and Paris.
outline:
5m introduction and background @ WeWork and PayPal
5m why i18n matters
20m covering the different topic 
G11N, I18N, L10N
ENCODINGS, UTF8, EMOJIs
LOCALES
FORMATS, CLDR
TRANSLATIONS, CATs
REGIONALIZATION
CASH, CURRENCIES
LQA 
5m: Takeaways
5m; Q&A

title: Level Up - Building High performing team culture
abstract:
What does it mean to strive for ENGINEERING EXCELLENCE? As your engineering organization grows, you want to encourage teams and individuals to develop and improve their technical proficiency and practices.
Growth puts stress on your teams' ability to deliver kick-ass code consistently. 
To help them improve and grow, we built the LEVEL UP model to represent everything that's expected of an excellent engineering team.

In this talk, Iâ€™ll review why we built this model, refined it and how we got teams to adopt it and the effects that it had on our department. I will also give you the tools to either use our model or fork your own specific one for your organization.
outline:
5m intro about self
5m background about WeWork's engineers and growth
10m pain points in growing and org and what led us to build the model
10m the level up model itself
5m takeways
5m q&a

title: High-Performing Engineering Organizations
abstract:
Speed vs Stability that's the basis of an age old discussion. Recently with the release of the research in the Accelerate book we have actual scientific proof that it's not this or that, rather it's both.
In this talk I will go through the main points researchers present and explain what makes an elite organization 2555x times faster and 2.5x more likely to succeeded than a low preforming org.
Covering topics from deployments, org structure, feature flags, monitoring and more we'll review how to shift your org to be the BEST.
outline:
5m introduction: myself and WeWork
5m history of engineering culture, the research in the Accelerate book 
10m covering the main metrics and differences between high performing and low performing orgs
15m covering a few topics that you can do in your org. Org structure, Product focus, Agile Dev, Engineering practices.
5m questions

title: Co-Coding 2020 : Down the Same Old Road.
abstract:
On the threshold of the twenties, we rave about serverless computing and artificial intelligence, autonomous cars and the Internet of things. And at the same time, we continue to bump into the same walls  when it comes to collaboration between humans. But there are also models that work! 
Let's talk honestly: why is it so hard for us to work together and does DevOps help with this? And if not - what can help us?
outline:
First we will look at how collaboration in the field of IT has developed up to the present moment, what pains we've felt and how we tried and continue trying to soothe them. And how often we think that we are fixing stuff, but in fact - it doesn't hurt any less. And how DevOps promised us something, but does not fulfil. Finally - we will talk about how to detect this false collaboration and how to deal with it.

- Introduction: Hacking humans hacking software
- Coder mindset
- A brief history of collaboration in IT
  - Lonely hackers
  - The SDLC and the crisis of software
  - The old new methods
  - Scrum My Kanban
  - And what about Operations?
  - Hello, DevOps!
  - Agilestyle perversions
- Ten years later, or deadly diseases of ten-year olds
- Why is everything so deplorable?
- Let's understand:
  - Human in a group
  - What's the story?
  - And where is the motivation?
  - Collaboration in times of crisis
  - Dialogue and cartography
- Common language and a new story

title: Can Kubernetes Keep a Secret?
abstract:
Weâ€™ve all experienced it: youâ€™re working on a task, adding some code, and then you need to store some sensitive configuration value. It could be an API key, client secret or an encryption key â€• something that must be kept secret. And this is where things get messy. 
Kubernetes has a promise to simplify this process by using the native secret object, which, as the name implies, can be used to store secrets or sensitive configurations. Unfortunately, Kubernetes secrets are imperfect.
But no need to worry â€• there are solid tools for storing secrets securely on Kubernetes platform. Join me for this session to learn how to develop a Kubernetes application that can keep a secret â€• for real.
outline:
5m: Introduction - Managing secrets with GitOps flow is a challenge - these are highly-sensitive credentials that cannot be committed to source control. This becomes even more challenges when choosing a decentralize company structure and DevOps culture - when developers are responsible for everything. Can we find a secure solution to this problem?
7m: Kubernetes secrets - challenges:
Cannot be stored in source control - the value is not encrypted
Creating and consuming secrets by the application is a challenge - there is no easy and secure solution
There are solutions to create encrypted like Sealed Secrets and Helm Secrets. Both imperfect - either not secure or requires coupling to a specific CI
5m: Hashicorp Vault - challenges
Not a GitOps flow: devs need to write secrets manually to Vault
Permissions: Need to manage permission, and create least privilege rules to developers and applications the read secrets from Vault
Deployment: If Vault is not used, the user needs also to deploy a Vault instance securely.
8 min: Kamus - demo, threat model and why it solves the problem
Designed for GitOps flow
Simplified permission model: Allow dev to encrypt a secret for a specific application
Various mitigations to harden Kamus we will be discussed as part of the threat model
5 min: Wrapping up and questions

title: Yes you can! A simple algorithm for networking that always works
abstract: A few years ago I was looking for a senior position, and was told that networking was the best way to find a job. I was terrified by this word, networking. I never networked before. Luckily, I got great tips from friends, that worked for me so well, that I started to love networking. I compiled my experience into a simple algorithm that everyone can follow. Over the years I shared it with many people, who used it to reach surprising achievements. In this session Iâ€™ll share the algorithm with you.
outline:
2m Present myself and my professional background
5m Breaking some myths about networking 
5m How networking works
5m The Algorithm 
5m A script for conducting the networking meeting 
3m The networking surprises    
5m Time for questions

Total time: 30m

title: Peer to Peer: How to build peer relations that actually work
abstract:
I studied at the Technion, where I learned a lot about software development, but they never taught me how to work with peers, especially when thereâ€™s a built-in conflict between us. As a developer and as an R&D manager I always had complex interfaces with my product management and customer success peers, and frequently with other development teams. When there are limited resources, different priorities or simply lack of trust, peer communication can become flammable, consume our energy and significantly hurt our work satisfaction.  
In this session Iâ€™ll present some ways I developed over the years to overcome these gaps and build a productive working relationship with my peers.
outline:
2m Present myself and my professional background
5m Typical conflicts in hi tech companies, and why they happen 
5m The vicious cycle of Trust, and why itâ€™s important to deal with conflicts early 
13m Methods and tools to achieve more productive relationships with our peers
5m Time for questions

Total time: 30m

title: Say it again: Driving a culture change using clever use of words
abstract: Leaders, either managers or just people who want to make an impact, usually have core values and work culture, that they expect to see in others as well. For example, weâ€™d like our teammates to have a can-do attitude, to think like the customer or to have end to end ownership, but we often struggle with how to make them follow these values. Sometimes, the solution is much simpler than what one would imagine. Sometimes itâ€™s about the words we use and how we use them. A small change that can drive a large impact. In this talk Iâ€™ll present a simple, effective way to use words to change your teamâ€™s culture.
outline:
1m  Who am I and the problem I want to solve 
3m  A sample cultural value and various ways to introduce it in work situations 
1m  Some more examples and a call for action 

Total time: 5m

title: From trainwreck to empire â€“ the rise of a falling software group
abstract:
Have you ever felt as if your software group is drifting into a pit of despair? Did it feel like there was no way out? It did for the software group I began leading. In this talk, we'll see how big corporation software groups and small startups are not that different when things start to fall apart.
I will show you how I found the right methodology to save my software group when it had become one big mess. 
By the end of my talk, both developers and managers will be able to see the faults in their teams, roll up their sleeves and get to fixing.
Let's leave that miserable rabbit hole behind!
outline:
2m - introduction: who I am and my professional background.
3m - proper software process: use case of inserting a feature, from the idea to deployment.
5m - false assumptions regarding a proper working process as described, and how they did not exist in my group.
7m - mapping the problems within the group and the problems with product manager, project manager and clients 
10m - solutions: presenting methodical work, step by step to restore power and ability back.
3m - there are no easy solutions, but the right methods can lead to bigger and better developers and products. Everybody has the power to bring great changes.

Total: 30m

title: OKRs driven development
abstract:
Adopted by Google in 1999, objectives and key results are a simple way to align, focus and engage a team around company goals.

In this talk, I will show you how we are using OKRs at Nanit from the company's vision down to the sprint tasks. 

I will also talk about adopting OKRs for personal goals
outline:
5m Intro about Nanit (the company I work for) and myself
10m About OKRs including examples from known companies around the world
5m How it all started for Nanit (why we adopted OKRs)
10m How we do OKRs at Nanit

title: Hacking git's security solution
abstract: Git the popular version control system was originally initiated by Linus Torvalds for managing the code base of the open source Linux project. On Feb 2017 researchers from CWI and Google published the details of their successful collision attack on the Sha1, a hash on which git heavily relies. This made me curious about git's security features. While the Sha1 turned-out to be the least important security feature in git, what I discovered was Linus Torvalds hack on common perceptions of security and a new perspective on what it takes to create a safe space for individuals' to collaboratively innovate and create code.
outline:
2m Why I became interested in git's security features.
5m Present git's security features and why they did not make sense.
5m Common perceptions on security  
12m Present Linus Torvalds hack 
6m What can we learn from Torvalds hack on creating a secure space for collabrative innovation and development of software? 
Total: 30m

title: Scheduled Tasks - The Evolution Way
abstract:
Scheduling and executing predefined periodic tasks is a capability each company needs sooner or later. 
However, investing in a complex and robust scheduling system might not be the top priority for most companies at any given time.

In this talk we will cover the requirements and practical implementation methods of a job scheduler, starting from the basic ones that might fit small startups (like Trax used to be) to the most robust systems that large enterprises (like Trax today) may rely on.
outline:
3m Introduction: Who I'm and what are we doing at Trax?
3m Scoping:  Why do we need scheduled tasks?
5m Quick & Dirty: The quickest MVP solution that stands for a small startup (Pros & Cons)
7m Robust but Easy: Describe the implementation of a robust (yet easy) solution implemented using out of the box managed cloud provider services.
7m State of the art: Describe a full scale-able multi-cloud solution for a large enterprises, based on K8S
5m: Q&A

Total time: 30m

title: Why Developers Need to Be Part of the Product Discovery Phase
abstract:
In Product we know our job starts well before a feature goes into development. But we also usually embark on the journey alone, pulling in developers only when sitting down to write the spec at best, and often times only when there's need for a dev discovery or planning. 
In this lecture I will offer an alternative which I found do be very useful in the product flow but also drives benefits to the product itself - and that is to involve engineers in the earliest stages of a product, from brainstorming to client discovery sessions into defining KPIs.
Hoping this will make every PM in the room to apply this method, and every engineer to push themselves into these processes.
outline:
â€¢ 2m Introduction: Who am I and my professional background
â€¢ 5m Traditional product cycle: what PMs do and where this process meets engineering. 
â€¢ 5m Describe the problems that arise from this process and how they lead to the ancient 'product-dev' battle.
â€¢ 10m True story: an example of a real process I went through with a big agenda with high profile in the company, where I struggled, and where dev presence in the early stages helped me tackle the beast and led to a better product!
â€¢ 5m: What were my takeaways and how I employ them in my PM work ever since.
â€¢ 5m Q&A
Total time: 32 minutes

title: Massive Scale Anomaly Detection Framework
abstract:
Early detection of abnormal events can be critical for many business applications, however there are numerous challenges when implementing real-time anomaly models at scale. Moreover, most analytical models have been traditionally designed for the batch processing paradigm and usually cannot be easily adapted to unbounded datasets and real-time latencies.

At PayPal, we've built a generic framework for developing robust and scalable anomaly detection streaming applications, focusing on flexibility. Inspired by the design of scikit-learn and Spark MLlib, we've designed a simple pipeline-based API on top of Spark Structured Streaming, to capture common patterns of the anomaly detection domain.
outline:
2m introduction
10m go over the challenges in implementing real-time anomaly models at scale
10m cover the generic framework that we've built for developing scalable anomaly detection streaming applications, and the different choices that we took
5m Examples of anomaly use cases that can be detected by this framework
2m conclusion
5m Q&A
Total time: 34m

title: Massive Scale Anomaly Detection Framework
abstract: At PayPal, we must be able to analyze billions of events every day in real-time as early detection of abnormal events can be critical for many business applications. However there are numerous challenges when implementing real-time anomaly models at scale.  Especially since most analytical models have been traditionally designed for the batch processing paradigm and usually cannot be easily adapted to unbounded datasets and real-time latencies. This need drove us to build a generic framework for developing robust and scalable anomaly detection streaming applications, focusing on flexibility to support different types of statistical and machine learning models.
outline:
2m introduction
10m go over the challenges in implementing real-time anomaly models at scale
10m cover the generic framework that we've built for developing scalable anomaly detection streaming applications, and the different choices that we took
5m Examples of anomaly use cases that can be detected by this framework
2m conclusion
5m Q&A
Total time: 34m

title: Identity Resolution in Cyber Security
abstract: Resolving actor's identity is imperative in many online systems. Misunderstanding of your actors' identity means that you may be confusing bots with people, mistakenly resolving an individual actor as several different other actors, mislead by multiple identities which are actually the same actor and many more. These misunderstandings may well be wreaking havoc in your analytics be it by wrong visualization or by introducing noise to your statistical models. We will learn a strategy to try and mitigate this problem and how this strategy fits into a broader security system.
outline:
â€¢ 2m Introduction: Who am I and my professional background
â€¢ 5m Alert Fatigue and popular ways to eliminate it
â€¢ 5m Zooming in on identity resolution problem
â€¢ 10m Identity Graphs and interesting things about them, including how they can be used to help improve security products and services
â€¢ 3m Summary
â€¢ 5m Q&A
Total time: 30m

title: I:Tech:Lead:) Make a business impact with technology
abstract:
I would like to share with you my experience and  a methodology of the transition you will experiencing when you become a tech lead.
As a developer, become a Tech Lead, you suddenly realize how lonely the role is. You will no longer be â€œjust a developer,â€ and you will no longer
be treated as such. When you look for support and advice, you find that no one can understand your unique position, team and context.
outline:
2m Introduction about Tech Lead role
8m I part: your uniqueness, branding your self and dealing with self management.
8m Tech part: Getting a  wider outlook and guiding the tech solution.
8m Lead part: Building trust, influencing with authority and making your self redundant. 
4m Q&A

title: Full Stack Evolution to Full Cycle
abstract:
As of today, the concept of someone that can hold both sides of an architecture and be able to program both frontend, backend and data, is no more. The reason is that there are complicated frameworks that need special expertise on every part of the system.
The polyglot world adds to this issue even more, where different solutions need different programming languages.
The new expertise that is requested from a developer is to be very flexible and agile, and to be able to jump from one discipline to another and from one language to another. Having good basics in software engineering can help the programmer to juggle between environments and platforms
outline:
5m Introduction of What is Full Stack
10m The real challenges of a Full Stack Developer
10m Welcome to Full Cycle Developer
5m Q&A

title: DDD: Strategic Patterns and Microservices by Example
abstract:
More and more teams are facing difficulties integrating and extending Microservices with the high cadence promise they initially delivered.

After adopting a Microservices architecture at Fiverr, development was a breeze compared to the mighty monolith... but once the honeymoon period was over thier progress was slowing down as they encountered issues such as:

* Losing transactionality
* Unclear data ownership
* Dependency graph for deployments

If you feel you are approaching the end of your Microservices honeymoon period, then this talk is for you!
I will explain what DDD's Strategic Patterns are and how adopting them helped them deliver high quality products faster!
outline:
2m: Introduction: Who am I and my professional background

10m: Fiverr's architecture:
* A glorious Monolith
* Issues and why we chose to go the Microservices Route
* The honeymoon period
* What went wrong?

5m: Solution - DDD's Strategic Patterns:
* Ubiquitous Language - building up a common, rigorous language between developers and stakeholders. 
* Domains and sub-domain types - Core domain, supporting domain and generic domain.
* Bounded Context - dividing large models into different Bounded Contexts and being explicit about their interrelationships.

10m: Elaborate examples:
* Rearchitecting Fiverr's Financial domain from a Monolith into multiple bounded contexts implemented as Microservices with clear transactional boundaries and ownership.
* Buyer experience personalisation: how we split a horizontal concern across the user journey into bounded contexts owned by different teams.

3m: Q&A

title: Scaling Production data across Microservices @ Fiverr
abstract:
During the past 8 years, Fiverr migrated from a LAMP architecture all the way to 200~ Microservices with more than a dozen teams pushing a few hundred deploys a week.

Working inside the monolith was simple, all data was available but the move to microservices presented challenges as data was exposed via REST API, which caused performance and reliability issues, dependencies between teams and much more...

If you feel that your current strategy for sharing data is brittle this talk is for you!
I'll present our robust solution for sharing data across Microservices, utilizing Kafka as a data hub using techniques borrowed from CQRS and DDD to tie everything together and iterate much faster!
outline:
Outline:
2m: Introduction: Who am I and my professional background

10m: Fiverr's architecture V1-V3:
- V1: Classic LAMP
- V2: Async Writes.
- V3: Introducing Microservices

15m: Architecture V4: Production Data Integration at Scale
- Kafka as a data hub
- Protobuf for type safety
- Read optimized views
- Stream processing for data projections

3m: Q&A

title: Clarizen adventures with the wild GC in the holiday season
abstract: Clarizen is a leading SaaS company in project management and work collaboration systems which serve thousands of enterprises around the world. System stability and performance are on our top priority, that is why when complaints about sporadic slowness issues began to appear in the middle of 2018 we immediately started to investigate and track it to wild garbage collections that were happening exactly every four hours. Like Murphy predicted, the problem reached a critical point exactly in the holiday season (Thank you Murphy :-/). In this session you will learn the tools and techniques Clarizen used to analyze the problem and find the surprising reason for the mysterious problem.
outline:
1m Introduction: Who am I and my professional background
5m Clarizen architecture:
3m the problem
6m the analysis process and the solution

title: The secret to becoming a better engineer - connect to the product
abstract:
I've been working with and leading tech teams for over 12 years. It took me a long time to find what's in common between the engineers who contribute most to the company. They're not necessarily the smartest, those who write the cleanest code or the best architects. What makes the difference is how much they understand the product and the business goals. 
- Why I switched from sprints and 'micro-tasks' to 'Tech feature owners'
- Why I believe half baked PRDs with open ends is the best thing for developers
- About building a holistic team where developers are a part of the product, marketing and customer success
- How to become more product oriented.
outline:
- How I was finally able to map what is unique about the top tech contributors
- What does it mean being a product-oriented engineer/ product oriented development 
- Our previous working method (sprints, micro tasks) and our new one - 'tech feature owner'
- How we were able to shorten the dev cycles by focusing only on what matters
- About half baked PRDs and why there's nothing wrong with it
- How to communicate product and business goals
- Holistic teams - tech, product, marketing and CS
- How to start understanding the product goals better

title: Performance Analysis Challenges in Modern Servers and Enhancement Coming in IceLake
abstract:
Optimizing an applicationâ€™s performance for the underlying machine is a difficult task. Increasing hardware complexity, workload diversity, and the unmanageable volume of data produced by performance tools increase the optimization challenges. At the same time resource and time constraints get tougher with recently emerged segments. 

This session overviews the Top-down Microarchitecture Analysis (TMA) method and its handling of cycle accounting in modern out-of-order cores. It illustrates some performance problems that call for truly top-down-oriented metrics, presents recent challenges of modern data centers, and performance monitoring unit (PMU) enhancements to address them
outline:
A refresh on Top-down Microarchitecture Analysis (TMA)
Example 1: New PMU event for ITLB_Misses
Challenges of Modern Datacenters
Example 2: Google web search
Example 3: SMT x-thread interference
Icelake enhancements for TMA
Per-thread, over 2x counters, built-in metrics

title: The Folly of TDD
abstract:
Spun off of the eXtreme Programming movement, Test Driven Development has taken the software industry by storm. From a highly controversial approach, TDD has become a ubiquitous industry practice and the poster child of software engineering maturity. But is it all it's cracked up to be?

Severely misunderstood, argued about vehemently and lacking in critical research, the popularity of TDD is such that it's barely challenged anymore.

In this presentation we'll take a journey through the hype and into to the essence of TDD, observing its shortcomings, hidden costs and unfortunate dogma.
outline: Existing slide deck available at https://speakerdeck.com/holograph/the-folly-of-tdd

title: React Hooks and ContextAPI as an alternative for Redux
abstract:
Building a large web application usually requires a state management library. 
up until now Redux and Mobx were the two major players, but with the new Context api and React Hooks,  it seems that there can be an alternative for developers looking to reduce the boilerplate code while maintaining clear state separation
outline:
2m Introduction: Who am I and my professional background
5m state management: why we need state management libraries for web applications
5m React Hooks: what is react hooks which was released in latest version 16.8.0
5m React contextAPI: what is context api
10m hooks & contextAPI: how we can create a solution for state management with hooks and contextAPI which requires less boilerplate code
2m optimizing our code: small code optimization
Total time: 29m

title: So whatâ€™s the real deal with P and NP
abstract: Most of us vaguely remember complexity classes P and NP from the old days in Uni... Back then it was mostly about passing the test, but what really stands behind it? Is it really that interesting? Does P = NP or what? In this talk, Weâ€™ll learn about the most famous open problem in computer science and then hear about updates from recent years as well as other growing fields in the complexity computation theory world.
outline:
2m - intro and history of the problem
2m - recent updates about the problem
1m - growing fields in complexity theory
Total Time: 5m

title: Your Software As A Garden: Building Systems That Don't Rot
abstract:
Advocates of TDD often refer to Emergent Design as the holy grail - allowing design to emerge via small cycles of test-code-refactor is an excellent way to yield a lean, simple system that is adaptive to changes - thus being maintainable over time. But what do we do when reality forces us to adhere to some (Big Bad) Upfront Design?

For years, I thought the two are incompatible, but when forced with hard requirements I had to adapt, and accidentally stumbled upon an excellent way to combine the two, allowing us to quickly grow a team and parallelize work early and efficiently.

This talk is a case study of how we did that.
outline:
Talk will be based on the two blog posts below (or maybe just the first? dunno yet), and will describe the process we at Orbs used when writing the first code for our system so that the codebase stays maintainable, reliable and adaptive to changes.

https://medium.com/orbs-network/big-design-up-front-or-emergent-design-hexagonal-architecture-gives-us-both-9b864ebe6df7
https://medium.com/orbs-network/inside-the-inner-hexagon-component-tests-b714e3b6b83c

title: WARNING: Developing on Wearable Devices Ahead
abstract:
Development of wearable devices always seemed fun. The chance to make a physical impact, getting to know interesting new fields, and producing a tangible product, other than the virtual one in the software world. But what happens when you need to test augmented reality on a basketball court, but you're still in the office? When you can't get concentrated enough to get the brain sensing headband running?

On this talk, we'll present all the pitfalls we encountered while developing on wearable devices
outline: Pulse headset, Google Glass and smartwatches

title: Underground Art: the Agile Way
abstract: Every project starts with a single task. Our first task in Kaduregel Shefel, an alternative art project documenting cultural diversity through football, was to produce our first ever exhibition at an underground gallery in Tel Aviv. The exhibition was a success, with raving reviews from both visitors and media. This was an inspiration for us to continue and expand the project. As the developers that we are, we decided to be agile in order to scale. Using scrum, we were able to scale to video content, producing events abroad, managing communities and meet-ups, collaborating with artists and creating unique products. In this talk, we will explain how we leveraged agile on underground art.
outline: Intro, What is 'Kaduregel Shefel', Agile principles

title: Strike gold (and avoid drowning) with streaming algorithms
abstract:
Streaming algorithms are everywhere, and are relevant for any developer that has to deal with scale - whether it's message streams or queries on big data.

While many developers will just treat them as black magic, a slightly more in-depth knowledge of them can be interesting and critically useful.

In this talk, I intend to:
* Explain what streaming algorithms are,
* Show how, in Glassbox, we used them in original ways to implement otherwise impossible solutions,
* Present the difficulties and surprises,
* Present a small catalog of useful algorithms that you could find original uses for.

After this talk, you will have powerful new tools in your coding arsenal.
outline:
â€¢ 2m Introduction: Who am I and my professional background
â€¢ 5m What are streaming algorithms, what are they used for.
â€¢ 3m Give a simple example of one - cardinality estimation - HyperLogLog++
â€¢ 2m Short overview of how a distributed query (in Elasticsearch at least) executes and combines results across shards
â€¢ 3m Present the problem we had in Glassbox - calculating cardinality is slow, calculating partial results in advance is impossible.
â€¢ 5m How we solved it - saving the internal state of HLL in the partial results, which enables combining partial results at query time.
â€¢ 5m Some more examples of streaming algorithms, which can be used in unexpected scenarios - e.g. graph matching, Bloom filters, count-min sketch
â€¢ 5m Q&A
Total time: 30m

title: Lessons Learned Building Micro-Services App From Scratch
abstract:
When we began working on a new system that will replace other, ageing, systems, we decided to go for the Micro-Services path.
Our starting point was tough - There was no Micro-Services-Oriented knowledge in the organization, we couldn't use cloud-based product, and the schedule was quite strict.
Now, a year and a half after making that decision, we can look back and analyze that decision.
In this talk we'll discuss, among the rest:
- Why did we decide to go with Micro Services at the first place?
- What did the design phase look like?
- What kind of training did we have to do?
- What technology and platforms we decided to use, and why?
- And, of course, did it work?
outline:
2m Introduction: Who am I and what is my role in the team
2m A little bit about the system functionality
3m The development team: Skills, tech and more
5m Why did we go for Micro Services?
6m The design phase, Micro & Macro
5m Technology & Platforms we used
4m The first service - how long did it take to design & develop it, and how many LOC did it have?
5m The rest of the services
2m Did it work?
3m Q&A

Total: 37m

title: The hidden cost of life without automation
abstract:
Automating processes became trivial - development groups have devOps tasks to set up an environment, build and deploy code. Still, thereâ€™s a gap - are these the only things we do regularly? How often should I repeat some process in order to automate it? I encourage you to automate as soon as itâ€™s worth it, but sometimes, as a busy developer,  you just donâ€™t get to it. Psychology says that you will probably continue to do things manually if you did it manually long enough. Well, itâ€™s a fallacy, I claim itâ€™s almost never too late.
Iâ€™ll give examples of how creating a code generator made our life easier along the way, and of how I didnâ€™t fall for the fallacy when I just didnâ€™t get to it.
outline: 2m intro, 3m general overview about automation, 10m about best timing to automate, 10m about psychology term sunk cost fallacy and how it affects timing and decisions regarding automation, 10m real life examples and Q&A. Total: 35m.
