title: The wait is over. How to accelerate your builds with Bazel
abstract:
As Wix Backend grew exponentially with more than 800 micro-services, our previous CI solution has been slowing us down.
We decided to switch to the Bazel build tool and Google Cloud Build CI platform.
The migration and adaptation was challenging and some promising directions had to be abandoned.
The end result was a dramatic improvement in performance and accuracy.

What makes bazel stand out as such a fast build tool? Is the migration to it hard? What are the pain points? Come and find out from our experience.
outline:
In this talk I would explain the pros and cons of switching to bazel build tool, who will enjoy its benefits most and what are the migration pain points and tips gathered from my experience at Wix

* 7m Intro to Bazel and google cloud
* 5m How to choose the right build unit granularity
* 5m How to Decide on CI Server and remote execution / caching
* 5m How to optimize local dev experience
* 3m How to decide on amount of source control repos
* 2m How to optimize 3rd party version management
* 3m Q&A

title: Practice makes Scala perfect
abstract:
Scala 3 is a major breakthrough for this teenage language. 
From having too many options in the past, Scala 3 tries to be more opinionated and has gathered many best practices into the language itself.

These include constraining the abuse of implicit conversions, reducing boilerplate for Type Classes and the Tagless Final pattern using implicit function types and a whole new design for enums that enable Algebraic Data Types.

In this talk we will deep dive into these important features that will make our functional code more comprehensible and clean.
outline:
* 2m intro on myself
* 5m intro on Scala 3 compiler, Dotty and the TASTY revolution
* 5m Constraining of implicit conversions, 
* 7m Reducing boilerplate for Type Classes and the Tagless Final pattern using implicit function types 
* 8m a whole new design for enums that enable Algebraic Data Types.
* 3m Q&A

title: The Polyglot Manifesto - The quest for learning and writing in a new programming language
abstract:
"I'm quite good in Java, why should I be a Kotlin newbie?"

When we become proficient in the language we have been writing in for years, getting really comfortable with its technological stack, we are afraid to lose all that we have gained and start all over again with some other programming language. For me, this was the case after I gained a lot of experience with C#.

A few years ago I decided to leave my comfort zone and started writing in Scala. Later I added more languages to my toolbox like JavaScript and Python.

Iâ€™ve discovered that learning and becoming proficient in more languages has many advantages and benefits and the the continuous learning process can be quite easy.
outline:
* 5m Introduction: Who am I and my professional journey through various programming languages
* 10m Advantages of learning new languages from my experience
* 5m Disadvantages for being polyglot
* 5m how continuous learning can become an easy thing to do
* 5m Q&A

title: Between AI and JS
abstract: AI became the biggest buzzword in the tech world for the past few months. Somehow â€“ it always feels like some rocket science reserved for data scientists or python developers far away from the front end. In this talk, Eliran will show how easy it is to create your first prediction model with a simple web application using TensorFlow.js and other deep learning tools that can run on your browser! No python, no server, no data scientists â€“ just javascript.
outline:
â€¢ 2m Introduction: Who am I and my professional background
â€¢ 13m AI overview: What is AI? Who need it? and why should I use it in the client side
â€¢ 15m live demo: build a model of captcha using tensorflow.js, train the model and show how to solve a captcha using only JS.

Total time: 30m

title: My Website is Slow, Now What?
abstract: You built a great-looking, feature-rich website. But it also has a big problem: it's just too slow. As a result, your visitors are frustrated, and your bounce-rate is high. So now, what do you do? In this session I will explain what web performance actually means, and how to measure the performance of your website. I will show various tools and techniques you can use to pinpoint the performance bottlenecks, and various methods and technologies  you can use to overcome them. Finally, I will describe processes you can put in place to ensure that the performance of your website doesn't degrade again in the future.
outline:
Introduction: Who am I and my professional background
The importance of performance on the web
What performance actually means
Tools and techniques to measure performance
Methods and techniques to overcome performance problems
Processes for maintaining good performance
Summary and Q&A

title: Are Requirements Overrated?
abstract:
Even though we have moved from waterfall to agile, too many organizations still spend too much time writing and reviewing very long requirements.

In this talk, I will claim that writing short requirements is good and should be practiced more not out of laziness, but rather because it saves time for the whole team to focus on what matters, it let developers be more creative and involved, and it reduces the need to develop unnecessary things you became in love with.
outline:
- 2m introduction
- 5m: From Waterfall to Agile - even though we moved from waterfall to agile too many product managers write much more than necessary and too many developers demand that product managers fill every details
- 5m: Valuable Time of the Product Manager - a product manager should have time to spend on the problem and strategic
- 5m: Smart Creatives - Developers want to think. They donâ€™t want just to get orders and implement them. By writing too much details, you are actually getting less motivated developers
- 5m: Escalation of Commitment. Everybody may get too attached to the solution
- 3m summary
- 5m questions

title: 5 AB Tests Results That Blew Our Minds
abstract:
We, at JoyTunes, ran hundreds of ab tests in the past three years. Some are simple (red/green buttons), some are complex (full pledge features that took weeks to implement). Over the years we developed some intuition on our users - what is likely to work and what is not. But every once in a while came a test that just blew our minds - tests results that were so surprising that no one expected them. 
In this talk I will share a few of those ab tests and their unexpected results.
outline:
1m - Who am I, WIFIM, 
3.5m - Examples of ABTests and their surprising results
0.5m - Summary and take away (which is basically - Do ABTests the results will surprise you)

title: The ABTest Framework We Dreamt About
abstract:
Like most startups we are running ab tests, like most startups we looked for an abtesting framework we can use and like most startups we ended up writing our own framework for abtesting.
In this talk I will share our experience from a 3 years and hundreds of tests perspective a on the decision to write our own abtests framework. What worked for us, what did not worked and what you should consider when you find yourself in the same crossroad.
outline:
2m Intro: Who am I and WIFIM
5m: The problem we faced and our needs
10m: The solution we went for
10m: What we learn for it - what went well and what did not
3m: Summary + take away

title: Managing for dummies: Managing people smarter than you
abstract:
*What if I told you that not all managers know everything?*

This session shows my feeble attempts as a technical engineer manager to not be overwhelmed by my smart minions. In addition, the session talks about of how a manager can bring value even without taking a pause to get a P.hd in every field the team members are experts in.
outline:
* 1m â†’ whoami
* 5m â†’ Introduction
    * The problem (freaking smart people with domain expertise)
    * What do people really need from a manager?
* 20m â†’ The solution
    * Know thy strengths, stop being frustrated (yes, people will notice)
    * Never be ashamed to say: "I don't know", on the contrary, learn and know the next time.
    * Contribute by enabling people - noise filter
    * Sharing is caring, concentrate on culture mentoring in addition to technical
    * Know thy context, contribute with completing the big picture for your engineers
    * One on ones => Venting and Ranting
    * Do learn and understand each team members domain as much as possible, but WAAY more important than that, understand each team members pain
* 1m 30s â†’ Summary + ending dad pun

title: How software could play a role in malaria elimination
abstract:
Malaria is one of the deadliest diseases, but we can defeat it. In fact, many countries already have - for example here, in Israel, decades ago. But it is not easy - operations must be planned and executed perfectly, and many countries fail.  
In this session, I want to tell you how we tackle this problem. I will not dive into technical details. Instead, I want to share my hopes and inspiration. 
Currently, Zzapp is one of the leaders of Zanzibar's malaria elimination strategy and is one of the top ten teams in the XPRIZE AI competition.
outline:
â€¢ 2m Introduction: Who am I and my professional background
â€¢ 7m malaria overview: What is the toll ofmalaria and which approaches were used to tackle it
â€¢ 8m Our approach: Data that makes the operation successful
â€¢ 8m Challenges with AI and low-quality data
5m Q&A
Total time: 30m

title: CI, That's so 2018
abstract:
Continuous Integration has almost become a de facto standard in most organizations nowadays, however we are all still not giving CI the proper emphasis on our day to day work.
Why invest in your build times when there are sexy things like Continuous Deployment and Kubernetes?
Now that we have a plethora of CI tools and SAAS offering, are there still things we can do differently?

In this talk I'll delve into some of the history of CI that's still relevant, go over very common mistakes and how you can level up your CI game with very little efforts.
outline:
* 1m â†’ whoami
* 3m â†’ CI History, from Martin Fowler's commandments to our lord and saviour Kohsuke to the current CI SAAS landscape
* 5m â†’ What are we doing wrong today 
* 10m â†’ 10 CI rules to follow in the modern era
* 2m â†’ Summary

title: PRESIZE : How my career transitioned from SW engineering to algorithm developer
abstract:
Senior engineers often question their possible development opportunities. As senior Python developer, working in an image-recognition company, I was waiting for the right algorithm challenge.
In this talk I will present PRESIZE, an algorithm that infers the physical measurements of retail products in an image, which I developed end-to-end.

Trax specializes with on-shelf retail data. Surprisingly, the physical dimensions of retail products is rarely available.  We decided to use scarcely available information and utilize it in a simple and straight forward geometric algorithm,  to infer the physical sizes of image elements.
outline:
1 m: Me
2 m: Trax - what do we do
4 m: What we want to solve - understanding physical dimensions of elements in a retail-shelf image

Our solution:  
 3m: The available data
10m: Linear equations set constructing & solving.
4m: Translating to physical dimension.
5m: Applying results to rest of image elements.

5m: Q&A

Total: 34 m

title: DRYing up your CI/CD with Git Rebase
abstract: The world of CI tends to be neglected, causing engineering problems both in moral and quality. Things either take too much time, or are quick but unpredictable. In this talk I'll share how we at BigPanda cut down our CI/CD time by drastically, without compromising our confidence in quality, by simply using Git in a more sane way!
outline:
* 30s -> whoami
* 1m -> The problems in CI today
* 5m -> Git to the rescue!
  * 1m -> One commit to rule them all
  * 2m -> Trust gates
  * 1m -> Versions in source control, not in source!
* 30s -> Summary + ending dad pun

title: The AI that tricked me - Data Driven Front-End Development
abstract:
Machine Learning has become an industry standard when it comes to personalisation - everyone is trying to utilise data to improve the user experience and increase relevance of the content. But, do we really accept the supremacy of AI over our intuition without any validation? 

In this talk, I will guide you through real episodes of my front-end development work, as I go through case studies to demonstrate the importance of critical thinking, experimentation and correct analysis of results. This helps to challenge well-known assumptions and open up to new data-driven innovative ideas.
outline:
* 1-2m intro: Who am I and my professional background
* 2m stage setting: What I'm going to tell you and why, what is the value for the audience
* 8-9m use cases: examples of my actual work, stories and learnings from each case, including surprising facts and unexpected turn of events.
* 3-4m conclusion: final words and short Q&A
total time: 14-17m approx

title: Behind the scenes of running the biggest Machine Learning community In Israel
abstract:
3 years ago I have found "Machine & Deep learning Israel" - One of the biggest technical communities in Israel. That's without understanding almost anything about ML at that point. 

Over the past 3 years, I have learned a lot about running an operating a technical community and now I wish to share my knowledge with others. I will take about the early days of the community and how to create value to attract others. I will speak about the difficulties of running a big technical community (13K+ members) and finally, I will share some tips for everyone else who thought to launch a new community.
outline:
2m Introduction: Who am I and my professional background
5M: Presenting my community: "Machine & Deep learning Israel".
10M: Talking about the early days of the community and how everything started.
8M: The difficulties of running a big technical community.
5M: Tips for running technical community

title: Sprint to live, Scale to survive
abstract:
Scaling up your development is never easy task, It's only matter of time until you experience this problem. But it's never the first problem, the first problem is get to market, prove the project/product is actually valuable,  fast, efficient and on budget. 
It's going to be almost impossible to pay the price of scaling from day one.

I will demonstrate how to start a micro-frontends solution even if you working alone. Then I will show how you can scale this solution for multiple teams.
Fast & comprehensive kick-start: From nothing to full solution with release pipeline, Angular, React, VUE...

* I assume you already familiar with micro-frontends I will focus on "how" not on "what" and "why"
outline:
- 3m Background story: introduce the problem we face
- 2m Introduction: Who am I and my professional background
- 20m Create your first micro-frontends solution - slides with demo
- 5m summary

title: Two Years, Zero servers: Lessons learned from running a startup 100% on Serverless
abstract: Running a Highly Available Large Scale Systems is a lot of work. For the past 2 years, we've been running 100% serverless on a full production environment, serving customers worldwide. No VMs, no containers, no Kubernetes. Just code. In this session I will present why we decided to go fully serverless, how it helped us move faster than our competitors, where did serverless computing worked best and where there's more work to be done. At the end of this session, you'll learn how to run your next side-project, production service, or even your complete startup, without losing a night's sleep.
outline:
â€¢ 2m Introduction: Who am I and my professional background
â€¢ 5m Quick Serverless overview: Why are we talking about serverless? What does it solve? An example function-as-a-service use case.
â€¢ 10m What we learned to be great with Serverless
â€¢ 10m What we learned needs improvement in the Serverless eco-system and must be considered before using a Serverless solution
â€¢ 5m Quick summary & Q&A

title: Leverage habits, donâ€™t create them
abstract:
In 2019, each of us has multiple devices, tons of apps and endless notifications that keep us busy and actually - overwhelmed. We are addicted to technology but our attention span is minimal â€“ weâ€™re lazy when it comes to getting used to something new. 
Since weâ€™re already flooded with noise, information and entry points, itâ€™s almost impossible to create new habits. Tools are much more likely to succeed when leveraging existing habits, and using them to provide value to the user without interrupting their natural flow. In this session weâ€™ll better understand what â€œleveraging habitsâ€ means and see some examples of successful products that did it right.
outline:
1 minute: opening
3 minutes: deeper explanations and examples
1 minute: closure

title: Defend Your Infrastructureâ€Šâ€”â€ŠHandling 3,000 Hungry Users
abstract:
The whole point of running a data lake is to let users consume the data and make powerful business insights. But sometimes, as expected when you have many users, things will go wrong. And when they will - you should be ready.

In my talk, I'll present an incident that happened to us a few months ago and how monitoring the usage of our users (with the ELK stack) helped identifying the source of the problem.

I'll also explain why it took us so long to find what caused the problem, and the practical conclusions we made.
outline:
* my blog post about the subject:
https://medium.com/@adirmashiach/defend-your-infrastructure-handling-3-000-hungry-users-379783b24d51


* 2m Introduction: Who am I and my professional background
* 2m A little bit about our kind of usage: how many users do we have, levels of them, etc.
* 3m Describing the mystery: what happened that made me start an investigation?
* 2m The investigation: how did I found out the abusive user
* 4m Practical Insights: Creating an Elastic index + Kibana dashboard to identify such 
things proactively
* 2m Q&A

title: The battle of the techies - developers vs product managers
abstract:
The tension between developers and product managers in our industry is a well-known secret. 
In this talk, I will analyze why this tension exists and give some tips and ideas on how to overcome it & create a more synergetic win-win relationship between product managers & developers.
outline:
2m - Intro about the tension between product managers and devs
3m - what is the tension about: introducing the 3 factors: Time, Quality and Scope. 
7m - Time, or lack of it. How can we manage our time better, why are estimates important  etc. 
4m - Code Quality - what should we compromise on and what not, why do we have technical debt 
5m - Scope -  How to plan the scope of sprints to include all needed tasks, how to handle technical debt
6m - Narrowing the gaps - some ideas on how to create a better work environment and better relationship
2m - summary 
total - 30 min

title: CI/CD for Microservices: Rule them all
abstract: Microservices development environment have become more and more popular in cloud-based companies to support better CI/CD methodologies. In this talk, Iâ€™ll show a case study illustrating the best practices for managing CI/CD for over 200 microservices on Docker/Kubernetes and Puppet production environments. Iâ€™ll also go over how developers can control all of these microservices using various tools, internal developments, and technologies.
outline:
2 minutes introduction
The rest is the session with the examples 
This is a very successful session from my experience. 
2 last minutes for Q&A

title: In a galaxy far, far away - A procedural generation tale
abstract:
Let's create a game set in space!

For this, I have to render a nice looking galaxy. How do I do it? 
Do I create a pre-rendered image and place 100k stars manually (oh no!), or do I try to create something random procedurally that looks awesome?

In this talk, I'll delve into the basic concepts of procedural generation - mostly around the basic mathematical tools at your disposal as a developer to create awesome procedural generated art. 

With every step in creating a realistic looking galaxy, I will provide code examples in JavaScript.
outline:
The slides of the talk are available here: http://slides.com/shaydavidson/galaxy#/

- 2m Introduction: Who am I and incentives for this talk.
- 3m What is procedural generation? 
- 1m What are we trying to create during this talk?
- 15m Creating the basics of the galaxy - random functions, distributions and easing.
- 10m Creating a spiral galaxy - how do we modify our galaxy math to achieve a realistic, spiral look?
- 5m Adding finishing touches - rotation matrices and eye-candy in CSS.

title: Our journey of developing Mimic, an open source API mocking tool
abstract:
Mimic is a client-side mocking solution that helps frontend developers become more productive by allowing to work without a server, simulate different scenarios, and even create mocks for automated tests.
This talk is about the journey of developing Mimic, from internal use to open source, the rewrites, the re-designs, the feedback we get from the community, and how it helped us become more productive when writing client-side code.
outline:
1m Introduction
4m The need and the tool - why we developed Mimic and a short live demo, it's benefits and use-cases
5m Our journey - the challenges in on-boarding users from the community, why we decided to pay for UX and was it worth it (it was!!), how we chose the name and why we changed it (it used to be called BDSM :))

title: The zero defect team: PRs without comments, pagers that never ring
abstract:
Developers nowadays have gotten really good at setting up systems to spot mistakes, bugs and defects, and avoiding the usual suspects. You know better than to deploy a big change right before the weekend. Youâ€™re using pull requests and have great reviewers that catch all the mistakes. And youâ€™ve got great tests coverage.

But, is that really the best we can expect of our teams? Spending so much effort to create a childproof environment?
In this talk we will explore the sci-fi-like world that I believe is attainable: professionalism, a team where PRs with comments are the exception, breaking builds are signs of real issues and unexpected downtime is almost worthy of harakiri.
outline:
- 2m: Intro
- 5m: Overview of how teams currently behave
- 4m: Why we should expect better
- 10m: How developers can do better
- 7m: How managers can help their teams do better
- 3m: Q&A, standing ovations

title: Creating the autonomous team: because no one got into management to run a kindergarten
abstract:
Youâ€™ve heard a ton of jokes about micromanaging and you get it, really. Yet you have that sinking feeling that if you keep your eyes off the team for a day, things will go haywire. 
People will stop thinking, somehow youâ€™ll have 3 new programming languages in production, and someone will agree to a deadline that will require acquiring Amazon.

Is this really why you got into management? Is running from meeting to meeting and constantly slackâ€™ing your whole team truly the best manager you can aspire to be?

Letâ€™s talk about creating a team thatâ€™s like a good iRobot: set and forget.
outline:
- 1m: Intro
- 2m: The kindergarten problem
- 1m: The iRobot vision
- 3m: 3 parts of a well-balanced and autonomous team
- 5m: Mitigating Slack
- 5m: Mitigating Execution
- 5m: Mitigating Autonomy
- 3m: Summary
- 3m: Q&A, standing ovation

title: I worked with 18 companies in 6 years, hereâ€™s what I learned
abstract: Over a period of 6 years Iâ€™ve worked with 18 different companies. Ranging from tiny startups, through Fortune 100 companies to government units, in 3 continents. You would be surprised how much all of these have in common. Hereâ€™s what Iâ€™ve seen to work again and again and what I understand never works.
outline:
- 2m: Intro
- 3m: The bureaucracy scale
- 5m: Maker schedules
- 3m: Different kinds of teams and autonomy
- 3m: Different kinds of managers
- 4m: What culture really means
- 4m: The evolution of companies
- 3m: Q&A, standing ovation

title: Meet WebVR and A-Frame & Let's build a VR game together
abstract:
ðŸ‘¾ Meet WebVR and A-Frame & Let's build a VR game together - Adi Polak and Uri Shaked ðŸ‘¾
WebVR is an emerging standard that enables web developers build Virtual Reality experiences using the familiar technologies we all love - HTML and JavaScript. We will show you how you can create a fun VR game, from scratch, that will run on multiple platforms - Oculus Rift, Google Daydream, Windows Mixed Reality and even on standard phones.

We will live-code everything (with some help from the audience), and then call some brave volunteers to play the game we just created and compete against each other. Who wins?
outline:
-2 min introduction to the speakers
-3 min why WebVR and a-frame
-20 min live code session
- 5 min Q&A

title: DevOps Data Collection: Measuring and Quantifying DevOps Outcomes
abstract:
DevOps is a world surrounded by information, starting from a single commit and ending in roll out to production.
In this talk, I'll introduce you to the world of Taboola DevOps data collection, to better understand what goes on under the hood.
The system we've developed in-house helps us collect and analyse the entire DevOps process from the very first commit all the way to production.
It provides us a full clear view with a drill-down toolset that helps keep us away from the dark side.
Our KPI's moved from being abstracted ideas to data driven goals, which we can measure and act upon.
outline:
- 2m Introduction: Who am I and how I got into the world of data
- 3m background buildup for how are we surrounding by data but do nothing with it
- 5m How this data can benefit me as a Developer, DevOps engineer and manager
- 7m Our solution: Measuring everything, from git push to code being deployed in production, how did we do it. Text turning to events and number into metrics (elasticsearch & metricTank)
- 4m Data visualisation, build graphs displaying a system overview on top of Grafana
- 4m Deep dive into the pipeline using Kibana, looking at events and identifying whats good and wrong 
- 5m Q&A 
Total: 30m

title: Building a product that customers fall in love with
abstract: A wise Chinese man once said - small details matter. In this lightning talk, I'll demonstrate how companies we all know (and also, some we don't) are focusing on the small product details, to drive emotion, make your life easier and get you to fall in love with the products they build.
outline:
* 15 sec - intro
* 15 sec - Why I think it's important that customers will not only use, but also, love with your product.
* 4 min - slides with screenshots from popular (and some not so popular) products, which demonstrate how the small details can get people to fall in love with a product.
* 30 sec - wishful thinking: I'll consider adding a few slides to present a "I wish that..." about small details I wish some products we all know would have implemented, to make me fall in love with their product even more.

title: AnnotBot  - The open source annotation chat bot
abstract:
Those who worked in machine learning and especially in Natural language processing (NLP) know that the hardest part of the job, is getting quality labelled data.
However, labelling thousands of example can be tedious.
At BestPractix, we came with an innovative solution - label the data by conversing with a telegram chatbot. 
We even walked the extra mile, and made this bot open source and available for everyone.

In this talk we would cover use cases, and show a short demo of AnnotBot.com .
outline:
1m - Supervised learning and the need for quality labels
3m - What we needed labelled, and how
2m - Creating a chatbot with Telegram
3m - A Quick demo of Annotbot.com
1m - Summary  and Q&A
Total Time: 10m

title: Better Software Design With Mind Maps
abstract:
Have you ever tried to design a complicated bit of software and ended up with a great big tangled mess? Designing software is hard and formal processes can be frustrating. Is there a better way to approach this task? 
Mind maps are a fun and intuitive way to brainstorm and organize your ideas on paper or a whiteboard. In this talk I will show how to use mind maps to design software well, convert your thought process into an excellent technical spec, and break it down into workable tasks while leaving lots of room for agility and flexibility.
outline:
- 2m introduction
- 3m explain what mind maps are and show some simple examples
- 15m "Let's design twitter" (or some other "standard" design example) demo
- 5m letâ€™s convert this design to a spec/task list
- 5m Summary & WIIFMs
Total time: 30m

title: Handling Errors With Grace
abstract: All programs have errors. Some are caused by the environment, some by user errors and some are due to bugs in your code. Yes, even yours. The success of your application depends on how you handle those errors, so you better have a good strategy in place. In this talk I will discuss different approaches to error handling, their advantages and disadvantages, and how to choose between them.
outline:
- 2m introduction
- 3m User errors
- 10m using error codes
- 10m using exceptions
- 5 minutes summary and WIIFMs
Total time: 30

title: Ad Auctions in the Wild
abstract: Optimizing auction revenue from the seller's perspective is a well studied problem in Game Theory. However, as is often the case, practical auctions extend well beyond the simplifying assumptions made in the literature. This talk will exemplify some of the gaps between theory and the optimization of real-time bidding ad auctions at Outbrain, and will highlight areas where theoretical ideas may still be productized despite the gaps.
outline:
Introduction: 
 - First-price and second price bidding, what are optimal auctions
 - Real-time Bidding in real life

Theory assumes: independent bidders, one-time auction, typically single item being sold, auctioneer has oracle knowledge on bidders.

In reality: bidders are correlated, auctions repeat billions of times, multiple ads slots are being sold, auctioneer only learns about bidders from data.

Consequences of said gaps - how can RTB sellers still leverage theory despite all the aforementioned gaps.

title: Labeling against all odds
abstract:
A common misconception is that data science is only about choosing the right model for the problem at hand, when, in fact, considerable time and effort are put into more fundamental challenges. One major bottleneck in machine learning is getting reliable labeled data to train the model on. 

How to learn on partially labeled data? How to deal with a data set that may potentially contain miss-labeled observations? How to create a feedback loop on your model predictions?

These are some of the labeling challenges that we are dealing with in PerimeterX. Many of them don't have a single, clear solution, and can be approached from different angles. Our talk will review some academic approaches that discuss these issues alongside case studies from PerimeterX.
outline:
-1m, Introduction: "So my name is Dana and I'm going to tell you a little secret..."
-4m, Describe the problem: why do we need labels, why is it so challenging in the cyber-security world

Now, three parts describing some of our challenges - academic aspects and our in-house practical solutions:

-7m, First challenge: how to extract binary labels from a rule-based system 
-7m, Second challenge: how to use semi-supervised methods to learn from both the labeled and unlabeled data
-7m, Third challenge: how to cope with possible noisy labels (misclassified observations)

-2m, Summary: main lessons (semi-supervised >> supervised, constant validation, easy and automated feedback mechanisms)

-2m, Q&A  

Total time: 30m

title: Nothing Good Ever Happens After 2am
abstract:
It was a quiet Sunday at the office. We deployed an innocent looking change to some legacy code. We were happy... for 24 hours. Then our support team got in touch to tell us about clients reporting an issue. It was quickly linked to our, now notorious, patch.

What happened during the following hours is a tale of fellowship, accountability and positive intentions; but also one of SLA definitions we'd forgotten, oncall procedures we ignored and a revert plan we didn't have.

During the session, I'll give a quick explanation of our outage procedure, talk through the events and actions of the â€œlong nightâ€ and give you some valuable company-agnostic takeaways.
outline:
Outline:
1m Introduction: Who am I and my professional background
2m: The outage procedure in BigPanda
5m: The unfolding events and the actions taken during the outage
5m: â€œsemi-liveâ€ outage postmortem, including insights and lessons learned
2m: Recap and takeaways
1m: Q&A

Example of takeaways:
1. Make sure all oncall personals are aligned with the outage procedure and understand the difference between an outage and a critical bug (P1/P2/P3).
2. Revert the change that cause the issue is in general the first approach to consider, especially over fixes and patches after work hours (â€œnothing good happens after 2amâ€ HIMYM)
3. Incident Manager On Call is an important function, use it!
4. Don't commit to action items during the night without consulting VP R&D/SRE
5. Importance of dividing responsibilities and reducing the noise in the communication channels.
And a few others...

title: From Fears to Fierce: Dealing with Leading
abstract:
The transition from individual contributor to engineering manager is hard. We spend years honing the skills we need to be good developers, only to discover that we need totally different tools to be good leaders. It's like starting our careers from scratch.

We'll talk about what's scary about managing a team. How do you handle developers who are smarter than you? How do you empower them and keep them engaged in an imperfect environment? And how do you keep your own career on track, continue to develop your technical skills and live with the understanding that if the team fails, you fail?

We'll also discuss solutions. How do you put aside these fears, become fierce and deal with leading?
outline:
2m Introduction: Who am I and my professional background
5m: The difference between the skill set required for a developer and that of a manager
5m: The fears of managing a team
5m: The fears a manager has about his/her own career
10m: Suggested solutions, tips and tricks to cope with the mentioned fears and other useful resources for answers
3m: Recap and takeaways
2m: Q&A

title: In-House Hackathons: A Survival Guide
abstract:
Internal company hackathons can be incredibly valuable. They're growing in popularity and for some great reasons.

If your organization hasn't run internal hackathons before, getting started can be a challenge. How do you explain to Product, or VP R&D, that you're about to spend at least a day working on anything but their features & bug fixes? What can you do to make sure that the teams start the day motivated and ready to work on worthwhile & interesting projects? How do you structure the day in a way that'll be fun & memorable, but still give people a chance to build something they're proud to demo?

We'll talk about what I've learned running hackathons for different organizations. I'll share my successes, my failures & everything you need to know to run your first company hackathon.
outline:
30s: Who am I and my professional background
30s: What is an internal company hackathon, how is it different from a â€œregularâ€ one 
    * Consider explaining what is a hackathon
1m: Why your company should run a hackathon
    * Break from day-to-day work
    * Doing something innovative and creative
    * Get to work and know people from a cross the company
    * Create opportunities for fresh faces to step up and lead
    * Have a great time!
2.5m: How to produce an awesome, memorable event
    * The team - who should be involved in planning
    * Prerequisites and preparations
    * Logistics
    * Suggested timeline
30s: Summary and takeaways

title: Sboblegate - how the famous Internet Guru Forced me to roll back the Change that Could have Saved G+
abstract: In 2011 I was the PM for the team that powered the Google+ social graph (such as it was.) In this session, we will post-mortem a previously untold incident, in which my team developed a new algorithm for suggesting friends, which we had hoped would catapult the social network on a new trajectory to success. We soon found out, in the middle of the night, that we had miscalculated badly. We will learn how optimizing for the wrong metric can spell doom even if the engineering is flawless.
outline:
- intro - alice in wonderland:  "If you don't know where you're going, any road'll take you there" 
- brief reminder to young folks what google+ was
- introducing the social graph team
- the problem we tried to solve: connecting people with people they know more intimately 
- Robert Scoble calls Vic Gundotra - where are all my followers
- analyzing what happened
- finding out the real metric we needed to move was not for intimacy but for engagement, and celebrities are good for that
- a secondary lesson - you have to make sure what you are doing isn't just 'right' but also does not expoe your boss politically
- conclusion

title: Breaking Barriers: Deploying hundreds of changes a day is not a dream
abstract:
By now, you're probably thinking: "This is yet another CI/CD session".
Well, its not - at least not the ones you are used to.

Think back to the first time you heard about Continuous Deployment. You immediately thought that's a fantastic idea and a right fit for your company.
That as a long time ago. So why aren't you doing Continuous Deployment yet?
In this talk we'll cover the technical, but most importantly the organizational and physiological barriers in adopting Continuous Deployment, and how to slay each one.
After attending this talk you will have the tools to convince the stakeholders, detect bottlenecks and lead the way to a smooth, painless, automatic deployments in your company.
outline:
2m introduction: Introducing myself and my career
4m problem overview: overview terms and concepts surrounding CD and the real challenges one faces when wanting to apply CD in a real world organization
15m the three barriers:  walking through the three barriers - automation, visibility and trust, and laying out proposed solutions and processes for each one
3m feedback loop: how to improve the CD process itself as part of the overhaul feedback loop
1m summary

Total time 25m

title: Earn $$$ from your home!
abstract:
The home assignment for tech interviews became widespread. Companies like them, as they save interviewer's time and present an objective scale.
Interviewees should like them - They work on them when it's convenient, not in the middle of the working day, without standing nervously in front of the whiteboard.

If you're a junior developer, this is your chance to demonstrate how you're better than your years of experience. Prove that you know the best practices and principles of building a small project, instead of just talking about them - Show, don't tell.

Join and learn what the company actually looks for.

Navigating the pitfalls of the home assignment will land you more options, better offers than before, and open doors previously closed. And eventually $$$ in your pocket.
outline:
The goal is to help junior developers understand what companies look for in their home assignment submission.
We'll cover:
- Communication: Questions asked during the process
- Presentation: Show your github skills, don't send a zip file.
- Architecture: Project structure
- Code appearance
- Tests
- Documentation
- How to work on it - Better having something partial but working perfect, rather than partially checking all requirements in a patchy way

title: My Full-Rewrite project wasted time. Act surprised.
abstract:
I knew the project in and out. I knew the requirements. I knew every line of code that got into it, every feature, every compromise. I put in half of the bugs myself.
I knew we where we tied ourselves to a specific vendor, and how hard it'd be to separate.

When things became unbearable, I tried to do the rewrite.
Took me 3 months to understand I'm not going to succeed. Why didn't I see this before?
outline:
- Describing the problem we got into
- My elegant solution
- Why nothing works as elegantly as you imagine

title: The unspoken challenges of software architecture in deep learning domain
abstract:
Deep learning applications are used across all life domains, and inference applications are getting deployed everywhere from data center to edge devices. This brings an appealing opportunity to create an accelerator to optimize inference flow. 
In this talk I will describe the software challenges we faced in building such an accelerator
outline:
2min introduction: who am I and what weâ€™re going to talk about
5min introduction to DL/inference domain and why itâ€™s interesting to build accelerator for inference ( increasing numbers of customers, number of papers > mooreâ€™s law,..)
15 min What should the software stack include for building an accelerator?
Framework support to get a workload
Compiler passes to generate code for your accelerator 
Memory placement decisions
Device placement decisions
Quantization
Optimization passes
Support for new operations
Support for new topologies 
API for executing the workload and manage the accelerator
Device driver for the accelerator
What can possible go wrong?? :-)

5 min - â€œHw from mars, software from venusâ€ - how to bridge between them and ask for hw features nicely. 

(5-10 Specific requirements that are unique to the AI domain, and example of how they break throughout development of a product)
Summary 
q&a
total time: 35 minutes

title: Supercali-monorepo-expi-microservice: A timeline of development and architecture at FDNA
abstract: Everyone knows that monorepos are meant to ease development and microservices are meant to decouple code - but we lived through the pains within both these seemingly unrelated ideas. When we broke the monolith apart, we paid by complicating development. When we simplified development, we paid with low performance and costly deployments.  At one point, we had 10 times as many repositories as we did microservices! I would like to share our own unique story about where we started, what we went through and where we are now in regards to our development process and system architecture, mixing in the cultural aspect, business goals and the team make up and how it all adds up to our AI based SaaS for healthcare.
outline:
â€¢ 1m Introduction: Who am I and my professional background
â€¢ 1m Introduction to FDNA today and some history
â€¢ 10m Timeline of our code and system architecture side by side with timeline of our team make up and business constraints
â€¢ 3m Some take-aways, tips and tricks, lessons learned
â€¢ Total time: 15m

title: CÌ¶rÌ¶aÌ¶cÌ¶kÌ¶iÌ¶nÌ¶gÌ¶  Fixing the coding interview
abstract:
Everybody talks about cracking the coding interview. Dozens of articles and heated discussions on how to prepare, what to ask, and even how to handle the infamous brainteasers.

But letâ€™s face it: the way we interview engineers is broken, and there is a very good reason for that - we are engineers! We know how to write code, and fix problems, a whole other set of skills than assessing other peoples' technical competence.
In this talk, we will share six mistakes we were doing while recruiting engineers and share the path to master the skill nobody talk about - being a better interviewer.
outline:
5m: a personal story about experiencing the recruiting process from both ends. and why we love and hate the interview culture created by "Cracking the Code Interview".
2m: who are we, and why we are authorized to talk about interviewing skills. 
15m: six things we've missed while interviewing, how we've fixed it, and how it boosted our recruiting success and productivity. 
5m: why you should treat interviewing as a skill, and how should you acquire it, and teach it.
3m : Q&A

title: Why Vue.js Is taking over?
abstract:
Vue.js is a lean-and-mean framework for building modern frontends 
its easy to learn, has great performance and encourage productivity.
Building apps with Vue is easy and fun, Its very versatile (suitable for huge and tiny apps)
Letâ€™s look at the newest evolvements of the framework, review some real life case studies, and rediscover joy in coding!
outline:
â€¢ 2m Introduction: Who am I and my professional background
â€¢ 8m The frameworks scene
â€¢ 10m The awsomeness of Vue, Vuex and the CLI
â€¢ 5m: The roadmap 
â€¢ 5m Q&A
Total time: 30m

title: Choosing the wrong thread
abstract: When you process billions of requests a day concurrency & multi-threading is critical for performance.  As heavy users of Aerospike & Clojure as our primary backend language, we needed to write a clj library for Aerospike as there wasn't anything readily available.  As part of its functionality we thought it would be useful for the library to encode and decode DB values to work with the diversity of serialization methods we use across our DBs (JSON, gzip, protobuf, etc).  However, we had a bit of an oversight in making the library non-blocking, and an even bigger mistake of having the wrong thread do the decoding.  All this created an extremely slow performance on high load of our production clients. We will dive into how we handled the issue rapidly in real time & the lessons learned.
outline:
2m introduction
5m what we have done
5m what was the problem
3m lessons learned
total: 15m

title: Creating an early stage architecture
abstract: In the early months of our venture, we wanted to validate our idea for a chatbot. Instead of developing chatbot capabilities in our MVP, we built a system for human operators. We learned a lot about our users, and  pivoted twice in 5 months (eventually switching to a web-app solution). In this talk I'll explain how to get into the mindset and principles for creating such a flexible architecture.
outline:
2m intro - who I am 
5 min - what was our initial product idea and plan to be very flexible when validating our MVP
10 min - the human operators approach (similar to zappos story in the beginning) and how our architecture supported it
10 min- how you can adopt this mindset and create an architecture to allow this flexibility.

title: Artificial Insanity - How to Keep Calm & Combat Imposter Syndrome
abstract: We've all suffered from imposter syndrome from time to time.  But it turns out imposter syndrome has some really clear patterns, and there are actually a few simple tips and tricks to start appreciating ourselves more.  This talk will provide some tools to help you keep calm and focus on your small successes  that eventually translate to big successes - similar to Kaizen.  And that all this starts with allowing ourselves to be human first and foremost.
outline:
Here are my shell slides (it helped me think)
https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1-o8TENr0baN2RqUqxAp7t23fyKzr6ct5DrVnO6McQc8/edit#slide=id.g4f59bf46a2_0_151


Defining different concepts (imposter syndrome, dunning kruger, kaizen)
Analyzing patterns of imposter syndrome manifestation
Tips and tricks to overcome

title: How to stay statistically significant in Agile environment?
abstract:
There is a conflict of interest: data science field has evolved from academic routines and is often based on long-term cycles of research and seeking for the optimal solution. On the other hand, product development requires fast execution, flexible decision making and constant deliverables of new solutions to production.

In this talk Iâ€™ll share how agile product development principles work in harmony with machine learning development on real examples from my work at Booking.com. I will explain how embedded data scientists in cross-functional team structure and data-driven culture can contribute to daily standups and constant deliverables, and how to tackle big machine learning projects in short cycles.
outline:
Gave a similar talk at Booking.com meetup (https://www.meetup.com/booking-com-telaviv-tech-meetup/events/257103331/) in front of 200 participant and got requests to repeat the talk in front of a bigger audience (and that is my main reason for application). It took me 30 mins without questions.
The (WIP) slides can be found here:
https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1CGOb8-cQzr6eQWhc_w1Bc3-pl3hp_WTM5XZVGkm-9Mw/edit?usp=sharing

title: How a Seemingly Small Issue Can Make your Software become a Zombie
abstract:
Our SDK is used by more than 130K+ applications and is what delivers all of our incoming traffic from the different platforms being used.  Recently, we encountered a critical issue, that prevented any incoming traffic from Android devices to AppsFlyer.

As part of our anti-fraud solution, we use the Dexguard algorithm to prevent reverse engineering, where the large majority of our 130K apps use the same tool. However, due to the issue, some source files in the SDK were corrupted on the client-side, breaking the backbone of the SDK, basically shutting down the outgoing mobile SDK traffic to AppsFlyer.  This talk will dive into the timeline of the incident, decisions we took in real time to mitigate the incident & the lessons we learned that we think can help others in a similar situation.
outline:
- [ 1m ] Introduction: Who am I and my professional background
- [ 1m ] Brief Overview: What our software does
- [ 5m ] Subject: Diving into the timeline of the incident, decisions we took in real time.
- [8m ] Lesson Learned and Tips

Total time: 15 min

title: Let it go: stay secure without holding back your developers
abstract:
What was once a bad dream is now a reality: any developer can push any code to production at any time (and sometimes multiple times a day) without any sign-off.
In order to cope with this fundamental change, we need to surrender control and put more trust in our developers. But how? How can you build a decentralized security approach? What tools are available? How should your work culture change to support this new reality?
In this session, you'll hear about the journey we've gone through at Soluto â€“ what has worked, what hasn't, and what we're still working on. Youâ€™ll gain some practical advice and learn about tools that allow you to "let go" without compromising on security.
outline:
- 3m Introduction: The move from waterfall to agile/scram and continues deployment methodology. The benefits of the new models, and why it's challenging for the old security model (the gating model).
- 3m decentralized culture: The only way for security to keep up to speed is by moving to a decentralized culture. Empower developers and help them to write secure code. But how?
- 7m security champions: Software developers from the entire organization who shows interests in security. They are responsible to improve the security of their teams, and being the local representative of the security team.
- 7m security tests: Security tests helps developers detect security issues in their code. This section will focus on how to do security tests correctly so it will affect developers and help them. For example, tests that are not breaking the build are useless.
- 7m continuous threat modeling: Threat modeling is a tool that helps us find security issues in the design. This part will include a really quick introduction and then cover how we can do threat modeling at scale
3m - Conclusion.
The session will focus on the experience we gathered at Soluto. For each part, Iâ€™ll share what we tried, what worked and what didnâ€™t. Attendees of this session will get practical advice they can use in their work.

title: Let it go: stay secure without holding back your developers
abstract:
What was once a bad dream is now a reality: any developer can push any code to production at any time (and sometimes multiple times a day) without any sign-off.
In order to cope with this fundamental change, we need to surrender control and put more trust in our developers. But how? How can you build a decentralized security approach? What tools are available? How should your work culture change to support this new reality?
In this session, you'll hear about the journey we've gone through at Soluto â€“ what has worked, what hasn't, and what we're still working on. Youâ€™ll gain some practical advice and learn about tools that allow you to "let go" without compromising on security.
outline:
- 3m Introduction: The move from waterfall to agile/scram and continues deployment methodology. The benefits of the new models, and why it's challenging for the old security model (the gating model).
- 3m decentralized culture: The only way for security to keep up to speed is by moving to a decentralized culture. Empower developers and help them to write secure code. But how?
- 7m security champions: Software developers from the entire organization who shows interests in security. They are responsible to improve the security of their teams, and being the local representative of the security team.
- 7m security tests: Security tests helps developers detect security issues in their code. This section will focus on how to do security tests correctly so it will affect developers and help them. For example, tests that are not breaking the build are useless.
- 7m continuous threat modeling: Threat modeling is a tool that helps us find security issues in the design. This part will include a really quick introduction and then cover how we can do threat modeling at scale
3m - Conclusion.
The session will focus on the experience we gathered at Soluto. For each part, Iâ€™ll share what we tried, what worked and what didnâ€™t. Attendees of this session will get practical advice they can use in their work.

title: Putting security tests to the test
abstract:
Writing secure code is hard, and thatâ€™s why I love the idea of security tests. Iâ€™ve spent countless hours researching tools, integrating them into the pipeline, and help developers use them. Itâ€™s all based on one big assumption: security tests can detect real, juicy vulnerabilities.
But have we ever stopped and questioned this assumption? I didnâ€™t â€“ until I started preparing a talk about how security tests can help people write more secure code. The point was to see how many vulnerabilities we can find by scanning a vulnerable application with security testing. But youâ€™d be surprised to find out how many were actually detected.
In the session, weâ€™ll find out how many security issues we can detect in OWASP Juice Shop by using various security tests. Ready to put security tests to the test?
outline:
5m Introduction: The promise of security tests. How security tests can help us detect security issues in our code - before it gets into production.
5m OWASP Juice Shop: Introduce the project - an intentional vulnerable web application, for educational purposes. This part will cover the type of issues exist in Juice Shop.
10m Scanning security tests: Using 3 different security tests (SAST, DAST, and packages scan) to scan Juice Shop. This part includes a live demo and discussion on the findings.
10m Conclusion: Discussing which issues detected in Juice Shop and which didnâ€™t. What type of issues is hard to detect? Why? How can we detect them? 
Attendees of this session will learn what value security tests can provide - but also, the limits of security tests. What kind of issues it canâ€™t detect - and what they can use instead.

title: Being a Product Management hacker - Decoding your product managerâ€™s language
abstract:
Hack your way into Product Management world, and letâ€™s try together to decode some of the PMs lingo.
If you conversations with your PMs sometimes sounds like â€œblah blah blah $choose_from_the_below:
-	Yup, itâ€™s on my roadmap
-	We should A/B test it
-	I need to prioritize it
-	MVP what?
-	Product CEO
-	Did you open a Jira on that?
-	Low hanging fruit
-	Wowable, ha?!
-	It is not delightful enough
-	Why is it taking too long
-	Technical debt again?
-	Super-Strategic
-       Lo-fi, Hi-fi

Then you should come down to the ignite sessions, to get a good practical understanding of whatâ€™s going on in a PM head and why it all means good, but not always sounds like that :-)
outline:
Lightning session:
- 30 seconds: intro
- 30 seconds: presenting the topic and challenge to be solved
- 30 seconds: why strong PM make your developer life easier
- 3.5 minutes: PM says (divided into logical sections in that time frame) and what they really mean for you as R&D day-to-say and how you can understand product aspects better, to streamline your product-R&D communication

title: Part Time, Full Impact
abstract:
Part time work is great. It enables people to work while spending more time on their studies, family or startup. But it also comes with challenges.

How do you manage your tasks and time when you're only working 1, 2 or 3 days a week? How can you make the best of your time at the office?

If you have a part-time team member, how can you benefit from their expertise, without getting stuck waiting for their input?

Also, managing yourself as a part time worker is hard, managing a part time worker is just as hard. How should your management style and expectations change to enable them to work efficiently?

In this talk I'll share my experience, and hopefully some answers.
outline:
* 2 minutes - Introduction of me, how i got to where i am and why
* 15-20 minutes - Presenting each obstacle with being part time (and moving from full time to part time), and ways to handle these obstacles: 
    * Being the blocker for projects and team members
    * Managing your time efficiently (without giving up on coffee breaks)
    * Dealing with big ongoing projects
    * Managing your tasks on a daily basis 
    * Feeling the change from being in the office 100% of the time to being only X%
    * etc..
* 5-10 minutes - As a manager how can you help your part time employees, the dos and don'ts and also why having a part time employee on your hands is not bad, and might even be good for YOU
* 3 minutes - questions

title: Want to become an architect? Follow these easy 99 steps
abstract:
I have been an architect for over 10 years. 
Many engineers that I met over the years don't know what is the meaning of this position, either because this role doesn't exist in the organization they work for, or because they don't have a close interface with an architect.
I get questions like: How do I know if this role fits me? what I can do to improve my skills and get to that place?
In this talk I'll share insights about the role and the answer I give to these frequently asked questions.
outline:
5 min intro about my career path of over 20 years in development and architecture
10 min - what an architect does (depending on team size, organization type, org structure, project needs, your personality etc)
10 min - How to know if this role fits you , and what do you need to do to bring yourself from the developer to the architect mindset and position.  
5 min - Q&A

title: Tech Debt? I take that!
abstract:
What do you think about when you hear â€œTech Debtâ€? 
Most people think about bad things which must be avoided at all cost. Bad design, no tests and unmaintainable code are just a few examples.
When I hear â€œTech Debtâ€, I think about managing risk and opportunity. I think about a powerful tool which, when used correctly, allows delivering great products.
I believe learning to use tech debt in a smart way (vs. â€œcutting cornersâ€) is difficult, but is a key factor in becoming a mature engineering team that ships successful products.
In my talk, I will explore common misconceptions about tech debt, what types of it exists, and how to leverage it to achieve your product development goals. 
I will also cover the fact that tech debt must be payed back, and share practical tips on how to do it.
outline:
2m - Introduction
2m - How tech debt is perceived
2m - What a tech debt really is
2m - The high opportunity cost we pay when we donâ€™t use tech debt
5m - tech debt types
   * Accidental 
   * Planned
   * It seemed like a good idea at the time :)   

10m - how to create tech debt in a smart way
   * Hide it (abstraction)
   * Externalize it (to a different service)
   * Optimize your code for easy deletion    

5m - when and how to pay it back
2m - summary

title: Entity and Word Embbeding: Evaluation and Out-Of-Box Thinking
abstract: Embeddings in general and Word embeddings, in particular, are real-valued entity representations able to capture context semantics and trained on unique corpora.  Models proposing these representations have gained popularity in recent years, but the issue of the most adequate evaluation method still remains open. I will present an extensive overview of the field of words and non-NLP embeddings evaluation, highlighting main problems and proposing a typology of approaches to evaluation.
outline:
2-5 min about myself and a bit about Fiverr
10 -7 basic explanation to set everyone on the same line
10 - 15 Evaluation on embedding 
7 min out-of-box thinking with embedding
5-7 min QA

title: Text2Gigâ€Šâ€”â€ŠContextual Text Similarity
abstract: Text2Gig is our contextual text similarity recommendation model. This is our new approach on Fiverr, free text search and similar item text-based recommendation. Iâ€™m going to talk about all the process from A to Z in creating this model. I will start with ideation of this model, continue with the development and the framework for this model and for dessert I will saw you some use cases of using the model and the results of testing the model on live users
outline:
3-5 min introducing myself and explain about Fiverr
5 min ideation and why we took this path
5 min basic explanation about word2vec and doc2vec
7 min presenting text2gig
5 min use cases 
3-5 min QA

title: Infusing security awareness into Agile product management
abstract:
It is a common illusion that Product Managers in the current reality, can continue working to define products, without thinking about security aspects, and that this can be done at a much later stage in the product lifecycle. How can we turn the Product Manager to be a real security ambassador?
Weâ€™d like to show how a very comprehensive security program, managed by a dedicated security office in cooperation with a professional Product Manager, can raise the â€œsecurity organizational conscienceâ€ and can successfully integrate security aspects in every product, with emphasis on agile development lifecycle!  We will describe a process to bring security to the early stages of product lifecycle, starting from the planning stages ( aka â€œshift leftâ€), which is impossible without full cooperation.
outline:
2 m - Intro
 -Secure Development vs. Agile Development
 -Secure Agile Development 
-Who are we?
2m Best Practices
2m The Game of Thrones Is such conversation common?
2m Shared Goals
1m How to infuseâ€¦
10m Checkpoints
 -Kickoff\Pre Planning
 -Design\Implementation
 -Signoff\Demo
 -Kickoff Example
 -User View
 -Developer View
 -Attacker View
 -Defender View
 -Signoff  Example
2 m WIFM - What's In It For Me?
1 m Summary
5min Q&A
Total: 27 m

title: Well-architected serverless application
abstract:
Designing the right architecture when building a software application is imperative. As serverless based applications are new, it is essential to learn from other team experience as you are adopting the methodology. 

In this talk we will discuss: 
- Major design and architecture considerations
- Best practices for serverless architecture
- Mono-repo vs. multi-repo
- Fat lambda vs. thin lambdas
- Actionable recommendations for cold starts, scaling, concurrency, layers and more
outline: In my talk, I'm raising a set of architectural questions when building a serverless application and I'm sharing how our team overcome each one, what where the options and why we selected a specific option

title: Serverless Testing
abstract: Serverless technology is emerging, and the adaptation by software engineering teams is very high. Like any new technology, there are many benefits but there are some new challenges as well. Testing, which is an important part of software development, in a serverless environment is challenging and different from what we are familiar with. In this session, we will quickly go over the special characteristics the developer needs to consider when developing and testing serverless functions.
outline: I will explain the change is the importance of different test type, the new testing pyramid in the serverless world. Then we'll discuss the options on how to do serverless testing, pro, and con of each and my recommendation based on experience. We'll finish with tips how to perform serverless testing in an efficient way.

title: Scaling Flat - how to do more with less (managers)
abstract:
When you have a small team and everyone is working on the same project, everything is easy. How do you deal with a team growing to 20 people and more with lots of projects to handle?  
I know what you're thinking - just split to teams. But are teams _really_ the best answer?
I would like to tell you about how we keep a **flat** structure and maintain a very **dynamic** work environment, while still working in small and effective work units.

Hitting the right formula has been a big effort and I want to take you through our journey to productivity.
outline:
* 2m Intro: About me
* 3m Vonage: How our company operates generally in terms of teams and cooperation
* 5m My team: The challenges facing (my) backend team - big rewrite, growing team size.
* 5m How are other companies tackling this problem (Teams, Squads, etc.)
* 10m Our model - keeping a dynamically shifting workforce, able to respond to challenges quickly yet stay focused for long periods of time.
* 5m Summary and Questions

Total time: 30m

title: GraphQL in production - solving common problems the GraphQL way
abstract:
So, everyone is doing GraphQL and you want to do it too! 

You created a POC for a GraphQL server and it looks great! It works, its cool and your client devs are happy. You want to graduate to a production solution but... then you start running into real life problems like authorization, performance, boilerplate code etc.

We were exactly at this point a year ago, and in the process of solving these issues we learned a lot. In this talk I will share with you what we learned and use this as an opportunity to dig deeper into how you can use GraphQL's strong points to solve common problems. 

So, if you are curious about GraphQL and want to get a deep dive into this world or if you are a seasoned GraphQL veteran and want to get another perspective, this talk is for you.
outline:
Introduce myself - 2 minutes
Intro to the talk describing the outline of what we will talk about today - 3 minutes
Short recap of GraphQL core principals for people who are not familiar with it - 5 minutes
Describing three real world problems we faced when using GraphQL implementation in production and how we tackled them:
  * Authorization - 6 minutes
  * Performance - 6 minutes
  * Boilerplate and repetitive process - 5 minutes

Recap and summary - 3 minutes.

title: Oh, the places youâ€™ll go: Being a first developer in a startup
abstract: When you work in a team within an already-based company, the flow of day-to-day work is very straight forward. But what happens when youâ€™re the first developer to join a new founded startup? A few months ago I made this career move, and Iâ€™m here to tell you what itâ€™s like: What can you expect the day after? What new skills will you have to learn? What decisions will you be making, and how are you going to make them? Letâ€™s talk about your first time being a first developer.
outline:
30 sec intro: a quick overview about the subject and myself. 
4 min: the important questions to ask about being a first developer, and their answers from my point of view.
30 sec wrap up: what can one expect from this experience?

Total 5 min

title: The story of a 16 years old developer
abstract:
As a 16 years old developer (Gen Z), and before I'll become part of the official grown-up high tech community, I would like to share with you my learning journey and development experience.
It started at the age of 6, when I first wanted to build a virtual world (now www.tornado.world).
I will show you how your kids can learn to develop and how I think, they should start
(forget about 'CodeMonkey', I'll talk about that also in my session).

How I overcame the language (English) barrier, being a 6 yo native Hebrew speaker.

Learning security through hacking Aroma, Cinema-City and some other SQL injections (including taking down my high school site after retrieving all students' info)
I will also touch some legal aspect, technologies I used, revenues, development process etc...
outline:
2m: Self introduction and my dream
7m: My learning journey - and how you might apply it on your kids.
4m: Development process - Utilizing my screen time
6m: Taking detours. Security aspects - when users are trying to hack your site, do it to others.
8m: Challenges I faced and how I utilized the "Hi I'm Or and I'm 12 years old..." e-mails
3m: Summary, a flow diagram of my learning process.

title: Is Your Product Passive-Impressive?
abstract:
As we build products and features, one of our main goals is for our users to actually use them. One of the best ways to increase product adoption is to create Passive Impressive features - those that remove the need for the user to opt in, but without being intrusive or â€œPassive Aggressiveâ€. Or in other words - opt out features that encourage users to ask â€œWhy Shouldnâ€™t I use this?â€ instead of â€œWhy Should I?â€ 
In this session, I will talk about why we should focus on â€œopting outâ€, why it doesnâ€™t apply to everything, and give tips on how to increase the focus on this in your organization.
outline:
5 min Lightning Talk
- Intro - and what is a Passive Impressive product - explaining that it is about opt out features that are not "passive aggressive" and intrusive, but instead features that remove the need for clients to ask "should I use this" and instead ask "Why shouldn't I"
- Why should you focus on opting out, what is the impact, will share a personal story/example
- How to opt out - examples from Dan Ariely, from my personal and professional experience, features that we worked on in Kenshoo, and their results due to the opt out approach and examples from other companies (Google email suggestions as a great example)
- When you do need to use opt in - examples from Kenshoo and from the Industry
- Tips of how to increase focus of this in your org
- Summary


I am also submitting this as a Full Featured session - as I believe this can be a great lightening talk, and also a great full session.

title: Is Your Product Passive-Impressive?
abstract:
As we build products and features, one of our main goals is for our users to actually use them. One of the best ways to increase product adoption is to create Passive Impressive features - those that remove the need for the user to opt in without being intrusive or â€œPassive Aggressiveâ€. Or in other words - opt out features that encourage users to ask â€œWhy Shouldnâ€™t I use this?â€ instead of â€œWhy Should I?â€ 
In this session, I will talk about why we should focus on â€œopting outâ€, why it doesnâ€™t apply to everything, and give tips on how to increase the focus on this in your organization.
outline:
Full Featured - 30 min
- 2 min Intro - and what is a Passive Impressive product - explaining that it is about opt out features that are not "passive aggressive" and intrusive, but instead features that remove the need for clients to ask "should I use this" and instead ask "Why shouldn't I"
- 3 min - Why should you focus on opting out, what is the impact, will share a personal story/example
- 10 min - How to opt out - examples from Dan Ariely, from my personal and professional experience, features that we worked on in Kenshoo, and their results due to the opt out approach and examples from other companies (Google email suggestions as a great example), and give examples of Passive Impressive vs Passive Aggressive Features
- 5 min - When you do need to use opt in - examples from Kenshoo and from the Industry
- 5 min - Tips of how to increase focus of this in your org
- 2 min - Summary
Total: 27 min

I am also submitting this as a Lightning Talk - as I believe this can be a great lightening talk, and also a great full session.

title: Of Islands, Monsters & InnerSource
abstract:
Software world is changing rapidly, and software developers in organizations are finding it difficult to keep up, and have no time to learn new technologies, although they are probably used by other groups in the organization.
In the long run, this can affect developersâ€™ satisfaction and their employability.

Adopting Inner Source (the act of leveraging Open Source Software development practices within the confines of a corporate environment) seems like the answer.

Elbit's Inner Source program relies on the Software Guild (an innovative gamification approach) and the  Skill-POOL - a market place encouraging developers to experiment with new technologies as a meaningful on the job training.

The talk offers an overview of the journey of the Inner Source program.
outline:
â€¢ 2m Introduction - What does gamification mean.
â€¢ 3m Background - Which pains are we trying to address.
â€¢ 5m `let the: journey begin` - How the software Guild started, and the shape it took
â€¢ 5m An overview of some of our way to encourage developers share knowledge and code
â€¢ 10m : The impact of the Guild on the development community within Elbit.
â€¢ 5m : The next step:  Skill POOL - a gigs marketplace within the corporate.

title: Making a change - Becoming an entrepreneur in your own workplace
abstract:
Pushing major changes in the organization is hard. Not only technology-hard. But also - cultural-hard. You need to convince people to embrace a new paradigm, technology or product. While you may have a vision in mind, your colleagues might not see it clearly.

In this talk I'll share my story about moving Planck from a two-weeks version release to a CI/CD workflow. But it's not a talk about CI/CD (you've probably heard some of those already), it's a talk about being an entrepreneur inside your own organization - find your "investors", build the MVP, show results, overcome dogmas and so on...
outline:
2m - intro
2m - Background @ Outbrain where I "soaked" deep CI/CD culture and my early days @ Planck where I was frustrated about my team version-release (A.K.A promotion) process and my goal to change the dev org to work with CI/CD instead.
2m - WIIFM - asking myself - does it make sense for Planck to do CI/CD? Am I not dogmatic myself for trying to push a process just because it worked well at Outbrain?
5m - Understanding the resistance, the fears, etc... I will talk about how I tried, as the new guy, just to learn. I realized that CI/CD for an AI solution (with models that need to be tested for accuracy with each deploy -> which is expansive and long) is not as simple as I was used to. Then coming to the realization that it can be done and the problem is more cultural (fear of change) than technical

5m - starting small:
- Engaging the team - find champions (design-partners), repeat the "mantra" (in months from now  there won't be no promotion ×ª×’×–×¨×• from that to what we need now).
- Overcoming the fear (the MVP): Creating a dev env with a CI/CD plan to staging (it's not production, what's the worst that could happen) -> Let's dry-run (× ×ª××ž×Ÿ ×¢×œ ×™×‘×©)

5m - Find investors
- After we've started small, now let's convince stakeholders - CTO, CEO, product
- I'll share about our on-call routine in which everyday we've had a dev on-call. The dev on call had an ×´×¢×œ×™×™×ª ×ž×©×ž×¨" and ×´×™×¨×™×“×ª ×ž×©×ž×¨" where we gathered statistics about our problems such as: Dev time spent during the shift, dev time spend on/off-hours (after 19:00), MTTR, the severity of bugs and impact on customers etc...
- The stats are meant to show the opportunity - the time wasted on promotion, on bugs that we can't fix until the next version and on customer requests that would have to wait until the next version.

5m - Expand
- After recuring the champions and the investors it's time to expand
- Have a deep analysis on the on-call stats and reports -> Find out what's the ROI for fixing issues easily
- Improve the system until.

1m - Summary
I will talk about becoming an intrapaneur, how to fight dogmas and change the culture to improve your organization. This will go through the main tips and tricks during the story and how to apply them on other projects, not necessarily CI/CD

3m - Questions

title: Making the most of Security Tests
abstract:
Red teaming, pentesting, white box testing â€“ many definitions and even more ways to conduct these tests, but how they help in the ultimate decision if the product requires additional investments? This paper will deep dive into a real attack executed by a red team against a multi-layer product. All the cool hacks leading from XML-RPC interface to root access act as a mere excuse for discussing:
- where the different tests fail and succeed in finding vulnerabilities
- what the tests tell about the risks estimation
- how to achieve actionable results
- how to benefit from the results reported
outline:
1m whoami
2m Presentation outline and goals
3m Description of different security tests compared
2m Initial finding
2m Blind SQL execution
3m Attempts to achieve actual SQL output
2m Reading actual data by blind SQL execution
4m Achieving actionable SQL injection
1m Achieved access examples
1m Escalating access
4m Different approaches comparison & conclusions
5m Q&A
Total time: 30m

title: All you need is... Chrome!
abstract:
One day I desperately needed to pass a mandatory web security e-learning. Every stage ended up asking for a flag that could be obtained by completing some lab exercises.
The problem was ... somebody left the office or company, turned down some boxes and the lab servers were not available...
Problem? Rather a challenge!
First thought - live off the land!
This live demo shows how to take advantage of Developer Tools embedded in web browsers including Chrome, Firefox or Edge to perform rapid static and dynamic analyses of JavaScript.
The example will focus on passing the annoying e-learning, but there will be also a quick story shared, how the same method allowed me to score some best-dad points helping my son to impress his girlfriend
outline:
1m Problem statement - guessing unguessable password
1m Tools available in Chrome (and all other modern browsers)
1m Reconnaissance
1m Breaking through
1m Quick repeat of the method to overcome artificial constraints in... railways tickets system

title: What hit my webservice with 408?!
abstract:
One night, a webservice hosted on a popular cloud provider was struck by a mysterious http request and surprisingly did not recover for half an hour. That event reminded that starting a publicly available webservice means becoming a target for scanners that relentlessly crawl the internet poking for vulnerabilities.
