This lightning talk discusses a real-world story of a certain message from such a massive scan that instead of failing gracefully with 404 response code (Not found) started to cause 408 (Request timeout) - a much bigger threat of Denial of Service. 
In order to reproduce the issue, different methods of logging were examined - both using cloud services, as well as Java application based. Surprisingly, it also offered a way to optimize the load on the hosting infrastructure.
outline:
1m Initial outage
1m Quick analysis of massive access logs
2m Different attempts to catch the full details of a suspect
1m Conclusions & load optimizations

title: What Clash Royale teaches us about retaining users
abstract:
Clash Royale is arguably one of the most successful and profitable mobile games. Iâ€™ve been playing it daily for over 2 years, with several unsuccessful attempts at quitting.
Iâ€™ve watched kids and adults rage-quit, swearing never to play again, and eventually return to play with even greater addiction. 
Thereâ€™s a secret sauce that can, when used correctly, transform mediocre products to a huge success. In this talk Iâ€™m going to share some of the ingredient of this sauce: on boarding, notifications, social aspects, rewards and of course - FOMO.
outline:
* 2m introduction: about myself and my background
* 3m: presenting the game: whatâ€™s Clash Royale and some figures (amount of users, daily revenue, etc)
* 15m: Techniques used in the game to on board new users and retain existing ones. Things like rewards, social aspects, push notofocations, FOMO and more. 
* 10m: summarizing and explaining how to port these techniques to other types of products

title: Learning by writing - What creating transcripts for Reversim can teach you
abstract:
Have you ever noticed that every Reversim episode comes out with a full transcript? Have you ever found it useful? or thought what's the point?
For the last few months I'm helping in creating the transcripts for Reversim episodes, and found it to be a very interesting experience, with many benefits, some of them are far from obvious, which could be useful for any professional who's looking to expend her or his knowledge (aren't we all?).  On this quick talk I'll review some of those aspects, and highlight some key takeaways any of us could use.
outline:
1m - why transcript? it's an audible thing . . . 
1m - learning by writing
2m - example for Easter eggs - funny, and helps you connect the dots
1m - call for action: try it yourself :-)

title: Retrospect on retrospectives
abstract: Battle tested tips & tricks for conducting postmortems/retrospectives. In the last 2 years we completely changed our learning culture at Trax Engineering. We would share with you the best practices we learned along the way.  Practical ideas to switch from blame games to ace games.
outline:
Outline:
* Understanding the pain
    * Why do we need them?
    * How much of what we learn is really absorbed in the organization
* The golden rules of retros
    * NOT a BLAME game!
    * When? - when is a retro is required
    * Ownership - Investigation and solo-brainstorming for AI's (action items)
    * Importance of the ceremony
    * Transparency is not Boolean - Your retro is a ticket not PDF!
    * Single source of work - How to properly log your AI's
* How can we now measure our learning process
* The pitfalls to be aware of
    * The police ticket syndrome

title: Scalable BPF in real life
abstract:
BPF (Berkley Packet Filter) has many uses and is used extensively in the Linux world. It is used for observability, for controling packet capture with Wireshark, and for data processing in XDP. The cillium.io Linux uses BPF exclusively for network configuration.

However, using BPF once one thing and developing a portable, predictable BPF program that works with different kernel versions is an different story.
Getting BPF to work is made even more challenging since many important details such as  the ELF file format and kernel error messages are scarcely documented.
In this talk, I'll take you through the process of creating a stable BPF program that grabs interesting bits out of TCP connections at high throughput.
I'll discuss what you should do to get BPF to work, what you shouldn't.
outline:
- 2m introduction of me
- 3m Explain problem BPF solved in practice
- 10m overview BPF internals
- 5m BPF related tools and debugging techniques
- 5m BPF pitfalls in practice
- 5m Q&A

Total time: 30m + 5m Q&A

title: Visualization tips to boost your effectiveness
abstract:
Have you ever attend a long discussion, where people kept talking and getting nowhere?
Have you ever had a team that just could not figure out their progress? A retrospective meeting that was all over the place?
Are you looking for any easy and quick way to do it? 
We often talk about the transparency that agile practices enables us while on our daily work we often forget visualization. We just want to have a short chat and get it over with. 
Visual facilitation and other visualization tools can boost your discussions and processes effectiveness just by displaying the data. 
In this talk I will share with you tips and visualization tools I often use on a daily basis that you can start using right away.
outline:
Some facts about our brain & challenges we face  - 5 min

A list of tips on visualization for each:
1. problem space 
2. solution space 
3. example 
total - 20 min 

Takeaways  & Closure -  5 min

title: Putting Data Science to work at scale - from development to production
abstract:
Bringing Data Science to Production poses some unique challenges, such as how to mobilize large code bases written in a variety of technologies and tools, some of which not optimized for production resiliency and scalability.
In our talk, we will share Gong.io's experience, presenting our current Data Science CI / CD and production flows, what works well, and what we plan to improve.
outline:
5m Introducing the gap between data science needs and production requirments
10m What processes and tools do we use at Gong.io the bridge the Gap
5m Gong.io Data-Science CI/CD Process in the Spotlight
5m Tips and Tricks from our Data-Science CI/CD experience
5m Q&A

title: From two developers to a billion dollar company - the WalkMe engineering story
abstract: The WalkMe product development started 8 years ago by two developers in an apartment. Fast forward to the present and our R&D team has more than 150 people. It has been a roller coaster ride with many ups and downs. In my presentation I will tell the WalkMe engineering story and highlight the strategic decisions we made along the way. I hope my presentation would be interesting, fun, educational and inspiring.
outline:
Some topics I will cover:
* Evolution of code ownership - What is the right structure for the R&D for each phase?
* Technical debt - Is it worth taking?
* To customize or build a generic product?
* Security and privacy - When and why do we need to start thinking seriously about this?
* Supporting customers - How to do that effectively?
* Off-shore development - To do it or not?
* VP R&D and CTO - When does it make sense to have two roles?

title: Getting a handle on software architecture
abstract:
What is software architecture? This seemingly simple question has baffled researchers and practitioners for decades. Industry legends such as Mary Shaw, Martin Fowler, Grady Booch and Ralph Johnson have weighed in on just what architecture is; but as an industry, we have yet to come up with a compelling description or concrete requirements from the role.

In this talk we'll consider software architecture in a new light, centered around one key observation: good architecture isn't about dealing with current requirements, but rather about avoiding future constraints. With that understood, we can have useful discussions about what is or isn't good architecture; hopefully, you will leave this session with ideas on how to build/evolve your software towards an unknown future comfortably.
outline:
Outline:
- Who or what am I? (1 minute at most)
- Overview of accepted wisdom re architecture (up to 5 minutes)
- Why I think existing observations aren't useful (2 minutes)
- "Software architecture: the set of decisions that constrain future evolution of the system" (2 minutes + 2 minutes for contrast with e.g. Grady Booch's definition)
- Making it actionable: how do we choose a good architecture?
  + Understanding oragnizational goals (2 minutes)
  + If we're avoiding constraints, this is less about the do's and more about the don'ts! (1 minutes)
  + List of don'ts (e.g. pick a monolithic "solves all your problems" framework) (10 minutes)
- Q&A (5 minutes)

title: Zero downtime RDS Aurora upgrade with ProxySQL
abstract:
At Cloudinary we use AWS Aurora managed database service that reduces overhead allowing us focus on product development. 
Aurora comes with a lot of great features out of the box such as: 
automatic failover in case of master db issue. 
It also constantly upgrades with new feature, security and performance improvements. 

However, upgrade requires up to 1 minute downtime which for heavy load SaaS company is not an option. 

In this session, I will present our journey.
From the research for proper tools to accomplish zero downtime upgrade with ProxySQL - proven to be a great tool for various scenarios.
I will also describe the long POC and issues we faced and will provide code snippets and configuration examples, along with a  LIVE demo of Migrating Aurora cluster without any downtime.
outline:
2m introduction, me and the company
5m RDS Aurora: advantages, features and our setup
5m Problem description, possible solution and PROXYSQL
15m Our solution: proxying all application traffic through proxysql. the format will be a live demo of cluster migration
5m Q&A
Total time: 32m

title: "Web Components"- Convince your team to use them and you will live a full agnostic life.
abstract: Whether you realize it or not, you are already using web components when you develop. Elements like forms, HTML tags, and more are all web components native to web browsers. Beyond these standard elements, you can also create custom web components to further simplify the process of building and maintaining web applications. I will explain how to make custom encapsulations, imports, templates, and built-in elements by using web component specifications.
outline:
Introduction: What are web components, why should we use them? 

HTML Templates - weâ€™ll see the how to use HTML templates to provide a standard way of declaring template markup. 

HTML imports - How to tell the browser to include a chunk of HTML code and make it reuse.

Custom Elements - Defining new HTML tags to reuse in our code and make our code more clear. 

Shadow DOM - a way to encapsulate style scripts and content inside out custom elements so they donâ€™t interfere with other elements in our web app.

title: â€œConcentration & Efficiency â€ - How will I be able to be more concentrated and efficient at work
abstract:
As software developers, we are required to sit long hours in front of a computer trying to solve difficult problems. This way of life requires us to go meetings, reading emails, writing emails, writing designs, writing code and read Slack messages every day and list is never-ending. 
So, how can we Concentrate more on the actual work with all this disturbance? There are a lot of different ways to achieve concentrations and efficiency at work. From modern day prescription drugs to meditation I will try to show you all the ways to be more concentrated and efficient.
outline:
Introduction: Do we really have a problem being more concentrated? Why should I be more concentrated and efficient at work or in my life?

 Drugs, give me drugs - exploring all the prescription medication options we have today and the pros and cons.

Sport - how sport affects our body and mind thus causing us to be more essential and vivid. 

Pomodoro - The Pomodoro Technique isn't like any other time-management method on the market today itâ€™s a tool that can really change the way you work. 

Mediation - how can 10 minutes of meditation change our whole day. 

Apps & blockers - Will blocking the internet will help me to be more concentrated? 

Time Management - once you manage all your time you will be able to do more and achieve more. 

Nutrition - You are what you eat. How to Increase productivity and efficiency with eating habits. 

Final note - do what feels right for you, there isnâ€™t one way to achieve this.

title: Developers as a Malware Distribution Vehicle
abstract:
In 2015, compromised developers unwittingly used a malicious XCode to inject malware into thousands of apps, stealing data of millions of users. In both 2014 and 2017, millions of Uber user and driver records were leaked following an improperly secured token commited to a GitHub repo. And in 2013, a phished developer was tricked to give the Syrian Electronic Army to the Financial Timesâ€™ site. 

What do all of these have in common? We, developers, caused them. 

In this talk, weâ€™ll better understand the damage we can cause, from distributing trojans to exposing user code. Weâ€™ll better understand the techniques attackers use to compromise us, so we can be prepared. Most importantly, weâ€™ll talk about how we can defend ourselves â€“ and our users.
outline:
â€¢ 2m Introduction
â€¢ 15m Details on XCodeGhost, "Reflections on trusting the trust", Malicious python, npm, ruby packages
â€¢ 3m the recent "eventstream" malicious package
â€¢ 5m Takeaways
â€¢ 5m Q&A

title: Interviewers be nice!
abstract:
Letâ€™s face it, recruitment is hard. We want only the best engineers to join our incredible team.

We, as interviewers, have a leading role in the recruitment process as we have to assess whether a candidate is a good fit for our team. We sometimes forget that we have significant impact on the interviewâ€™s atmosphere, which can greatly affect the candidateâ€™s performance.

This short lecture will pinpoint some of the things that you, as an interviewer, can do to make the interviewing process a lot nicer for candidates (and yourself). Ultimately, helping them be at their best and therefore, making the decision a lot easier.
outline:
30s About me 
1m Why being nice interviewers helps the cause
1m Take the time to show the candidate around the team/facility
30s Start the interview slowly, build confidence as you go
30s Make the questions a little more of a conversation 
30s Focus on what is important for the team and where the candidate needs to fit in
30s Share what the team is good at. Donâ€™t sugar coat everything, do tell some weaknesses, you are recruiting for a reason

title: Application Monitoring at Scale @ebay
abstract:
At ebay we operate at scale.
3-4PB of application logs per day, ~300K compute resources (BM, VM, containers), 1.5M system metrics per hour. This requires some consideration and planning into how to find the proverbial needle in the haystack.

This session describes some of the challenges we faced, how we tackled them and how we gained real value from application monitoring (in production and all other environments we have).
outline:
Agenda

* A Little bit about ebay, Structured Data - 2-3m
* Application Monitoring - brief overview - 5-6m
** Whatâ€™s Application Monitoring
 ** Reactive, Proactive, Predictive
* Challenge #1: Itâ€™s all about the KPIâ€™s, man! - 5-6m
** What are the KPIs to use?
** How to separate the wheat from the chaff? 
* Challenge #2: scale, Scale SCALE! - 10m
** 1st Attempt - Prometheus; Grafana; Kubernetes; etcd
** 2nd Attempt - InfluxDB, VMs
** 3rd Attempt - HAProxy, Promxy, NGINX
* Challenge #3: Business Metrics: Introducing P365 - 5-6m
** Data Retention
** Business Metrics Galore
Total time: 30m

title: Do we really need to go to the office?
abstract:
1.5 year ago I decided I want to choose when I want to work and where I want to work from. So I found a remote job and bought a one way ticket. 
At this talk I'm going to share my experience of how I did it, what are the benefits and the difficulties in working remotely, how to work with a remote team and is that the right thing for you.
outline:
15s - About me
30s - who can work remotely
2m - Why working remotely
1m - Working remotely challenges
45s - Tools for a company with remote employees
30s - How to find a remote job

title: Managing Edge Computing for Retail with Serverless
abstract: Yaron Haviv will present a Kubernetes-based cloud-to-edge solution for retail analytics, which analyzes data from hundreds of sensors and external sources in real-time using serverless functions. He will introduce the Intelligent Edge concept, which includes a variety of data services, managed Kubernetes, AI and serverless functions, all controlled and monitored from the cloud. Developers in the audience will learn how serverless works for large edge volumes and how to leverage the edge as a real-time extension of the cloud to run real-time AI solutions such as image recognition and predictive analytics.
outline:
2m Introduction: Who I am and my professional background
3m Introudction to Edge Computing: The need for portability between the cloud and the edge
5m Servelress at the edge: How serverless accelerates management and performance at the edge
3m Demo: Retail demo showing a cloud-to-edge solution 
2m Q&A

title: What color do you want your Blockchain? Introduction to Blockchain for business & Hyperledger Fabric
abstract:
Hyperledger Fabric is a blockchain framework implementation and one of the Hyperledger projects hosted by The Linux Foundation.
In this talk you will learn about Hyperledger Fabric components, such as endorsing peers , ordering nodes , committing peers ,  consensus , membership services, smart contracts called â€œchaincodeâ€ and more. I will also describe how to build your first Blockchain app using a "code pattern"  : creating an asset-transfer app that enables you to transfer marbles between multiple owners
outline:
5m introduction to Blockchain
20m Hyperledger fabric  components : endorsing peers , ordering nodes , committing peers ,  consensus , membership services, smart contracts called â€œchaincodeâ€
2m "code pattern"  : creating an asset-transfer app that enables you to transfer marbles between multiple owners
3m Q&A

title: The End of Silos
abstract: Data scientists are adopting modern frameworks like Jupyter, TensorFlow and Dask, while data engineers mostly use legacy tools comprised of traditional databases, BI, data warehousing and Hadoop-powered data lakes. Can we really keep going with two different silos and disciplines? GPUs are widely used to accelerate machine learning, while new libraries like NVIDIA RAPIDS make it possible to process data frames in the CPU and accelerate packages like Pandas and Scikit Learn. However, processing data with multiple servers, or larger datasets is more challenging. In this session, we will demonstrate how to automate the deployment of big data tools side by side with a modern data science stack and GPUs. This solution means multiple jobs and interactive notebooks now run over the same cluster.
outline:
2m Introduction: Who I am and my professional background
5m The Architecture Today: Overview of today's siloed architecture and common tools
3m How it effects the entire data science life-cycle in terms of efficiency
15m The solution: Multiple jobs and interactive notebook running on a single cluster
5m Q&A

title: Present, not future: Data science is completely changing how digital products interact with humans
abstract:
Digital products around us suffer from lack of personalization and low retention rates. Users are bombarded with messages and promotions all day, with very few of them actually relevant to our needs and state of mind. 
Creating a truly personalized human-centric products sounds a thing from science-fiction movies, but in fact -it's not. Current technology, AI and data science allow us to create products that actually understand the human behind the user and adapt their service to best fit his needs. At Neura, we work with companies who are making this leap into human-centric, not user-centric, products.  
I will present the personalization challenge for every digital marketer and product owner today, and showcase not only the solution, but how it is implemented in real life.
outline:
â€¢ 3m - Introduction: Who am I and my professional background - a personal AI-related story, which caused me to create 'Neura' 

â€¢ 5m - past simple: how digital product are all basically 'stupid' (or just very plain), which causes us to be constantly dissatisfied.   

â€¢ 5m - The reason: no awareness level. digital product do not understand human and are based on web data. This causes very low retention rates.

â€¢ 10m - present progressive (or:The solution): using smartphone sensors to help products become human-cnetric. Using AI to understand human traits and behavior. turning AI into an integral part of analytics to create products and services that know who the user is and what he does throughout the day. Using at least one case study. 

â€¢ 2m - future perfect: how digital products and services will behave in the near future. Those who don't will be left behind. 

â€¢ 5m Q&A

Total time: 30m

title: Towards Explainable Machine Learning
abstract:
At Firefly.ai we use autoML to build models for users from various industries. These models can achieve high scores, but this usually comes at the price of complex models that are hard to interpret. Understanding how our models make their predictions is important for quality control, revealing patterns in the data, etc.

Interpretability of ML models is a relatively new field that is researched through a variety of aspects. In this session I will review how we applied techniques such as sensitivity analysis, PDP & ICE, and LIME for explaining the predictions of generic, black-box models at Firefly.ai. Using two real-world use cases from the banking and real-estate industries, I will describe the pros and cons of each method, differences between the methods, and production considerations.
outline:
3m: Introduce myself and my work
5m: Machine learning overview: explain the need to understand ML models, the difficulty to understand complex ML models, and describe the types of interpretability.
6m: Review sensitivity analysis with real word use case.
6m: review PDP & ICE with real word use cases. Describe the advantages and disadvantages over sensitivity analysis.
5m: Review LIME- local explainabiliy approach. 
5m: Q&A
Total time: 30m

title: Serverless Best Practices and Code Patterns
abstract: The promise of serverless plays out mostly at both high scale and bursty workloads. In this session we will present the promising OpenWhisk (Function As A Service Open Source) internals, discuss useful design patterns and demonstrate some code patterns, ready to use to help you jump start your journey with Cloud functions
outline:
â€¢ 2 min Introduction: Who am I and my professional background
â€¢ 5 min Architectural overview: OpenWhisk internal ant why it is built for scale
â€¢ 8 min OpenWhisk Architectural Patterns
â€¢ 10 min OpenWhisk Code Patterns
â€¢ 5 min Q&A
Total: 30 min

title: Tick Tock on the Clock - Hope the Data Don't Stop
abstract:
This is a story of a race against time!  So hang on to your seats...

During a customer migration to a new attribution system, a huge project for AppsFlyer Engineering in 2018, we found ourselves facing a potential data loss catastrophe.  It all started with the primal sin of a premature optimization made where we set the incorrect data retention timeframe for a database holding 65 billion records.

When we discovered this, with only one week to respond before the data is permanently erased, we channeled our Macgyver skills and got to work. During this session I'll describe the chain of events that brought us to the cliff's edge, the steps we took around the clock to save our data, and how we managed to forestall any data loss for our clients.
outline:
2m - intro: who am I, and what AppsFlyer does
2m - describe the project at hand - migrating all 40 Billion events per day to go through new flow / code
3m - oh shit moment  - how we found we are going to lose data + what we did wrong
5m - war mode - what we did in the time left to save the data
3m  - post-mortem conclusions - what did we learn  + what did we change for the future

title: 5 concepts I took from Data Science to Team Leading
abstract:
Data science and machine learning have become very popular recently and some of the â€œmagical black-boxâ€ methods such as deep-learning became common buzz-words in tech industry slang. However, while moving from data science towards leading people, you suddenly realize that there are things that you cannot apply directly from online courses. To make this transition smoother, I propose to â€œtransfer learnâ€ machine learning jargon to management.
In this talk Iâ€™ll share a few machine learning concepts that can help you understand team behavior better and explain how to deal with the â€œdropoutâ€ of your team members and avoid â€œoverfittingâ€ your approach to team leadership.
outline:
It's a short and humanistic session of transferring heavy machine-learning subjects to people leadership.

The topics I'm going to cover are:
-Non-Linear Activation
Invested effort is not translated into linear returns, but follows sigmoids
-Dropout
Missing some of the team members contributes to team robustness. Fully connected layers are stronger now.
-Back-Propagation
We learn a lot from mistakes, especially when we are their key contributors. We tend to underestimate learnings that are done by others.
-Overfitting
Developing a method its nice, but be careful about using same approach to all team members (best-recipe)
-Pooling
Sometimes to analyze the picture youâ€™ll need to deep-dive into edge cases (min/max pooling) and avoid looking at the average.

title: â€œMicro Frontendsâ€- You Keep Using That Word, I Donâ€™t Think It Means What You Think It Means
abstract:
"Micro Frontends" is the new buzzword in the Frontend world, but too many times people use it in the wrong context or with different things in mind.
Micro Frontends can refer to different kinds of solutions that solve different types of problems - starting from using different UI frameworks on the same app or letting different teams work on separate parts of the code independently.
In this session, we'll go over the different problems we have when building a big app and how different micro-frontends solutions can help with this.
outline:
- Introduction: what are the challenges we're facing when a system reaches a certain size (in lines of code, in complexity or number of contributors)
- Web uniqueness- we'll go deeper into specific things that are unique for web apps and why we can't just steal solutions from other domains (like micro-services).
- Our story- our team in WeWork is building an app that has been growing exponentially, and it's getting harder to manage it. We also wanted a way to dynamically turn on and off specific modules in the app (like all the features related to billing, or things related to sales). Breaking the monolith was necessary.
- There are many options- there are many ways to break your web app; some of them are generics, and some of them are framework specific.
- But before you choose a solution, know what you want to solve- don't try to solve ALL THE THINGS. For example, we know we don't need to support different frameworks since we are all working on React.
- Choose the right solution for your needs- as said, there are many options out there: starting from arranging your code in some way, or using some tools like Lerna or Yarn Workspaces, or going all in and using a complete system that supports this, like Single-SPA or Web Components (or many things in between).
- Tips to choose the right solution- the process we did and what helped us with the unknowns.

title: Not everyone is a manager, and that's ok.
abstract:
Where do engineers go when the management path is not an option? Do I have to manage people in order to move forward with my career? And if I don't like that, should I quit and start from scratch? 
Don't worry - there is an alternative, and it's called being an "individual contributor."
In this session, Iâ€™ll describe what the Individual Contributor (IC) path is, what are the steps to become a good IC, and offer some tools and tips to become one.
outline:
- Introduction: I'm Shem, and I'm a Staff Engineer at WeWork. In this session, I want to share my journey and I how became a Staff Engineer and what I learned along the way and hopefully save other some pains that I had.
- Personal story: I was promoted to a manager position a couple of years ago. I thought this was the only way that I, as an engineer, could advance in the organization. The problem is that I didn't like that and I was pretty bad at this.
- I was frustrated and looked for alternatives.
- So I joined a new company with a great title- â€œsenior engineerâ€ in something called IC path - problem solved!
- Not really. Now I was on the right path but couldn't figure out what to do there, since this is not very common track and I didn't have a lot of role models.
- Slowly I started reaching out to other ICs and managers, I read all kind of blogs and tried to understand what should I do and where I could make an impact.
- This track is still not 100% perfect or clear, but now new senior engineers have much more clarity, and I have much more context about what I should do.

This talk is based on  blog posts I published:
https://engineering.wework.com/not-everyone-is-a-manager-4fe01a329ed1
https://medium.com/@shemag8/so-you-are-a-senior-engineer-now-what-35ee2116f635

title: Multiplayer Pac-Man with RSocket
abstract: One of the challenging aspects of building modern games is making it multiplayer. Can we use HTTP there? We can, but we will not get a real-time game. Can we use WebSockets / TCP? Of course, we can and we should! However, developing API on top of WebSocket is another challenge that no one wants to solve, but everyone does. Existing libraries do not give us a required variety of communication models. Today we will show you the way to tackle this - using RSocket. RSocket is an application protocol that makes developing any networked application as easy as pie. To prove that, we are going to build a multiplayer Pac-Man, and during the process compare different ways of making a multiplayer game.
outline:
- 2m Introduction: Who am I and my professional background
- 5m application definition with analyzing of types of network communication in our app
- 5m-7m HTTP impl overview with definition advantages/disadvantages of building app using that protocol
- 5m-7m WebSocket and subsequent libs overview with definition advantages/disadvantages of building app using that protocol
- 5m-7m Grpc and Grpc-Web overview with definition advantages/disadvantages of building app using that protocol
- 10m intro to RSocket and overview with definition advantages/disadvantages of building app using that protocol
- 1m summary 

(existing slides - https://www.icloud.com/keynote/0FkW4FagDTsmpjyawtkAnwAKg#Multiplayer_PacMan_With_RSocket)

title: A glimpse into a Data Scientistâ€™s work - implementing algorithms from research papers
abstract:
The field of Data Science is currently on fire. Many people want to work on something related to it. But what does it mean to be working in this field? I am going to show you a part of my daily work as a Machine Learning researcher. Specifically, how do you approach a research paper and implement the described algorithm? 
In this talk, I will share practical tips and advice I collected during my years in academia and the industry. I will present examples how they can be applied on deep learning algorithms.
outline:
â€¢ 45sec Introduction: Who am I and my professional background
â€¢ 15sec Describing the example that will accompany all tips
â€¢ 3.5m Tips for algorithm implementation, including examples
â€¢ 30sec Summary and recap of take-home message

title: Turning Art Into Practical Web Designâ€Šâ€”â€ŠFrontend art meets commercial UX
abstract: UI interactions are about to significantly change for the better, and this time it'll be driven by Frontend engineers.  For several years, web interactions had a very little innovation, mostly due to designers not having code skills that provide exploration flexibility. On the other hand, Frontend scene is flourishing with stunning interaction projects that playfully engage users. The problem is that those projects are usually applied as backgrounds or out-of-context activities, without any direct impact on conversion. We'll discuss the mindset switch for bridging the gap between the interactive art and practical web design, with some open source examples we made.
outline:
- 1min Intro
- 1min Overview
- 2min Examples
- 1min Our suggestion

title: How to unit test with a complex legacy system
abstract:
There is a best practice of writing unit tests during the development. Some experienced developers say that developing and writing unit tests together is faster than to develop without writing unit tests. When we tried to adopt this method of writing unit tests, we found that it costs more time with no benefit: The tests never failed due to a real bug. 

In this talk, I will present when unit testing gets wrong and why. I will describe what method we used to write unit tests with a positive outcome, how it relates to DDD and clean architecture and how to apply it to systems with legacy code. By the end of the talk, you will have the strategy for unit testing against the living products that seek to continue growing, even though they are all built of complex legacy code.
outline:
3m Introduction: Who am I and my professional background
5m How unit tests get wrong when coupled to concrete implementation - example from our company
3m Refactoring
5m Clean architecture, DDD and DIP principle for the ideal unit tests.
5m Deep dive into unit tests meaning
3m The process of unit testing and growing with legacy systems
4m Summary
3m Q&A

title: Reactive: How and Why?
abstract: Reactive, what an overloaded word. Many things turn out to become magically Reactive these days. But what does it mean? Reactive is not a new term but recently used in many domains. In this talk, I will present from my experience and research, what is it all about? and: how does it solve traditional error-prone programming?
outline:
1m What does "Reactive" mean
1m The traditional implementations and their drawbacks
1m How "Functional Programming" is better
1m "Reactive" with the help of "Functional Programming"
1m Reactive Streams

title: All (reasonable) Roads Lead to Functional Programming
abstract:
It is not uncommon to hear about how elegant Functional Programming is. Granted, some notions of beauty do have their place in the world of software development, but that alone is not a sufficiently compelling reason to endeavour into the unknown.

In this talk, I will describe my (somewhat idealized) journey from the world of imperative, Java-style programming down the never-ending path of Functional Programming. We will be motivated by simple and relatable concerns, such as: the wish to have less bugs, to write simpler tests and to have altogether more predictable software. This will almost inevitably lead us to re-discover and embrace Functional techniques and the benefits that follow.
outline:
- Intro: my background as an imperative/Java programmer (2m)
- Motivation: what is Functional Programming and why should we care (5m)
- The problems: outline various concerns that are relevant in the process of software development, such as bugs, testability and the ability to reason about the code (5m)
- The path to Functional Programming: show how the concerns above lead to techniques from Functional Programming, such immutable data, the use of pure functions and higher-order abstractions (15m)

title: React Native - Under The Bridge
abstract:
Even if you are familiar with React Native, do you really know how it works?
Did you know about the bridge which is the secret sauce of React Native and makes it work on every platform and gives you the option to create a Native-Like apps?
In my talk,I am going to reveal that there is no magic in React Native.
There is a real smart mechanism that lets the JS code communicate with the Native code.
A major part of this mechanism is The Bridge which is written in C++ (wait..what??) and mapping between all you app modules and even lets you create custom ones of your own! 
In Addition I will talk about its new architecture.
If you are a curious React developer who believes that knowing the internals of a library makes you a better developer, join me to the journey Under The Bridge.
outline:
- 1m Introduction : Who am I and my professional background
- 5m The structure of the bridge, oh no..C++ again??
- 2m Bi directional communication between JS and Native code
- 5m The magic behind it - from building the app until it is open and ready
Differences between iOS and Android
- 3m Short Peeking to other frameworks - flutter and native script
- 4m The future - React-360, React-TV, and React-Hardware. Learn Once, Write Anywhere
- 3m Bonus : JSI - the future architecture of The Bridge

title: Lesson-Learned from Startups: How Scaling-Oriented Thinking Can Drive Better Products
abstract: Scaling is one of the biggest challenges in todayâ€™s startup world. We can never think ahead about all the features, the scale and the challenges that the success of our products, and the growing user base can bring along with it. In this talk, Iâ€™ll show case some of the challenges I had to overcome, and suggest a new mindset of building scale-oriented products. Why is it so hard to scale from 5 users to 100 users, or to scale from SMBs (small/medium businesses) to enterprise customers? In this talk, Iâ€™ll try to convey the mindset and tools to help with this massive change.
outline:
Outline: 
- 5m The challenges: Why is it so hard to scale from 5 users to 100 users, or to scale from SMBs (small/medium businesses) to enterprise customers
- 10m The Mindset: How to speak to your PM or CEO about scale? Not all Product Managers care about the architecture. However, they do care about the business value. They might not care if you use a Docker or a Monolith, but if thereâ€™s an outage every Friday night, they do care about it. When speaking to your PM or CEO, try to focus on business value. 
- 5m Q&A
Total time: 25m



Notes:
When I just started in WhiteSource, it was a lot different than other organizations I used to work for in the past. Every decision and mostly implementation of new feature took a lot of time. 
This had one main reason: The customer based grew rapidly. WhiteSource exists for more than 7 years now, but over the last year, it multiplied its number of customers. In addition to the number of customers, their size changed. From small Startups, mostly in Israel, we started to work with fortune 500 companies: from SAP to IBM to Oracle, and these are to name just a few. Since the system was growing so fast, there was never enough time to think thoroughly about the decisions that were made. This goes from engineering and architectural decisions, but mainly in the product area. 

Why is it important for Product Manager and CEOs to understand the scaling challenge?
How do I convince my CEO/PM that these things are important. Product Managers donâ€™t care about your architecture. However, they do care about the business value. They might not care if you use a Docker or a Monolith, but if thereâ€™s an outage every Friday night, they do care about it. When speaking to your PM or CEO, try to focus on business value. 

When working for fast-growing organizations, thereâ€™s always a tradeoff. If we take too much time thinking about each feature, interviewing hundreds of customers, we will never get to a point where we actually make the decision. However, often we focus on the first problem, and choose the best solution. 

Selling your product to customers is (sometimes) easy. The real challenge is the ongoing delivery, inventing the product each time and the long term relationship with our customers.

title: Want a performing R&D team? Build them like a rock band
abstract:
Hi, Iâ€™m Tsaela, Iâ€™m the lead singer in a rock band, and Iâ€™ve been developing code and managing teams for the past ten years. 
It never never ceases to amaze me how much the two loves of my life have in common. 
Albert Einstein once said that â€œThe greatest scientists are artists as well.â€ Great developers can be compared to other kinds of artists who join together to bring their visions to life.
Talented musicians share many of the traits that we look for in good coders. They are detail oriented and notorious perfectionists. Theyâ€™re at their best when theyâ€™re analytical, logical, and methodical. Sound familiar? Thatâ€™s probably because those are the same traits that our best developers have.

In this session Iâ€™ll share my experience of building an R&D team to perform like a rock band.
outline:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QMvLdoMvdn4
0.5m Introduction: Who am I and my professional and musical background
4 m practical principles and tips of how to help Your Software Development Team Make Beautiful Music Together:
 
Independence: A Good Band is a Self Sufficient Band
Heterogeneity: Variety is the Spice of Life â€” and of Software Development
Keep it Simple
Listen
Build a Strong Foundation
Mind Your Deadlines
Keep Calm and Have a Beer

0.5 m: Summary - Having musical aspects in our life will make us better developers. If programmers are like musicians, one way to make sure that they give their best performance is by following the same principles that let a rock band fill a stadium

title: Creative hiring in startups - interns & contractors
abstract:
Early stage startups may find it hard to to hire developers.  They lack the money for a decent salary, they sometimes need to build the very basic foundations of their code base, and the technical co-founder may end up doing tons of other stuff that are not development-specific tasks.
My short talk will share my experience as a co-founder struggling to build a product with very limited resources. I will discuss more creative solutions like hiring interns (where to find them, how, what to expect) and using remote developers as contractors
outline:
00:30m about me
2:00m the problem - early stage startups wants to build a product without real funding
2:30m  the solution - hiring interns and contractors: Where? How? The Recruiting Process. What to expect? Tips.

title: What if you don't trust your cloud provider? (Seriously, you shouldn't)
abstract:
You want to move your application to the cloud - It's cheaper, more resilient and it scales better.
But how can you trust the cloud vendor with your application?
What about your private keys? Your users' data? Will your application code be maliciously modified?
What if you chose the most trustworthy cloud vendor and now it's required by a court order to breach this trust??

This talk explains how Intel's SGX technology can be used to build trusted cloud applications.
We will describe the infrastructure we have built and how it has allowed us to transform an existing application into a trusted one in a short, painless manner.
outline:
5m - The problem - why cloud vendors cannot be trusted?
10m - Intel SGX - what it is and how it works.
10m - Our framework - how it overcomes SGX limitations to help us achieve a smooth migration.
2m - Demo  
5m - Q&A

Total - 32 minutes

title: On demand testing environments
abstract:
In the last few years, it became common practice for developers to have an end to end ownership on their features / services.
New tools and frameworks are required for enabling developers to develop, test, deploy, monitor their features, while keeping the development speed as is.
Our R&D at taboola has more than 250 developers. They constantly push code and want to deploy their services to production. When I arrived to taboola, 2 years ago, one of the first things I noticed is how hard it was to test your service. It requires a new solution that would be dynamic, fast, UX friendly and easy to maintain.
In this talk I will present the on demand testing environment concept we built at taboola. with this framework, any developer can start a private environment for him to test in minutes.
outline:
Definition and motivation
What is a testing environment and why do we need it?
In large R&D groups with complex architecture, itâ€™s hard for a developer to run a full or even a partial environment on his laptop. For example, we have a service that required multiple DBs from different kinds + 2 other taboolaâ€™s services. Each one of those components take a respectful size of resources. Starting it on your laptop might be possible, but it would work slow and you wonâ€™t be able to do much with it. A test environments allows you to build private testing environment of different kinds, depends on your requirements. With those environments you can:  

Test your service manually
Test your service automatically
Use it for tutorials & hands-on
Use it for demos

I will describe the use cases of a testing environment 

Our solution
As taboolaâ€™s R&D grew dramatically, we required to have better tools for testing. The first thing I did was analyzing the developers requirements. I met with several developers from different groups, figured which are the most used services, what are the common cases that solving them would allow to break the bottleneck we had.
Next, we built the solution. The idea was using a Jenkins job, where the developer choose his environment type and the job creates it for him. Behind the scene, there is a Jenkins groovy code that calculates the total required services (the asked services and their dependencies), and creates a nomad hcl file. Then nomad runs the job, creating docker containers on its different nodes, and Jenkins returns the environment details to the developer.
In the automation use case, we create an environment with multiple instances of the same service, so we can scale the tests and run them much faster. The improvement in times was drastic.

Issues
As every new system we had some issues and we learned some important lessons:
The nomad cluster was not managed as a production service and that was wrong
Docker storage driver caused a lot of issues at the beginning and we had to change it 
Scaling the automation tests didnâ€™t work on the first runs, containers crashed and we had to tune their resources to make it work

Future
what improvements and changes we plan to do?
As a of our production services move to k8s, we plan to move that cluster as well.
While using the environments, developers asked for new features, bug fixed , etc. we also plan to do those
Make it a self service - today when a developer wants to make the environments support a new service, he needs to talk to the release engineering team. In the future we plan to make it a self service, the developer would need to do a simple action like filling a short form or commit a file, and his new service would be supported.
Total time: 30 minutes

title: How to face your fears and improve as an engineer
abstract:
Ever thought about presenting your work to others? Talking in a meetup or a conference? 
In the past I couldnâ€™t even think about it, I thought that itâ€™s not for me and I wonâ€™t get any benefit from it at all. In the last year and a half, things have started to change.
I was always curious and looking for ways to improve as an engineer, so I did what most of us do: read tutorials, posts and watch technical videos. Still, since I came from a different background from most engineers, I felt like I had a knowledge gap that blocked me in many ways.
The journey that I will describe in this talk will show how I improved my technical and soft skills by helping others in platforms like stackoverflow, writing blog posts and talking in meetups.
outline:
the will to improve and how it's related to talking to people
In this section I will give some background about myself, where I started (QA) and where am I today (Release engineering / DevOps). I will talk about my curiosity and how it pushed me on finding ways to learn and improve. Then iâ€™ll connect it to helping / tutoring others.
Getting my toes wet
This is basically is where and how I started. The first step was opening a stackoverflow account, read and then answer questions. Answering questions is a great place for an engineer to improve, since it makes you to get into details in your answer.

Giving into the lecturing world
In this section Iâ€™ll talk about twitter, conferences and meetups. This combination of meeting new people, listening to talks and following some tech leaders let me understand that by talking I can Improve myself much more. Iâ€™ll tell about my first 3 talks, how I got to do them, how did I prepare, and how it improved me as an engineer. 

The journey continues
In the closing sections I will discuss about:
what I plan to do next (talk on a main stage)
The opportunities we have to improve as we gain more experience
 the comfort zone and how we can change it 
Summarize the benefits of public speaking

title: A successful hire can be measured only after 6 months -  the importance of onboarding new employees
abstract:
Two years ago I quit my job. 
Thatâ€™s not really unique, is it? What makes it unusual is that I took this decision less than 6 months after I started. As a veteran R&D manager I know how many efforts are spent on talent acquisition. So I started on a self retrospective move to investigate why did I choose to leave so fast. What went wrong with me? 

A month later I started another job. This time I was very aware to what is happening with me as a new employee. I could compare the two onboarding experiences. The lessons I've learned surprised me so much. 

In this session, I shed some light on the psychology of a new employee and give practical ways to deal with it. Weâ€™ll See through a new employeeâ€™s eyes and understand what the ingredients are that can turn onboarding into a success.
outline:
- 3m: Opening (personal story of starting 2 jobs in one year)
- 2m: The problem/need: linked-in shows 31% leave in first 6 months. 
- 3m: What goes through new employeeâ€™s mind - the mental pendulum
- 3m: Training vs onborading. 
- 5m: The time frame and predicted events
- 5m: The perfect onboarding process: addressing the mental need right on time
- 5m: Onboarding plan I tailored as a lesson (Taboola's "Rookie program")
Total time ~25m

title: You are about to be a manager. Congrats! Doâ€™s and Dontâ€™s - tips that will help you to start right.
abstract:
One of the first things you find out when you turn to be a manager is that your success is no longer in your hands. You rely on the people you lead. 

People are awesome and delicate creatures. Especially engineersâ€¦ Each one of us is unique but we all have common things we like and dislike. 
Extracting 23 years of R&D leadership into 5 minutes sounds like a crazy task. But at the end of this lightning talk you will get tips that will help you pass your transition to leadership successfully and I will probably need to wipe my sweat :)
outline:
- Who am I and where I bring my experience from
- Few tips (one/two slides per tip, as time allows.). Blend dos and donts.
- One slider summary

title: A strategy for building application suites
abstract:
Your company grows and its business portfolio becomes richer. Multiple views are usually then split to different independent teams and each serve a different business functionality.
Enterprise-grade software development will require that all of these applications will have a **common product backbone**: unified look-and-feel, single-sign on, shared entity management, access control, common services and so on. 

Engineering organizations struggle to determine the right amount of decoupling, reuse, and interoperability needed to excel through this growth. 

In this talk I will cover different approaches for building application suites and state pros and cons for each proposed strategy.
outline:
- (2m) About myself (math at uni -> software development -> FED -> TL -> architect -> group leader -> product manager -> VP rnd -> sales(!) ) 
- (4m) Problem definition and how common it is
- (2m) The similarities/differences to micro-services architecture 
- (1m) "What's in it for me" (what the audience will learn here) 
- (5m) examples of real application suites that we all use 
- (7m) the ideal application suite and how challenging it is to develop/specify/operate 
- (10m) Building a suite in 5 stages
- (2m) how this currently works for us
- (2m) The "small words" - things to look out for given your taking this path 

Total: 35 minutes

I will be happy to work with you to crystallize the message and expand/reduce on specific chapters

title: Becoming a Data Scientist without getting stuck in local minima
abstract: Machine learning is the new black, and it seems that everybody wants to be a data scientist. But to be a great Data Scientist you need to be a good mathematician, a curious analyst, a smart computer engineer, an expert in the problem's domain, and a charming person overall. Furthermore, with the field  moving so fast, you have to run at full speed just to stay in place. In this talk, I'll discuss the top mistakes people make in their early days as data scientists and give tips for a smooth and successful transition.
outline: This is a proposal for a lightning talk. Among the things I'll discuss are ignoring the "Data" in Data Science; ignoring the "Science" in Data Science; optimizing the wrong loss function; getting stuck in a local minimum; using too many layers and more. The talk is intended to be a bit informal and funny (to the best of my limited powers).

title: Engineering Diversity: Why diversifying your R&D team is easier than you think
abstract:
Diversity is more than just a buzz wordâ€“ itâ€™s a proven way to generate innovation, increase productivity, and meet business goals. However, as the talent demand continues to grow for hi-tech R&D teams, the massive gender gap among them still remains. Currently, women only make up 23% of Israelâ€™s tech professionals and only 16% of its tech management. 

So...why should you care? 

Tapping into the knowledge our team at Joonko has gained over the last few years, this session will prove that diversifying your staff does not have to be as hard you think. In fact, diversifying your R&D team can lead to a big ROI. Learn how to uncover the hidden biases that are holding your team back and build a more inclusive, innovative workforce.
outline:
â€¢ 2m Introduction: Who am I and my professional background
â€¢ 3m Overview: Why diversity is important? The stats, and impact of diversity in tech and R&D.
â€¢ 2m Unconscious bias. You prevent yourself and your company from having diversity.
â€¢ 3m Why R&D and not HR: The role of R&D and the responsibility of its leaders, and why they have a better starting point than HR.
â€¢ 15m The doâ€™s and donâ€™ts: Easy steps to have tomorrow morning.
â€¢ 5m Changing your approach: the perception of diversity - is it a problem, goal or a means to an end?
â€¢ 5m Q&A
Total time: 35m

title: Watching birds and writing algorithms
abstract:
YOU CAN NEVER KNOW WHERE YOUR NEXT GREAT IDEA COMES FROM!

We were struggling with a big challenge and after evaluating a variety of approaches it felt like a dead end.
And then we found the answer! It was at the 2017 Reversim summit following a session about a thirty years old algorithm mimicking a flock of birds. It was an aha moment for us - taking us to an almost two years path of solving the challenge by applying biomimicking algorithms.

I will present the concept of biomimicry and treating biological processes as algorithms nature has created.
I will also take you through a specific use case and demonstrate how treating job postings as a flock of birds can optimize budget spend!

By the end of the session, I hope you have a different perspective on both nature and machine learning.
outline:
3m - A personal introduction
7m -The concept of biomimicry with some cool examples from the engineering world.
5m - A specific use case - presenting the challenge we were facing.
8m - Presenting the "flock" algorithm -  treating job postings as a flock of birds to 
          optimize budget spend.
5m Q&A
Total - 28 minutes

title: 3D Printing: Support Needed!
abstract:
Looking at an everyday 3D printer - the printing procedure looks quite natural and straightforward. However, like traditional construction techniques things are not so simple. Indeed, just as scaffolding is extensively used in many building techniques, similar physical support is needed during the 3d printing process; different 3D technologies use distinct scaffolding methods. 
In this talk, after introducing the 3D printing ecosystem in general and the celebrated polyjet(â„¢)  technology in particular will describe the intrinsic difficulties of supporting the polyjet printing process, and hopefully demonstrate bone-fide algorithmic solutions to these problems.
outline:
Introduction: Who are we and why are we here (3 mins) 
Polyjet Printing in a jiffy (+ neat examples) (5 mins) 
The big Polyjet Support issue, and how is it attacked (12 minutes) 
A shallow dive into the algorithms (5 mins) 
Any questions? (5 mins)

title: Agile Data Science
abstract:
Bringing an idea from a poc to production is one of the main challenges data scientists struggle with today. 
While thereâ€™s yet no consensus solution for this, recently more and more leading companies began building data science infrastructures. These are designed to support the cycle of research, deploy, retrain and monitor.
My team at Check Point is currently focusing on building such infrastructure for company-wise use, while keeping in mind various use-cases, different data types and separate production environments.
In this talk, Iâ€™ll share our work done in this area, and our future vision for this infrastructure, and how we tend to build it.
outline:
* 5 minutes Intro: Who I am and presentation of the problem.
* 10 minutes Serving productization: choosing a metric, defining result API, model evaluation, dockerized serving solution, logs and monitored dashboards.  
* 10 minutes Training productization: managing experiments, evaluating and comparing them, data store & data pipeline approaches, and deploying the chosen one to production
* 5 minutes future vision: our vision for future development and other data science cycle tools and infrastructures.

title: How to Gratify the Dragonfly, a Talk About Latency
abstract: 300 million years of evolution have turned the dragonfly into the perfect predator. With unmatched maneuverability, super fast eyesight and unparalleled response time, this small insect can catch his prey before we even notice what has happened. But will a dragonfly will be satisfied by todayâ€™s web applications latency? In this talk, we will take a thought exercise and try to understand which changes need to be done in our technology stack to make dragonflies happy.  Along the way we will delve into the ingredients that build up latency.
outline:
* Intro [1  minute]
* The Dragonfly - features response time and vision capabilities.(The dragonfly response time is 30 ms opposed to 250ms of a human beings. A dragonfly sees in 300fps opposed to 60 fps of human beings)  [3 minutes]
* Latency definition. The latency histogram and why it is important. [5 minutes]
* What builds up latency on a single server  [5 minutes]
  ** Garbage collection (describe latencies) : Example Good: C4,ZGC Bad: G1,CMS
  **Slow IO devices Magnetic disks / SSD /Memory Caching good 
  ** Batching 
  ** Queueing theory latency under high throughput
* Latency composition(â„¢) : What builds up latency when more than one server is involved. 
  ** Network hops. (TCP/ SSL) 
  ** Failure detection and waiting for timeouts  (TCP timeout is 3 seconds)
  **Coordination and double dispatch  [5 minutes]

title: â€œShow Me the Garbage!â€, Understanding Garbage Collection
abstract: â€œJust leave the garbage outside and we will take care of it for youâ€. This is the panacea promised by garbage collection mechanisms built into most software stacks available today. So, we donâ€™t need to think about it anymore, right? Wrong! When misused, garbage collectors can fail miserably. When this happens they slow down your application and lead to unacceptable pauses. In this talk we will go over different garbage collectors approaches in different software runtimes and what are the conditions which enable them to function well.
outline:
* Intro [1 minute]
* What are the problems GC is solving [2 minutes]
* GC terminology [10 minutes] 
  ** Mutators, collectors,
  ** Concurrent and parallel collectors 
  ** Precise vs. conservative GCs   
  ** Memory Fragmentation 
  ** Memory locality.
  ** GC Overhead 
  ** Max pause time
* Building blocks  [7 minutes]
  ** The weak generational hypothesis and generational collectors 
  ** Mark, Sweep and Compaction 
* Approaches taken by different runtimes JVM/.NET, GO , RUBY, JS [7 minutes] 
* Solving GC problems   [6 minutes]
  ** Computational overhead and application throughput and  how to improve it 
  ** Pauses: small ones, big ones and how to avoid them 
  ** Fragmentation
  ** Collectors vs mutators race. 
 
* The future :  Pauseless collectors 2 minutes

title: Data pipelines using Spark Streaming
abstract:
We will present our journey from batch-based to real-time analytics.  We implemented a data-pipeline lambda architecture using Spark Streaming for real-time analytics. We will introduce the main components of this architecture and  will overview its different use-cases. 
The first use-case is to build and run real-time predictive analytics using Contextual Multi-Armed Bandit models for UI optimisation.  The second use case is to do CTR (click through rate) estimation based on real-time data using weighted linear regression models. 

In the end of the session, you will learn how to use Spark to combine real-time and batch analytics, and become more familiar with Spark's capabilities.
outline:
2m Introduction
3m current batch pipeline
5m Architecture overview - data pipeline, batch, streaming,...
10m Solution - Spark as a platform, Spark Structured Streaming, ... 
10m use cases  - contextual models and CTR predictions

title: Beyond Word Embeddings
abstract: Since the advent of word2vec, word embeddings have become a go-to method for encapsulating distributional semantics in NLP applications. This presentation will review the strengths and weaknesses of using pre-trained word embeddings, and demonstrate how to incorporate more complex semantic representation schemes such as Semantic Role Labeling, Abstract Meaning Representation and Semantic Dependency Parsing into your applications.
outline:
-2m introduction
- 10 min overview of state of the art nlp
- 15 min on the future of nlp
- 5 min q&a
37min

title: Umm, Scratch That: A Tale of Big Data Architecture Rewrite
abstract:
It was late 2017 when we realised that we have to ask our biggest client to stop sending us clickstream events. 

We knew something had to change, but we never imagined it would be a full rewrite with a brand new architecture. 

Do you have a component that is reaching the boundaries of its ability to scale? So did we! Join me for a tale of how we moved from batch to stream processing, how we went from unstable to solid and scalable technologies, how we reduced latency and increased throughput, all while reducing our cost.
outline:
- About me, Riskified, and how clickstream analysis is useful for fraud detection (3 minutes).
- What we had - old architecture (2 minutes).
- What didnâ€™t work (2 minute), why we thought it didnâ€™t work and why it actually didnâ€™t work (4 minutes).
- Requirements and end goals (1 minutes).
- Off we go: (13 minutes).
  - Choosing technologies and evaluating alternatives.
  - Leveraging each tech to reach our end goals.
  - Turning batch to stream processing.
  - Modelling our data right this time.
  - Hardest part: keeping features out!
- End result (1 minute).
- Some impressive numbers and charts (2 minutes).
- Could this complete rewrite have been avoided? (1 minute).
- Takeaways ( 1 minute).

title: Real-time fraud detection in 15 lines of stream processing code
abstract:
In this talk, we'll build a gatekeeper to your website. 
Our fraud detection system will target various types of malicious activities, such as account takeover, parameter tampering, forbidden access and more. We'll try to identify potential attacks and react to them in near real-time. 
Addressing this problem in a classical batch fashion will result with a complex, non-scalable nor real-time solution. We'll adjust our clumsy implementation to a modern, stream processing windowed-aggregation, use Kafka Streams as our streaming framework, and end up with a beautiful, clean and maintainable code.
outline:
2m - Introduction
5m - Present the problem
5m - Present an old-fashion solution to the problem
2m - Discuss the problems in the solution
5m - Present an alternative approach, describe the technology and its benefits
5m - Coding the solution
1m - Summary - what have we achieved
5m - Q&A

title: 3D PolyJet Printing: Support Needed!
abstract:
Looking at an everyday 3D printer - the printing procedure looks quite natural and straightforward. However, like traditional construction techniques things are not so simple. Indeed, just as scaffolding is extensively used in many building techniques, similar physical support is needed during the 3d printing process; different 3D technologies use distinct scaffolding methods. 
In this talk, after introducing the 3D printing ecosystem in general and the celebrated polyjet(â„¢)  technology in particular will describe the intrinsic difficulties of supporting the polyjet printing process, and hopefully demonstrate bone-fide algorithmic solutions to these problems.
outline:
1. Introduction: Who are we and why are we here (5 mins) 
2. Polyjet Printing in a jiffy (+ neat examples) (5 mins) 
3. The big Polyjet Support issue, and how is it attacked (10 minutes) 
4. A shallow dive into the algorithms (5 mins) 
5. Any questions?

title: Orchestrating Data Workflows Using a Fully Serverless Architecture
abstract:
While scheduling a limited number of data workflows is a generally manageable task, scaling to hundreds of data workflows with dependencies and diverse job types, requires a substantial customized engineering, complexity, and overall expensive resources. Serverless-based architectures offer an alternative to traditional resource management.

Tomer Levi explains how the data engineering team at Fundbox uses AWS StepFunctions, Docker containers, and Spark to build a live serverless data orchestration platform. Tomer will further describe AWS StepFunctions state machines, their limitations, and how to overcome them by building a custom job scheduling and dependency features. Finally, the talk will illustrate how resource bottlenecks were overcome using Docker containers and AWS Fargate.
outline:
2m Introduction - about myself
5m Problem definition - describe the challenges, why is it so hard? 
15m Solution walkthrough  - a step by step walk through the process of building the platform
3m Summary - what we learned and what are the drawbacks 
5m - Q&A

Total time: ~30m

title: How I reduced Secure File Copy (scp) transfer time by 70%
abstract: Transferring files between nodes is a common task. When these files are large it also consumes time. Time we usually don't have. A very commonly used utility is 'scp'. This is the story of how I worked on a task and as a by-product reduced transfer time by 70%. And now it is available as an open-source for all.
outline:
2m Introduction: Who am I and my professional background
2m SCP basic overview
5m Introducing PSCP: how it works and some performance data + demo
1m Summary
Total time: 10m

title: Donâ€™t lose control when building on top of external services.
abstract:
In our days, more and more products rely on 3rd party APIs to consume services and transfer data, in and out, while building their product value on top of it.
This might sounds like an easy task, Rest/GraphQL/Messages itâ€™s all the same, I have my client lib, my json objects and Iâ€™m ready to go, what can go wrong?!

My name is Yinon, API team leader @ Kenshoo and for the past 3 years I was focused on building integrations between our product and multiple publishers, In this session, I will cover the concerns, risks and how badly implementation of APIs might impact your product while providing specific guidelines for how to approach, manage and develop your product  which relies on other [out of your control] services.
outline:
- 2m - Introduction: Who am I and my professional background
- 3m - Beware of the maintenance  (
     -- Upgrade frequency
     -- Backward compatible
     -- Working in partnership - any RMFs?
- 5m - Start working with API - POC project
     -- Do you have all the information you need? (docs, tokens, test accountâ€¦)
     -- Code your first api call
     -- Is the data reliable? Whatâ€™s the readiness ratio?  timeframe dependency?
- 5m - How, why and when to test
     -- Mocks VS test account/playground 
     -- The different between Data validations VS Integration VS E2E, 
- 10m - Execution
     -- Beware of client libs (shading when must).
     -- Proxy your api caller (common auth/headers/logs & block sync / whitelist your test accounts)
     -- Error Handlers and retries
     -- Recovery plan/processes
     -- Bulk operations - in and out - and the limitations.
     -- Be careful of 2 way sync - parallel/merges/conflicts.
     -- Scale - Delta-oriented  sync-in and sync-out. (reliability again)
     -- Rate-limit and throttle you api calls
- 5m - Take it to production
     -- Logs - when? Should I log every request/response?
     -- Alerts  - behavior/doc changes and unexpected errors.
     -- Nightly/on-going automation jobs.
     -- Metric your customers usage for amount of calls made.
- 0m - Take care for communication - Support/Partner on the other side (just a tip ;)

Total time: 30m

title: Data Science Project Flow for Startups
abstract:
Data Science projects in startups have some unique characteristics when compared to both software development projects and more traditional research projects. Both the data scientist and her peers can find the respective differences unintuitive and confusing, and find some aspects of the typical flow of both lacking when used to run an agile data science project.

The aim of this talk is to present the characteristic project flow that I have identified in the working process of both my colleagues and myself in recent years, working as data scientists in various startups. Hopefully, this can help both data scientists and the people working with them to structure agile data science projects in a way that reflects their uniqueness.
outline:
The talk is based on a blog post I wrote on this topic: https://towardsdatascience.com/data-science-project-flow-for-startups-282a93d4508d

â€¢ 1m Introduction: Who am I and my professional background
â€¢ 3m Motivation: Describing the unique challenges startups face when running data science projects
â€¢ 3m Overview: A brief walk through of the flow, both in the breakdown into the product-ds-data-engineering axis, and the four project phases over time.
â€¢ 5m The Scoping Phase - Including examples and takeaways.
â€¢ 5m The Research Phase - Including examples and takeaways.
â€¢ 4m The Development Phase - Including examples and takeaways.
â€¢ 4m The Deployment Phase - Including examples and takeaways.
â€¢ 2m Key takeaways and caveats.
â€¢ 3m Q&A

Total: 30 minutes

title: Easy and efficient performance tests with Predator: The open-source performance testing framework
abstract:
Requests per second, request latency, and overall system performance and reliability are some fundamental concepts that need to be taken into account when designing a high capacity API. With CI/CD becoming a common deployment methodology, deployments to production are a constant occurrence. How can we ensure that the core capabilities we initially designed our system with to have remained intact?
We built Predator.
It allows us to manage the entire lifecycle of stress-testing a server, from creating a test file, running scheduled and on-demand tests, and viewing test results. Its seamless integration with both NOSQL and SQL databases keep test results persistent.  Bootstrapped with a user-friendly UI alongside a REST API, Predator helps developers simplify the performance testing regime.
outline:
-15sec Introduction: Who am I and my position at Zooz
-2m: Performance requirements we had at Zooz and our incentive to develop Predator
-6m: Quick Predator demo with the UI:
         -----1m: Local initialization of Predator using Docker
         -----2m: Test file creation
         -----1m: Running test
         -----2m: Showing the live and final reports
-2m: Possible use-cases of Predator
Total time: 10m

title: Domain driven design using Event Storming: Brace yourself, a storm is coming
abstract:
Building a good services architecture is hard. Building a good services architecture aligned to an evolving business and a massive r&d growth is even a greater challenge.
As a R&D Director at Taboola, a super-growing company, I kept asking myself how to overcome this challenge. This is when I came across DDD and Event Storming and became passionate about it.

Domain-Driven-Design, aka DDD, is a well known approach used by Netfix etc for designing complex software with alignment to the business. Event Storming is a tool for implementing this approach, mainly used in EU&US and not IL, at least till I give my talk:-)

In the talk I will explain how to visualize business flows using Event Storming,and how this visualization helps creating biz domain ownership in your engineering organization.
outline:
Note: This talk is a longer version of the event storming intro I gave in a DDD meetup recently.
Video&Slides can be found here:
video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oWTJlbThlaw&feature=youtu.be
 Slide deck: https://www.slideshare.net/OraEgoziBarzilai/introduction-to-event-storming-132360662/OraEgoziBarzilai/introduction-to-event-storming-132360662


Talk Outline

- 2m Intro  - about myself and about Taboola

- 4m Domain Driven Design advantages - bring everyone to speed on what DDD is and how it can help a growing organization like Taboola

- 15m Event Storming overview - Event Storming is a unique way for visualizing business flows in an event-driven way. In this part I will  use a step-by-step example to explain all the ingredients for a successful Event Storming: 
 * The setup - having the right participants, preparing the room (not a usual room)
 * The process itself - creating a colorful event driven flows using sticky notes.
 * Heuristics - doâ€™s and dontâ€™s for a successful session.

-8m Benefits of Event Storming - This part will focus on using the outcome of the Event Storming for:
 * Discovering domains of your system - which will be used for building a business driven system.
 * Discovering the boundaries of the domains - which indicate the boundaries between r&d teams.
 * Discovering anomalies in your system - with Event Storming it is easy to find simple bottlenecks as well as problematic org structure affecting the system architecture (Conwayâ€™s Law).

- 1m Q&A 

Total:30 min

title: Stop the 'Abuse' of the Hebrish Language!!
abstract:
We all use technical terms - all day - every day, but sometimes - we cannibalize these terms from English into some weird Hebrew form - for the lack of a better way to use them.

Lightning talk - with humor, fun and Music - and some outrageously funny usage of the Hebrew (is that Hebrew???) language
outline:
This is a fast paced lightning talk - with lots of humor - showing us all how ridiculous some of the terms we use in our daily lives actually are.

They are not English, they are also not Hebrew, but some mishmash of a terms we have all invented for ourselves.

It is time to set the record straight!!

title: Keep sharing while growing - how to keep the knowledge spread in the hyper growth organization
abstract:
"Why Two-Thirds of the Fastest-Growing Companies Fail?" is an article by the author of "Startup Leadership". His answer to the question was "these failures can be avoided by consciously creating a culture that simultaneously values the competing ideals of innovation and efficiency"

My story begins 1.5 years ago in Taboola Engineering. I found an organization that grows FAST and the need to learn and share your knowledge grows accordingly.  

By the end of this talk you will know how to improve peopleâ€™s performance by *creating a culture of sharing*. If I had to summarize it in one sentence - find the people that shine, use their passion for making your company grow.
outline:
Why knowledge sharing is critical? It improves performance, improves alignment within your peers and bring insights into the organization's working methods.

What's the problem? The bigger the company gets - the harder it gets.

Introducing myself with a few stories about the failures before got to a formula that works over and over again. 
Giving a few good examples: (â€œTrain stationsâ€ (â„¢) for training, Tech Sessions, Workshops)

Important milestones:
Who is your target audience and in what cases they need knowledge? 
Why it's hard to answer the question - â€œwhat knowledge/skills you need, to do your job better?â€? 
Why â€œbottom upâ€ method worked for me? 
Who can be a great partner for you? And who will not...
How would you know that you reached your goal? 

Closing words - how these concepts can help you?

title: Bashir: An opinionated development framework for bash, in bash
abstract: Bash is a great scripting language, available almost everywhere, quite easy to use and very powerful. Bashir is an opinionated development framework for Bash, written in Bash. The goal of Bashir is to ease the development process of tools written in bash, providing dependency management, code reuse, and some other common functionalities.
outline:
2m Introduction: Who am I and my professional background
7m Bashir: concepts and constructs, accompanied by live demo
1m Summary
Total time: 10m

title: Developers : Stay ahead of the game
abstract:
Being a good developer comes with a never ending pursue of the latest technology. Learning never stops making it difficult to find the desirable work-life balance we are all seeking for.

Imagine a concept which assists you to be always updated with the latest trends and technology including hands-on experience, yet also makes time to actually have a life !  

If youâ€™re only thinking technology, think again! Social interactions are equally important to create a more stimulating, productive and friendlier workplace environment.

In this presentation I will show you the environment I work in which implements exactly that. We will cover the way to set your work environment to be best technologically and socially.
outline:
2m - introduce myself
5m - introduce the problem and the way most developers are solving it
3m- introduce the solution
8m - introduce the technical part of the solution
8m- introduce the social part of the solution
