2m- show some statistics that support my solution
2m- summary +benefits for both developer and company

title: Playing the Certification Game..
abstract:
The eternal question many hiring managers deal with each day..

What is worth more in todayâ€™s job market? 
- Credentials (a.k.a. Certification or a degree) or 
- Experience (you know your stuff - because you have been around the block - more than once) 

I think that most of would agree that the second option has so much more value.
This is a question I sometimes ask myself - because I am a 6x AWS certification holder (all in the last 18 months)

This talk will go into the benefits of how pursuing a certification path can give the best of both worlds, both the experience and the accreditation that comes with it. 

A win-win situation  

And of course why we need to continuously improve ourselves to stay relevant in such a fast-paced technological world.
outline:
- 2m Introduction: Explain the dilemma and introduce myself
- 15m Go through the my personal journey of how I achieved my AWS certifications over the last 18 months
   - What I learned from the experience
   - What this did for my professional career.  
- 10m Why certification no longer matters. Go  over the market trends, how technology evolves so fast that what you learn today - is sometimes no longer valid in 12 months time.
- 3m Q&A

title: Demystifying git: from SHA to interactive rebase
abstract:
When I started using `git` 7 years ago, I was baffled by its mysterious jargon, and intimidated by the occasional French-revolution threat `You are in detached HEAD`. WAT?

I do like my head attached, so I kept the secret industry best practice: stick to `add`, `commit`, `pull` and `push`, and if anything goes wrong - copy the repo to another dir, pray, and apply some online black magic. This sucks. I decided to learn git from first principles.

In this session I will explain the git fundamentals: file structure, SHAs and objects, commits, refs and branches, up to the git interactive rebase. After this session, you should be able to understand git man pages, error messages, and repo states - without losing your HEAD.
outline:
# Motivation
I would like to create a good reference session in Hebrew about git, that can be used to explain the basics to developers in a meaningful and simple way. Most online sources today are either too long, assume outdated knowledge (e.g. "unlike subversion, git uses..."), and there's nearly nothing in Hebrew.

# Structure
This session is going to be fast and technical. I am going to cover one concept after another, and use terms defined in previous slides. However, I am not going to assume any prior knowledge with git.

# Tutorial
If time allows, I will create a sandbox tutorial repo that will enable developers to follow the session by practicing the actual commands covered on stage.

# Outline
* 1m Personal introduction
* 2m Version control 101: Snapshots in time, sharing, telling a code story
* 1m The problem: git is ubiquitous, but uses mysterious jargon. Understanding the basic concepts can help you understand any complicated git man page
* 2m: git as a distributed system, stand-alone repos
* 2m: Data storage: There's no DB. git stores data in files. The `.git` directory.
* 5m SHAs: Files, Commits, Trees. The `git cat-file` command.
* 7m The staging area: adding, reverting, resetting, checking out. Perhaps git stash. Something along the lines of https://dev.to/sublimegeek/git-staging-area-explained-like-im-five-1anh
* 4m Refs: Branches and tags
* 5m Merge, rebase, and interactive rebase
* 1m Credit and further reading

# Credit
I was influenced by the following sessions:
* Git Internals - How Git Works - Fear Not The SHA!, https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=P6jD966jzlk
* Jessica Kerr "Git Happens", https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Dv8I_kfrFWw

title: Interview(s) my lonely postmortem.
abstract:
Postmortem is never about pointing fingers, but what if it is just you doing the postmortem, and you're the only constant factor? 

In my talk you will learn about my unsuccessful interviews, why I failed, how I learned from my mistakes, and how did I work on not repeating the same mistakes, to be more successful in future interviews.

Most importantly I will talk about why it is essential not to play the blame game, but to use postmortems as a tool to learn about yourself and how to improve.
outline:
* 2 minutes  - About me, and my professional background.
* 3 minutes (times 3) - Incidents and postmortem points.
 Including things I did right, what I implemented from the previous incidents, where I 
 failed this time, what were the curveballs which I did not expect, and how did I stop myself from blaming others. I will share 3 incidents, 3 minutes per incident.
* 3 minutes to summarise and lessons yet to be learned, including how to improve my postmortem process, while thanking it for the fruit of its labor.

title: Dev Leads - Class of 2019
abstract:
Congratulations - you have just been promoted to a leadership role!
Now what??
Once the dust settles, you realize your new job is much harder than anything you've done before. Suddenly things look pretty different compared to what you thought it would be like. Is this really what you signed up for?

This talk is an introduction for new managers on how to ease into their new role. How to start this new chapter of their career. Obviously, there is no silver bullet, finding your own way just takes its time. However, there are some principles and guidelines that can support you through it.
This talk summarizes insights I collected during my own personal journey as a young manager, as well as from the young team leaders I had the opportunity to coach, mentor and manage on my day to day job.
outline:
[This can also be turned into an ignite]

* 2m Introduction
* 6m what people think management would be like and what it really is
* Body:
** 5m What to expect from your team
** 5m what to expect from your manager
** 5m What is your goal as a manager
** 5m How to leverage your skills as well as your weaknesses.
* 2m conclusions and recap

title: Busting software myths (or why I love tech debt)
abstract:
Any CS student can tell you that abstractions are good, and tech debt is bad. that code duplication is forbidden, and supporting future feature is important. Is that true? 

In this talk, I will challenge some of the well-known programming conceptions and principals, in order to help you be more skeptical and critical regarding popular perceptions and to write better code.
outline:
* 5m Introduction
* 5m ×”×›× ×” ×œ×ž×–×’×Ÿ - is BAD, very BAD. code examples showing that.
* 5m "there is no problem in CS you can't solve with another layer of abstraction" is a known slogan. well, it is true, but I will show code examples where it makes you write awful code.
* 5m code examples where DRY make use write bad code.  (DRY vs WET)
* 5m test coverage - is an important metric. is it? real examples where this metric is useless and make us write bad tests
* 5m Why I love tech debt. 
* 5m Q&A

title: Behavioral Programming: New System Designs with a New Paradigm
abstract:
Behavioral Programming (BP) is a novel programming paradigm. BP has many interesting traits for software engineering: it is modular, asynchronous, concurrent, and (eventually) intuitive. Unlike objects or functions, BP threads align well with business requirements. Most importantly, systems written in BP are verifiable - it is possible to formally prove they contain no bugs. Even a programs written in "scripting" languages can be proven reliable and be used in mission critical systems. In fact, we are currently building a satellite controller prototype using this paradigm. In JavaScript.

Participants will learn about one possible future of Software Engineering, and how they can start exploring it today, using BPjs - an open-source BP tool suite for JavaScript b-programs.
outline:
* 3m Intro: BP is a new paradigm, short history, what we'll see, why it will be weird (in a good way)
* 2m Programming vs. Modeling, Classic Modeling vs. BP
* 5m Hello world (slides + demo)
* 10m More complex program(s): Code, demo running, demo verification
* 2m Program state-space exploration
* 7m Actual cases (tracking rover, satellite OBC and test harness)
* 1m Resources and how to use
* Questions

title: The good, the bad and the ugly of Scripts in Production
abstract:
When talking about running scripts in production a lot of developers would say it is not recommended or even tabu. Looking at the other side, the users that use software every day in production like IT, they run scripts all the time.
DevOps is mainly based on running scripts, everywhere all the time
So why as developers, we don't recommend it? What are the advantages of (if any) are there for running scripts? Why should we care? What can we do to help?
outline:
2m Introduction: Who am I and my background
2m Presenting the subject and the related questions
1m Open questions about the topic for the crowd
5m Presenting the Good about Scripts in Production
5m Presenting the Bad about scripts in Production
5m Presenting what can get Ugly in Scripts in Production
5m Summary
5m Q&A
Total time: 30m

title: The "last responsible momentâ€. Or when should we stop it all, and refactor?
abstract:
"That's it. It's too late. We have to write the code from scratch, and it's SO complex. Why didn't I do it a year ago?"
Sounds familiar. Hah? 
I myself experienced it again and again. Sometimes I caught it on time, and sometimes, I missed it.
This slippery â€œlast responsible momentâ€ to refactor the code, is something that you are sure about - mostly after it passed...
So, why are we always getting there? How can we identify it on time, and how can we handle it? 
In this session Iâ€™ll try to share from my experience, and explain - why do we always get to the point where we need to stop - and re-architect, and itâ€™s actually a good sign. Iâ€™ll give you the means to identify this moment, and handle it - without fully stopping the carriage.
outline:
- 2m - preface - understanding how many people think that their system is not well architected, and how many of them think that itâ€™s too lateâ€¦
- 2m - intro. Who am I, and why is this interesting me at all
- 5m - The fact that you need to refactor - is actually a good thing
- 5m - How can I know if the time has arrived? Should I stop, and rearchitect the product?
- 5m - oh noâ€¦ you should not
- 5m - to talk is easy. How should I do it?
- 5m - One slide is enough. Letâ€™s summarise

title: Architect, start doing your damm job
abstract:
Thatâ€™s it. You are a system, lead or chief architect. You really want to make a difference in the organization. But how? Designing more and more features, building architectures for more and more infrastructures, is not enough.
After doing it again and again, I understood that lead architect goal is mainly focused on the *architectural vision*.
But I like to be practical, and setting a vision is not enough. I want something concrete, tangible and measurable.
In this session I will present you the â€œwell architectedâ€ pattern. This pattern includes 3 sets of standards and guidelines: Software architecture; People & Processes; Quality.
We will drill down to the pattern, and I'll show you how to use this tool in order to set an "architectural vision" that is practical.
outline:
- 2m - intro. Who am I, and why is this interesting me at all
- 2m - whatâ€™s in it for you - or, how would you be changed after this session
- 5m - The challenge of the architect. Especially in growing companies. Reactive architecture vs. Proactive architect
- 5m - the â€œwell architectedâ€ pattern - including practical examples
- 2m - â€œwell architectedâ€ evolution over time.
- 5m - practices of implementation
- 5m - main takeaways
- 4m - questions

title: $ git clone onboarding
abstract:
Starting as a new developer in a new company can be a stressful experience. In your first day you're expected to:
- setup your dev machine
- get credentials 
- get the app working
- understand where the company KB is 
- understand who  can help you out

It is very time consuming (you always forget something), Not to mention the confusion of new recruits "what else do I need to do?" ðŸ¤·â€â™€ï¸

so how can we use tools that developers already feel comfortable with, to make the onboarding process easier and more fun?

Imagine you can run a script on your first day on the next day you can start to be part of the team (just like anybody else).

I'll try to present a simple concept of how to onboard with a one-stop shop script. that include provisioning, git, slack bots, docker and other automation.
outline:
- **5 Min** Me me me
    - Who I am
    - A short history of how I got into this subject
- **10 min** Why
    - The pains of onboarding 
    - Why you should invest time in your onboarding (why take it seriously)
    - How onboarding should look like 
- **10 min** How
    - What I include in my recipe
    - What you need to create your own
    - What weâ€™re are doing in Ni besides my project to make it easy on newbies
    - Future steps
        - Cross platform 
        - Cross departments 
        - Call for help (internal tech community)
- **5 min**
    - Questions

Total: **30 min**

title: API gateways (but this time, on the client side!)
abstract:
API gateways are a common practice - usually the "public face" of your internal system & are served via one or more backend services.
Besides providing a uniform API, they also facilitate a standard way of authentication, permissions, versioning & much more.
What if we could gain some of those benefits when we build our web applications? 
What if we could compose our app from multiple agnostic parts, each with its different underlying technology & version, thus, enforcing a global authentication flow without rebuilding the whole system?

This talk will show you how we took the core concepts of an API gateway & applied them as the base architecture for our web apps, & scaled to 30+ apps in production while sharing libraries of various versions, managing a global state, routing & more.
outline:
2m Introduction
8m presenting the problem in appsflyer. handling 30+ production webApp
10m talk about how we took a server pattern and used it for our web applications
8m talk about our implementation
2m Q&A

title: A modular SDK in a Fragmented Landscape
abstract:
Web SDKs need to provide a host of capabilities & are a contradiction in terms - on the one hand, they need to be "fully baked" & "closed" in order to provide a uniform API. On the other hand, they need to be flexible in order to support future development & a wide range of clients.
While this can be achieved by "baking" a custom SDK per client - this is not very scalable (nor practically applicable with a business in exponential growth). In order to be able to deliver on the promise of modularity, we wanted to enable users to decide which capabilities they want to enable, without having to define this in advance.  This talk will dive into the development methodology we used in-house to support this and eventually, how we serve multiple SDKs in a uniform manner to a diversity of clients.
outline:
2m Introduction: who I'm I
10m present the problem we had with multiple SDK's sitting on the same clients
10m presenting the available patterns and using new browser methodologies to implement the dynamic SDK
5m Talk about the whole solution
3m Q&A

title: MAKE AUTOMATION GREAT AGAIN
abstract:
This is a spine-tingling tale of 4 men embarking on an impossible mission of automating the test process of a single Android application.
A single Android app with over 30 and counting flavors in different languages, different assets and features. Each of those flavors has its own custom backend and DB configuration. In order to make the system viable for the company, we had to parallelize the process and enable it to run on multiple mobile devices on the cloud and spin up a dedicated K8S cluster with the backend code for each tested device.
With lots of sweat, sleepless nights, coffee, coke, pizzas and furious keyboard strokes we are finally ready to share the world our experience, wisdom acquired and scars across our poor souls.
outline:
2m: Who are we
5m: The problem at hand and the possible challenges
5m: The possible solutions
3m: Selected solution
10m: Dive into Android Espresso
5m: Q&A
Total time: 30 minutes

title: Coding Game â€“  Using Minions as a strategy and not just as a cartoon.
abstract:
Haggling is a negotiation game in which pairs of players try to reach an agreement on how to split a set of assets, while striving to maximize their score. 

In Outbrain we used haggling as a coding challenge in the form of a game / hackathon which swept up the entire R&D organization; keeping everyone playing, strategizing, coding, hacking & learning - all in two weeks of pure energy and fun. The winning team was interestingly comprised only of woman engineers. Our secret sauce? Come and hear! 

In this talk we'll tell you more about the haggling game, how we leveraged it as an R&D organization wide learning activity, and how we won!
outline:
2m Introduction
5m Playing games as organisation challenge
5m Game Rules
5m Basic Strategies for haggling 
10m Our winning strategy
3m Results

title: How Sh!t Works: Open Source Vulnerabilities
abstract:
Thereâ€™s a lot of hype about the risks of using open source components. (http://techgenix.com/linux-security-concerns/) Whether itâ€™s a highly publicized court case or a huge data breach. After 10 years as a developer and one year as the head of an R&D group in an open source security startup, I learned first hand that a lot of the risks are manageable. 
In this tech session, I will demo open source vulnerability, and assess how a vulnerability in one of the most popular open source libraries impacts your code (or not). 
This session will provide developers with a deeper understanding of how open source vulnerabilities affect their code, and the practical tools to manage and mitigate their open source risks.
outline:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Xe_hgyXO-RI
2m Introduction: Who am I and my professional background
5m open source vulnerabilities 101: where are they found? Who finds them? Who fixes them?
How exploitable are they?
15 m: open source myths: debunking and confirming:
Effective Usage Analysis: how does one popular vulnerable open source project impact our code? Weâ€™ll analyze and trace the library and its dependencies to pinpoint the issue and how it affects the dependent code.  
Linux Kernel: letâ€™s check whether itâ€™s the most vulnerable open source project
NPM: whatâ€™s behind the rise in NPM vulnerabilities? We will look at packages to find out.
PHP & SQL injection: why are we still seeing SQL injection issues in PHP. 

5 m: Stay calm and open source! Practical tools for using open source components without flooding your backlog with security tasks.

title: Committing to Improve - Version and Organize Your Machine Learning Projects Effectively
abstract:
Keeping your code organized and versioned is of obvious importance to software developers. It saves us precious time. The machine learning (ML) field is only beginning to catch up. This stems from fundamental differences in workflows, requiring different tools.

In this talk, we will review these counter-intuitive differences and the state of the ML world today. Weâ€™ll introduce DVC, an open source command line tool that complements Git and enables organizing and versioning of machine learning projects, in order to fill the gaps required by the ML workflow. We will show a case study, and attempt to encourage the growth of an open source ML community in Israel.
outline:
2m Introduction: Who am I and why you should listen
5m Technical comparison: State of code versioning and project organization (and collaboration) in software development vs. what similar things exist in ML.
5m Root cause of this difference: reviewing the fundamental difference in workflow between software development and data science/ML.
7m The Solution: Introducing DVC, how it complements the Git workflow, and the advantages it can bring to your ML project. This includes data, model and pipeline versioning, as well as easily working with remote storage.
3m Project comparison: Showing the same project, once without and once with DVC.
3m Open Source ML: A few words on how open source machine learning can make the world a better place an what role DVC can play in that world.
5m Q&A

title: OSML - Are We Ready for an Open Source Machine Learning Community
abstract: Open Source Software has fundamentally changed the world of software development. But machine learning is lagging behind. The main reasons are that truly open source ML means open source data, and true reproducibility (dumping code is not enough). In this talk Iâ€™ll review how a world with open source ML would look like and why we should want to live in that world.
outline:
1m Software open source state of the union: Examples of open source software changing the world.
2m Machine learning open source today: How open source machine learning projects look today, and what they are missing - namely data and reproducibility.
1m Motivation: Examples for how open source machine learning might change the world.
1m What you can do: How you can help contribute to this (utopian?) dream of an open source machine learning world.

title: How to Push to Production on Thursday Afternoon and Live to Tell the Tale
abstract:
Taboola has >250 developers creating over 20 releases a day. We have almost 700 frontend servers in 7 data centers serving over 500k HTTP request per second.  Going from QA to production means exposing a new feature to 1.4B monthly unique users and up to 500K HTTP requests/sec which can be frightening.

In my talk, I will demonstrate the concepts we use in Taboola to tackle the above challenge. How and what technologies we use for our metrics, alerts and Canary deployment. How we encourage developers to take end to end responsibility and know the business. 

I believe that working the way we do make me a better developer. It is helping me be more creative and responsible, take bigger risks and most importantly enjoy. I will be happy to convince you to try and work as we do.
outline:
This is a lecture I gave at Geek Time Code and at a Meetup. It got really good reviews and I believe it could also be relevant and interesting for Reversim. The attached video is the lecture I gave at a Meetup.

2m describing the challenge:
Describe the challenge we have in releasing new code to production.
The challenge to make sure that a new code that is being developed by more than 250 developers and being exposed to 1.4B unique users per month is reliable and stable.
Practical:
I believe there are big advantages to work the way we do, and I would like to share this.

2m Introduction:
What Taboola does and what is our scale. Who am I, what am I doing in Taboola?

3m No corner cases at big scale:
Introducing the scale of our RnD (250 developers) Vs. the scale of our production (500K HTTP request/sec) to emphasize that on such scale every bug that could happen will happen.

4m The importance of metrics
Metrics is an integral part of our code design and code developing. When developing a new feature we define KPIs for the new feature on production scale right from the beginning.
Practical:
Think in productionâ€™s scale from the beginning 
Few words on the technologies we use

4m The importance of alerts
After defining the metrics, how do we define alerts? Who receives the alert? When? How do we assign the alerts from developing stage to full release? What infrastructure we use? What cultural methods we use to strengthen end to end responsibility at developers?
Practical:
Think in production scale from the beginning 
Few words on the technologies we use

4m The importance of feature flags
The importance of adding feature flags to control code in production. The way we use feature flags to gradually open new features and to act quickly during a crisis.
Practical:
Thinking production oriented and always integrate feature flags on new code

5m New feature pipeline
Describing our mechanism for Canary tests and canary deployment

2m Itâ€™s Taboola philosophy
Few words about Taboolaâ€™s philosophy which empower developers to work in the way I described above.

2m The advantages of working in such ways
I believe the way Taboola work is making me responsible, creative and daring developer. And even more important enjoy.
Practical:
I encourage everybody to adopt some of our principles.

2m Q&A

Total time: 30m

title: Hebrew NLP Tools -Where are we now?
abstract:
As Israeli developers, we want software to understand Hebrew text. Natural language processing (NLP) for Hebrew is necessary for creating AI applications.
As of 2019, this is far from trivial:
1. The computational problem of understanding Hebrew is hard.
2. Hebrew is a â€œsmallâ€ language, with lower commercial appeal.
3. Frameworks and tools for NLP in Hebrew are far and few between.

In this presentation we will explore the need for open source Hebrew NLP tools; the problems involved; which tools are available and what we want to improve, hopefully with your help. We believe that closing the gap in this field requires a coordinated effort, led by Academia and supported by government, volunteers and hopefully the industry to create the necessary open source Hebrew NLP tools.
outline:
* 2m Introduction: Who am I and my professional background
* 2m Why do we need Hebrew NLP? 
* 8m Why is Hebrew NLP hard? What are the needed building blocks?
* 10m  A survey of some existing tools for Hebrew NLP.
* 5m Description of initiatives for improving and creating new tools.
* 5m The desired solution, combining academic, government and community efforts.
* 5m Q&A
Total time: 37m

title: TimeKeeper - control the latency under extreme load
abstract:
At Taboola, as in many other companies, itâ€™s all about service availability and latency.

We have almost 700 frontend servers in 7 data centers serving over 500k HTTP request per second. They all expect to get an answer as fast as possible to meet our SLA. The load is not spread evenly throughout the day. The difference between low and high traffic varies up to 10X per geo and per data center.
Moreover, we have ~250 developers that change the code on a daily basis.
Breaking our SLA means Taboola is not serving recommendations - thatâ€™s obviously something we canâ€™t afford. 

You are invited to hear Taboolaâ€™s story of how we improved the way our services behave under extreme load, so we can avoid cascading service failures and we can fulfill the demands of the SLA.
outline:
â€œAlice: How long is forever? White Rabbit: Sometimes, just one second.â€

2m Introduction:
What Taboola does and what is our scale. Who am I, what am I doing in Taboola?


4m Our challenge:
We have 7 data-centers around the world. Each has peaks in traffic.  We have to keep our latencies low and service availability high. We are a growing company as more clients are being signed traffic increase.
Moreover, more programmers are joining us all the time and our code base grows rapidly. We must have good monitoring on how long takes each stage in the processing of a request. And obviously, we control this.
We want to make sure our SLA and latency is low especially if some crisis goes on to avoid cascading service failures.
Practical:
Emphasizing the issue using numbers and graphs


5m Analyzing the bottlenecks:
Our main service has hundreds of threads. Few dozen are handling HTTP requests and the other threads are doing all kinds of stuff â€“ Updating cache, send requests to other services etc. In order to have a clear picture of what exactly happens in the requestsâ€™ threads we develop the Tracing Context. It is a special mechanism that each developer can easily integrate into its code. The Tracing Context reports metrics about the time each stage in the requestâ€™s thread takes. This data is being reported to Grafana and Big Query and can be analyzed. In Big Query, this data also consists of the stack trace so it can be better analyzed.
Practical:
Demonstrating this mechanism by showing the pseudo code of how to implement it.
Showing a sample of the results in Grafana
Showing a sample of the results in Big Query

5m Server-side limits:
After analyzing the bottlenecks we had our culprits. So we could move on to define a hard time limit for each of those culprits. We developed a mechanism we called Time Keeper. As its name applies it keeps that every feature will have a defined time frame.
Practical:
Demonstrating this mechanism by showing the pseudo code of how to implement it.
Showing samples of graphs of the budget used by each feature and how we blocked some of the features
Showing improvement in our SLA 

5m Making the Time Keeper â€œsmarterâ€
First Time Keeper had only manually configured time â€œbudgetsâ€ for each feature. However, once we had this mechanism we could easily make it more adaptive to the current situation of our servers. I will introduce the Load Indicator, a mechanism that calculating the current load on the server and define the budget of each feature respectively.
Practical:
Showing how Load Indicator identify load
Giving a more practical example to use as adaptive server-side limits

5m Using the Time Keeper to prioritize traffic
Describing how we are taking advantage of the Time Keeper when we donâ€™t have any crisis going on. I will introduce how we are using the Time Keeper to give bigger time budgets to more important requests.
Practical:
Do you know what is your important traffic? 

2m Summary and what can you take of it
Summary of the principals we learned during this process and what can be taken from this by others.

2m Q&A

Total Time: 30m

title: Are you ready to go Secretless?
abstract:
Almost any application needs access to secrets. These secrets can be passwords, API keys, certificates and more.
Over the years, the ways applications used secrets have evolved from keeping them hard-coded in the application, to external files and eventually to using a secrets manager. But every method has its pros and cons, mostly around simplicity vs security. This is where Secretless comes into play. The Secretless Broker lets your applications connect securely to services - without ever having to fetch or manage passwords or keys. So you get simplicity without compromising on security.
In this presentation, I will explain what is Secretless, how it works, why itâ€™s good for security and simplicity, and how you can join this awesome project and become part of our community.
outline:
1m introduction: Who am I and my professional background
3m introduce the challenge: Why using secrets securely in applications is not easy
5m introducing the solution: How does Secretless help in solving this challenge
1m inviting everyone to join the Secretless open source community

title: From Spark to Elasticsearch and Back - Learning Large Scale Models for Content Recommendation
abstract: In this talk I'll deep dive into building a machine learning framework over Spark for content recommendation, and show how we use Elsaticsearch-based serving architecture to recommend content, at a scale of billions of recommendation requests a day, and under strict latency requirements of several tens of milliseconds per request.
outline:
Outline

â€¢ 2m Introduction: Who am I and my professional background
â€¢ 3m What are content recommendations and what are the challenges of selecting the most relevant content for each user under Outbrain's scale and latency requirements
â€¢ 10m How machine learning is used to figure out which content is the most relevant to each type of reader and how we scale it up with Spark
â€¢ 10m How Elasticsearch is used to select the most relevant content at scale of billions of requests a day and under a 30 milliseconds per request
â€¢ 5m Q&A

Total time: 30 mins

title: Can Your UX Be So Bad You Get Sued? Ask Domino's USA!
abstract:
Did you ever get frustrated spelling a password over the phone? "\*Capital\* B, and then the \*digit\* 6, not s-i-x". After making sure the language is not set to Hebrew, capslock is off and your dad can tell a zero from an O, you give up before getting locked out. Now, imagine this is how internet is. 

15% of the worldâ€™s population experience some form of disability, many of whom consume the web using assistive technologies that basically function as a middleman. Often, due to lacking implementation of websites, these technologies supply a partial, sometimes unusable, experience.

In this session I will give a glance at how web is perceived with assistive technologies, explain how they technically work, and share some practical tips to make your product accessible.
outline:
1M - Self presentation
1M - Anecdote: Dominoâ€™s inaccessibility lawsuit
2M - What is web accessibility? Explain by examples of impairment, UX and require adjustment what is accessibility, and conclude accessibility could be thought of as the private case of usability
1M - Today Iâ€™ll focus on screen readers, because blinds suffer more (blocking issues, statistics), machine readability affects also SEO, and...
4M - Screen reader technologic overview
15M - Screen reader UX: go over real life 4-6 examples of bad UX, for each - run exiting tools (e.g. aXe), demonstrate SR, discuss solution (and implement if easy, like aria)
	(a few ideas, will change according to what's more interesting and has better takeaways)
	- Broken syntax (e.g. broken XML within the HTML, list item not wrapped by a list)
	- Images with no alternative text - illustrative images vs. meaningful ones
	- Wrong web semantic (e.g. button looking div - not navigatble and cannot be interacted with)
	- Keyboard navigation: unreachable content, non meaningful order, screen reader vs. tab-based navigation
	- Auditory noise: ongoing carousel
	- UX issue: Railpass country selector (a complex proprietary input with non intuitive UX, impossible for non-seeing)
	- Content (unclear language, text referrals to visual cues, wrong landmarks and heading hierarchy)
4M - Summary and takeaways - as was reflected from the examples
	- Accessibility could be thought of as the private case of usability
	- Building an accessible product requires work in multiple organizational functions (design, UX, product, R&D)
	- Better plan than sorry - plan ahead to avoid patches, big blast radius
	- Testing challenges (problems with current automatic tools - syntactic, static)
	- Practical tips: how to monitor and prioritize; solution approaches
2M - Q&A

title: Metorikku: spark ETL made super simple
abstract: Metorikku is an open-source library that simplifies the writing and execution of ETLs on top of Apache Spark. Using the Metorikku library, users can create complex ETL jobs by only relying on simple configuration files and SQL commands. Moreover, the library includes an infrastructure for creating unit tests. In this talk, we will show how we leveraged Metorikku at Yotpo and made spark accessible to our entire R&D.
outline:
â€¢ 3m Introduction: What is metorikku?
â€¢ 2m Example: dive into a simple metorikku use case
â€¢ 2m Metorikku in streaming applications
â€¢ 2m How we run spark applications at Yotpo
â€¢ 1m Q&A

title: Service Mess â€“ micro services architecture common pitfalls
abstract:
While building a micro-service architecture one is most likely to encounter the same common issues across multiple scenarios. One of the greatest challenges is to identify these issues, or patterns thereof, in real-time and to provide the optimal solution for the actual problem.
In this session I will share some of the ad-hoc fixes and workarounds we have encountered during these last few years, I will go over common mistakes and pitfalls, and discuss the strategies needed to take when starting to think about micro-services
outline:
3m intro - who am I and professional background
5m overall architecture and relevant otonomo system component for this session
5m covering 2-3 common challenges when building MS architecture and how they interact (auth, communication, shared data models, shared repressibility
12m real life example of these issues, how our solution evolved and solution alternatives and trade offs
2m summary
5m Q&A

total time: 32 minutes

title: The wild side of visual tests
abstract:
The motivation for a shared UI components catalog is clear - sharing components and resources, leads to a higher product quality, with significantly lower effort.
However, this kind of an effort requires workflow discipline, which usually fails.
So, how do you keep UI Components implementation aligned with designs?
Automated visual tests are critical to maintain a UI components catalog, the last standpoint which makes sure that nothing changes unintentionally.
In this lecture I'll share insights and experience regarding visual tests automation and integrating with a UI/UX designer team, which ensures high quality with minimum effort.
outline:
1m introduction: Who am I and my professional background
2m Tech stack introduction: What tools do we use.
2m Describing development workflow with a UI components catalog.
8m Discussing possible issues and solutions with shared UI components catalog.
3m Q&A.

title: Bundling at scale: How Javascript bundling works at Facebook
abstract: Building modern web apps require a lot of Javascript, which is necessary for making them intractable. Delivering JavaScript efficiently by splitting your bundles smartly, can shorten your time to intractability and overall load times significantly. In the session I will share how Javascript bundling work at Facebook, and how you can implement similar ideas in your web app.
outline:
â€¢ 2m Introduction - Who am I
â€¢ 5m Why the subject matters and what you can get from this talk
â€¢ 5m Naive solution for web apps with Webpack - what you can get from them and issues you may find at large scale
â€¢ 15m Facebook architecture for splitting bundles - terms, data collecting, and how to decide how to split bundles automatically.
â€¢ 3m Conclusion and Q&A

title: Mousless - a gentle introduction
abstract:
There is a better way of working a PC - keeping both hands on the keyboard and leaving the mouse alone.  It has a steep learning curve, nothing  like using a mouse and a desktop, but it is quicker and more powerful.
In the presentation I'll talk about the principle of keyboard-only input, the tools that make the keyboard and ASCII terminal as powerful AS any modern IDE.
outline:
- 2m Introduction
- 3m evolution: how has our workstation changed over the last 50 years
- 15m introducing the toolchest: bash, tmux, vi
- 5m mouseless on the web and at large
- 5m Q&A

Total Time: 30min

title: Startup growing pains - how to mitigate
abstract:
As a software developer I have experienced first hand the difficulties of growing startups. Today as the head of development in a scaling startup, Iâ€™m successfully implementing solutions to some common challenges. 
Here are just some of the topics we will discuss: 
How to keep the early core team engaged while scaling and incorporating new employees to the team? 
How to put some formal procedures while scaling? 
This session is relevant for developers currently working in startups since you could improve your work environment. For developers thinking about working in a startup since you could get a very realistic point of view on how itâ€™s like working in a startup. And even relevant for CTOs and founders since it will be unique point of view on common pitfalls and how they can be avoided.
outline:
- Introduction - who am I and my professional background - 3 min
- Challenges when scaling a startup - 2 min
- Keep your core team engaged - 2 min
- How to scale the team - 2 min
- Must have infrastructure - 3 min
- When to introduce procedures - 3 min
- What procedures make sense to stay agile - 3 min
- How to introduce procedures while staying customer centric - 3 min
- Takeaways for developers - 2 min
- Takeaways for managers - 2 min 
- Q&A - 5 min
Total time: 30 min

title: Branch Versions - Revolutionize UI Engineering
abstract:
Introducing a CI/CD paradigm, which my teams have been implementing and using for the past 3 years.
Branch versions allows stakeholders to test and verify different code variants without affecting production.
every code change creates a branch version which allows product managers, QA teams and different stakeholders to test and verify the changes, without merging the code to master.
In this lecture I'll demonstrate a basic implementation and usage for Branch versions step by step, explaining through implementation every concept and tool that I use.
outline:
2m Introduction: Who am I and my professional background
5m Concept introduction - Motivation, End result.
5m Tech stack introduction - React, Express, Firebase, Travis CI
10m Implementation - Basic app with different branches on production
3m Full cycle walkthrough
5m Q&A

title: The evolution of React Hooks
abstract: Hooks are a new addition in React 16.8. They let you use state and other React features without writing a class, solving many problems the React team encountered over the years. The evolution of Hooks is the evolution of design-patterns in React. In the session I will present different design pattern in React that led to the creation of Hooks: from composition with High-Order-Components (HOC) and up to Render Functions.
outline:
â€¢ 2m Introduction - Who am I
â€¢ 5m Why the subject matters and what you can get from this talk
â€¢ 5m What High-Order-Components solve and what are the main issues with them
â€¢ 5m What render functions solve and what are the main issues with them
â€¢ 5m How Hooks work and why the solve the previous issues and more
â€¢ 3m Conclusion and Q&A

title: AI & ML goes to production - now what?
abstract:
"models degrade in accuracy as soon as they are put in production" - every data scientist relates to this sentence. But why is this such a global truth? and more important - how do you deal with that? 
In this session, we would like to share some common practices re the data science and engineering activities required in order to maintain the health of the AI/ML models in production, and what can be done in order to identify potential risks as they happen -  avoiding the potential damage and mess created while waiting for the feedback loop to come in.
outline:
- 2 minutes - introduction to our professional background
- 5 minute - explaining what makes AI/ML go wrong in production
- 3 minutes - sharing "bad stories" from the field
- 10 minutes - what are the key parameters to look at, what do they mean and how to get them measured
- 5 minutes - how do others do it? sharing our observations re how different organizations solve these issues
- 5 minutes Q&A

title: Health KPIs of AI/ML models in production
abstract:
When AI/ML model goes to production - it immediately starts to have its own life and meet the reality of the production-mess data streams. 
Without the proper monitoring - a big mess is just a matter of time, letting the algorithm take decisions on GIGO basis (Garbage-In-Garbage-Out).
Looking at the traditional software/infrastructure KPIs will just dont do it. 
In this session, we'll share a few of the most important KPIs to monitor when you launch your AI/ML in a production environment.
outline:
1 minute - reasons to worry
3 minutes - top 10 KPIs to look at
1 minute - what can you do with all of this data, making sure you're in control

title: Spark + Pandas = â™¥
abstract:
With Spark being widely used as a map/reduce framework for various data pipelines, it lacked capability of defining intuitive user-defined functions (UDFs). Contrary to Spark, Pandas is one of the most prevalent data-processing python packages and while it works well locally, it cannot scale to out-of-memory computations.
In this talk I will briefly discuss the introduction of Pandas vectorized UDFs to Spark, why they matter, and how it enabled us to create a scalable and dynamic feature-engineering framework, crunching through TBs of data with ease.
outline:
3m intro - who am I and my professional background
9m spark 101 - spark basics and why it came to be, user defined functions in spark (pre 2.3), and vectorized user defined functions in spark (>=2.3)
3m otonomos' data, and why we need aggregative functions
12m our architecture for feature engineering based on vectorized UDFs
2m summary
5m Q&A

total time: 34 minutes

title: Rethinking JS form validations. Say hi to Passable
abstract:
Writing user input validations is something most front end developers get to deal with during their careers. For some reason, this simple enough task often adds complexity and bloat into the developer's code.

We borrowed concepts and syntax from the world of JS unit tests to create an open source framework that handles the most common pains of user input validations.
outline:
- First 3 minutes
    - Who I am and what I do
    - What we're going to be hearing about
- 5 minutes
    - A bit about form validations in the present day, and why it is a mess.
    - Showing some validations code
- 5 minutes
    - DR about a validation heavy feature that lead to the guidelines for a validations system
    - The guidelines for a validations system
- 5 minutes
    - Switching over to unit tests and the way they work.
    - Describe the contract which is the unit test - maybe it can be used to describe other things as well?
- 5 minutes
    - Some pseudo-live coding of how such a contract would look for a validation
    - Introducing passable
    - Migrating the example code from before to actually use passable
- 5 minutes
    - Conclusion + questions

title: Building Tools for Humans
abstract: Every day as developers we use dozens of tools, APIs and libraries without even noticing it.  That's a good sign - instead of adding friction, they are taking it away. What it's like to be on the other side - to be the one building tools for other developers. What's the process of designing a tool that's not only good, but also - easy and fun to use?
outline:
- First 3 minutes
    - Who I am and what I do
    - What we're going to be hearing about
- Next 5 minutes
    - What is a tool - the broad definition
    - Why tools matter
    - Why great tools matter
- Next 5-10 minutes
    - What makes a tool great? - examples and counter examples
- Next 5-10 minutes
    - How to design a world class tool - the process which a developer needs to go through to design their api
- Next 5 minutes
    - Conclusion + questions

title: Should you? Could you? Would you? - The Chronicles of Multi Cloud Deployment
abstract:
Running a multi cloud deployment - something that quite a few organisations have pursued in the past few year, is a pretty big challenge.
In this session we will talk about the motivation of running multi cloud, best practices, recommendations and lesson learned from our experience.
outline:
3m intro - who am I and professional background
5m overall architecture and relevant otonomo system component for this session
2m talking about motivation for multi cloud implementation
10m guidelines and method for implementation
5m lessons learned and best practices
2m summary
5m Q&A

Total time: 32 minutes

title: Data Driven - I don't think it means what you think it means
abstract:
It's everywhere! companies are offering "data driven" culture instead of young and vibrant atmosphere. Statisticians are data scientists, ETL developers - data engineers, data architects appear everywhere (they were here all the time, just feel safe to come out to the light now), and executives are talking about "data assets".
One graduate even described himself as "passionately data driven" in his CV!

Has everyone lost their minds?! (Sorry, "got their feature set mixed up")

In this talk I'll share insights I collected during my journey from "plain" software engineering to managing Kenshoo's Data Platform Group. 
I'll try to demystify the term "data driven" and what it actually means for a company.
And most importantly, what to do when your CEO ask you to leverage the power of your data.
outline:
* Introduction, my story (3 minutes)
* What people have in mind when thinking about "data driven" (6 min)
** What parts of it are right (decisions based on data)
** What parts of it are overlooked - how to allow it, which kind of decisions, by who, what data is needed?
* How to approach it and what you should do:
** Decision making based on data (10 minutes): The data you need, tools , skills.
** Data driven products (7 minutes): from insights to product, Data science & engineering, data science and product/support/sales...
* Summary and Q&A (4 minutes)

title: Youâ€™re Doing It Wrong! Things I Wish I Knew Before Starting Deep Learning
abstract:
Making the switch from traditional development to data science took some adjusting. I knew little about tensors, regression, epochs, hyperparameters, or that a CNN wasnâ€™t just a news channel on my TV.

AI is all around us and interest in machine learning, computer vision, and deep learning are growing at a rapid rate. For the past 20 + years Iâ€™ve built websites for music artists, enterprise backends, prototypes for car dashboards, and even large touch screen installations. However, I wish I knew these things before I switch to deep learning.

In this talk, weâ€™ll go through some of the most common pitfalls developer make when diving into the machine learning deep end.
outline:
1m - Introduction
3m - Past development experiences
5m - Why I got into machine learning from games
1m - How I like to learn
18m - Key concepts to know about machine learning
2m- How to continue your learning

title: Bringing Decades of DevOps Experience To Deep Learning
abstract: Deep Learning brings with it enormous amounts of data, complicated experiment results and intense compute requirements. Decades of experience in moving code to production yielded best practices in engineering that have not yet found their place in deep learning teams. Over the past few years, the term â€œDevOpsâ€ has become an industry standard but where are the DeepOps best practices for AI First companies? In this talk, weâ€™ll cover why most AI companies fail when it comes to reproducible training, data management, and deploying to production.
outline:
1m - Introduction
2m - What is DeepOps
2m - Learning from dev ops
10m - What you can learn from AI company failures
10m - How to implement DeepOps
5m - Q&A

title: Teaching Machines to Make 8-bit Music
abstract:
Iâ€™m a huge fan of game jams which force you to create something fun and playable in a short period of time. For years now Iâ€™ve used tools like Sfxr which generates 8-bit sound effects based on predefined templates. When I started developing my fantasy game console, Pixel Vision 8, I wanted to see if I could build upon Sfxr and create randomly generated music for those of us that know nothing about musical composition. To do this, I employed a collection of techniques to help teach my software how to make â€œgoodâ€ music randomly based on a set of predefined musical styles.

In this talk, Iâ€™ll walk you through how PV8â€™s music generator works, what itâ€™s capable of doing, and how I plan to leverage machine learning to help take it to the next level.
outline:
1m - Introduction
5m - Can computers make music
15m - How I taught PV8 to make music
4m - How can we make it better
5m - Next steps

title: RESTool - Stop Developing Apps for Managing RESTful APIs
abstract:
In the past 10 years as a front end developer, I found myself creating internal management tools for RESTful APIs over and over again, while in fact, the usage of these tools remains the same: creating, updating, and viewing data based on an API.

I had enough of it, so I created RESTool - a generic UI tool for managing RESTful APIs.

In this talk I'll present how to configure, run, and use RESTool, and what caused it to jump from 0 to 170 stars on Github in couple of months. 

Link: https://github.com/dsternlicht/RESTool
outline:
* 1m Intro: Who am I and my professional background
* 1m The problem: how everyone are repeatedly writing the same internal apps for managing RESTful APIs over and over again.
* 2m UI demo: demonstrating how RESTool UI works.
* 4m Configuration: How to configure RESTool to work with your API.
* 2m What's next

Total time: 10m

title: Druid on top of Kafka and Spark. Reducing analytics cycle from hours to minutes.
abstract:
Apache Spark and Kafka are essential tools in Big Data technologies. Apache Druid is a high performance analytics data store for event-driven data. 
On my talk I'm going to present how we used these technologies for building realtime analytics on top of billions of served recommendations. I'm going to describe the problems that we encountered and lessons that we've learned.
outline:
To define the problem - [3 min]:
In order to constantly improve our recommendations, we collect and store huge amount of data. This data is processed every hour in a batch mode. It means that we get insights from our data after few hours of delay. It would be great to reduce this cycle and to analyze the data in real-time.
To make a short overview of Apache Druid. We use it for real-time analytics and data visualization using Pivot (By Imply) on top of Druid - [3 min]. 
To make an overview of Apache Spark and Spark Streaming. To explain why we choose to combine these technologies [5 min]. 
To explain the logic of what we have done [8 min]. In a nutshell: we have Spark Streaming job that reads data from Kafka topic and enriches it by calling several services (adds more data for every record in Kafka topic). It also changes the format of the data from Avro to plain Json. Then it writes the output to another Kafka topic. All this prepares data to be analyzed by Druid.
To show the final solution including Kafka, Spark and Druid [2 min].
To show the Druid analytics dashboard and to describe the value that it gets [3 min].
To tell about problems we had and lessons we learned [5 min]. For example, one of the problems was that we had a â€œgapâ€ in Druid data each time we redeployed new version of Spark application. We needed to fix it by storing Kafka topic offsets for the job.

title: weighted lottery - from bottleneck to coding challenge to open source
abstract:
Weighted lotteries are used when we need to randomly select k of n items with given probabilities - commonly used by Outbrain's recommendations system to provide diversity for our users. Once we identified that our naive implementation is a production bottleneck, we decided to solve the problem in a fun way, and turned it into a coding challenge, followed by releasing creative benchmarked solutions along with classic algorithms to the community

https://github.com/guyko/weighted-lottery/wiki
outline:
2m: what are weighted lotteries
2m: naive implementation, what's wrong with it
3m: generalize. how we turn it into a coding challenge, what are we measuring
2m: Interesting solutions 
1m: how can you contribute

title: Next generation Serverless CI/CD, let the bot serves your favorite dish
abstract:
Chatbot interactions are becoming the next thing in development cycles. One of the areas that can benefit from this is the CI/CDâ€”the idea of a simple: Start interactive session with the CI/CD infrastructure instructing it to build artifacts, spawn and tear down environments, deploy, rerun tests â€” everything you need to get to the finish line.
Our journey started when we realized we want a to move from traditional CI environments to an on-demand, short living CI environment. We insisted on making it a developer-driven experience.

The secret sauce is combining Jenkins-Xâ€™s serverless version, GitOps and some other goodies. Weâ€™ll be happy to demonstrate how to put them together
In the end, we realized that this also cuts the costs for cloud infrastructure.
Letâ€™s change the way we brew CI/CD.
outline:
â€¢	2m Introduction: Who I am and my professional background
â€¢	5m the traditional world:  Architecture, Pros, Cons
â€¢	5m The Serverless World solution overview Serverless Jenkins (CasC, Knative), Chatbot (Prow) etc.
â€¢	5m: Run it in your  private cloud: customization and security challenges 
â€¢	5m Demo â€“ things in motion: creating a new micro service from scratch, unit test it. Show the dialog flow with the chat bot
â€¢	5m Q&A

title: Think outside the box: think about money
abstract:
As software architects, we usually have a few parameters when designing a solution for an upcoming feature. Those parameters might be delivery time, maintenance and extensibility. But we often forget about one crucial parameter: cost.

When your team keeps cost in mind, you start exploring new tools that you didnâ€™t even know existed. So in this process, you learn about new technologies and you start thinking more about efficiency rather than sticking with what you know.

In this session, I'll explain how we adopted a culture of considering costs, how we track the cost of our production environment and how in three days we started saving $25,000 per month. Iâ€™ll also discuss how thinking about money expanded our teamâ€™s knowledge in new and up-and-coming technologies.
outline:
- 2m Introduction: Who am I and my professional background
- 3m Background story: How we came up with the idea of looking into the company cloud  expenses
- 12m The Solution: Costs tracking tool that we built and how it monitors our production environment with alerts
- 10m Culture change and how the developers in the company benefit from it
- 5m Conclusion and CTA

title: The portrait of Multimedia
abstract:
The way that we consume content in the web has come a long way from the days of text blocks and images to AR/VR and live-streaming nowadays. Have you ever wondered how the magic happens?
In this talk we will cover some of the defining moments in the evolution of content consumption in the web.
Then we will show the ease of implementing rich content experiences in comparison to 5 or 10 years ago.
outline:
2m - introduction
13m - brief history of multimedia in the web. Image tag proposal, flash, red5, RTMP etc...
5m - WebAudio API
5m - WebRTC
5m - WebGL
total time 30-32m

title: Beware of JavaScript Shenanigans!
abstract:
The web is a crazy place! In this talk I will go over some weird and dark aspects of the JS eco-system, highlighting common security issues and pitfalls which we, as web developers, can learn to protect against.
I will start by going over some wonky NPM packages that made it into the JS ecosystem, including: â€œNoCodeâ€, â€œIsThirteenâ€ and â€œJsF**kâ€.
Then, we will revisit a couple of stories that are now part of web history, including #SmooshGate and recent NPM security issues from 2018.
Next, I will go over some fun pranks using CSS to mess with people.
Lastly, I will present some techniques one could use to make the most annoying website possible, stressing some common security pitfalls which front-end developers can learn to identify and block, such as the infamous â€œwindow.openerâ€ property.
outline:
â€¢	2m Introduction: Who I am and my professional background.
â€¢	5m Weird NPM packages: Some interesting and weird packages that made it into the JS ecosystem.
â€¢	5m Security issues found in NPM in 2018.
â€¢	10m CSS/JS pranks and how to deal with them.
â€¢	5m Q & A.
Total time: 27m.

title: Coding for growth
abstract:
Being a part of a fast-growing company is an amazing experience but a challenging one as well. In a reality where your engineering doubles itself every few months, You experience an interesting side-effect that at any given time roughly 50% of your team is new. 

So how can you build a codebase that can support a fast-growing company? I believe itâ€™s all about empathy. It's about writing code that guides developers to make the right choices even when you are not by their side. Itâ€™s about making context visible in your code, itâ€™s about helping developers focus on â€˜howâ€™ instead of â€˜whereâ€™, â€˜whatâ€™ or â€˜whyâ€™.

In this talk, Iâ€™ll share some principles Iâ€™ve learned along the way on transforming our codebase for growth.
outline:
2m: intro, who am I, what I do.  
3m: the experience of joining a fast-growing company.  and the dysfunctions of a "new" team. 
20m: transforming your codebase to enables growth 
* empathy design - helping people make the right choice.
* visibility through code - helping people understand and be consistent with our flow and culture. 
* the path to productivity through storytelling - how to reduce the number of where what and why questions.
* leveraging existing mental models to deobfuscating business and architecture.
* being consistent with patterns. 
2m:  summary
3m: QNA

title: 3 lessons about building magical products Iâ€™ve learned at Disneyland
abstract:
Disneyland is not just a theme park, it's a magical experience where you can actually live the fairy tale. Where else in the world you can fight Darth Vader, fly together with Peter Pan and hug Mickey Mouse in the same day?

And itâ€™s no surprise, as Disneyland is meticulously and deliberately engineered to be fun & immersive. This practice is called Imagineering. 

What if you could use the same principles to bring a magical experience to your users? 
In this short talk, Iâ€™ll share 3 Imagineering principles Iâ€™ve been using, and you can use too!

So join me if you want to learn how Amazon.comâ€™s homepage is similar to Cinderellaâ€™s Castle, and how snow white helps Airbnb create a better mobile app.
outline:
1) the Disney is the epitome of magical experience (wonderwalk)
2) imagineering - the principles of designing magic.
3) principle 1 - Storytelling.
4) principle 2- wienies. (and wayfinding)
5) principle 3 - "its a small world" effect. making things memorable

title: Demystifying SSD and NVMe
abstract:
In this session, we dive into the world of storage.
We start with SSD internals: Flash Translation Layer, Garbage Collection mechanism, differences between MLC, TLC, and QLC and different workloads patterns.
Next, we present the NVMe protocol and show how it is superior to the older SCSI and SATA protocols. 
We will finish by introducing NVMe over fabric: the latest â€œbig thingâ€ in the storage industry that allows separation between storage and computation.
outline:
2m introduction
6m what is SSD, its benefits and issues, different NAND types (SLC, MLC, TLC, and QLC)
7m what is FTL and GC: what do they solve and what issue they introduce
7m NVMe: why was it needed (what was wrong in the old protocols),  advantages, basic features and performance numbers
3m NVMe over fabric
5m summary and Q&AS

title: Teaching Neural Networks to Emulate CGI Effects
abstract:
Nowadays we can see Computer-generated imagery, better known as CGI or movie effects in most large feature film and even in the smallest of commercials.
While these are handcrafted by specialists with years of knowledge assisted by design software I challenged myself with creating an automated version of a crowd favorite movie effect. Join me in this session to see how I created a custom dataset for the job and trained my network to give eye-pleasing results.
outline:
- mission state
- collecting data
- getting segmentations
- cleaning data
- training our neural network
- results

title: Breaking up with your frontend monolith
abstract:
The world of frontend is constantly evolving. Every month, new technologies and ideas are introduced. Migrating old code to the next popular Javascript framework is never easy. We always want to stay ahead but it's getting exhausting, aren't you getting tired of it?

This session will cover CyberArk's strategy for dealing with migration to a new framework and autonomizing modules. This strategy includes breaking down a monolith to independent modules and running those modules as mini apps under a parent application (AKA shell), making it a seamless experience. We'll talk about the development process and deployment mechanisms, as well as the design behind our smart shell.
outline:
â€¢ 2m Introduction: Who am I and my professional background.
â€¢ 5m Motivation: What is micro-frontends and why do we need them.
â€¢ 5m Architectural overview: How generally micro-frontend architecture should look like, and how it answers the motivation.
â€¢ 15m Our solution: Built an app-shell and insert the monolith to it, then started to break-down the monolith into small pieces, and I will present some technological challenges along the way.
â€¢ 3m Summary + Q&A

Total time: 30m

title: Hyperparameter Tuning (Optimization) for Large Deep Learning Models
abstract: When learning from complex data such as medical scans or video feed we encounter long training periods and large memory demands. This makes searching for the best set of hyperparameters a hard to nearly impossible task. Most researchers simply try a few sets of hyperparameters by trial and error or use a grid search at best. These hyperparameters are usually chosen by some intelligent guess based on prior knowledge. It is clear to see this is not the best practice. A more DATA DRIVEN approach required.
outline:
1m - Introduction
1m - Learned parameters vs hyperparameters and the task of tuning
5m - Search algorithms
5m - Open source tools
3m - Best practices when working on large tasks
2m - Q&A

title: Compressing Ensemble Models for Improved Inference Performance
abstract:
Deployment of large ensemble models can create large overhead on memory and disk space with energy consumption as a derivative. One solution is to reduce the quality of input data or the rate of inference.
In this session, we will speak about a set of tools to make our trained ensemble networks smaller in size and in memory, enabling them to run on cheaper hardware or on edge devices.
outline:
1m - Introduction and Mission state
3m - Types of solutions: Prunin, regularization, and Quantization
1m - Result on Ensemble models

title: Understanding Containers by Building One
abstract:
Containerised deployments  have rapidly become an industry wide standard.

We use container engines such as Docker to develop and deploy our applications on a daily basis. Many businesses depend on this technology to survive - but do we understand how they work?

This talk aims at demystifying concepts and terms such as  cgroups, namespaces and â€œlightweight virtual machinesâ€.

By writing a container from the ground up we will discover that a container is simply a sandboxed Linux process. 

Audience members will walk away with
* Understanding the underlying concepts of containers.
* Learn how to implement a container from scratch.
* Understand the pros and cons of this technology and what it can do for your startup / business.
outline:
* 1m Introduction: Who I am and my professional background
* 2m What is a container? Why should we care about them?
* 5m What our container will do -> defining the features we will support in the demo container
*  20m - Namespaces, container pids, container control groups...
* 2m - Summarizing container concepts
Total time: 30m

title: If you can drive you can architect a system
abstract:
Architecture and solution design can be challenging and involves tradeoffs and understanding concerns. One example of such trade-offs and design principles could be demonstrated even in a simple question as â€œwhich car would you buy?â€ what will be your question if you have 1000$? And if have 10M$? Would you buy the same car? Will it affect your decision If you were driving 10 mins a day? 10 hours a day? 
In this talk,  I will demonstrate how architecting a solution can be as natural as driving a car, by implementing similar concerns and logic you use in your daily life to your design can make you a better engineer and your services more efficient. We will cover the principles, trade-offs and things you should NOT do when architecting a solution.
outline: Even the best engineers sometimes struggle with architecting their services, especially when talking about complex data flows and components dependencies. and even engineers with the best intentions miss important concerns in design, from my experience itâ€™s usually due to lack of awareness and/or knowledge and not from lack of willingness. In this talk, I will demonstrate how natural system architecture can be if you look it from a different perspective. Understanding that architecture is always a trade-off is necessary for a good design, this talk aimed to raise your awareness of architecture and design concerns both from performance and resilience. Note: You donâ€™t need a driver license to attend this talk.

title: Understanding p2p file sharing protocols by building a BitTorrent Client
abstract:
With decentralized applications we can build unstoppable apps with no single point of failure.

BitTorrent was one of the most popular dapps ever created. At one point it was estimated that BitTorrent traffic accounted for over 50% of total internet traffic.

In this talk we will learn about the ingenious p2p file transfer protocol by implementing a bit torrent client. We will discuss the finer points of the protocol and understand how the BitTorrent protocol can be used to reduce the server and network impact of distributing large files, reduce dependence on the original distributor and much more. 

Audience members will walk away with
* Understanding the underlying concepts of p2p file sharing.
* Understand the pros and cons of p2p protocols and file distribution.
outline:
* 1m Introduction: Who I am and my professional backgroundâ€¨
* 4m What is a p2p protocol? Pros and cons of a decentralised approach in file sharing, Tech background on bit torrent and its scale
* 5m What our client will do -> defining the features we will support in the clientâ€¨
* 20m - Building the client with an emphasis on understanding the core concepts that make it decentralized, encourage file sharing etc.â€¨
* 2m - Summarizing p2p concepts and a glimpse to how they will be (hopefully) used in the future.
â€¨Total time: 32m

title: SandBlast Mobile to infinity and beyond
abstract:
You had a great Idea, you wrote the perfect program for it and it's working. Now you have a few customers and they are thrilled with your product. So you think to yourself what's next? why not sell it to everyone? Oh wait, you can't.. your system will crash under the load.
Recently Check Point managed to overcome the challenge of scaling up its system to support bigger customers, and now there is nothing we can't do.
In this session I will describe the difficulties we faced and how we managed to handle them:
- Monitoring: Identify bottlenecks in the system
- Scale In: 
  * Save time with bulk operations.
  * Add optimizations based on system behavior.
- Scale Out: Make adjustments to enable auto scale.
- Deployment: Migration and scale up was done with zero downtime and no customer impact.
outline:
- 2m Introduction: Who am I and my professional background.
- 5m Architectural overview: I will describe our system architecture and its limitations. 
- 5m Identify bottlenecks: How we monitor the system in order to find its bottlenecks.
- 15m Solution and deployment process: Review of the changes we made and how each change affected the system behavior. I will describe how we deployed it in a zero-downtime process and how we monitored it.
- 5m Q&A

title: All Aboard the â€œHackatrainâ€ ðŸš‚
abstract:
You may have heard about big companies allowing their engineers to work on whatever they want. You probably thought to yourself "well, they have too much money to waste". Here is where you might be wrong. Hackathons not only improve a companyâ€™s product with new innovations, but also provide teams with the opportunity to learn, grow, and share experiences with their colleagues. Havenâ€™t you always wanted to make your [technical] dreams come true? 

Companies of all shapes and sizes have recently started to embrace Hackathons. Through this lecture, I will try to list all the right reasons why your company, should be next to hop on that â€œHackatrainâ€. If you already have hackathons at your company, thatâ€™s great! The lecture will also share more tips and tricks to help you make them better.
outline:
Who am I & WIIFM [2 min]
What is a hackathon? [2 min]
Timeline and tips to do it right Get ready for it / as it goes / wrap up [5 mi]
Project types + examples [3 min]
How it can improve your product? [5 min]
How it will help people grow? [5 min]
Caveats / tradeoffs [3 min]
Summing up [2 min]
Q&A [3 min]

title: What can software developers learn from car manufacturers?
abstract:
Building and maintaining a mobile app over time is a very complex issue every mobile company encounters.
This issue becomes exponentially harder when we talk about a suite of apps a company might offer (B2C & B2B, different markets, different functionality with similar core etc..)
In this talk, we'll cover this issue and see how it is possible to achieve a state where developing and maintaining mobile apps becomes easier, faster, better organized and SOLID using modular approach and platformization.

Weâ€™ll also review how this methodology forces you & your team to adopt a specific culture which has very positive & empowering components.
outline:
* 2 min - Who am I and why should you bother listening to me
* 3 min - How a typical mobile codebase would look like and why is it bad (hint: tightly coupled monolith)
* 10 min -What software developers can learn from car manufacturers? what is platformization and software modularity and what are the great advantages they hold (with a focus on mobile)
* 5 min - Private pods 101 (iOS example)
* 5 min - JitPack 101 (Android example)
* 5 min - How working with this methodology helps you empower your team
* 5 min - Q&AÂ 

Total time: ~35 minutes

title: My Rules of Thumb forÂ Writing Maintainable Tests
abstract:
As we mature as developers, we develop our personal style, best practices, dos and don'ts in regard to our craft. One major part of that craft, in my humble opinion, is testing.Â 
In this talk, I'd like to present some of the guidelines I personally use to write better, readable and maintainable tests.
outline:
â€¢ 1m Introduction: Who am I and my professional background
â€¢ 1m talking about bad tests
â€¢ 1m talking about test length and test cases
â€¢ 1m talking about failing tests
â€¢ 1m talking about testing frameworks

title: Sigterm:  Everything that has a beginning has an end
abstract:
Everything that has a beginning has an end. **EVERYTHING** including the programs we write and run.  How can we prepare to this final goodbye? Turns out that In order to die well, our programs need to live well - or at least have a decent architecture.
Also don't try to cut a deal with death, zombies are the worst
outline:
* Establishing that everything that has a beginning has an end - including our short living processes running our programs and raising the question
* What might kill our programs
* Handling death
* Patterns and software design considerations
* When to handle? touching signals
* Say no to deals with death

This might also be a 15 minute technical talk with more emphasis on architecture patterns - which might be preferred

title: Deleting Tests with Types
abstract:
The less code in our systems, the better we are. Less to maintain, less to read, less to onboard. And tests? They're code. A _lot_ of code.

But wait, we *need* tests. Tests increase our confidence in what we've built.

In this live coding session, weâ€™ll delete a lot of tests while keeping our confidence high.
outline:
*Outline:*
* 1m Introduction
* 1m EVERYTHING IS TERRIBLE: Of the need to push checking for issues as further back in the software development lifecycle as possible
* 4m Why tests are not enough to keep confidence in the code and other fallacies of unit testing lore
* 20m Live coding and explanations of 
* 4m When to complement tests with static typing and when not to do that, based on the business's needs

Total time: 30m

This talk was presented internally and was afterwards presented to more audiences at the request of other parts of the org.

title: Fear is the little-death that brings total obliteration - devops role in the new world
abstract:
What exactly is DevOps, and what does a DevOps do?

In this talk, I will focus on the main role of DevOps as I see it: eliminating fear!

Devs have plenty to worry about: 
How do I deploy to production? How do know my code isnâ€™t going to break production? when production break, what will I do? 

Management also has its share of anxieties: 
After a production issue - how do we make sure it wonâ€™t happen again? 

DevOps have one core fear: How do I know everything is working? 

Weâ€™ll discuss some best practices: testing, CI/CD, monitoring tools, and postmortem. 

But with a twist: using these tools not just to solve technical issues, but as a way of creating a cultural shift within the company.

The end-goal of our talk is simple: Learn how to move fast and break free of your fears!
outline:
1. Who am I and my professional background
2. What is a dev ops? little bit on the dev/ops history.
3. What are the challenges R&D team face today?
4. Which tools can help us make the team move faster and better?
5. Why is it so important to make the team move faster.
6. Understand why it's the dev-ops role to pushing the team forward and set the tone.

title: PyTorch Code Sample to Unpack Andrej Karpathyâ€™s Most Common Neural Net Mistakes
abstract:
With deep learning and computer vision, there are many pitfalls and hacks to work around and debug. On June 30th, 2018, Andrej Karpathy, Director of AI at Tesla, tweeted a short list of first things to check when your neural network isnâ€™t working.

In this session, you will see what these mistakes look like in code and performance metrics. Using a computer vision dataset and a PyTorch code sample - weâ€™ll walk through each of these pieces of advice, test it and explain it. Expect a technical deep dive and a review of best practices when debugging a PyTorch computer vision experiment.

Original tweet at: [https://twitter.com/karpathy/status/1013244313327681536](https://twitter.com/karpathy/status/1013244313327681536)
outline:
â€¢ 2m Introduction: Who am I and my professional background
â€¢ 8m Mistake #1 - you didn't try to overfit a single batch first.
â€¢ 5m Mistake #2 - you forgot to toggle train/eval mode for the net.
â€¢ 5m Mistake #3 you forgot to .zero_grad() (in pytorch) before .backward().
â€¢ 5m Mistake #4 you passed softmaxed outputs to a loss that expects raw logits.
â€¢ 5m Q&A

title: Understanding customer reviews
abstract:
A review usually consists of the customerâ€™s opinion on various aspects of the product, the service, or the website itself. Extracting these opinions can help e-commerce store owners understand the state of their business and improve it accordingly.

In this talk, we will give an intuitive explanation on how NLP models work, and describe how we built our Insights engine for extracting topics and opinions from reviews, along with their corresponding sentiment scores (i.e., good, bad or neutral).
outline:
This lecture has a 1-hour version. In addition to the slides on how the Insights engine works, I also give an intuitive explanation on how machines understand text, along with code examples showing how anyone can use these models in python (this was given as a lecture to our entire R&D).

The following is a 30-minute outline:

Outline:
1. Introduction (8 min.)
1.1. Motivation: the benefits of understanding reviews (2 min.)
