1.2. The Insights engine and UI (2 min.)
1.3. Cool success stories (2 min.)
1.4. Algorithm overview: step 1: extract topics & opinions, step 2: analyze opinion sentiment, step 3: group similar topics & opinions (2 min.)

2. A 10-minute tutorial on â€œhow machine understands textâ€ (actually, 12 min. :) )
2.1. How do machines represent text: use vectors instead of IDs (3 min.)
2.2. How do machines learn word representations: the Word2Vec approach - words are similar if they appear in similar contexts (3 min.)
2.3. Different training data => different embeddings (2 min.)
2.3. How do machines understand text: a quick overview of neural network models, that first learn a word embeddings and then learns how to combine them into a representation of the text (4 min.)

3. How to analyze the sentiment of opinions? (10 min.)
3.1. Problem definition of opinion sentiment analysis (2 min.)
3.2. Why the trivial solution does not work (2 min.)
3.3. Our approach (4 min.)
3.4. Summary (2 min.)


If possible, I would be happy to give the full 1-hour talk.

title: Please Don't Join My Team!
abstract:
While recruiting a candidate with the required skills is a challenge, their personality should be your main concern. If their technical skills fits, but you still have your doubts, then maybe you haven't examined their emotional intelligence enough?

Well you cant just ask them! All the "tell me about yourself" questions will never reveal their true identity. You must be discreet. You must be devious.

This lecture is about finding the right balance in your expanding team dynamics - analyzing current's team atmosphere and identifying problematic characteristics the candidate might have. After all, we all want to have a perfect match - let me help you with that.
outline:
- 3m Introduction: Who am I and why I am passionate about the subject?
- 8m What might happen if you prioritize technical skills on human skills - My amusing experiences, in the biggest human testing ground this country can provide(the IDF).
- 5m Analyzing your team relations and atmosphere: What are the core bonds? Who is the most dominant and how it affects the others? What can you learn from a common lunch conversation?
- 8m Interviewing like a psychologist: How to secretly challenge the candidate's emotional intelligence. He will be answering some "technical questions", without knowing you are also analyzing his personality.
- 6m Personas matching and decisioning -  Humans are predictable, and they can be matched to personas. When may a candidate's persona harm your team dynamics?
- 5m Q&A.

title: Zen Programming - Become a better version of yourself
abstract:
The Samurai adopted Zen and practiced their daily work to the level of art. They were the best warriors thanks to their ability to be fully engaged and present in the moment.

Zen theory emphasises the importance of meditation and daily practice as away to control your mind and understand the simple truth of our existence. 
Zen is a way of life, work and art.

In the past year I started to learn and practice Zen. 
Step by step Iâ€™m merging Zen practices into my daily routine as a young father, husband and developer.

In this talk I will give you a short intro to Zen ideas and set of practices which can make us to be modern Samurai programmers and our code a piece of art.
outline:
Outline:
1m - Introduction - Zen 101
1m - become a better version of yourself 2.0
How to protect our consciousness? 
How to stay focused? 
How to be stable as a mountain and flow like a river

2m - The Zen programmer - daily work and coding practices
1m - Code as a piece of art

title: Hunting down the silent killers of your team's productivity
abstract:
Bugs vs Features is a daily rat race and a reality for devs everywhere. But havenâ€™t we had enough? How can we find the details that if noticed, would save tons of time and make dev teams happier? Thatâ€™s what this talk is about. I will cover:

â€˜Rebuildâ€™ Button
An â€œinnocentâ€ button gone rogue. Why do we keep pushing it? And should you care?

Jenkins/CircleCI/Docker/AWS sucks
Letâ€™s move past criticizing our tools and juice them for better performance.

Debug Hell
The value of monitoring tools, and why each minute of not using them will turn into hours of debugging. 

Numbers Donâ€™t Lie
How much of our time simply goes down the drain? How can we get the metrics to find issues?
How do we know weâ€™ve fixed them, and how to convince the MGMT these points are crucial.
outline:
1. Who am I and my professional background
2. Some examples from my day to day life on "silent" issues.
3. Why is important?
4. Go over multiple examples (rebuild, debug, build, deploy etc) 
5. How can you find those issues?
6. How to change the management mind?

title: Going the FULL MONTY - Opening our AI blackbox as academic research
abstract:
One of the many challenges faced in building AI solutions for healthcare is gaining clinical buy-in, convincing doctors to trust the â€˜blackboxâ€™. For them, it is a questionable science which they need to understand before trusting AI as part of their work.
To bridge this gap, we have decided to expose the internals of our core algorithm in a scientific publication, in Nature Medicine.
I will discuss why choose this path, what alternatives were considered? Whatâ€™s painful about exposing your IP to the world? How to bridge the worlds of academia and industry research, build the story, prepare the code and experiments, and what workarounds we found to address seemingly impossible technical requirements. Finally, itâ€™s retrospect impact, and how others can benefit from this story.
outline:
- Background : 5 min
                - About myself.
                - About FDNA, what is the main problem we are solving
                - About our solution, high level on how we develop technology (Data, collaborations, research, product)
        - Why we decided to publish our work as a scientific research? 5 min
                - What problems we had and what we tried before.
                - Why this path seemed feasible 
        - The writing process: 5 min
                     - Building the story, what is publishable and interesting? 
                    - Initial version, how bad was it 
                    - identifying the right people to add to the publication, 
                    - feedback from getting feedback from collaborators, and marketing-CEO-Engeneering-academy
        - The review process: 10 min
                - The Process of a scientific publication
                - Review process: timeline, requests, understanding this process
                - How to meet requests a startup cannot handle - release code, release dataset, etcâ€¦ 
                - Make your research reproducible - Dockerize all experiments.
                - Good reviewers will find your wholes, make sure you manage the risk properly
                - Automate data extraction when possible as you may change a lot during the review
                - Managing publication repository (Latex and word)
        - Conclusions: 5 min
            - Learned short list.
            - The archived impact

title: Building a Claw Machine - a Story About Innovation, Teamwork and Winning ðŸ¤–
abstract:
â€Ever dreamt about building your own Arduino machine but never dared to? Youâ€™re not alone.

â€In a 5 days hackathon, with no previous experience or technical knowledge in physical computing, and not even knowing where to start, we built a fully functional claw machine (the kind that fetches puppets), controlled by an Arduino board.

â€In this talk we will share our experience, what challenges we faced and fun things weâ€™ve learned. We will walk you through our journey, from figuring out the materials list, the motors, learning Arduino and electricity, to teamwork, collaboration and even winning the hackathon!
outline:
2m - intro - who are we
3m - intro to project - what's HackWeek, why claw machine
8m - preparations before the Hack week (figuring out and buying the materials, networking)
12m - during the HackWeek: how we organized the project and split it to independent sub-projects. The challenges we faced
3m - what added value we gained from leading such a project (10 people participating) 
2m - sum up +Q&A

title: Predictive Innovation - Understand why customer make choices, and what causes them to buy products
abstract: Predictive innovation is something humanity has always been struggling with.â€¨ We, as product builders, lean too much on gut feeling and a bit of luck when launching new products or introducing new features.â€¨â€¨ People don't just buy products; they hire them to perform a certain job.â€¨â€¨ In this session, I will introduce Jobs-To-Be-Done theory that helps us understand the causality behind people's choices and deconstruct their decision-making process so we can create a replicable process to uncover people's unmet needs and build better products for them
outline:
- Effective Innovation - why it all matters
- The short history of Design Thinking, Personas and the flaws in this approach
- Intro to Jobs-To-Be-Done theory
   - What is a job and why it helps us to uncover customer's unmet needs
   - Understanding the need
   - Examples
- The Process - How to implement it in the organization
   - How to create "Jobs Map"
   - How to analyze the customer desired outcomes
   - How to make the process data-driven and quantifiable
- Growth Matrix
   - How to score the opportunities and analyze competition
   - How to choose the right strategy for your company
- Show two successful use cases of Jobs-To-Be-Done process
   - Airbnb
   - Intercom
- Summary


Timeline: 
Section 1 --> 5 minutes
Section 2 + 3 --> 10 minutes
Section 4 --> 5 minutes
Section 5 --> 5 minutes
Sections 6 + 7 --> 5 minutes

title: The foxiest fox a neural network has ever seen looks like random noise... Wat?
abstract: After training a neural network to decide whether an image is of a dog, cat, fox, or boat, we can do various manipulations to try and understand how it works. One method is to take a single class and optimize an image that would maximize the networkâ€™s conviction of that single classification. For example, we could optimize to generate an image that isnâ€™t just classified as "fox" at 80% confidence, itâ€™s 99.9% fox. For some reason, the result is not foxy at all, itâ€™s a big pile of random noise pixels. Weâ€™ll discuss why that is, how to fix it, and other techniques to improve our understanding of what the neural network is thinking when itâ€™s classifying. Maybe weâ€™ll find the foxiest fox after all.
outline:
1m - How convolutional neural network classification and training works
1m - How we reverse the classification process to generate or modify an image
1m - See and explain various results of this backwards optimization
1m - List and explain techniques how to fix the noise problem
1m - Show image results of these different approaches

title: Live metric monitoring in Python. Not that there's anything wrong with stdout... But...
abstract: How do we launch Python code that runs for hours and once every few seconds updates a chart? Machine learning professionals are more often staring at a terminal than at a line plot. Itâ€™s easy to agree that visualizations are useful but setting them up in all the different environments can be a hassle. Weâ€™ll explore multiple ways to visualize deep learning metrics and the tradeoffs they bring in the console and in notebooks.
outline:
1m - Looking at numbers in stdout
2m - Two ways to use Matplotlib in notebooks
1m - Plotting using unicode in the terminal
1m - Plotting using experiment management solutions (ML and TB)

title: Lessons from hiring engineers and how to screen for culture
abstract: Hiring well in a competitive market is a hard and time consuming task. Moreover, we all want to hire someone which has the technical potential but also fits the team and culture. In this session, Iâ€™ll briefly review the main aspects of hiring engineers and drill down to three aspects which are crucial, but are often overlooked: screening for culture, building the right hiring process and how to learn and constantly improve.
outline:
2m intro: Who am I and my professional background
5m about the problem domain: What are the main aspects of hiring engineers and what are the three that are often overlooked?
7m about hiring processes: Why is hiring a task, just like delivering a user story? Iâ€™ll share some lessons learned from my past and share a guideline to get it right
7m about screening for culture: Why is it so important and some tips about getting it right.
4m about what can you learn from hiring and how to keep improving
5m Q&A

Total time: 30m

title: Stop being surprised at deployment time! A smart error detector
abstract:
Taboolaâ€™s R&D had expanded from ~50 developers to 250 in the past two years. With a fast and effective CICD pipeline we are rolling out releases on a daily basis. Because multiple developers commit new features to the same code base, we had to have a smart error detection tool to prevent a bad merge from happening. This led us to develop an in house Error Detector Mechanism, which is sensitive to the nature of our data.

A development error can be DC specific, and peaks of errors can appear in certain rush hours of the day, certain days of the week, etc. Taking into account these factors, our constantly updating class-specific baselines can detect errors fast, with zero effect on performance, saving money and post mortem analysis effort. 

We invite you to see how it is done at Taboola.
outline:
1. Motivation (2 min)
I will shortly describe the naive error rate alert we used to have, its problems, and also state other products exist in the market and explain why we chose not to use them.

2. Architectural overview (5 min)
I will explain the architecture components and data path for creating the dataset.

3. Creating and updating a baseline (5 min)
I will describe how the class-specific models of errors are being created and constantly updated.

4. Monitoring and Alerting (5 min)
I will show the graphs of errors, filtered by rush hours and special days of the week, and will give an example of an integration with PagerDuty, and a real troubleshooting scenario.

5. Integration with CICD pipeline (5 min)
I will describe how we integrated the error detector tool with our current existing CICD pipeline, and how it made the process more reliable.

6. DB flags and classes white lists (2 min)
I will briefly discuss the edge cases, and the need of whitelists.

7. Future implementations and Q&A (5 mins)
I will elaborate about our future plans regarding the error detector, and answer questions.

Total: 29 min

title: Hacker vs Company, Cloud Cyber Security Automated with Kubernetes
abstract: Looking at the ongoing risks on any company today, no matter how much time and money you'll invest in cyber security as CISO or any security practitioner, You always arrive to same conclusion, it's not enough to achieve high standard of security, you have to do it 24/7. In the talk we'll give a brief overview on different aspects of Cyber Security in the modern world. The "How": We'll share how to build an infrastructure for security researchers that will allow them to concentrate on business logic and writing hacker â€œtasksâ€. Using Docker and Kubernetes on Google Cloud. Lessons learned promised and a glimpse of the Hackers view, because it's always interesting to see how you look from the outside.
outline:
These are the slides of the talk:
https://www.slideshare.net/demibenari/hacking-for-fun-profit-the-kubernetes-way-tal-demi-at-panorays-pyconil-2018

Total time is around: 30 min to 60 min.

title: Why running developer communities made me a better engineer
abstract:
After running developer communities over the past 5 years, meeting a lot of great people and learning a lot of things about the Israeli Hi-Tech ecosystem, Iâ€™ll share all that Iâ€™ve learned about what it actually means to create what is 
called a â€œCommunityâ€. The value that you as a community lead can give to the people in it and the things that you can gain as a geek out of it. Youâ€™ll be surprised to learn how easy and hard it can be at the same time.   
Iâ€™ll tell about the steps that Iâ€™ve taken in this journey, what in my opinion might kill the concept of â€œDeveloper Communityâ€, by the end of the talk you'll have as many tools as possible for you to be able to create a 
community of your own.
outline:
There are the slides of the talk:
https://www.slideshare.net/demibenari/bootstrapping-a-tech-community-demi-benari

The talk takes from 30 min to 45 min - Depending on the content.

title: The art of saying "No" and sucking at it!
abstract:
Things that I've learned as being a tech entrepreneur and as a software engineer is that it's super important to know 
to say "No" to things, more specifically choose which things to decide not doing. It comes in mind even when trying to 
tell the difference between a Junior Engineer and as Senior one, the ability and the skill to know what NOT to do.
Telling from experience of more than 13 years as a software engineer, more than 5 years of running developer communities
and over 3 years as an entrepreneur, I'll mention all the mistakes a long the way, trust me, it's not a success story :)
outline:
5m - Introduction: Who am I and my professional background
5m - Common mistakes of the entrepreneurial world, failures in founding a startup company.
5m - Junior vs. Senior in engineering
5m - Developer communities and outfacing the company as 
5m - Why is it so important to learn to say "No" to things to keep being in focus.
5m Q&A

title: Crypto 101 for Developers/ Common mistakes using cryptographic tool
abstract: In this talk I will provide practical guidelines for using cryptography in many common software engineering tasks. Will cover several common pitfalls of how we can take secure tools and build insecure applications. Some tasks we will discuss include: Encrypting, authentication, session management, data bleaching, and one time tokens. The talk is geared towards experienced software engineers who have limited background in cryptology (e.g 0-2 college courses on crypto & security).
outline:
Intro - 2m 
Encryption modes(ECB) - 3m 
Random (segway via IVs), good sources of randomness, bad sources(UUID) -  3m 
Authentication. General purpose hashing vs KDFs, salt(briefly this is common knowledge) - 3m
Timing attack on user login, Audience participation - 2m 
Insecure hash functions - large state doesnâ€™t mean secure (Python). 3m
Data bleaching, hashing is reversible if we can guess input - 3m 
Malleable encryption, client side session. 3m
Resources and summary - 2m
Buffer&QA - 6m

title: Computerstones - lessons from 40 years of programming
abstract:
When I started my army service in Mamram, I saw for the first time a giant mainframe computer - the IBM 370. It contained 1.6 MB of memory, divided into 8 slots of 200KB, one program runs in each one.
That was 40 years ago. Since then the world of programming has changed dramatically, but some lessons can be learnt from the old days: can you imagine writing your program on a piece of paper, then printing it into a bunch of punched cards? Or that following an exception you'd get a hexadecimal memory dump, on paper (!), and this was your only debugging tool?
Working in the industry today, I can sometimes hardly believe it myself. Software design was key at that time, dry runs and a lot of thought before actually running anything live. 
Is any of it still relevant today? Let's find out!
outline:
Actually the idea came from my daughter, who is a programmer in a high-tech company, and she encouraged me to give a 5 minute talk about the "beginning of programming". 
1m - present my self.
2m talk about computer programming in the "Flinstones age"
2m Which lessons can we take from these times to our days.

title: Applying Software Engineering Methodologies to Data Processing
abstract:
In Outbrain weâ€™ve noticed that big data processing is tricky, Itâ€™s a challenge to estimate delivery time, deliver high quality ETLs and maintain them over time. 
These challenges make life hard for all parties involved: engineers, data scientists, managers and business .
Many of these difficulties may lie in our scarce usage of known software methodologies in the ETL domain, Methodologies such as good variable names, useful comments, testing and runtime alerts.
Weâ€™ll compare these methodologies prevalence in Outbrains code base vs Hive jobs vs Spark jobs and see how we bring more of our software best practices to ETLs
outline:
3m intro on me and Outbrain with emphasis on how data is generated and used
3m on how tasks involving ETLs are challenging to deliver and maintain 

Compare and contrast coding methodologies usage in Outbrains code base vs Hive jobs vs Spark jobs with examples and how to improve:
5m on comment usage 
2m on variable name usage
8m on testing
5m on alerts

4m Q&A

Total: 30 min

title: Lessons learned from 5 years of applying deep learning to medical imaging
abstract:
Automatic analysis of medical imaging is transforming medicine as we speak. However, 
 it is no easy task - the medical imaging domain poses unique challenges in one's way. For example - privacy concerns make obtaining data and labels a major challenge, medical imaging data is not your standard RGB input, can be 3D or even 4D and can often be of huge size. In this talk I will describe some of the challenges we encountered at Viz.ai, how we tackled them, and how this work translates into saving lives.
outline:
- 2m personal intro
- 5m intro of Viz.ai, our mission and vision.
- 5m the mess that is medical imaging and how we make sense of it
- 7m  crowdsourcing of medical annotations 
- 5m handling 3d data - tips, tricks and augmentations
- 6m some cool examples

title: I am an (simple) architect , but i'm also an hands-on developer
abstract:
When my manager offered to become an architect my big concern was..... to be an architect mean that i will stop write a code as a developer.
I'm so happy that my concern didn't turn to be a true.

Having say that.... Many think I'm no longer fit to be a developer
In this talk i will try show that you can be an architect (or a manager) and still be an hands-on developer

We will do it base on code kata (like a 99-bottles Kata) 
I hope that after the talk the opinions a about architect as a developer will be with me
outline:
1min - Subject overview and introduction 
3min - Code kata Demo
1min - Summary and call to action

title: When Machine Learning HitsÂ Reality
abstract:
Whether you are a data scientist or a machine learning developer, you have probably encountered the following scenario: you have a new bright and shiny machine-learning model that you validated with a test-set and it produces great results. Yay! After the successful deployment, users start complaining about the performance of this new model and you wonder - what went wrong?
In this talk, we will map 3 major reasons to explain why machine learning models perform so much better on the test set compared to production and propose ways to avoid this situation.
outline:
â€¢ 2m - Introduction: Who I am and my professional background
â€¢ 3m - describe the problem - after testing the model on a test set and achieving great performance, its performance in production is much worse.  
â€¢ 10m - the main 3 pitfalls that usually cause this situation: 1- biased test set. 2- Overfitting in preprocessing stages. 3- a gap between test implementation and production implementation. 
â€¢ 8m - The solution: how to detect and avoid those pitfalls. 
â€¢ 2m: a quick summary. 
â€¢ 5m Q&A

title: Protecting prod â€“ how to go from partisans to a synchronized team
abstract:
All new teams are familiar with the pain of stressful releases to production. Of not knowing what content was tested, and what wasnâ€™t. Itâ€™s a chaotic environment, and it is difficult for the  team members to be synchronized and effective. In this talk I want to enlighten the audience about  how it is possible to change working patterns within a team and make all members coordinated.
Describing the transition of a new team from incorrect development procedures, mis management of source code, flaky testing habits, both manual and automation, to a robust procedure that allows stress free and fail-safe deployments to production and how my team matured from partisans to an awesome functioning unit that works together.
outline:
1m introduction, me, my position, my team.
1m the problems we had caused by the way we worked â€“ not knowing what code was deployed to production, not testing before deployment
2m â€“ Our solution, how we transitioned to branches for dev and automation and manual qa, and then we know the content of our Master, and that our Master is always production grade so all deployments are stress fee.
1m - wrapup

title: Running Elasticsearch on Kubernetes
abstract:
Elasticsearch, the leading search engine and real-time analytics platform, can scale to hundreds of nodes and easily accommodate huge amounts of data while still preserving sub-second query latency. How cool would it be if we could run it on top of Kubernetes, the leading container orchestration platform?

As it turns out, we can do that easily and safely!

Join us in this talk where we will walk you through how to deploy a production-grade Elasticsearch on Kubernetes while adhering to best-practices of both technologies, keeping your data safe and your availability high.

We will also discuss scaling and auto-scaling of Elasticsearch and the Elastic Stack components while running on Kubernetes, and how the Elastic Stack components can be leveraged to a successful and happy deployment.
outline:
1m about me
2m about this talk + context
3m Elasticsearch concepts
2m K8s concepts
3m deploying a best-practice cluster
3m maintaining cluster
5m scaling and auto-scaling
4m Dealing with catastrophes
2m Relevant Elastic Stack components
5m q&a

title: Public Cloud vs Private Data Center deployments
abstract:
Amazon introduced EC2 back in 2006. Since then, additional vendors introduced similar public cloud offerings. As a result, new applications and businesses were created based on the new features, cost and business models that these public clouds are offering. The question of private vs public deployments keeps being considered in many new as well as existing applications.
The simple logic of "this deployment costs X in private data center and 3X in public cloud deployment" is missing some of the key consideration like: agile architecture changes, flexible consumption models and will likely lead to wrong conclusions.
This talk will focus on a several considerations, based on real life experience, on when it makes sense to use the private data-center and when to use the public cloud.
outline:
- Intro 
- 10m Tradeoffs (HW and SW innovations, usage patterns, upgrade cycles).
- 5m Trivial cases for private clouds
- 10m Real life example
- 5m The human factors and summary

title: Web Components Are Here, itâ€™s Time For You to Know How to Use Them.
abstract:
This lecture focuses on the core of Web Components, it will answer the What, Why and How we use it.
For years, libs & frameworks in JavaScript tried to build components for reuse, but the solutions suffered partially or all from: capsulation, inability to import templates, reuse, no standards. Web Components is the solution, It solves all these troubling issues above for agility, to make the apps more flexible, reusable and stable. It modifies the development approach to be more microservices oriented.
outline:
1) Welcome + Agenda [1m]
2) Motivation for using Web Components [2m]
3) How we solved it in the past [4m]
4) Web Components API [6m]
5) Complete example [10m]
6) Current compatibility / polyfills [1m]
7) Future usage of web components [2m]
8) Thanks & Additional reading [1m]

title: Deep Learning for everyone
abstract: Deep Learning is everywhere, it is the future, it overlooks the backend and the frontend. In this lecture we overview this field and provide a good playground to start from. I will give a good understanding of its jargon, we will highlight the difference between deep learning and machine learning. In addition, we will review the model types (CNN, RNN... etcâ€™) and will touch on the differences between Supervised and Unsupervised. I will continue to talk about the tools that are common today and how as a developer you can harness them to help you. I will try to remove the barriers from this field.
outline:
1) Welcome + agenda [2m]
2) Deep learning vs machine learning [5m]
3) Model types & jargon [10m]
4) Supervised and Unsupervised [2m]
5) Tools [5m]
6) Barriers [5m]
7) Thanks [1m]

title: Your next employee should not be your employee.
abstract:
Companies no. 1 threat for growth is their challenge to operate at full scale due of their inability to hire great talent, or hire almost great talent fast enough. 
This trend is expected to get worse before it gets any better and so, we are faced with two options:
Hire tier 3-4 engineers or rethink the problem as a whole.
The new workforce generation is moving towards more non-traditional employment- freelancing
There is a huge pool of highly talented freelancers, who you are not interacting with today.
It is time for organizations to start experimenting with on-demand talent pools, build knowledge & methodologies, create practices and muscle to operate at full capacity
In this session we will review the landscape, opportunities and look at some examples that are thriving in this economy
outline:
* 1m - The worldwide gap in hiring into technology related jobs
* 1m - The new generation of talented workforce choosing to be freelancers
* 1m - Rapid pace of change in business needs, plans and priorities 
* 1m - Agility and flexibility in how we work with technological talent
* 1m - The set of skills you need to build in order to take advantage of this change
total: 5m

title: Ensuring 100% uptime in the cloud of failing GPUs
abstract:
Viz.ai uses AI to analyze CT scans of stroke patients to facilitate faster detection and treatment. This is a performance critical mission where any failed processing may result in harm to patients (1 minute delay equals the loss of about a week of healthy life to the patient). We leverage AWS GPUs to deploy our deep learning algorithms, and use dynamic allocation to control costs as the traffic changes throughout the day. Ensuring the health of a AWS GPU instance is critical. 

In this postmortem we will tell the story of how we detected a faulty GPU hardware on an AWS instance, and how we now automatically detect and mitigate such GPU hardware failures to ensure 100% uptime.
outline:
-2m personal intro
-5m background on Viz.ai and why our GPU instances are critical 
-4m what happened when an AWS GPU instance had hardware failure
-4m how we now mitigate such issues automatically

title: Pro-Bono Software for NGOs in Israel
abstract:
Israel has many social NGOs that help lot of people. Most of them are technical clueless and don't have anyone that know how software can help them. They desperately need help in defining and writing software tools (like mobile applications, web application etc).

Pro-Bono of software engineers is great help for such NOGs. 

In the short speech I will demonstrate what we do in MicroFocus to help NGOs and what we learned from over the last 6 years.
outline:
1min - who am I
1min - NGO needs
2min - The solution - pro bono development
3min - examples
3min - KODA project - market place from NGOs and developers

title: Graph your way out
abstract: The way we store our data sometimes makes a lot of difference. At Trax, we store our data in relational tabular form, and while this data representation is useful for certain queries and applications, we had a hard time calculating several KPI's and answering certain business questions. In this session, I will present how using a complementary graph representation of our data helped us utilize the geometrical aspects of the shelf to solve problems in a much easier and efficient way and opened a door to new capabilities.
outline:
â€¢ 2m Introduction: Who am I and my professional background
â€¢ 5m Data Representation overview: relational database vs. graph databases. how we store data in Trax.
â€¢ 5m What can we do easily and what not in Trax using the relational tabular form.
â€¢ 13m Introducing a graph representation: why representing our data in graph form, where each node is a product with edges to its neighboring products, thus adding 'spatial awareness' and helping us to compute KPI's that were hard to calculate before, and how it opened the door to other capabilities such as anomaly detection and fraud detection quality improvement, shelf context and more.
â€¢ 3m Examples of other use-cases where the use of graph representations can be beneficial
â€¢ 3m Q&A
Total time: 31m

title: My adventure in the the field of neural networks for information retrieval
abstract:
I started my master's degree at the Technion with no knowledge regarding neural networks(NN) and a lot of motivation to create a better search engine than Google. After 8 months of hard yet interesting work, I came to the conclusion that I will not be able to achieve my goal using the hardware that was at my disposal. 
In this lecture, I will talk about how to start working with NN from scratch and all lessons I learned in the way of applying NN in a domain which requires large amounts of data and NN is not the conventional approach.
outline:
1m - Who am I and my professional background.
1m -Introduction to Neural networks (NN). Basic understanding of the algorithm, why it become popular in recent years and in which domains it consider to be the state of the art
1 m- Introduction to information retrieval ad hoc search.
1 m - NN are algorithms that required a lot of training information.
1m Creative ways to deal with the need for massive size training data (weak labels,  convolution, transfer learning)
3m- Understanding the size of the problem that I tried to solve:
the network architecture 
The training set size 
The amount of memory required to run it
Number of hyperparameters configurations
6m Lessons learned:
The effect of batch size on the network performance and memory consumption
Impact of learning rate on the ability of the network to learn
Recommended learning rate per optimization algorithm
Common ways to reduce the input dimension in text
Sparse matrices in Pytorch
Implementation of new layers in Pytorch
1m Q&A

title: 10 golden rules for data analysis
abstract:
Data-driven decisions is a hot buzzword but it's also a way of life.
All of us (product, engineers, analysts, etc) encounter and analyze a lot of information daily and we are expected to use this information to reach conclusions that will affect our products.
I will talk about how to approach data analysis, discuss common mistakes made in the process (even by experienced data veterans), share examples from my own experience and provide tips and guidelines for analysis and visualization.
outline:
* Into 1m

1.     Everything that can go wrong will go wrong / Donâ€™t trust anyone (especially not yourself ). (3m)
In this section I talk about what to do when a chart seems to have a big spike / drop and what can cause it. I also go over common â€œdata errorsâ€ such as date formatting, timezones etc.

2.     Is it that time of year again? (2m)
In this section I cover daylight saving time and time changes and how errors caused by companies forgetting about it

3.     AB test everything (including the test) (2m)
Iâ€™ll talk about the why AB tests are awesome and guide lines and tips on how to run and test them.

4.     Donâ€™t get scared of a lot of data. (1m)
what to do when you are not data savvy and got a lot of log / row data. Main point is not to panic, taking it bite-sized and following the next rules

5.     Use whatever tool you want (2m)
selecting the right tool for your analysis process, using something you are comfortable with, excel is a great tool I use but a developer might prefer Pyton or a data person SQL. The point is that at the first stages of an analysis, where you are still unsure what you are looking for exactly its more important to use a tool you already know and then switching to something you can replay and share (like a BI tool)

6.     Pivot and breakdown (4m)
how to slice the data methodologically to find what you are looking for when investigating something. I show a clear example of a problem clearly seem when broken down by a specific dimension.

7.     Always ask why (1m)
the importance as a data person to not just provide the answers but to truly understand the business / product question behind it. Just showing a trend and making it look like what we want is definitely not the way to be data-driven

8.     Anything can influence your numbers (5m)
I show an interesting example of an investigation I made while working at conduit, I had sporadically looking a drop in search data that I was trying to pin point its cause (so we can fix it). What was the actual reason and how I found it. I also explain the connection of holidays, big events or other reasons your website traffic or app usage might be affected by real world and unrelated reasons.

9.     Think about it again in the shower (2m)
what to do when you are stuck on a problem / analysis. My main point is to clear you head and talk to other people about it. Also a coffee brake is always a good idea.

10.  Visualizations are your friend (5m)
charts, how to do them correct, what not to use and common mistakes.
* Q&A 2m

title: How to become data driven in 5 minutes or less
abstract: we all want to make smart decisions (based on data) but often end up going with gut feelings. In this short talk, I will try to cover: why it's so important to really on data, how to get to a data-driven mindset, cover some basics on what the organization need to do so and  some quick high level tips
outline:
* why do we want to be data-driven 1m
* what does it mean to be data-driven 1.5m
* what are the basics that we need 1m
* some tips 1.5m

title: Hybrid Web App â€“ Angular & React, the love story
abstract:
Have you ever received an FE application as a gift from your manger? You were so happy ðŸ˜Š!
But when you opened it you didn't like what you saw!!
You didn't like the design, you didn't like the implementation, the build processes are too long and not clear, packages are not maintained, and a lot of dead code, not to mention lots of bugs and the poor UI/UX.
Then you said to yourself â€œwhy should I do this to myselfâ€? Why work with bad infrastructure? It's like putting a band aid on a wound and not really solving it.
Then, you see the light! Why not build it from scratch? But how will I do it? I canâ€™t just revise the code. I need a gradual evolution, with the two applications running together.
Where to start? What will the design be like? Build process? Communicate & routing between them?
outline:
â€¢	2m Introduction: Who am I and my professional background
â€¢	5m history of the legacy project and what lead us to turn to hybrid
â€¢	5m build process â€“ how to host a sub project in the main project
â€¢	7m routing strategies
â€¢	5m communication 
â€¢	3m routing issue
â€¢	3m Q&A

Total time: 30m

title: How to grow and stay small?
abstract: Something changes in companies when they grow above 150 employees. But it is not only possible to achieve exponential business Growth with a steady head count, itâ€™s also more fun, engaging and effective. Instead of hiring, focus your efforts in Growth dev, marketing and the happiness of your employees.

title: The Art of Printing
abstract:
Once upon a time printing was a major part of any system developed. Documents, reports and manifests were the ultimate output. But today everyone hate paper. Not only it's bad for the environment, you can't even zoom-in or search in it!

Alas, sometimes a web project demands you to enable your users to print from the client side. So before you dive into the muddy pool of paper margins,  page breakers and footer-header sections let me tell you about the print @media query and how it allows you to develop a print layout which is non intrusive to your on-screen design.

In this talk I'll share all the secrets, hacks and tips to make you a lean mean printing machine.
outline:
2m Intro.
5m Overview - different kinds of printing scenarios (client vs server) and the issues they rise.
10m - Printing on-screen data. How to make your design printer friendly without hindering normal layout
10m - Printing documents - How to print branded documents such as receipts, invoices or letters.
3m - Q&A

title: Reduce AI data preprocessing with PyWren and IBM Cloud Functions
abstract:
Data is one if not the most important component today to make a great machine learning process. but data itself sometimes isnt enough and you have to process it in some way to make it ready for machine learning, this process can take time.
In this lecture I will demonstrate how serverless computing can provide a great benefit for AI data preprocessing. as an example I will take face recognition deep learning using the Watson Machine Learning service, while letting PyWren with Cloud Functions do the data preparation phase. This makes an entire process up to 50 times faster compared to running the same code without using serverless computing.
outline:
- 1 m about the problem and the tools we have today
- 2 m about the tools that I can use to solve the problem
- 2 m demonstration of the code and the process
Total time : 5 min

title: Functional Reactive Programming: What Does It Solve? Does It Solve Things? Let's Find Out!
abstract: Reactive Extension (Rx) libraries are everywhere, with the promise that they will make our code more declarative, less prone to bugs and overall simpler. But there is a price to pay for this simplicity â€“ the Rx learning curve is notoriously steep. So before we jump head-first into yet another paradigm that promises to solve all our problems, letâ€™s figure out what exactly there is to gain. In this talk weâ€™ll look at some common front-end problems, and their proposed solutions in RxJS, and try to answer the question - does FRP really make our lives easier?
outline:
In this talk I will review common problems we face in front-end and the way they can be solved under the Functional Reactive paradigm, as it is implemented in RxJS. Use cases will include: polling, auto-suggest (two common examples, where RxJS has clear benefits), consistency problems (updates from both user and server that need to be displayed quickly and consistently), animations, and handling multiple user interactions. Beyond demonstrating the approach to these problems, I will present a discussion as to the benefits and costs of applying this paradigm. 
1 min - intro
2 min - overview of FRP and RxJS
5 minutes each - examples - covering the use case and the code to achieve it in RxJS. Polling and auto-suggest will take 5 minutes together, since they are relatively well-known examples, so 4 examples total.
5 minutes - summary
total - 28 minutes

title: How to open a bug on an open source project without alienating the maintainer
abstract:
We all work with open source projects and wish to report bugs or missing features that we need to be fixed. Maintainers of open source project frequently context switch between reports from completely different production setups and workloads, causing a long wait until those are handled.
In this short talk, I will illustrate the right way to open a bug report for an open source project that will help the maintainer, rather than alienate them, and speed up the resolution!
outline:
1m introduction
3m tips on good bug report: validate, describe setup, describe actions and how to reproduce, what was the expected outcome? what actually happened?
2m summary

title: SALE. 90% Off. 10x Performance + 10x Cost Reduction in your Big Data systems.
abstract:
Our talk walks you through the process of re-architecting huge expensive cloud systems to run leaner and cheaper (MUCH, MUCH cheaper). Weâ€™ll show you how by walking you through 2 of our projects that improved performance by 10x and drove costs down by 90% - saving $2,000,000/year.

You will hear about where to start, what to look for, what ideas to try and which ones to drop. Weâ€™ll show you how weâ€™ve solved these issues on the cloud, using Serverless, EC2, FAAS and Spark clusters. You will see expensive code examples and The Fast and Furious code that makes it CHEAPER.

At the end of this talk, you too will have the recipe for re-architecting your systems to run FASTER, BETTER, CHEAPER.
outline:
2m introductions: who we are and a bit about nielsen
2m agenda and WIFM: what are we going to talk about and what will the audience learn
4m overview: what is cost reduction, when cost reduction is needed, is it always worth it
8m first project: 1m overview, 2m pain points, 2m solutions, 1m results
8m second project: 1m overview, 2m pain points, 2m solutions, 1m results
5m cook-book
1m summary

title: Deeper Than Abstractions II â€“ React Hooks and Suspense
abstract:
In late 2018 the React team announced the introduction of Hooks â€“ a new API that enables the use of state and lifecycle methods in functional components. The Suspense API is in its early days, but will soon be used for data fetching, and the combination of the two will essentially make class components redundant.
This raises the question - how does React do that? How does it make the setState mechanism and lifecycle methods accessible without inheritance from React Component? And what does it actually mean that Suspense â€œsuspends renderingâ€? Time to dive into library internals, again! Letâ€™s look at Reactâ€™s source code and figure out whatâ€™s going on under the hood here.
outline:
This talk is a similar concept to the one I did last year, this time focusing on the new APIs in React, which are game-changers!
Intro: 1 m
Overview of hooks and suspense: 5 m
Hooks source code review and explanation: 10m. Focused on the question - how does React make this functionality (usually accessible through inheritance) available in a functional way.
Suspense source code review and explanation: 10 m. Focused on the question - what does it mean internally to suspend the rendering of a subtree, and how will this be used in the future for data fetching.
summary: 2m

Total: 28m

title: Don't reuse. Don't abuse.
abstract:
The bad kind of code reuse, with everyday examples.
I will present (in a humorist way) the reasons for avoiding code reuse.
Also, by attending, you might learn a new cake recipe !
I will also cover a few practical DO and DO NOT advices for real life coding. Be sure to bring your "ctrl-c" and "ctrl-v" buttons along.
outline:
1m - Intro to what is wrong with code reuse
2m - A world where Cake Recipes have Polymorphism & Dependency Injection
1m - How I grew to hate my previous self in 10 minutes of coding.
1m - Do's and Do not's. Actual advice.

title: S2Utilities - Geo utils for everyone, easily, the Google way
abstract:
https://github.com/dmarcous/S2Utilities
This projects aims at providing a set of tools to make working with geospatial objects quick and painless. These tools were designed with S2 objects (Google's "geometry on a sphere" abstractions) in mind as the leading data structure to be used when working with geospatial data.
* Written in Scala
outline:
1m : Why I wrote it (AKA "The problem")
2m : What's in it (AKA "The solution")
2m : S2 library - what is it good for?
3m : Code examples (AKA "Quickstart")
2m : Q&A

title: Hyperparameter Tuning (Optimization) for Large Deep Learning Models
abstract:
When learning from complex data such as medical scans or video feed we encounter long training periods and large memory demands. This makes searching for the best set of hyperparameters a hard to nearly impossible task. Most researchers simply try a few sets of hyperparameters by trial and error or use a grid search at best. These hyperparameters are usually chosen by some intelligent guess based on prior knowledge. It is clear to see this is not the best practice. A more DATA DRIVEN approach required.

In this session, we will learn practical methods to search for the best set of hyperparameters under an arbitrary limit of resources (run time or machine cost) by selecting the correct optimization algorithm and training settings.
outline:
1m - Introduction and mission state
1m - Tuning DEEP neural networks
1m - Open source tools
1m - Best practices
1m - Results

title: From 0 to 1 in $0 and 100 hours
abstract:
From the moment they click "Submit" for this session description, Shem and Eyal will embark on a journey to launch a side project to production.
They'll have less than 90 days and no more 100 hours to dedicate for it. They'll rarely meet in person, and will probably work at different hours.

See the results of this experiment, and hear about the challenges they faced.
If they succeed, you'll get the blueprints.
If they fail, you'll have a cautionary tale and know exactly what not to do with your side project.
outline:
- Problem: A lot of people don't start a side project or a proof of concept (POC) because they are worried it will be too hard.
- Some of their concerns:
  1. People think building a POC will take them a lot of time
  2. People think building a POC will cost them a lot of money
  3. People think building a POC with more than one person is hard
- Motivation: building this kind of projects will make you grow, get you out of your comfort zone and let you create awesome things.
- As ones that constantly have side projects and building things from scratch in our work, we feel that it's really important and much easier than you think
- We picked an (almost) random project and show you that it's possible, by logging every step in the way
- Detailed report on how we made it
- Tips:
  1. How to pick the right product
  2. How to start
  3. How to find the time
  4. How to manage this whole thing
  5. How to be efficient
  6. How to focus on the right things
  7. What are the tools out there that will help you save time and money
- Summary: you can do it!

title: How we used Large-scale AI inference to find the Medical Imaging Zebras?
abstract:
Medical Imaging AI uses deep learning to assist radiologists in recognizing findings.  Zebra Medical Vision is aiming to develop algorithms that "find the Zebras" (why we are called Zebra?)
Testing our algorithms performance is subject to many challenges, specially when tagging Â significant amount of data requires enormous efforts. 

I will present two use cases, in two algorithms where we developed a distributed dockerized reproducible pipeline system, enabling running multiple instances of algorithms parallelly. 

We used large scale inference to evaluate emulated T-score, that measures lumbar spine density from CT scans, and Pneumothorax identification, a rare acute finding from Xray scans.
Results of analyses done on these runs helped us evaluate performance during development process.
outline:
3 m introduction: Zebra medical scope and vision and me
3 m background
3 m methodology and tool
5m results
5m results meaning - discussion and what we learned
3 m conclusion and future directions
5 m Q&A

title: How we Built a High Performing Engineering Organization by Hard Resetting our Hiring & Onboarding Pr
abstract: Have you ever found yourself struggling to build an engineering organization that is quality-driven with consistently great results?  When we analyzed why we didnâ€™t feel our organization was performing at the level we had anticipated, we reverse engineered this to fundamental issues with our culture.  Once we started working on this it had a ripple effect to our hiring process & then our onboarding process as well.  This talk will dive into how we refactored our hiring & onboarding to set up new hires for success from day one. This ultimately delivered a well-oiled high performing engineering organization through a practically applicable methodology that is easily replicable. This not only enabled us to improve the quality of our hires, but also retain excellent talent in the long-term.
outline:
Intro & Problem Statement - 5 Mins
How we diagnosed our pain points & friction - 5 mins
Rebuilding our culture to drive better engineering practices - 5 mins
How this drove us to rethink our hiring and onboarding 5-10 mins
Tips to apply this in your engineering organization - 5 mins
Q&A - pending time

title: How We Went All-In on Reducing Technical Debt - And Lived to Tell the Tale
abstract: Imagine the technical debt of a startup in exponential growth for 6 consecutive years (5 engineers to 160, 10M daily events to over 70B). Until the last 2 years the team focused on product expansion with an â€œif it ain't broke donâ€™t fix itâ€ attitude, resulting in inherent bugs, system instability & more than 80% of the team's focus on maintenance. This will be a tale of how we went all-in on reducing technical debt by allocating more than 70% of the team for 1.5 years to reduce debt. I will share how we rewrote our core engine; almost 2 years into the process we managed to reduce the maintenance effort, number & severity of production issues & increased our velocity significantly. It was all possible due to a craftsmanship culture weâ€™ve been cultivating which grew stronger with the process
outline:
- Intro to AppsFlyer & Tech Stack - 5 Mins
- Engineering Culture - 5 Mins
- Accumulating technical debt over the years - 5 Mins
- War story about rewriting our core engine and other core services to brink us back from the cliff's edge - 10 mins
- Key takeaways and lessons learned - 5 Mins

title: Once upon a code
abstract:
We read other peopleâ€™s code 80% of the time. While our code feels like a backyard playground, others code tend to be a scary jungle. Why is it like that? And what can we do about it?
Let me show you some eye opening tips for turning this frustrating day to day task into a nice - even preferred - one (hint: it can tune your brain, just like training a machine learning model!)
outline:
During the first years of my professional life, I used to say â€œwell, Iâ€™m a programer, not a poetâ€, didnâ€™t put enough attention on naming, ordering, or anything that has to do more with the english language then pure algorithmic logic. Computers will understand me anyway, wonâ€™t they?.. This approach changed a lot since then.
We find ourselves diving into others code when trying to integrate our just-being-written code into an already existing block of code, when trying to take over an existing component, or as part of a code review. It always takes longer than it should, never a paradise.
I will start with a cool exhibition demonstrating the difference between the way a programer writes code, the way a co-worker reads it, and the way a computer runs on it. (ref: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Hs8rDvC3GZg&feature=youtu.be)
Then, Iâ€™ll explore few tips for handling it easier (the â€œchains of actionsâ€ approach, the code-style approach)
At the end, Iâ€™ll give a motivation for reading as much code as possible.

title: Large-scale Medical Imaging AI inference using Big Data tools for model performance estimation
abstract:
Medical Imaging AI identifies patterns in medical imaging, assisting radiologists improve their ability to recognize acute findings. However, human radiologist tagging resources limitations, result in relatively small pre-engineered testing datasets which sub-optimally represent wide population, especially when findingâ€™s prevalence is low. We used a distributed dockerized reproducible pipeline for large scale inference of a Pneumothorax recognition model from chest x-ray, a rare acute finding. 
Methods
We randomly selected a big cohort of xray scans, ran inference on scale and analyzed results. We estimated yield (successful run rate) and False Positive Rate, which assisted evaluating user experience and improve development process by pointing out possible algorithm pain points.
outline:
3 min Zebra and mine intro
3 min Background
2 min the tool and what we did
5 min results of analysis
5 discussion and conclusions and how we benefit from this process
5 m Q&A

title: Tell me about yourself - How a good job interview should be and why.
abstract:
Everyone goes through a lot of job interviews in their life, but many don't realize what the actual purpose of the technical interview is. Candidates arrive to interviews geared up for a battle with the interviewer, interviewers ask irrelevant questions, and everyone ends up stressed.
I want to share my vision of what the purpose of the interview is, how to achieve it, and how can the candidate show the best side of themselves during it.
I think that this talk can be of great help to developers who are job hunting and having stress with interviews, and also to the leaders who are struggling with how to find the right people.
outline:
2m - Introduction
5m - Discuss the guiding principles - the interview is not there to trick the candidate but to bring out the best of them - the interview needs to give the candidate all the chances to succeed, it needs to be personalized to the person..

Breakdown of the interview parts
3m - 'Tell me about yourself' - the first part of general storytelling, why it's there, what the interviewer gets from it, what the candidate should focus on and why
5m - Programming questions - what to ask, what gives a good insight into the candidate's level and what is too dependent on luck / prior experience
5m - Non-programming questions - 'thinking tests' - why there's no place for riddles in an interview , how to challenge the candidate. The importance of tailoring the questions to the candidate's strengths and experience.
5m - Technical test - Why I believe each candidate has to write code at their interview. How to pick a good test challenge, how to grade it. The importance of followup questions.
5m - Q&A

Total - 30

title: the monk how ran the algorithm -meditation as a data science use case
abstract:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AoB5bAGk8ms

We use algorithms and the data science process in every facet of our lives.

In this lecture we will explore the data science process with an unorthodox use case: Meditation.
By running the meditative algorithm on our own Dataset (our mind) we can optimize our experience of life and find insight into our own mind-body phenomena. 
At the end of this session you will look at the data science process in a new light:
â€¢	The stages of data science process (and their meditative counterpart)

â€¢	Understand the difference between the data science process and the scientific process  
â€¢	How to apply the approach in different context
â€¢	And as a bonus a new way to look at meditation
outline:
â€¢	3m Introduction: Who am I and Me and Meditation
o	    Me as a developer and data science  
o	    Me as a meditator
â€¢	3 The data science process			
â€¢	3 m Business Objective
o	    Minimize suffering
o	    Understand the Mind-Body phenomena 
â€¢	4m Exploratory Data Analyses
o	    Understand the scope of suffering
o	    Cause and correlations to suffering
o	    Identify elements that reduce suffering 
o	    Execute Methodologies to reduce suffering 
â€¢	4m Metrics
o	    Concentration 
o	    Mindfulness 
â€¢	5m Run the Model (meditation tanning)
o	    Zen (simplest model)
o	    Body scan
â€¢	3m Explanatory Hypothesis (Science)
o	    3 main parts of the brain
o	   The Somatic feedback loops
o	    Create the gap between feeling and thinking 
â€¢	1m Stack Overflow (enlightenment)
â€¢	4m Q&A
30m

title: Breaking Down Our Billion User Reach with HyperLogLog
abstract:
Measuring unique users in a billion user network is hard - accurate counting is space consuming and not easily distributable.

In this talk I will describe HyperLogLog, a probabilistic cardinality estimation algorithm and data structure and how we used it to provide breakdowns of our billion user reach.
outline:
5m: Introduction, what business requested
5m: Count is easy, count distinct is hard
5m: Intuitive example of probabilistic estimation
10m: HyperLogLog algorithm explanation and demo
5m: Implementation in production and summary
Total time: 30m

title: Cut your service latency with adaptive double dispatch
abstract:
Serving millions of requests per minute with a microservices environment is not an easy task. Every request is routed to many applications, and may potentially stall or fail at any step in the flow. 
Needless to say, not every one of the hundreds of microservices was written by the strongest coderâ€Šâ€”â€Šwhich means that context switches, gc spikes or just inefficient code could creep up on you at any moment
We always try to find ways to reduce latency, and one elegant and efficient ways is using adaptive double dispatch, which I will cover in this talk
outline:
1m - how does you latency graph looks like
1m - what's wrong with timeout
1m - what is double dispatch
1m - what's wrong with constant thresholds?
1m - what is adaptive double dispatch and why it improves latency

the talk is based on this blogpost:
https://medium.com/outbrain-engineering/cut-your-microservice-latency-with-adaptive-double-dispatch-64911b1b707f

title: Troubleshoot through your users' eyes
abstract:
Analytic data, heat maps and screen recordings are the bread and butter of improving the user experience. By using these tools, we can literally see and understand our usersâ€™ behavior and from there, translate these insights into an even better experience.

But do these tools help us understand and solve technical problems? Here at Soluto, yes! They help us in understanding our usersâ€™ experience from a technical perspective. 

In this session, Iâ€™d like to share how common tools like screen recordings help us troubleshoot through our usersâ€™ eyes. This process gives us invaluable data and helps us gain empathy for our users in order to turn our products from good to exceptional.

title: Pay It Backwards: How Learning New Languages Can Benefit Your Current Language Skills
abstract:
As developers, we sometime hear the advice to "go learn a new programming language every year". But why?
In this talk, I will suggest that other than keeping up with current trends, exploring new languages makes us better coders in the ones we use today.
You'll hear about our own experience at Riskified, where we found that working on greenfield Scala apps helped in levelling up our existing Ruby codebase.
Come and get inspired about geeking-up and exploring new territories! Also, you might figure new ways to convince your boss that reading blogs and books at work is, in fact, time well spent!
outline:
Since this is a lightning talk suggestion, I didnâ€™t feel time estimations are relevant. The following should be my main slides:

* Hypothesis - go learn a new programming language every year
* Background story:
** Presenting my happiness with Ruby as my primary language for a some time
** Comes in a new language - my team gets to be in charge of a new application in Scala
** How I went through an in-house Scala training that got me excited about the language
* Longing for missing features:
** How I felt secure building APIs with Scalaâ€™s type system
** How I then needed to talk to a Ruby app and missed that very thing I loved about building a Scala API
** How I found a community of Ruby devs that feel like me, who developed libraries to solve those problems (a library called dry-rb)
* It clicked! : How my colleagues loved this new development experience in Ruby, and adopted dry-rb wholeheartedly
* Conclusion: keep learning new languages and technology and actively look for goodies to bring back to your base language(s).

title: Building event sourced systems with Kafka Streams
abstract:
Apache Kafka is a battle tested stream-processing platform. Combined with Kafka Streams API, itâ€™s possible to build scalable, fault-tolerant and distributed event driven systems.

In this talk, I will describe the key components of an event sourced system, and how simple building blocks can be combined using the powerful and declarative streams API to deliver business value. I will demonstrate possible solutions for the challenges of eventual-consistency and the object-relational impedance mismatch.
outline:
* About me
* About Wix
* Short intro on Wix Invoices (the event-sourced service we wrote)
* CRUD and the object-relational impedance mismatch
* Event sourcing 101
    * Event sourcing is a loose paradigm, which many flavors (even in Wix)
    * High level overview of Eventim (the event sourcing infrastructure we wrote)
    * Challenges (rebuilding views, transactionality, eventual consistency)
* Kafka streams 101
    * Streams vs tables
    * Kafka streams application
    * Architecture
    * Stream DSL vs KSQL
        * join / filter / map / flatMap / ...
* Demo
* Tradeoffs
* Takeaways

title: Building your own Serverless CDN & URL Shortener
abstract:
Static file hosting - from your CV to large media files - is a handy tool for sharing files that are either too large or change frequently. URL shortening enables you to track the usage of links you share online, and make professional-looking links that start with your own domain name.
In this session I will show how I created these two services with Serverless tools with a near-zero cost and ~200 Lines of code. We will review the design and dive into code. This session should be helpful for developers who wish to build Serverless applications and reason about their architecture. No prior Serverless knowledge is assumed.
outline:
# Motivation
Serverless is one of the most powerful tools under a cloud developer's belt. This session teaches practical and architectural insights and best practices by walking through an actual design.

# Repo
The source code for this session will be shared publicly, and developers with a public cloud account will be able to create their own services within minutes.

# Outline
* 1m `whoami`
* 4m Intro to Serverless: Pay for what you use and never worry about scaling. In Hebrew - ×ž×©×¨×ª×™× ×œ×©×™×¨×•×ª×™×.
* 4m The problems I'm solving: Why is a private CDN so cool? What's special about URL Shortening? Examples: Honeypot (sending a tiny URL to a malicious party), "Did they open my CV"
* 6m Architecture and design: DNS and Domain (Route53), CDN, Static hosting (S3), Serverless DB (DynamoDB), FaaS (AWS Lambda) functions, equivalents on other clouds, and why I chose these building blocks
* 5m Magic - Infrastructure as code - coding my architecture! (with The Serverless Framework , possibly showing Alternatives  like CloudFormation, Terraform)
* 5m Reviewing the Lambda code
* 5m recap and spare time

title: Stop being discreet: thoughts about today's hiring process
abstract:
Send your CV to hiring agencies, *discreetly*. Slack off for interviews giving awkward excuses to your team mates. Get an offer, give your boss a 30-days notice, and start your new job.

Every part of this description is wrong!

In this session I will try to persuade you that you quitting *before* applying to jobs is the most efficient way of getting your dream position, and why hiring agencies and friends are just one channel for hiring (hint: VCs).
outline:
# Planned Outline

* My own hiring (hi)story
* Getting a job today: agencies, discreet search, last-minute notice. American influence
* Why is it broken?
  * Shallow reach
  * No references from current employer
  * Short notice causing mayhem
* The alternative: Give long notice, make your search public, give your employer a chance to improve your settings
* The huge benefit: larger reach!
* The Hiring agency's broken incentives
*  Alternative hiring channels: VCs, Twitter, Meetups
* Recap

title: Scheduled tasks - from cloud native to kubernetes
abstract:
A major way for us at Soluto to communicate with our customers is through emails, and email sending is a recurring task that is being activated after some decision making process (either manually or by a program).
Scheduled tasks are a well known concept, existing in native cloud platforms for years, but did you know that you can use the kubernetes abstraction to run them on top of any platform with ease?
In this talk I will walk you through our journey from running scheduled tasks on custom native cloud solutions to eventually using kubernetes cronjobs.
outline:
* 2m of a quick overview of my professional background
* 2m of overview of what we do in Soluto and examples of critical scheduled tasks we use
* 10m journey through the native cloud solutions and what was problematic in each one
* 10m about the kubernetes cronjobs - what is it and how we use it
* 5m comparing the different solutions - you should fit the tool to the problem!
* 1m Q&A

title: Security â€“ only developers can make it proactive
abstract:
Whether we use high-level languages like Java, Python, C# or we dive into the world of C/C++, the lists of dependencies of our projects contain more and more external frameworks and libraries. It makes developersâ€™ life easier and helps us to focus on delivering business value. Are you sure you know all the tips and tricks to use the framework in a correct way?

Join me during an exciting LIVE DEMO. Get to know how to weaponize known Spring Boot Data Rest library vulnerability. See how to use Remote Code Execution to actually fully compromise the server hosting an application. Using the vulnerability in an actual attack uncovers the underlying mechanism and to find the detection patterns if it is attempted to be exploited on our infrastructure. And have fun to hack the servers!
outline:
3m: Introduction: Who am I and my professional background
5m: Long dependencies list in our projects, the current approach to penetration tests and updating components
2m: What have I changed? The proactive approach to components updating
3m: Deep dive into CVE found in our services
10m: LIVE DEMO: Steps which I had to make to be able to compromise server with use of RCE
2m: Summary: There are examples of vulnerabilities, which are fixed not with a single patch, but rather through a series of upgrades leading to more secure solutions, so it is important to stop for a while and think about other attack paths. We can do much better than just blindly upgrading components!
5m: Q&A

title: DIY Lambda-like platform - The magic behind the scenes.
abstract:
We wanted to enable our end users to write and execute their own code in our platform. â€¨Here enters...â€¨
Function as a Service (FaaS). It enables developers to instantly write, deploy and run their code with absolutely no DevOps concerns.â€¨â€¨

With one click you can instantiate a function that serves millions of requests, scaling up to thousands per usage.â€¨â€¨

Discover the HOWs and DOsâ€¦
â€¨- Functions lifecycle.
â€¨- How an FaaS instance works.
- Elasticity and scalabilityâ€¨
- Cold-start and moreâ€¦â€¨â€¨

Join us in a journey, raise the curtain and understand how a serverless FaaS platforms works using tools such as Kubernetes, Knative, Istio, GIT and more.
outline:
â€¢ 1m - Muaâ€¨
â€¢ 3m - What is an FaaS platformâ€¨
â€¢ 3m - Hands-on demo: Terminal experience function deployment from creation through run time and finally hibernation.â€¨
â€¢ 10m - Micro and Macro: Dive into the micro of how the function instance works including a high-level view of how a DIY platform handles the lifecycle.â€¨
â€¢ 3m - Lifecycle breakdown: Understand how to update an existing function and revert back to older revisions.
â€¨â€¢ 5m - HOWs & DOs: Handling scalability, cold-start, function tests, etc...â€¨
â€¢ 5m - Q&A

title: Building a modern, cheap and open-source data-warehouse
abstract:
For many organizations data is where the money is, but storing all data forever is often times too expensive and unfeasible.

Luckily, today is easy to build data-lakes and data-warehouses that are cheap to build and maintain. Efficient querying on cold data, extended SQL language with features like geo-spatial queries, joins between different data sources (SQL to join data from HDFS, Elasticsearch and Kafka anyone?), and the ability to run on containers and cheap servers - all are features you can and expect from your data-warehouse technology.

In this talk we will present Presto, a Distributed SQL Query Engine for BigData. We will discuss data architectures, Presto features and why is it so good for your data, and then the challenges of ETL and maintaining it for the long run.
outline:
1m about me
3m challenges we want to solve
2m about presto
5m presto features
5m data architectures
5m challenges: ETL, data migrations, data updates
5m maintaining Presto
5m q&a

title: Load Time Screen: Itâ€™s All About Transparency
abstract:
One of the challenges that development teams face across the world, is optimising a product to achieve fast load times while maintaining performance and quality. 
Monitoring performance is a key aspect of an engineering team, though in some cases, using third party services, or imprecise indicators (like network issues), might affect performance. 

Introducing a runtime, deep analysis tool named â€œLoad Time Screenâ€ which visualises the loading phases and adds transparency to the loading sequence, lets us investigate reasons for slow load time of a specific instance. This allows support teams and R&D teams to get better information from the client and identify issues. 

In this talk, I will demo and elaborate on this technique, why itâ€™s important and how to implement it in your product.
outline:
â€¢ 2m Introduction: Who am I and my professional background
â€¢ 5m About the technique, why its important and how R&D teams can use it to improve their product and the communication with the customers
â€¢ 3m Demo of existing "Load Time Screen" in production
â€¢ 20m Code Code Code (Vanilla Javascript) - we will implement a Load Time Screen together inside a cool project

title: A Complete Serverless Stack in 3 Commands - Knative
abstract:
When asked to create an FaaS solution I was confused. What is serverless? What is FaaS? Why are we here? It seemed like everyone had a different answer.

In the end, I realized I had to create my own personal definition: â€¨
	â€¢	Allow the end user to post a snippet of code.â€¨
	â€¢	Run it on demand.

Two steps, thatâ€™s it! â€¨Learn how you can do it in 3 bash commands in under five minutes with Knative!!
outline:
- 1m - what is serverless stack?â€¨
- 1m - 1. Install Istio - What is it?â€¨
- 1m - 2. Install Knative - What is it?â€¨
- 1m - 3. Create a function - What happened?
- 1m - Run the created function

title: Refactoring Frenzy - Respect your IDE, and it will respect you too
abstract:
Every second, Legacy code is being written everywhere in the world for poor unfortunate future maintainers to "delight" upon.. The best weapon against legacy and code decay is the art of refactoring.
In this session I'll be live coding in "frenzy mode" in order to refactor the famous Gilded Rose code Kata, while harnessing Intellij IDE to my advantage.
outline:
~ 0.5m  Who I am and why we are here
~ 1m    Presenting the concept of code Kata and how practice makes perfect while setting expectations about the speed and the importance of staying sharp throughout the session
~4m     Presenting the requirements to what we are about to do, presenting the code as well as some guidelines and techniques 
~22m   Live refactoring and coding              
~2.5m  Summary and Q&A

Total time: 30m

title: Distributed Data Processing
abstract:
Data processing at scale has wide challenges: each framework has a different approach on how to write the code, and they differ between batch and streaming. Operations-wise, building and maintaining a cluster for distributed data processing has a lot of overhead and cost, even if youâ€™re using a semi-managed cloud provider solution.


Google Cloud Dataflow developed a unified batch and streaming data processing SDK that became an open source as Apache Beam. Beam supports multiple execution engines like Spark, Flink and Google Cloud Dataflow.

In this talk, weâ€™ll see how a unified model helps solve many use cases of data processing at scale, and how the Google Cloud Dataflow managed service reduces the operations overhead to zero as your data and business needs grow.
outline:
1m: Introduction
5m: Why frameworks like MapReduce and Spark hard to write
10m: Google Cloud Dataflow & Apache Beam SDK use-cases and how to write jobs
10m: Google Cloud Dataflow fully managed service features and how itâ€™s solve different devops concerns.
4m: end2end use case for data pipeline to solve ride sharing problems 
Total time: 30m

title: Break the data workflow complexity
abstract:
So you need to move some data from here to there in some given time - easy! You write a few scripts and let *nix Cron handle the tasks. Then you realize that you need a more robust solution with some dependency between tasks and more visualization on them, so you build a few pipelines in Jenkins to handle that. As the data and business needs grow, handling scheduled tasks for different missions at scale becomes too complex:

* Task dependencies (fan-in / fan-out) 
* Task priorities & SLA
* Task modularity
* Multiple data sources
* Parallelize tasks 
* Visualization of tasks over time
* Task logging
* Task timeouts
* Retries on failure
* Notifications on task error 

In this talk we will take a deep dive into Apache Airflow, and how it helps us solve that complexity.
outline:
1m: Introduction
5m: Evolution of data & business growth in data pipelines processing approaches
20m: how Apache Airflow helps to solve different problems by complex use-cases
devops concerns.
5m: end2end use case for data pipeline to solve ride sharing anti-fraud problems 
Total time: 30m

title: State of the art anomaly detection
abstract:
LOL, I hope you didnâ€™t take the title too seriouslyâ€¦ Two things are sure in life: death; and the fact that no one anomaly detection algorithm can rule them all. Anomaly detection has various benefits for almost any company - system and business wise - but to make such a system valuable, there are multiple challenges, ranging from algorithm theory to system operations you should be aware of.

In this talk we will go through those challenges and the theory behind that field, and how you can get valuable insights.
outline:
1m: Introduction
10m: Explain why anomaly detection is complex by different use-cases
10m: Explore different algorithms and approaches to get the right insights from your data with multiple OSS systems in that field
9m: end2end use case to detect fraud and spikes with ensemble approach in your business 
Total time: 30m

title: Your career choices as an optimization problem
abstract:
We are engineers.

Or at least rationale, realistic and methodological creatures.
We are great at optimizing CPU cycles, load times and conversion rates -- but what about our own career path?

During our professional career, we are given countless opportunities to steer it towards its optimal course.

But what are we optimizing exactly? What are the choices we are given? What is the optimization function? What hidden factors are part of it? 
Are there known "right" or "wrong" choices?

Let's optimize!
outline:
- Who am I
- Optimization problems in our day to day work (examples)
- Optimization problem formalization
- Career steering as an optimization problem
- Known factors in the equation (short/long term optimization, optimizing for income / interest / satisfaction / work-life balance)
