- Understanding and factoring in irrational factors (imposter syndrome, "gut feeling", etc.)
Total time: 5m (Lightning session!)

title: Neural Psychedelic Aesthetics - Deep Learning for Creative Machines
abstract: Deep learning technology and generative neural networks have just started the age of creative machines. We will review the latest state-of-the-art applications of generative deep learning algorithms in image processing, text generation, design, creativity and art. I will also exhibit my own digital artwork and perform live demos.
outline:
2m intro
8m image processing
5m GANs + demo
5m Text2Image + demo
2m generative video
8m NLG + demo

title: Go where the Experiments take you!
abstract:
Staying relevant and moving fast with 15 years of code, hundreds of developers, and no code reviews is a challenge.

In this talk I'll share how A/B experiments allow developers to move at top speed, staying relevant and adventurous - using machine learning models to experiment on different personalisation hypotheses but ultimately going where the experiments take us!

I will explain how a company of this scale can survive while testing in production, what can be the consequences, and what are the components you need to work (and succeed) this way.
outline:
* 2m Introduction: Who I am and my professional background.
* 3m Why experiments: The challenge of a hundreds of developers working on the same code base and making the right impact. 
* 8m Which experiment next: How do we make a decision as to what to experiment on - user research, data analysis, where would we have the biggest impact.
* 7m Machine learning in experiments and case Study: The challenges of experiments based on machine learning and an example from start to end.
* 10m The architecture behind the experiments: What components do you need to be able to work this way - how do you record the information, present, monitor.

Total time: 30m

title: DIY (and fast) -  Billions of events streaming Based Solely on Open Sources
abstract:
While the concept of using an open source in your business is old news, integrating several of them for the purpose of moving  huge data sets in real time from hundreds of databases  - might sound crazy.
It was a real roller coaster ride - integrating and relaying on 5 open sources (Debezium, docker, kafka connect, kafka, Kubernetes) as the major part of the application code, especially when the main source, Debezium, didnâ€™t even celebrate his first birthday. However, it works like a charm. 

In this talk, I will show you how to combine few reliable open source technologies, get some help from their community, and after a month of no sleep, get the project running on massive scale successfully. By â€œmassiveâ€ I mean 600 different data sources and millions of events per second.
outline:
â€¢ 2m Introduction: Who am I and my professional background
â€¢ 5m What motivates people?:  people are motivated by getting more and more professional - that is why we play the guitar on weekends or contribute to open source on our free time, even though we donâ€™t make a profit out of it. This is weird economic behavior.
â€¢ 5m why you would want a project based on open source:
We took some risks on the way - we are talking about relaying on 5 open sources that are the majority of the application code, while the main source, Debezium, was an opensource that didnâ€™t even celebrate his first birthday yet. 
The integration of so many open sources wasnâ€™t easy, but at the end the benefit is clear- short dev time, robust and fault tolerant application that runs on huge scale. About 600 different data sources and millions of events per second.
While every company nowadays needs its own data streaming application, how many software companies can make the necessary investment of letâ€™s say 5 development teams and a year of work, needed to create this kind of project? The answer is quite clear... 
Most of the companies want and need these projects - but not at any cost, and thatâ€™s why all of you can benefit from our experience.
â€¢ 15m Our solution:
â€¢ Our solution + Architectural overview: 
Challenge - moving huge data sets in real time from hundreds of OLTP databases into a powerful in memory DB that can handle analysis at scale. 
Solution - Using change data capture (CDC) design patterns to identify every change being made in our  databases and writing it to Kafka as a shared resource
Architecture challenges - 
Scale -hundreds of Databases and billions of events being processed on each single database. Horizontal scalability was achieved by isolating each CDC agent to work independently across many servers.
Maintainability - Having different CDC agents for every single DB for hundreds of instances can be a challenging task when you need to maintain it. So we dockerized the environment and allowed Kubernetes to carry on the burden.
â€¢  Scale overview : facts about our scale - hundreds of data sources (600), millions of events per second, how we managed to scale up the project.
â€¢ Open source community help: how the open source communities helped and accompanied us in every step.
â€¢ 3m Q&A
Total time: 30m

title: Hacking the learning curve with interactive programming
abstract:
Interactive programming using notebooks (such as Jupyter), is probably one of the most productive ways to write software. More specifically, itâ€™s an amazing tool to use when youâ€™re learning new things (like with data research), and specifically when learning a new shiny technology. I think this is kind of paradoxical because in my own experience most libraries do a poor job of making it easy to use them in an interactive environment. 
This is a story about my own python library that did a very bad job as an interactive tool, and how I solved it by creating custom auto-completion tools. Weâ€™ll go into why and how you can use the same methodology to improve your own favorite libraries, and even dive into using the same ideas for non-interactive development using VSCode language servers.
outline:
2m Intro: Who am I and WIFIM
3m: Notebooks and interactive coding, why itâ€™s awesome
3m: Presentation of my own python library (simplified version of a data research API I wrote in during my military service).
2m: Letâ€™s try to use it interactively, and see what itâ€™s lacking.
3m: Presenting my original solution, an auto-complete ipython-extension made specifically for this library.
3m: How I implemented it, and things I learned since then about ASTs and code parsing.
4m: A bunch of examples of other python libraries, and why they need to make their interactive experience much better.
Pandas, Opencv, PyMongo.
2m: Letâ€™s back out. What makes an interface easily interactive?
	Learning from bash and CLI best practices
2m: What about other languages? There are more to cumbersome libraries than just being non-interactive.
Linux socket API, Swift/Objective-C NSRegularExpression, Angular.
5m: Using VSCode language servers to improve the user experience with libraries in a non-interactive environment.
1m: Summary + Key takeaways 
thinking about interactivity when writing libraries
using development environment tooling to improve a libraryâ€™s interactivity
Total time: 30m

title: The evolution of data architecture: A real-life story
abstract:
Choosing how to handle your data is not an easy task. Every database and data processing framework will try to tell you it is the best in the market and can solve all of your problems. But when real life strikes, you learn that every solution has its pros and cons and you might find yourself struggling to fit your data into the right model. 
In this session, we will tell the story of how the data architecture of Otonomo evolved during the first three years of the company.
You'll understand why we made some technological and architectural decisions based on the ever-changing nature of a growing startup.
Having all the tools in the belt is not enough. You have you know when to use them.
outline:
1m introduction: who am I and my professional background
3m Technological overview: Quick rundown of NOSQL and bigdata technologies
2m Company overview: what Otonomo does
18m Our story: What are the data solutions Otonomo implemented over the years
2m Summary
4m Q&A

title: A scalable, available, searchable and near realtime system. but at what cost?
abstract: As our SQL table storing the customers of our users - our users being small to medium business owners - grew too large to be performant we needed to start looking at other solutions for storing a large volume of data. But our data is not just large in quantity, that would be too simple. Our data is somewhat relational in it's nature, it changes often, it needs to be searched effectively and fast, and it needs to be GDPR compliant. In this talk you will learn about our stack, about acceptable limitations to the system as well as some unexpected caveats we encountered, while designing, implementing and shipping to production a large scale, searchable, available and near real time system.
outline:
Introduction to who I am - 2 minutes
Introduction to the problem: the original issue we set out to solve as well as new requirements that were added once we started - 5 minutes
Laying out the designed solution: the stack, tools and data modeling approach - 10 minutes
The known unknown: what we decided not to support and why - 5 minutes
The unknown unknowns: issues we didn't expect that made development take much longer or that made us reduce functionality - 5 minutes
Possible improvements and future changes: what we hope to achieve this year - 5 minutes (if time permits)
Q&A - 5 minutes
total - 37 minutes

title: Googlies! Grubbers! Lollies! How cricket helped us improve our throughput by 200%
abstract: I never imagined Iâ€™d know who Indian cricket star Rohit Sharma is, but then traffic to our real-time HTTP request sender service suddenly increased from 20 to 40 million events per minute. The reason? An app streaming the first game of the Indian cricket season. While growth is a good thing, we found ourselves unprepared for this sudden spike and we needed to scramble. Initially, we just threw money at the problem, but this wasn't sustainable. My talk will describe how we found low-cost, programmatic and architectural solutions to this problem and how we prepared ourselves to handle massive spikes like these on top of our existing 70 billion events per day. I'll explain our process of profiling, performance enhancement techniques, and some important lessons learned along the way.
outline:
- 2-3 min introduction about myself
- 5 min description of how our systems underperformed when the cricket season began and how we initially reacted
- 5 min about how we approached and profiled the issue and understood what tools we were lacking in order to fully understand the problem
- 5 min about some solutions we found to help increase our throughput generally and help us be more elastic in the face of massive traffic spikes
- 5 min about conclusions and transferable for how to approach problems like these in our other services
Total time: 22-23 min

title: Kubernetes - Top Down vs. Bottom Up Approach
abstract:
As with any complex system/framework, Kubernetes can be/is a complex one to grasp.
In this talk, I will describe my "Natively Clouded Journey" with Container Orchestration and Kubernetes in specific. 
A personal experience with what happened to kuebrnetes,  and the ways to consume whilst gaining trust working with it [Top Down], and how to customize it / mold it to your needs once you have [Bottom Up].
outline:
2m Introduction: Who I am and my professional background.
2m Which path to choose: Top-Down vs. Bottom-up approach
5m Homegrown K8s vs. KaaS & The Cloud Native promise
5m How to ease-in to Kubernets: from "Say What?" to "Say How!"
2m True Story: how swarm didn't suffice
5m Architectural Overview: How Kubernets get things done!
5m True Story: Cloud-native filling the gaps of Kubernetes primitives
5m BottomUp: When your ready to commit to k8s how to "challenge the chain of command"
Total Time: ~31m

title: Logging in the cloud: machines first human come second
abstract:
Developers arenâ€™t big fans of writing logs.
This is because when writing code we feel logs donâ€™t bring any value - Our code is good, we understand it, so why do we need logs in here!??!

Sadly we understand why we need logs when itâ€™s too late -
When the system is down (at 3 am), Or when a customer is facing some massive bug. 

More than that the first â€œpersonâ€ to read your logs in today ecosystem (cloud/lambda/k8s)  is no longer human, Itâ€™s a machine!
Therefore your logging infrastructure should be written in accordance.

This talk will cover:
* how to format a logs
* Why Logs that â€˜people readâ€™ doesnâ€™t scale
* Causality and correlation. 
* Distributed tracing to the help. 
* Telling a story using logs
 Come and find out whatâ€™s broken in logging design, and how to fix it :)
outline:
1.  Who am I and my professional background
2. Why developer hate writing logs
3. When do we need logs
4. Best practices when building a system

title: Microservices: A retrospective
abstract:
SOA has been around for decades, and its latest iteration - microservices - for a while now. Just five years ago microservices were hip, dominating the agenda at conferences; now we almost take them for granted. With microservice-focused conference talks losing steam, the time is ripe to consider what we, as an industry, can learn from the microservice disruption; more importantly, we have a golden opportunity to consider what we have yet to learn!

In this talk I'll analyse the lessons hammered into us as we've adopted microservices, and take a hard look at the challenges I believe we still struggle with as an industry. If you're not doing microservices you'll leave the room knowing where the pains will come from; if you are, you will leave with ideas and leads on mitigating these pains.
outline:
Outline draft:
  * who am I and why you should care (built microservice infrastructure as well as actual production services at Wix, WeWork and others) - 2m
* quick history of microservices (3-5m) -- maybe as a newspaper montage?
  * where did the term come from?
  * how has understanding of the term evolved?
  * how do microservices differ from soa? (microservices = soa + devops)
  * how widely-adopted are microservice architectures?
* lessons learned (10m)
  * small is good (the micro in microservices): smaller codebase is easier to grasp, easier to evolve, forces low(er) coupling...
  * conway is important! microservices force you to have a cohesive organizational structure, otherwise you can't meet SRP and teams step on each other's toes
  * operations are paramount: you cannot operate a SOA-esque system without significant investment in automation, monitoring and delivery (just observe the rise of devops and docker)
  * infrastructure is paramoutn (or: immutability, immutability everywhere)
    - generation 1: mutable, long-lived machines; 
    - generation 2: api-driven, ephemeral cloud nodes with "immutable infrastructure", provisioning automated by chef, puppet
    - generation 3: whole topology automation via terraform, pulumi and other 3rd gen systems
* what have we yet to learn? (10m)
  * CAP theorem: we're all building distributed systems, but we don't take the time to learn the laws of physics
  * debuggability and observability (aggregate logging, metrics, tracing and actually reasoning about distributed systems)
  * replication is a first-class concept! (eventual consistency, data replication between services, cross-DC replication...)
  * how to take advantage of microservices (it's taking shape already, consider new computation models: actors, csp, aws lambda...)
  * how to evolve microservice-based systems (backwards compatibility and protocols standardization, new architecture patterns: event sourcing+cqrs, CRDTs...)

title: The AI Revolution in Digital Art
abstract:
According to AI experts, the art and design scene has been taken by an AI storm, if youâ€™d ask artists though, AI art is just a gimmick. But what do the techies think? 

In our 30 minute talk we will dive into the depths of programming a genetic algorithm that plays god and creates forests and other eco-systems on city walls. We will discuss current ML algorithms that form amazing experiences, how do they relate to the history of computer science, some topics in human perception and finally, why and how everyone should create at least one interactive program.
outline:
Intro - 3 min
The depths of programming a genetic algorithm that plays god and creates forests and other eco-systems on city walls - 15 min
Current ML algorithms that form amazing experiences - 7 min
How do ML interactive works relate to the history of computer science - 5 min
Why and how everyone should create at least one interactive program - 1 minute

title: How to speak American
abstract:
In our day to day jobs most of us work with people from the other side of the Atlantic, and yet we still havenâ€™t found the perfect way to communicate with our American counterparts. When they say something they often mean something else, and when we Israelis speak, we often come across as insensitive. So how how can you flourish in conversations when youâ€™re from a different culture, and worse yet, speaking in English?

I was born and raised in a very Israeli household in Pittsburgh. Having worked as an American among Israelis and as an Israeli among Americans, I have seen the miscommunication coming from both sides. This talk will include practical methods on how to understand each other better, choose your words more carefully, and have productive conversations.
outline:
- 2m Introduction on who I am
- 3m Illustrate the pain point by a real world situation where Americans and Israelis miscommunicated and the negative business impact 
- 10m Real example of a challenging conversation and tips on how to navigate it, broken down components
- 10m when Americans say x, they really mean... when an Israeli says x, an American really understands ...
- 3m Essential tips to conduct better conversations immediately
- 2m Q&A

** This can also be condensed into a Lightning Talk - 
- 1m Who I am and why there is a pain point
- 3m Americans say x, they really mean... when an Israeli says x, an American really understands ...
- 1m A single tip to take and use in your next meeting to better communicate

title: UX Illustrations- Know if and where illustration is crucial in your product experience
abstract:
Now more than ever, illustration is an integral part of the product experience. Illustrations can be found in many areas of a product â€“ guiding users through onboarding, helping them understand how to perform complex tasks, and shaping their emotional response.

Whether youâ€™re working on a B2C product for the family or a B2B product for a large enterprise, using the right illustrations can help create easier-to-use products and facilitate more impactful relationships with your users.

In this talk, Iâ€™ll show you how to decide where illustration is crucial in your product experience â€“ and where it isnâ€™t.
outline:
2 min- introduction
8 min- topic overview
20 min- main roles of thumbs + example
5 min- tips + summary
Total time: 35m

title: Why we switched our old monitoring systems to a new cloud monitoring service, then to open source
abstract:
In this talk, we will share insights from our journey of monitoring multi-region systems. We started with traditional monitoring tools (Nagios, Zabbix), which didnâ€™t serve our needs.
Moving to a commercial cloud-based service felt like driving a Rolls-Royce and it cost like one. In the end, we moved to an open source solution, which served all our needs and cost almost nothing â€“ AKA Prometheus & Grafana.
We will talk about the moving parts, the DOs, and the DONâ€™Ts, so you can implement it in your environment.
outline:
â€¢	1m Introduce myself: Who I am and my professional background
â€¢	3m Monitoring tools evolution on our multi-region systems
â€¢	3m Architectural overview: what it is good for, and what it is not
â€¢	10m Prometheus entities and features (metrics, QL, alerts, client libs)
â€¢	4m Visualization â€“ using Grafana
â€¢	5m Live demo - ask the audience to vote and show results in a graph
â€¢	2m Prometheus â€“ the DOs and the DONâ€™Ts
â€¢	2m Q&A

title: Pushing impact velocity through the roof with an extreme squad-like structure
abstract:
At JoyTunes we run a fairly unique startup-within-a-startup pod structure. Harnessing lessons learned from Spotify, Netflix and a few others, we built the entire company around independent, fast moving and self sustained pods. 

In this talk weâ€™ll use real life examples, including listing the pods we currently have, projects weâ€™ve engaged in this manner and successes/failures. We'll briefly cover the reasoning and core principles along with the wonderful benefits and the not-quite-as-wonderful challenges, after doing this (successfully) for a little over a year.
outline:
2m intro - background & context
3m - Lessons learned from times we were excellent and times we sucked
5m - Spotify squads, â€œloosely coupled, highly alignedâ€
10m - JT extreme team structure, pods with devs, musicians, product, ux, marketing
5m - guilds
5m - Benefits (speed), and failures (some by design, some surprised us)

Total: 30 min

title: Put Grafana, Kibana & Kusto in a Blender. Hint: This Cocktail Gives You X-Ray Vision in Production
abstract:
In Taboola, we swim, and sometimes drown in data.

I will share my secrets of how to have good visibility to our big data.
For that, I use three tools: Grafana, Kibana and Kusto (Azure Data Explorer) together. Before that, I had to jump back and forth from one application to the other in order to build my puzzle. 

For example:
* Added the error count from Kibana to the CPU load from Grafana. Boom, got a correlation between CPU hogers to applicative errors. 
* Mixed HTTP error rate from Azure Data Explorer, Kibana installation timestamps and business KPIs from Grafana, this resulted in a razor sharp graph that tracks our SLA compliance in a glimpse of an eye. 

I am sure that by seeing how much value did I got from it, you also be interested in this cocktail.
outline:
â€¢ 2m Introduction: Who am I and my professional background
â€¢ 3m Architectural overview: Talk about our main monitoring tools and our culture of end-to-end ownership of our software engineers.
â€¢ 3m The problem: Show how each monitoring tool gives a partial picture and how much effort it takes to conclude the root cause of downtimes and latencies in our big data environment.
â€¢ 15m Our combined approach: Use cases of combining Grafana, Kibana and Kusto (Azure Data Explorer) to give a more holistic and complete picture, and of course super quick value. Here I will show how quickly I can identify the root cause of downtimes and how easily I can get to conclusions from the combined graphs.
â€¢ 3m How you can do it in your company, who to talk to (hint IT,Infra and DevOps)
â€¢ 3m Q&A
Total time: 29m

title: Indoor navigation for children with Autism â€“ a story of a contribution project
abstract:
One of about every 60 children in Israel has some form of autism. Some of these children require special attention and often need help navigating their schoolâ€™s interior space to move from one room to another.
After the â€œYahdavâ€ school had won the innovation competition with their brilliant idea, AT&T Israel accepted the challenge to implement an open-source solution for indoor navigation for kids. Numerous technologies such as GraphQl, nest.js and angular, as well as Unity and Kotlin, were used to develop this project with continuous integration while maintaining high code quality and speed of development. Collaboration between a large number of people made this project possible. This a story of success, technology and collaboration.
outline:
â€¢	Presenting ASD (what? How many? What are the challenges?) â€“ 2m
â€¢	Presenting theoretical solution to a challenge â€“ 5m
â€¢	Open source development strategy â€“ 5m
â€¢	Software architecture of the solution â€“ 10m
o	Tools we used for CI/CD
o	Libraries & frameworks
o	Management tools
â€¢	Where we are today â€“ 5m
â€¢	Movie of kids using the app â€“ 1m
â€¢	Q/A â€“ 2m
Total time: 30m

title: Data Science Life Cycle in Reality - A case study
abstract:
This year was the first time I felt I completed the ho so well defined(?) data science "life cycle" - what a ride!  
In this talk I'll describe the interesting question we tried to solve predicting whether a task we present to a crowed through our crowedsource app will be successfully completed on time. Given the fact crowed is an ever changing workforce and our tasks are flexible I'll try to use this challenge to take you through the bottlenecks, valleys and picks involved in the cycle, from a data scientist perspective. 
Hopefully, it won't be just a support group for frustrated DS but also help other individuals (product, exec, dev, PMs to name a few)  to understand better the process of working with and aside to data science teams.
outline:
2m : About my self. 
2m: About Trax, essential to understand the problem I'll describe. 
6m: Data Science Life Cycle - the Theory.
15m: Data Science Life Cycle - the real life story through my recent crowedsource-related project.
5m : Key takeaways. 
Total: 30m.

title: Make Your Life Easier with Vuex
abstract:
Letâ€™s talk about Vuex, Vue's state management tool, and what makes it so awesome. With Vuex, you get easily accessible, reactive and reliable app data.
Let's explore some basic features in a concise and applicative way, and learn how a state manager, Vuex specifically, can save you a lot of time and effort in the long run.

title: Creating a multicloud architecture
abstract:
There are a number of reasons for deploying a multicloud architecture, including reducing reliance on any single vendor, cost-efficiencies, increasing flexibility through choice, adherence to local policies that require certain data to be physically present within a specific area/country, latency reduction, and mitigating against disasters.

We spent two years designing, preparing, and implementing a full scale mutlicloud architecture. We invite you to learn from our journey which ended when our product - composed of 100+ services - seamlessly function on either AWS or GCP.
outline:
1m:  introduction
3m: why would you consider a multicloud deployment 
1m: when to do it, and more importantly - when to avoid it 
2m: the Trax use case (retail company on top of Amazon, a retail competition) 
3m: using a platform vs. writing your own abstractions 
7m: a POC phase, how to plan and execute it correctly
5m: Identifying pitfalls early on, and best practices for where to write the "if (cloud == X) then "
2m: the importance of selecting a primary cloud 
2m: "Single entity" use case at Trax
4m: The final blitz - can you avoid stopping your engineering organization for 1 month to move to the new infrastructure? (spoiler: you can if you listen to our mistakes)

Total:  30 minutes

title: Fun and Powerful Code Reviews
abstract:
Modern development processes define code review as a mandatory step before deployment to production. Since the process is done by humans, it is expensive, subjective and requires proper training.

My talk is divided into three parts: first, why code reviews are necessary for ensuring code quality and are critical to the engineering teamâ€™s growth. Second, Iâ€™ll elaborate on how to conduct focused and efficient code reviews. Finally, Iâ€™ll discuss issues that we experienced in our own code review process and explain how we overcame them.
outline:
- 2m Intro: who I am and what I do in Lightricks.
- 3m Incentive: why should we do code reviews and what's the scope of a code review.
- 15m I have code to review, what should I do now? 
(By email:  I will discuss a few questions that need to be answered by the reviewer to make sure enough data is gathered for properly reviewing the change, such as: who is submitting the change, what is the scope of the change, are the commit and PR messages clear enough, changes to project metrics, context of change etc. I will also elaborate how different answers to these questions can affect the entire review.)
- 7m issues raised in the code review process we encountered in Lightricks and how we solved them.
(By email: I'll elaborate on why code reviews are not being done well in stressful times (usually near deadlines), why it took a relatively long time for code in our workflow to be merged and how we can mitigate these issues by decreasing the turnaround time, minimizing the discussions scope in CRs and minimizing the number of rounds that are required to merge a change. These are things that dramatically accelerated our CR process while preserving the review quality.)
- 3m Q&A.
Total time: 30m

title: Engaging product teams to critical thinking using UX methodology
abstract:
The traditional UX role included being the giver of product critique. 
Splitting the role between the product team members like the product manager and the product designer might cause the loss of this important function since itâ€™s almost impossible to be your own critique. 
We suggest implementing UX methodologies into the product team day to day tasks allowing them to practice  critical thinking within their own product.
In our talk we will explain which UX tools are relevant and how to use them.
outline:
â€¢ 5m Story about a product feature/team from our experience - indicating there is a problem with the team critique abilities 

â€¢ 2m Introduction: Who we are and our professional background

â€¢ 5m The problem with splitting UX role between the product team members while losing the ability to efficiently  critique your own product 
â€¢ 15m Our solution: Using UX tools and methodology to engage the entire product team  to critical thinking.  This will allow them :
1. Use critique approach to understanding the problem 
2. Use critique approach to suggesting a solution

â€¢ 5m: Story about the same feature/team from the beginning of the lecture now in our way :-)

â€¢ 5m Q&A

Total time: 37m

title: Effective Refactoring
abstract: Over time, issues come up with large code bases as a result of having to support new features, increased scale, or expanding development teams.  In this talk, we'll discuss some effective strategies for dealing with architecture design, team culture, and development processes on a fast-changing project. You should leave the talk feeling more equipped to produce code that can change with your team over time, instead of becoming something that's difficult and scary to work with.
outline:
* 5m Introduction & discussion of complexity with refactoring large code bases
* 20m Deep dive on individual common problems and how to deal with them
** Breaking refactorings into smaller chunks
** Writing tests to support refactoring
** Dealing with legacy code & isolation behind interfaces
** Common design patterns for refactoring
** Reducing duplication
** Removing complexity and large methods
** Code organization
* 5m Summary and wrap-up
* 5m Q&A

title: From API hell to a Domain Specific QL
abstract:
As a big data IoT platform we need to provide our non-technical customers with insights on their data.

Terabytes of data is streamed into a perfect physical model with continuous data pipelines aggregating it in the exact shape we want - and reads are fast!

Exposing it with - yet another API - to fetch some data brought us to an API hell!

We've looked for a concrete mechanism for analyzing, manipulating and querying data. That is, we needed a query language.
 
In this session I will explain why we chose building our own Custom Query Language and deep-dive on how to develop a blazing fast Query-Language interpreter with a live demo.
outline:
â€¢	1m Introduction: Who am I and my professional background
â€¢	5m Our API hell: As a big data IOT platform we need to provide our customers with insights on their data. We found ourselves developing more and more APIs for more and more use-cases to retrieve data.
â€¢	3m What is a Domain Specific Query Language?  Text-based interface for data retrieval and analysis. The text acts as both executable software and a description that domain experts can read. 
â€¢	5m Why building our own Query Language? Abstraction for our special use-cases. Decoupling the display model and the storage model. Mostly give users a convenient way to build a personal view of data. 
â€¢	12m How to implement a Query Language interpreter ? Implementing all steps of interpreter: Lexical, Parser, analyzing and building execution plan. Will be followed with demo of how to use JFlex and CUP for parser generator.
â€¢	2m: Summarize â€“ What, Why How Domain Specific Query Language.
â€¢	5m Q&A
Total time: 33m

title: Managing outsourced development
abstract:
Startups often outsource their development, but how often are they really happy with the results? Outsourcing is often considered a "magic solution", making the contractor the magician - but even the best magician needs the right settings to work their magic.

In this talk we'll discuss the most common friction points I've encountered while working with various contractors, and how to minimize (or even avoid them altogether), for better outsourced results from day one.
outline:
Take a look at https://docs.google.com/document/d/1VtzUy6Bfz_pYXquaTOkIutePSstMEhyFL23dklHEMGI/edit?usp=sharing


* 2m Introduction
* 5m Why outsource
* 3m Outsourcing as a habit
* 10m Common friction points when working with contractors
* 10m Doing it better

title: Putting your irrelevant experience to work
abstract:
You know the one about the recruitment ad seeking an under 30 developer with over 20 years of experience in a specific FE language? What if I tell you that a FE developer with just 3 years of "relevant" experience, but with 5 years of experience as an architect - could actually do a better job, and improve the entire company's performance? 

Multidisciplinaries not only have in-depth knowledge of various fields often making them the go-tos for integrations, they also bring methodologies that create groundbreaking innovations and creative solutions.

Come learn how to make the best use of your entire team's diverse experience, and bring your own irrelevant experience to work, in a way that makes you stand out in the crowd.
outline:
* 5m Introduction
* 3m What makes experience relevant
* 3m How multidisciplinary experience benefits the team, the organization and the employee
* 7m Examples of putting relevant experience to work in a way that benefits everyone
* 12m How to put your own irrelevant experience to work (examples from the crowd)

title: 5 Things I Love About Vue.js
abstract: Have you heard about Vue.js but not really sure what it is or why it's so popular? This one is for you! In my talk, we will go over some key features that make Vue.js stand out in the framework crowd, explore its advantages and discover how easy it is to build scalable applications with Vue.js

title: Painless mentorship that solves understaffing
abstract:
Hiring? So is everyone else. How are you going to make sure you get the best minds on your team? You train them! Yup, your read that right, Mentorship is making a comeback.

While experienced workers may be easier to onboard fast, in today's startup economy there are clear benefits to hiring less experienced (potentially qualified) people who are just getting started. Mentorship has its challenges, but Junior Techies are more available, cost less and don't bring their wrong old habits to work.

A mentorship program can be painlessly applied with a few simple tricks, to help your understaffed team as well.
outline:
1m Introduction
1m Understaffing is everyone's problem
1m The ups (& downs) of Mentorship programs
2m Painless mentorship - How to

title: Research at scale - Model Assembly Line
abstract:
While there are many paradigms for scaling dev teams, this is not the case for data science teams.
 
In an attempt to keep up with company goals and growing demand for improved classification models, we had to shorten the research life cycle, and release the bottle neck of training, evaluating and deploying classification models. In this talk Iâ€™ll present the design of our model training platform - a set of independent tools and libraries, which allowed us to drastically increase the number of experiments we can perform, apply our findings easily to all existing models, and standardize the evaluation process.
outline:
[2 min] about me and riskified
[10] how we grow, and when why we needed a change
[5] framework components: data extraction, model training, model assesment components
[5] examples of tasks we accomplish with the framework
[4] future plans
[4] questions
total time: 30min

title: A journey to a UI library with Web Components
abstract:
This talk is not about micro-frontends.

At Trax, we use multiple frameworks to build a unified applications suite. The challenge of creating one visual language led us to a journey to find the most abstract way to implement reusable components. 

In a midst of a polyglot of frameworks, a ray of sanity and abstraction shined to guide our way out of the abyss. In other words, Web Components are awesome.

In this presentation I'm going to tell you our story, the technologies we investigated, the components we threw to the side of the road, and how data-binding and style-encapsulation can be made beautifully regardless of the wrapping framework.
outline:
2 min introduction
5 min overview of our product architecture
1 min the problem we wanted to solve
2-3 min about what were our options
10 min about web components
5 min example of a component
2-3 min how it all works now

title: Lessons from building deep learning recommendation systems
abstract:
Deep Learning models have been gaining increasing attention in the recommendation systems community, replacing some of the traditional methods. The sparse nature of the problems and the different inputs  types offer unique challenges for feature engineering and architecture planning, in order to balance between memorization and generalization.

During the past 2 years the algorithms team in Taboola moved all of our algorithms to DL. In this talk we'll share the lessons we learned doing so. We'll talk about building NN with multiple input types (click history, text and pictures); feature engineering in DL;  capturing interactions between features; and the way modelling decisions are related to system engineering and research culture.
outline:
intro - 3 minutes
problem setup and deep learning architecture for recommendation systems - 12 minutes
what we need to consider when making modelling decisions + case study - 10 minutes
Q&A - 5 minutes
Total time - 30 min

title: Connecting Engineers through delightful API experience
abstract:
API is the best way of connecting software engineers and sharing data, so building the perfect API for your partners can be quite a challenge. Partners can differ vastly in their requirements, programming languages and even API semantics.
In this session, you will learn how to build a delightful API experience for your partners.
I'll talk about delivering a clean API, easily generating documentation, mock creation for testing, cross-platform client generation, all within a predictable release cycle and without extensive effort (I promise :) ).
outline:
Intro: 1min The challenge we were faced with: 5 min
  • How to build API, and why is it so hard to build a good API
  • Back and forth communication with your partners
  • Is there is a standard?
  • API for integration
  • Alternatives
    • Reasons to go with Swagger: 5-7min
  • OpenAPI:
  • Harness HTTP features:
    • HTTP Methods Response codes Content types Authentication
  • Code generation:
    • Server side Client side
  • SwaggerHub
  • CI/CD flow:
    • Generating mock service from swagger.yml How we used Swagger to build Clear & Predictable API: 10-12min
  • Create customize with a higher standard API
  • From documentation to server code generation
  • Easily integrating with our partners, cross-platform client generation
  • Testing the API against a live integration machine.
  • Release flow
    • Summary 5 min Q&A 3-4 min

title: Engineering Meets Data Science - How to Balance the Tension Between Data Science and Agile
abstract:
After many years of Engineering management, I was faced with the challenge of managing a Data Science team for the first time. 

As Data Science pace does not meet the regular engineering rules, I needed to create a process to bridge between the new field in my life, and the company's goals and timelines. 

In this presentation I will tell how I learned the field, how we built a process which worked both for the Data Science team and management, and how trust and great communication can take you a long way when facing this problem.
outline:
2 min self presentation, Zencity presentation
8 min talk about the different side of the challenge 
5 min about the steps I took to learn the field from scratch
10 min about the process we have build to allow the team to have time to research and allow the management to be calm and involved in the details
3 min my conclusion about trust and open communication

title: Distributed Sagas, an approach to taming the beast of reliable interactions between microservices
abstract:
As microservices are becoming the â€œnew normalâ€ and architecture style of choice, many organizations quickly realize the challenges associated with distributing their system across multiple services, in particular, maintaining business process correctness while dealing with long-running processes, failures and eventual data consistency.
In this session, we will discuss how applying the notion of a Distributed Saga can help organizations deal with these challenges while touching on topics such as local service transactivity, compensating actions and contrasting message orchestration vs message choreography style of integration.
outline:
We will start by discussing system consistency in a distributed architecture framing one of the key challenges related to  distributing business processes across microservices

We will then briefly touch on how we tradeoff system consistency to gain business agility when using microservices

Next we will see how system consistency was dealt with in â€œclassicâ€ n-tier architectures and why these solutions break down in modern day architectures.

Enter the distributed saga - a way to orchestrate interactions between microservices while maintaining system consistency

We will touch on the finer details of implementing the saga pattern such as maintaining local transactivity and how we use grabbit, an open source tool developed in WeWork, to help us implement distributed sagas across our core financial systems.

We will wrap up by contrasting service orchestration using sagaâ€™s vs service interactions via message choreography, discussing tradeoffs and potential use cases.

title: Wake-up call: are you developing your product right?
abstract:
Developing a new product is fun and exciting, but itâ€™s also hard. The path to your new product will be filled with obstacles, limitations and blockers. Youâ€™re likely to waste more time and resources than you actually have, make a few wrong calls on the way, and even end up compromising on the outcome.

But it doesnâ€™t have to be that way. Itâ€™s time to try a new approach â€“ one that enables you to handle blockers, stay focused, boost your creativity, and increase your delivery speed.

In the latest product weâ€™ve been working on at Soluto, we decided to try a new method that calls for non-traditional steps to achieve our desired product. In this session, Iâ€™ll talk about our journey of creating a new product, and share insights and lessons learned from our experience.
outline:
3m Common problem introduction
5m The specific problem we faced at Soluto
10m Our approach to tackle the problem and the steps we took
8m Key take-aways for every B2B and B2C product development
3m Summary

=====

Goal of the session â€“

Open peopleâ€™s mind and make them question their working process when developing a new product.

We should seek to improve not only the product but also the way we work all the time â€“ in order to increase our focus, creativity and delivery pace.

 

We started working on a new product a few months ago.

We decided to tackle it differently from the traditional way and we keep trying new methods and approaches as we progress.

 

Updated outline - 



3m Common problem introduction

Challenges of developing a new product â€“ confusion on how to start, obstacles, blockers, limited resources, time limitations, etc.

5m The specific problem we faced at Soluto

How we found ourselves working on a new direct-to-consumer product (This part will provide context to the examples Iâ€™ll share later on) including a short introduction of myself.

10m Our approach to tackle the problem and the steps we took

In this part Iâ€™ll share the different steps we took that demonstrate different methods and approaches to developing a new product.

For example â€“

-          Usually you define a scope, estimate how long it will take to release it and start working with timelines based on the scope. We did the opposite â€“ defined the deadline (2 months) and then defined the scope. It forced us to think on a small yet real and valuable MVP, be super focused and efficient.



-          Usually you start with some research (target audience, competitors, etc.) and then start brainstorming your product. We decided weâ€™re not waiting for results, and in parallel started testing different value propositions (for example using landing pages). I'll share our ways to quickly test actual product offerings â€“ to speed up the process and identify opportunities.



-          Usually features prioritization is based on feasibility (technical complexity), user value, business value (profitability), etc.. As weâ€™re talking specifically on the earliest stage of the product (as itâ€™s new), we decided to add another criteria â€“ how much each feature â€œexplainsâ€ where this product is heading. Iâ€™ll share our examples for features that better deliver the overall product and potential value (and explain why).



8m Key take-aways for every B2B and B2C product development

Key take-aways Iâ€™ll share will be based on the steps we took and our learning â€“ how anyone can take from them something that is relevant for him/her. For example (compatible to the example steps shared above) -



-          Set reasonable yet close deadline to create the right focus, even before determining the scope.

Many times PMs, developers and UXs find themselves working on features or products for months that donâ€™t necessarily go live. Itâ€™s been too long and no longer relevant, there are other business opportunities, market needs changed, etc.

Starting by defining a deadline helps you â€œpourâ€ into it a focused scope, cleaning the backlog from anything that is not impactful or critical for the launch.



-          Start from pure value. Ignore the rest.

Test your ideas and value propositions as soon as possible on real users. In order to nail down the new product, put aside the work on the homepage, marketing, pricing, etc. and focus on the actual value (Great tools to do so for example are landing pages and surveys).



-          Choose the features that clarify where your product is heading.

As we all want to start small and fast (quickly learn, minimize risk, etc.) â€“ thereâ€™s a concern users will miss the overall offering of the product. Selecting the right features to start with is crucial for that. It should be features that help users understand how this product is going to help them with X, even if it's not actually doing it yet. 

3m Summary

title: Conjure: simple, polyglot RPC
abstract: â€œWhy on earth did we decide to develop our own RPC system?â€ is a simple and obvious question to ask, but a complex one to answer. In this talk, Dr. Robert Fink, Head of R&D at Palantir Technologies, will give a firsthand account of the development history of Palantir's polyglot RPC system, Conjure, from the first line of code to its rebirth in open-source. We discuss the rationale and design principles behind Conjure, its implementation, and the lessons learnt on the way (â€œself-hosting intermediate representationâ€, anyone?). If you are looking for a simple yet strongly-typed RPC system that works for servers and clients in Java, Go, Rust, Python, and TypeScript, maybe look no further than Conjure?
outline:
* Architecture of Palantir's data platforms: microservices, clients and servers in different languages
* History of Palantir's RPC systems: Java serialization, COBRA, Bespoke REST, Conjure, GraphQL
* Standardizing our RPC footprint: emergence of Conjure
* Design of Conjure: language features, code generators
* Unique Conjure features: API backcompat checkers, easy&extensible codegen, language support
* How to use Conjure: end-to-end example with clients and servers
* Lessons learnt

title: Innovation! Big mistakes corporations make when going innovative
abstract:
Has your organization recently stated how innovative it is? How many existing organizations still haven't gone that irresistible road?
Many organizations, wether big corporations or small startup companies want to be as innovative as they possibly can. That's what's hot nowadays. However, the actions taken aren't always as innovative as they think, and they might actually cause serious problems in the long run.
outline:
2min introduction: who I am, my professional background.
5min my organization: strenghths and weaknesses.
7min going innovative: the steps my organization took towards innovation, including examples from similar organizations.
4min my experience: what happened to me when the organization went all in on innovation.
7min big mistakes: how the steps the organization takes might lead to disasterous outcomes.
5min word of advice: what innovation means and how to encourage creativity without hurting the organization.

title: Is the Israeli Government in a mood for Open Source Development?
abstract:
Campus-il is the Israeli National Learning Platform, which enables free access to education to everyone, such as the Psychometric exam preparation course for free. It happens to be developed on Open edX opensource infrastructure provided by edx.org by Digital Israel in the Ministry of Social Equality.
How did we decide on the Development methodology of the project? What were the main challenges in running OpenSource product within the Government?  What are the main opportunities that we see in running National Digital Learning Platform within the Government?
All of that will be answered during our session.
outline:
5m Introduction: My background and current position
5m: Product introduction: what is Campus-il? What is Open edX? 
10m: Development methodology chosen for Campus-il Opensource development, the main reasons and the decision making process
10m: Opportunities and Challenges in the Development process and what were the lessons learned
5m : Q&A

title: Feds can do Threads
abstract:
We already know that client-side is no longer just html/css, and running on single threaded JavaScript is kind of sucks, so why not using the background threads web-workers?
In my talk, we will build an example of making our site much faster when using web workers. We will talk about when to use them and when not, and how to check if we did a good job.
outline:
2m introduction: Who am I, what I was doing in the past 2 years
15m Zero to Basic: Create a simple app using web workers and understand the advantages on the go.
10m Basic to Pro: Show some problems and how to best practice using web-workers that will help you create the best app and not make you fail in the future.
3m Q&A

title: Monitoring ML Models in Production
abstract:
For a while the ML engineering focus was around the Data Scientist needs, libs like _scikit-learn_, _TenserFlow_ and more, serves that need. The industry started to change the focus and put it more on the post-DS phases, we can see big companies like __Uber__ developing internal platforms like __Michelangelo__ to address these needs, but not enough mature open sources are out there yet.
That gave us [@Fundbox](https://fundbox.com/) the motivation to develop a __ML Monitoring__ platform.
In this talk I would like to walk you thru the product architecture, decisions we took on the way and the end solution. We will talk about the differences between stability and performance tests, what is a "concept drifting" and what kind of widgets we developed to reflect our models quality in production.
outline:
2m Intro: about Me and Fundbox
5m Concepts alignment: How ML model life cycle looks like? what is a model execution in production? what is a label? How we measure model performance? 
5m Background: The status of ML engineering in the world, known platforms, open sources.
15m Our solution: Architecture overview, features stability checks (distribution vs training data, % of nulls, ks and chi-square tests, etc...) , model stability (score distribution vs training data), model performance (confusion matrix, gini check, etc..).
5m Q&A
Total time: 32m

title: More of the same or not close enough - personalized diversity in recommender systems
abstract: Balancing personalized and diverse content is a major challenge for recommender systems: One must provide the user with diverse, previously unseen content, while at the same time match offered content with user-specific interests. To achieve this balance, we at Taboola combine NLP, similarity metrics and supervised deep networks into a single recommendation pipeline. In this talk I will discuss these elements and describe how their combined pipeline is used to optimize user-engagement within a personalized â€œinterest-spaceâ€.
outline:
1m: Personal introduction - who I am and what I do at Taboola
5m: Problem introduction - describe the personalization/diversity tradeoff in recommender systems
15m: Dive into the components - NLP for interest-space mapping, similarity metrics for matching user-history with available content and deep networks for learning the user's specific preferences 
5m: Describe the combined pipeline and the full solution cycle.
5m: Q&A
Total time: 31m

title: How To Be a Productive Git Citizen
abstract: Git challenges shouldn't be a trigger for a panic attack. Git gained its popularity because of its excellent performance and powerful options that anyone can harness and turn to a master of their domain. Empowered by the terminal, Git can turn into a powerful tool and solve many problems.
outline:
The purpose of this lecture is to motivate people to use git outside of their
IDE's and create curiosity in a demonstration of my habit of git usage.
I want to share the passion I have for this technology in a wide audience.

#### Think About How You Use Git (cli vs. gui)
#### Know Where You Are (pretty log patterns, --all, simplify-by-decoration)
#### Know Where You Were (git reflog)
#### Merge & Rebase Early (fetch --prune --tags --all, rebase, pull, merge)
#### Know What Others Are Doing (fetch, diff/log a..b vs. a...b, diff/log @{1}.., diff-so-fancy)
#### Use Branches, They're Cheap (41 bytes SHA pointers, meaningful names, tracking)
#### Stage Before Commit (add -p, add -i, do NOT add . or commit -a)
#### Comments: Code of Conduct (imperative mode, present tense, 50/72 rule, second line blank, changelog)
#### Clean Your Work (rebase -i, squash)
#### Publish Often (push, default push action when no refspec specified)
#### Pest Control (bisect)
total: 30m

title: Real-Time Image Processing: A Case Study
abstract:
Creating a real-time image processing filters is difficult, let alone on a mobile device. In contrast to many other real-time data manipulation tasks, the amount of elements that need to be processed on every frame is huge, and the operation can rarely be deferred to stronger, offline systems. At Lightricks, we've spent the last 6 years optimizing our iOS and Android image processing engines to provide a seamless user experience.

In this talk I will present a case study writing a gaussian blur filter. We will begin from writing a naive CPU implementation that performs poorly on large size images and gradually work our way to an efficient, scalable GPU implementation that runs in real-time.

No prior knowledge in image processing, GPU wizardry or performance optimizations is required!
outline:
- 2m Introduction: Who am I and what I do in Lightricks.
- 5m the Gaussian filter: what it is and what it's good for.
- 8m CPU: trivial implementation, separable filter, parallelism.
- 10m GPU: why GPU, how it works, writing a blur kernel function.
- 5m Q&A

Total time 30m

title: Managing Front-end Interrelated Packages â€“ Itâ€™s an offer you canâ€™t refuse
abstract: In the last decade, more products and teams choose a front-end application as their UI layer. Under the umbrella of a singular front-end system, comes a wider dependency on interrelated packages. The packages management is usually complex and time consuming. However, we usually address it as unavoidable. My talk main notion is to introduce the Package Coupling and Package Cohesion principles, as a very rewording architecture patterns set to cope with those challenges in front-end systems. I will suggest a set of guidelines based on my interpretation to those principals, for making a system stable, maintainable and testable, and allow decoupled deliveries, without hurting reusability. I will enrich the discussion by supplying a practical examples of CyberArk architecture evolution.
outline:
â€¢ 1m Introduction: Who am I and my professional background.
â€¢ 4m Architectural overview: Introducing the dependencies packages system starting point and the challenges different teams were faced with, as the system grew up.
â€¢ 10m Adhere to the Package Cohesion principles when redesigning the partition of front-end components into interrelated packages.
â€¢ 10m Adhere to the Package Coupling principles when redesigning the relationships between interrelated products and in-house infrastructure packages.
â€¢ 3m The benefits of implementing those principles in large fronted systems.
â€¢ 3m Q&A
Total time: 31m
*Every part of the lecture will be enriched with practical example of the CyberArk architecture.

title: Moving Mountains - disrupting traditional industries from the inside
abstract:
At Soluto, weâ€™ve rebuilt one of our core B2B2C product from the ground up. This changed the experience not only for our users, but also ourselves, and has led to disruption within our a 17,000 employees global organization. The revamped product became the heart of the companyâ€™s strategy which requires us to keep the innovation while creating synergy with numerous legacy flows and products the company hold.
In this talk, Iâ€™ll share a set of practical approaches to obstacles we had encountered - From getting the organization curious about a product to differ from the industryâ€™s standards, nurturing the product in a way it keeps evolving to new areas, through making the users excited about the direction the product is taking.
outline:
* 2m Introduction: Who am I and my professional background
* 5m What is Soluto all about - background, industry, working methods
* 10m How and why we reinvented our product and what opportunities it unfolded
* 10m The obstacles we had in our way and how we tackled them
* 5m Q&A
Total time: 32m

title: Large Scale Community Detection for Cross-Device Matching
abstract: Community detection algorithms try to partition a graph into communities with high connectivity inside each community and low connectivity between communities. In this session, we will start with an overview on popular community detection algorithms, optimization goals and parallelization methods. Then, Iâ€™ll present the community detection pipeline we developed and applied over probability-weighted identity graph in Oracle Data Cloud.
outline:
3m Introduction
3m Cross-Device matching: What is cross-device?
3m Community detection: What is community detection?
10m What should I optimize to find communities: Will present map-equation in house f-score method.
5m Community detection algorithms: What algorithms exists and what are the scalable ones? Go into details into louvain
3m Scalable approaches to community detection: Describe parallel version of Louvain called relaxmap.
3m What we decided implement and why: Talk a bit about our specifc use case and solution.
Total time : 30m

I'm not sure if out of the 30m I should leave time for questions (there is total time of 37m in the example). In this case, I will reduce the time approximately evenly (so, mostly from the details about the loss functions and the louvain algorithm) to make time for Q&A.

title: How to Manage Your Kafka in an Explosive Growth Environment
abstract: AppsFlyerâ€™s mobile attribution and analysis platform is used by the biggest and most popular applications on Earth, generating a constant â€œstormâ€ of 70B+ events (HTTP Requests) on our microservices, cloud based platform daily. In this talk, we will share how we built our microservices architecture with Kafka as its core piece.  With continuous growth in 10X capacity - we needed to â€œlearn on the jobâ€ how to improve our Kafka architecture by moving to the producer/owner cluster model, breaking up our massive monolith cluster to smaller and less fragile clusters with more resiliency and redundancy.In short this talk will discuss the steps we took to support our constant traffic growth.
outline:
â€¢ 2m Introduction: Who am I and my professional background
â€¢ 5m Architectural overview of old solution
â€¢ 20m Our solution: What steps we took to modernize out kafka architecture.
â€¢ 5m: Kafka Cluster Autoscale - how to achieve it?
â€¢ 5m Q&A
Total time: 37m

title: In the back(office) of your mind
abstract:
We all have them - admin pages or back-office tools - but nobody really wants to invest in them. 
This is a story about how two human errors in a single admin page - independently and within 24 hours - almost lost us a huge customer.
Weâ€™ll explore together how reliable admin pages may turn dangerous as organizations grow, and how a change in our mindset allowed for an improved product with happier users.
This talk attempts to sharpen your instincts - youâ€™ll understand when an admin page is actually an application in disguise.
outline:
2m Introduction: Who I am, what we do in Riskified
5m Incident description: What is our rules engine, how two bad rules sent wrong decisions to one of our customers and why this was at all possible.
1m Intermission: How we do post mortems in Riskified
2m Incident response: The immediate actions we took were to add stronger and smarter validations on the input and to add a framework for change management.
1m Beyond that, the incident forced us to understand this admin page is an internal application, which changed our view of the page as a product.
4m Understanding the admin page: a bit about possible stages from: a simple CRUD page and all the way up to an internal application. Some tips on understanding when to invest in a back-office framework.

title: The fastest guide to how to improve the sound in your app
abstract:
I would like to talk about Sound Design in applications & games and to share from my experience the following topics:
* Tips on how to easily create/edit better sound effects and music for your apps.
* Tips on how to work and talk with sound designers.
* What is Dynamic Sound & Adaptive Music, what does it have to do with your app, and some amazing tools to use in order to implement that in your app.
outline:
5m - Tips and experience sharing.

*** This talk can be expanded into a 15 minutes talk although it is not a postmortem.

title: Open the Deep Learning Black Box with Adversarial RNN
abstract:
While Deep Learning (DL) is proven effective black box, without the ability to peek into the inner workings of our model, to understand and guide the learning process, we quickly reach a glass ceiling.

We tackle this with an adversarial game: A DL model that learns  DL! 
While it can be generalized, we'll focus on NLP: Given an RNN that learns to embed text, we introduce an "Editor" model - by observing the  RNNâ€™s hidden states (without access to the input text) it predicts how editing each word will affect the RNNâ€™s performances - forcing it to analyze the RNNâ€™s perception of language and guide itâ€™s learning process.

We'll demonstrate the Editor as a highly effective analytical tool that reveals crucial patterns in our model's behavior, dataset and dramatically improve generalization.
outline:
2m Introduction: A little bit about myself and and my professional background

2m Defining the Problem: Why do we need to look inside the black box even if our model yields great results on our test sets (with some concrete examples)

3m Solution Overview:  An adversarial game between two players: An RNN that learns to read text in order to reduce some loss and an Editor that tries to increase the same loss by words editing. When the Editor edits a word, it replaces it by a token (â€˜editâ€™) and receives a penalty. Hence, the Editor needs to detect the most important words for the RNN in order to minimize the penalty. Note that the Editor's inputs are the RNN's hidden states, thus, it acts as a Deep Learning framework that learns machine learning. At the same time the RNN needs to utilize both syntax and semantics to compensate the missing information.

10m The Solution: Our reinforcement framework for the adversarial game

8m Experiments:  We use the editor both as a pure analytical tool (that is, without interfering the RNNâ€™s training) and for boosting the RNNâ€™s performances. We show our results for grounding textual phrases in images, where we are asked to find an object in an image based on a referential phrase.  This task offers a very intuitive way for us to understand how important each word is. While we observe a huge overfit, we see a dramatic reduction in overfit with the aid of the Editor. As an analytical tool, the Editor points us to a surprising pattern in the RNNâ€™s behavior and a destructive bias in our dataset. 

5m Q&A

title: What does 15 years of professional programming teach you
abstract: In years one and two you learn how to code. Then you spend the next 10 learning HOW TO CODE. The difference? Code written properly is easy to maintain, can be read like a book and you shouldnâ€™t need to study every line to understand what it is trying to achieve. Anyone can understand what you wrote, why you wrote it and its purpose. Like you would never need to refer back to a previous chapter in a book to understand what is happening, you shouldnâ€™t need to jump around the code to understand what a particular component, or statement does.  Code shouldnâ€™t just work. Code should communicate the concepts behind the software. During this talk I would like to share some of the techniques I have learnt in order to achieve that starting at requirements, to design and implementation to testing.
outline:
this talk is based on 2 modules I give in my courses.
I will need to shorten them, in order to fit into 30 mins.
The main topics I want to cover, are:
- naming- with respect to _intention_ of the object, and the relevant abstraction level.
 -making of simple, easy to use correctly API
 -reducing code
 -don't surprise!
 -unit testing, what and how.

title: From Zero to Hero- 3 months of Transfer (Learning)
abstract:
As data scientists in healthcare, we wanted to enhance our experience in Deep Learning.
Fortunately, the "Machine & Deep learning Israel" community managers decided to frontal teach, for the second time, the Stanford University course: "Convolutional Neural Networks for Visual Recognition".
We decided to jump at the opportunity.

In this lecture we will present our course final project, answering the following question: "Does Transfer Learning using a network trained to classify age and gender improves the detection of medical findings in chest X-ray images?".

This project is a collaboration with Zebra Medical Vision and is supervised by Ayelet Akselrod-Ballin, Eyal Toledano and Eli Goz. Extra credit to Amir Bar. Our classmates in the project are Netta Shemesh and Gil Baron
outline:
â€¢ 3m Introduction: who we are and our professional background
â€¢ 2m about "Machine & Deep learning Israel" community
â€¢ 5m presenting the research question: "Does Transfer Learning using a network trained to classify age and gender improves the detection of medical findings in chest X-ray images?"
â€¢ 2m the dataset that was used

â€¢ 15m The four stages of our project:
A. Training a network on the dataset (or a subset) to identify multi labeling of diseases in chest x-ray.  Loss will indicate the accuracy of the detected diseases.
B. Training a network on the entire dataset to detect age and gender of the subject. Loss will indicate the accuracy of age and gender.
C. Using transfer learning to retrain/ finetune the age/gender network to detect multi labels of diseases. Loss will indicate the accuracy of the detected diseases.
D. Introducing age and gender as features in the training process of network in a different stages. Loss will indicate the accuracy of detected diseases. Compare the training process and the result against the A and C networks.

â€¢ 3m Q&A
Total time: 30m

title: Now the code can listen - behind the scenes of voice biometrics
abstract: In this session, I will describe the fascinating world of voice biometrics and how we use it at NICE to address many use cases in our portfolio. I will explain how it is generally performed, main algorithmic approaches, the main challenges around such technology, and evaluation techniques.
outline:
5m intro to myself and to voice biometrics, what is it good for, where is it used.
10m Overview of the different techniques around speaker verification, and what are the challenges + ways to tackle them.
10m different evaluation techniques for these approaches.
5m Q&A

title: When my backend broke up with me
abstract:
Imagine that one day, your beloved and supporting backend partner decides that you should start seeing other API providers. 
â€œItâ€™s not you, it's me...â€ 
Thatâ€™s what happened to us, our backend was going to get deprecated and a new backend was about to be written in a way that supports multiple API clients and not just us.
Our endpoints will no longer be supported, our domain entities will no longer exist. How could we go on?Do we need to rewrite our entire code base to use this new backend? Is there anything we can do to ease the pain? Luckily, there are other fish in the sea, and in this talk weâ€™ll discuss the node server we created that helped us bridge between our existing client code and this new multi-clients backend.
outline:
* 1m - WHO am I
* 7m - WHY we needed a new Node Server - Our stack and basic architecture -> backend supports frontend directly through REST APIs. Wixâ€™s platform effort and intentions to deprecate old server.
* 4m - WHAT we built - Frontend server as a bridge, same endpoints on a new server.
* 15m - HOW we did it - outlining the work plan, creating domain entities translators, some helpful libraries that worked for us, integration cycles with the new backend, testing in production and how we transitioned.
* 3m - Q&A
Total 30 minutes

title: Meet IVY, Angular 3rd generation renderer
abstract:
The next major release of Angular will bring to the front stage their 3rd and most promising renderer engine, IVY.
What's making IVY so special? What causes Google to invest so much effort in re-writing their core framework renderer? What's the difference between the last view engine and IVY?  What is incremental DOM how IVY will make all FE development better and faster?
Join me to discover anything you need to know about IVY and Angular upcoming release.
outline:
Angular-UP 2018, "Generic Forms in Angular (30 min)": https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sb7tgsNF2Jk

JS-IL 2018, "Angular Universal - Server Side Rendering(20 min)": https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Hkow4k3ieeA

Angular-IL 2018, "Angular CDK - The Component Dev Kit(45 min)" https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0QAXh2UbsQU

Angular-IL 2018, "What's new in NGRX V7 & NGRX Meta Reducers"
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7Nwaw8OpJ0U

*Slides: https://www.slideshare.net/EliranEls/

title: Leading volunteers VS employees, does it differ?
abstract:
How do you drive your peopleâ€™s personal commitment?
If you look at management from the point of view of leading volunteers, how to make things happen without the power of â€œreal authorityâ€ and increase the employeesâ€™ motivation and ownership.
As a manager of both volunteers and employees, Iâ€™ll share my insights about dealing with those challenges.
I think that the approaches for the two might be much closer than one might think.
outline:
2m: Talk about the challenge as a leader of volunteers - making sure that the team is available, have clear communication between one another, representing the organization well and much more. 
2m: Talk about how to deal with those challenges - what most important is - appreciation! In addition to that, motivate the team, show the value and the purpose of your doing and clear guidance. 
1m: Explain how those insights can be applied easily to the state of mind of managing employees.

title: Predictably Lean - does Lean Startup mean No Deadlines?
abstract:
One of the main principles of Lean Startup is about creating quick build-measure-learn loops. While this is very helpful in finding market fit for products, there are occasions when setting and meeting a concrete deadline is the priority of the org. Think about a product launch, that should be coordinated with Marketing, Sales, Training etc.
In this talk you will learn about practical solutions for managing successful development teams that:
* Provide predictable deadlines and achieve them
* Use lean principles and iterate quickly
* Eliminate waste / buffers as much as possible
We will use a real-life case study of how we do it at Next Insurance.
outline:
1m intro and setting the context - The scope-time-quality triangle (choose two of the 3)
1m Not all features are born equal - use a hybrid approach: commit to hard deadlines for not more than 50% of the capacity, iterate and be flexible with the rest of the capacity.
1m Integrate before you implement - to expose risks as early as possible
1.5m real life example
0.5m closure

title: We donâ€™t need no specs!
abstract:
At Soluto we aim to empower team members, we want people to take initiative, engage, identify and solve problems. 
They have to do this while shipping in high quality and pace. 
We experiment with our process and keep what works.

For **technical tasks** we found ourselves repeating the same questions to DEVs (even after a spec session). Did you talk with X? How do others solve this? We felt we should do better.
Additionally quite often DEVs slipped from the Analysis phase into Development unconsciously, later waking up deep down a rabbit hole.

By the end of the talk attendees will know the simple "3 questions framework" DEVs on our team use to to breakdown tasks, so that they have a clear understanding of what they're going to build.
outline:
2m - Intro - Who I am, the team I'm on at Soluto.
5m - The problem we're solving, and how we encountered it. Developers not performing a good enough analysis of their tasks, resulted in wasted time and efforts.
3m - What we're trying to accomplish. This is supposed to save us time and make us more effective.
2m - Benefits we saw from using this framework. AKA - How we know this works.
8m - Presenting our solution to the problem - the 3 questions framework.
5-8m - Example.
2m - Recap.

Total time: ~30 minutes.

title: What I Learned From 9 Year Olds About Onboarding
abstract:
Only half of a mobile app's users use it more than once. Maybe they just got what they needed, but often they leave because theyâ€™re overwhelmed, not sure what to do or think they canâ€™t get what they came for.


Good onboarding and introduction can drastically improve this, but itâ€™s not easy to make it work for everyone. Some users like to be guided and hand-held, while others just want to explore. How can we support both types of beginners? Can we avoid a Clippy situation, an onboarding process that detracts more than it helps?


I spent 2 years at the MIT Media Lab investigating how to make it easier for kids to get started with Scratch, a coding environment for kids. In this talk Iâ€™ll share some key points learned along the way and demonstrate how to apply them in any onboarding process.
outline:
* Intro - My name and some context: worked on the Scratch team, researched onboarding in online, creative learning tools at the MIT Media Lab.
* The first thing I learned about onboarding: Itâ€™s harder than it looks! You need a lot of user testing and iterations, and things are not always as easy as they seem.
* Our â€œmantraâ€ for tools: Low floors, high ceiling, wide walls (easy to get started with, you can create very complex things, and it supports a variety of topics). 
* But how do you lower the floors, without lowering the ceiling and narrowing the walls?
To try to answer that, I created Scratch Microworlds which are simplified versions of Scratch, meant to help learners get started and make onboarding easier. 
* But I believe our insights are relevant for other tools as wellâ€¦
* We simplified - 
** Choosing few coding blocks (but not too few) - hiding elements can help reduce cognitive load. 
** Choosing ones that are simple, yet versatile and showcase what you can do - From ** â€œhello worldâ€ to â€œholy cowâ€.
** Our goal was supporting creativity, but in other tools it could be functionality/user goals. 
* We scaffolded -
** Scaffolding is creating a process you go through and learn a bit every time. 
** Avoid clippy situation! Nobody wants help thatâ€™s not helpful... 
** Knowing exactly what people want is really hard - instead, give them agency to explore on their own! 
** Users decide when to move forward
** Users decide where to go next - give options, not instructions.
* We motivated - 
** Help users answer the question - why should I even try this tool? 
** Show them whatâ€™s possible - there are many possible ways - intro video,  project gallery, tutorials. 
** We created a set of activities, each around a topics of interest, and made sure each showcases different aspects of things you can do. 
** Other products need to match the way they present possibilities to users with their product. 
* To sum it up, onboarding is not just helping your users know which button to click when, itâ€™s also a way to communicate your values, show what it possible, and help users expand their understanding. Itâ€™s not an easy task, but when it works, itâ€™s magical :)

title: From Zero to Agile: Scaling Your Data Science Team
abstract:
Data Science teams are usually highly-skilled and enthusiastic, but do they manage to stay relevant in face of extreme growth and an intense Agile environment?

In this talk, I'll suggest that although intuitively it makes sense to have an unstructured Data Science team that's not bound to agile principles, without any concern for execution and delivery -  ultimately this is counter-productive.
