I will review some fundamental steps to structure an impactful Data Science team, which includes creating a proper environment and work culture. 

In my experience as a Data Science leader, once weâ€™ve transitioned to become an Agile team that is focused on clear business KPIs, weâ€™ve managed to become a strong and independent force,  significantly impacting the companyâ€™s success.
outline:
5 minutes: 
Introduction, my role and the role of Data Science in my company. Review of the main principles of agile and how research & data science are usually different.


5 minutes: 
a review of the work environment and tasks performed by our data science team up until a few years ago. Examples to the kind of tasks weâ€™ve performed in our data science team and their (minimal) effect on the product.

10 minutes:
What did we do in order to make things better? We wanted to be able to plan and execute with higher precision, generate more value from time spent on research, and reduce noise and clutter from the day-to-day.  Weâ€™ve Established an internal language around deliverables and KPIs, defined an agile sprint structure to the teamâ€™s work and created a deployment infrastructure for new features and models in order to scale delivery of the teamâ€™s work, making it far more indepndent and impactful. 


5 minutes: 
Summary - what kind of feelings the team had during the â€œtransitionâ€ period where they suddenly had less independence and their work was more monitored and prioritized. 
Eventually, how did all of the changes affected the core product and its metrics and what did it do to our team members â€œsatisfactionâ€ metrics. 

5 minutes
Q&A

title: We donâ€™t need no specs!
abstract:
At Soluto we aim to empower team members, we want people to take initiative, engage, identify and solve problems. 
They have to do this while shipping in high quality and pace. 
We experiment with our process and keep what works.

For **technical tasks** we found ourselves repeating the same questions to DEVs (even after a spec session). Did you talk with X? How do others solve this? We felt we should do better.
Additionally quite often DEVs slipped from the Analysis phase into Development unconsciously, later waking up deep down a rabbit hole.

By the end of the talk attendees will know the simple "3 questions framework" DEVs on our team use to to breakdown tasks, so that they have a clear understanding of what they're going to build.

Intro video of talk:
https://youtu.be/jZiR4TRgGRY
outline:
30sec - Intro - Who I am, the team I'm on at Soluto.
1m - The problem we're solving, and how we encountered it. 
2m - Description of solution - 3 questions framework.
1m - Example.
30sec - Recap.

Total time: 5 minutes.

title: Mediocre Medians and Average Averages
abstract: As data scientists we find ourselves looking at the metrics of our analyses and models trying to figure out what's going on. We get so locked in on improving metrics such as MSE that we neglect looking at actual results. Sometimes biases in results are so blatantly obvious that just by skimming over raw results they stand out like a sore thumb. In this talk I'll focus on such a case I encountered while developing a recommender system for breaking news stories. By using examples from this project and some back of the envelop probabilities, I'll argue that looking at results for certain problems has more descriptive value than many summary metrics. Hopefully I'll convince you to get to know your predictions better, and next time you're analysing results you'll start by looking at them.
outline:
1 minute explaining the set up - we are data scientists and we don't look at data
1 minute - what happened in the project
2 minutes - how looking at the results solves this and what are the odds of seeing something relevant
1 minute - how this helps us to be better data scientists and save the world

title: Stop! Youâ€™re using your backlog wrong!
abstract:
At Soluto we try things to improve our work process, we keep what works, we found this adjustment to work, think it's worth sharing. 

Quite often teams find themselves in these situations:
1. A lot of tasks in the Doing phase.
2. Tasks not being completed. Dragging out.....
3. Knowledge Silos - â€œI donâ€™t know. Talk with X he worked on it.â€

A simple concept - Limit work in process --> Don't open new threads! Close exiting ones. 
Lead to to a small adjustment we did to the way we work which increased our team's focus and shipping speed.

This small change improved the way team members communicate and own tasks, it resulted in improvement to shipping speed, team spirit, and focus.

In this 5 minute talk Iâ€™ll show how teams can easily use this.
outline:
2m - Describe problem. 
1. A lot of tasks in the Doing phase.
2. Tasks not being completed. Dragging out.....
3. Knowledge Silos - â€œI donâ€™t know. Talk with X he worked on it.â€

1m - Intro to concept - Limit work in process - Don't open new threads.
1m - The solution we used.
1m - Conclusion.

Total time 5m.

title: The mystery of observables in the event loop cycle
abstract:
Although working with RxJs Observables simplifies complicated algorithms, the observable timing is not clear. Although the event loop cycle is described in detail in literature, it is not clear enough regarding observables. Is it a macrotask or microtask? Is it like setTimeout or is it like Promise? 
The answer is  - it can be both and we can control it with RX Schedulers.
outline:
â€¢	2m Introduction: Who I am and my professional background.
â€¢	5m RxJs intro.
â€¢	8m Schedulers in Rx.
Total time: 15m

title: Manage your Engineers as Managers
abstract:
Can you expect your engineers to act as managers?
Is it too high of an expectation or will it help them grow?
How will it impact your guidance and ability to closely work with them?

In this talk, I will share my experience, insights and conclusions as a manager of managers on this matter.
outline:
2m: What are the problems with expectations according to the current engineers' levels and with micro-management.
3m: What are the benefits of managing developers as managers - explaining how setting high expectation and provide freedom can contribute greatly to your team motivation and delivery.

title: From Developer to Manager and back again <==>
abstract:
The developer to manager path is a two way road.
We are Rona and Rona, working in the same team, both on the road, but in opposite directions. One transitioning from development to management, and one from management back to the IDE. And surprisingly, weâ€™re both going uphill.

When is the right time to take these turns, and why? What are the risks?

In this talk weâ€™ll each give her perspective, talk about how can one role benefit from the other, and share from our experience.
outline:
2m Introduction: who we are and our professional background
2m From a developer to a manager 
2m From a manager to a developer 
5m how to leverage your management skills in the developer role
7m Managing x-managers - how to elevate past managers in your team, and keep them motivated and growing.
7m The Risks - Can you become a manager again? Will you want to? What Will people think?
2m When is the right time to take these turns? Does this determine your career?
3m Q&A/Buffer

title: node.js love it or leave it
abstract:
Node.js has been around for a while now, and most will consider it stable.
But what happens when you turn your head away for a month or twelve? In this talk, I will share the adventures we went through to update a simple node.js app after not touching it for a year. It's a story about the good, the bad, and the broken API's.
outline:
2m intro: Who am I
3m prerequisite:  background story - why I didn't maintain the app for a year, what has changed in the meantime in the environment.
20m: what needed to be done in order to add new functionalities to the app, what did the background story expose, the highs, the lows and the breaking APIs
5m: Q&A

title: The question is not how, but why
abstract:
Questions, observation, assumptions. We keen to succeed and yet many of us fail to find the right formula. We utilize a set of primitives to accomplish that mission - asking questions, observing, and using our own assumptions to fill the voids. 

But perhaps because we're asking the wrong questions and reaching the wrong conclusions during our cognition, we fail that mission without a clear understanding.

This talk will challenge the way we approach our learning & conclusion. I will try to answer how we can improve our chances to nail that interview, deliver that feature we're working on, or just to be a better professionals.

I will try to demonstrate with real world examples how by rethinking the question - by focusing on the why, and not the how, we could achieve much more.
outline:
break the given illusion in interviews - nothing is given, ask everything. specific examples about few of the dozens of interviews I've been on both sides.

product task - same, remove our assumptions and question everything we believe.

title: What does it really take to move from Scrum to Kanban?
abstract:
After working in Scrum for years and struggling with its pitfalls, we've decided at Tipalti it's time to try a different project management approach.
We've started a journey wherein the end of it the entire organization was working in Kanban and practicing Continous Delivery. During this journey, we've learned many lessons about Kanban and about transitioning to it from Scrum. In this talk, I'll share the most important ones with you.
outline:
2m: Who am I and what does Tipalti do
2m: Why there are different project management methodologies
3m: Why Scrum didn't work for us, what options we faced
8m: Why did we choose Kanban - The non-obvious yet most important elements of it (task size, WIP limits) and how they solve our continuous delivery needs
5m: How the actual transitioning process worked, what were the main takeaways
5m: How do we make up for the weaker sides of Kanban - Using throughput, cycle time to measure ourselves and provide cost estimates
5m: Q&A

title: Economics 101 for Engineers
abstract:
Money, discount, debt, interest, regulation, incentives, and auctions are terms taken from the field of economic and are relevant for software development.

In this talk, I will give examples of how I used economics concepts and apply them to software development. This how I managed to take better decisions, motivate my team, and to improve code quality,
outline:
* Intro
* time is money - we set the time estimation for each feature and therefore sets its price. 
* discount - if time == money, then product manager love discounts., how to deal with it.
* interest - if time is money, you can borrow time, but then you have to pay interest. this interest is tech debt. Now You can explain tech debt to the business team.
* know your team - is it capitalist or a communist? if your team is a market, which type is it? does it support bottom-up innovation, and the best wins ? or is it a top down? 
* regulation - are you your team's regulator? who should set the standards? how to do it right.
* incentives - how I used the carrot and the stick method to execute a cultural change.
* How do we use auctions to motivate the team?
* summary

title: It Takes a Village: from training to community building
abstract:
You've been hired to migrate an organization from Ruby to Scalaâ€”two very different languages. It's your first day on the job. Now what?

In two years Riskified went from 2 Scala developers to 30, over 7 training rounds. Starting from a narrow focus on the immediate future, our mindset gradually shifted to "how to write good code" to "how we code".

In this talk I will describe how we evolved from training developers to forming a community inside the company, and share with you some strategies appropriate for growing companies.
outline:
- (2 minutes) I'll start by Introducing myself and Riskified
- (5 minutes) The challengeâ€”e.g. imperative vs functional, dynamic vs static, learning curve, etc...
- (12 minutes) From training to community building
  - Initial training program was limited to a specific stackâ€”why we chose this approach, and the drawbacks we later came to associate with it.
  - As teams mature, former trainees become mentors and trainers. Training shifts to language and mindset, teams pick up where formal training leaves off.
  - Ongoing training and cross pollination proved essential to successful adoption. I'll discuss what we tried, and what worked best for us.
- (8 minutes) Lessons learned: how to go through the adoption curve faster and more efficiently
- (5 minutes) takeaways, Q&A

The talk is planned for 30 minutes plus Q&A

title: 2147483647 OR watch your Int
abstract:
2147483647 = Integer.MAX_VALUE
We have almost reached this number of entities in our DB. we found it a few days before overflowing.  It could have been Outbrain Y2K bug, but it wasn't.

In this talk, I will describe the problem that we had, the action we took, the results, and the conclusions
outline:
* problem
* action we took, 
* results
* conclusions

title: Your Life Matters. Your Work Too. How Can You Find the Right Balance?
abstract:
â€œWork Hard Play Hardâ€ is a popular (and overused!) phrase among many hi-tech companies. But high salaries, game rooms, and Omer Adam are not all that matter in life -- or so I'm told...
Becoming a dad changed my priorities, and made balancing my work life and personal life more important.
In this talk Iâ€™ll share some of the things I do that have helped me find that balance, and try and answer the big question - am I still as valuable to my company and colleagues, despite spending less time working?
outline:
0.5m: Who am I and why am I talking about this.
1m: Why is work-life balance a good thing.
2m: What do I do to get a work-life balance
0.5m: Is your company parents friendly?
0.5m: The impact on the company - being parent-friendly and still be cool.
0.5m: takeaways

title: Tweek - Feature manager for the people
abstract:
Feature flags and user configuration systems are important! They allow PMs and developers to fully control their product behavior, run experiments, tweak user experience and handle a crisis. 

When we wanted to enhance our product delivery process at Soluto, we found out that publicly available feature management platforms are in short supply - most companies invest lots of engineering power for building their own in-house solutions.

In this session, Iâ€™ll showcase and demo Tweek - our open source, rich, user-friendly feature manager that can be easily used by everyone, anywhere!
outline:
1m - intro
1-3m - feature flags overview and examples
3-5m - intro to Tweek
5-7.5m - demo
7.5-10m - closing notes

title: How to Establish an Effective Open-Space Work Environment Without Going Postal
abstract:
Ever felt lost in an open space environment? Having a hard time concentrating with your co-workers warring over the AC? 
Creating an effective work space is one of the most important tasks in a companyâ€™s lifecycle.
Riskified has fully embraced open-space culture from its get-go. In this talk I will share how we learnt to not only survive its annoyances, but even thrive in what it offers in productivity, work culture and social relations.
outline:
* 30 seconds - Intro: work environments range from separated rooms, on to cubicles and to extreme open space.
* 2.5 minutes - at Riskified, we chose early on to go for the extreme open space. Doâ€™s and don'ts - the rulebook on how to make it work.
* 2 minutes - What we got out of it - start with productivity (how itâ€™s good for work), on to culture, and socially.
* Last 2 seconds: "Remember, if all else fails..." [take out and put on my noise-cancelling headphones]

title: Culture Manifesto (or How We Did It Together)
abstract:
[Culture Manifesto (or How We Did It Together)](https://www.notion.so/045066518a4f4692bee9d67dc790dc12)

[Logz.io](http://logz.io) took a very unique approach for defining It's Culture Manifesto. It involved the entire company in a several steps approach, which yielded a culture values statement we can actually stand behind and lean upon as our true north. In this lecture I'll cover what is a culture manifesto (with world-wide examples), why is it important to have a culture manifesto (the majority of Israeli don't have one), why it's not a BS as everyone thinks (i.e. how to avoid it), how did [logz.io](http://logz.io) manage to prepare one with the help of the entire company, and where we're headed with this process going forward.
outline:
-1m Intro
-3m What is a culture manifesto
-7m Examples from around the world
-15m The process we took to build [Logz.io](http://logz.io) culture manifesto
-20m The reasons why a manifesto is so important to build a healthy organization
-25m How to avoid turning it into BS
-27m What's next?
-30m questions from the crowd

title: Donâ€™t give me those puppy eyes
abstract:
Why do engineers feel so miserable when it comes to writing their tests?
In this talk, weâ€™ll explore this phenomenon, what is the mentality thatâ€™s causing it, truthfully look into the root causes (even if they are a bit embarrassing), and then talk about simple things that can be done to change that mindset. Letâ€™s make tests great again.
outline:
2 Intro
3 Why do I care?
Part 1 - Find the root causes
- 2 Why do engineers like to code?
- 3 Whatâ€™s the difference between writing â€œregularâ€ code and writing tests?
- 3 Why do engineers hate testing?

Part 2 - Resolutions
- 3 Getting into the right mindset
- 3 Understanding the down-to-earth value proposition of tests
- 5 â€œExpectation firstâ€ technique
- 2 Knowing your testing framework

3 Summary/Q&A

title: Doing Open Source by, for and with the Army
abstract: As many big companies and organizations in Israel - the army does its share of Open Source software usage. This short talk will cover its uniqueness and how does a closed network organization creates and releases Open Source. Also, Open Source is used to revolutionize the way it interacts with the IT industry.
outline:
1m - who am I
3m - what Open Source does the Army uses
3m - What Open Source does the Army creates
3m - How does the Army use Open Source to collaborate with the industry.

title: Python 2 to 3: Upgrading a large production system
abstract:
When Python 3 was released over a decade ago, it was slow and missing important features, in addition to being non-backwards-compatible. It took many years until the issues were resolved and most libraries added support for Python 3. Soon, Python 2 will finally reach the end of its life: when 2020 arrives, Python 2 will no longer be supported.

The amount of Python 2 code still in use is enormous! Many projects and organizations now clearly need to port their codebases to Python 3, but this is a non-trivial task which is usually met with anxiety.

I'll tell how I ported a large, monolithic codebase from Python 2 to 3, which approach and tools I used, and what I learned in the process. This should give a good idea of what such an upgrade entails and how it may be approached.
outline:
2m Introduction: About me and the context of the project.
2m What is Python 3: About 2.7, 3.x, and the long transition period.
2m Choosing an approach: How and why I chose to use 2to3.
3m How I used 2to3: How it works and how I used it.
2m Manual Fixes: Things I fixed manually since 2to3 couldn't.
1m Upgrading Dependencies: It basically just worked!
2m Hindsight: What I would have done differently, and how.
1m Results: Summary of this project's outcome.
1m Q&A

Total time: 14m + Q&A


Private note: I'm a much more charismatic speaker than the attached video would indicate! It's unfortunate my PyWeb-IL talks weren't filmed, as those would confirm this assertion :)

title: Anomaly Detection: The Bad Boy of Data Science
abstract: Rarely Normal or Normally Rare? Anomalies are by definition different and unconventional. A data point that doesn't follow the general rule.  The difficulty with defining the nature of the unconventional resonates with all the steps of trying to find it. In this lecture I'll review the art and  science of anomaly detection. We will explore classic and deep learning  approaches to define and find anomalies with any domain as well as some motivations to look for them in the first place.
outline:
2m: Introduction and examples of anomalies 
7 min: Review of statistical based methods
7 min: Review of model based methods 
7 min: Review of embedding based methods
Time left: Summary and time for questions

title: How We Hacked Zurich
abstract:
Last September I participated in HackZurich, Europeâ€™s largest Hackathon. Hundreds of engineers from all around the world gathered for 40 hours of coding, pizza, and NO sleep.
The Hackathon offered 16 different coding challenges. We chose to tackle the â€œMillenials on the moveâ€ challenge, provided by Esri and Zurich Insurance. The mission was clear - to use geospatial data to save lives on the roads.
In this talk, I will show how we came with an innovative approach to solve the challenge, which led to the winning solution.  We came home tired, happy and with awesome prizes!
outline:
1m - What is HackZurich
3m - Our project
1m - Tips

title: How to use Open Source to disrupt GIS in Israel
abstract: GIS software in Israel has for longtime been a monopoly. In recent years there's a shift towards Open Source both around the world and in Israel. But in our case, the de-facto monopoly makes this change more meaningful - both for technological and financial reasons.  This talk would go over the technology used to innovate in this market - from server side components to web and UI ones.
outline:
1m - who am I
2m - the problem of software monopoly
4m - Open Source software to the rescue (and why is more innovative)
3m - Mapping the market change, and the benefits from standards.

title: GraphQL - the missing piece in a serverless world?
abstract:
Microservices are awesome! Serverless is the future!! 
Who doesnâ€™t want to join the new revolution as we dissect, shard and split our evil monoliths into small, simple, stupid, smart, self-deployable units?
Yet, after we finish tearing up our backend, weâ€™ll need to face some new challenges such as joining our scattered data model, securing our different endpoints, and of course - creating a simple, robust API for our consumers.

For the last five years, weâ€™ve been using microservices heavily at Soluto and weâ€™ve encountered every one of these challenges.
In this session, Iâ€™ll dig into GraphQL, microservices, serverless, gateways and describe in details and code how GraphQL can serve as a uniformed layer across different services/functions/apps and provide the glue we so desperately need.
outline:
The talk will cover the evolution from monolith to smaller units and the challenges that come with it. We'll see how API gateway and more specifically GraphQL based solutions can tackle these issues.

0-2m - What's great about Monoliths
2-4m - Enter microservices
4-6m - The missing pieces
6-9m - More services/functions
9-10m - What do we need?
10-12m - API gateways
12-14m - Examples
14-18m - GraphQL intro, and examples
18-21m - GraphQL vs rest as a gateway
21-23m - Different solutions
23-28m - Soluto's GraphQL solution, with a demo
28-30m - Closing notes

title: Programmer or Activist? Why not both!
abstract:
Software-Engineering and Animal-Rights are two passions of mine.
When I do one and not the other - I feel something is missing in my life.
About 3 years ago I've started my journey as part-time programmer, part-time Activist (also a programmer) - and I'm not going back!

In my short talk I would discuss the challenges and advantages of this life-style for the programmer as well as for the employer, share some funny moments, and talk about the challenges.

I would like to encourage the audience to take that path - 
to make their lives - and the world - a better place.
outline:
1m introduction and my story - 
 * "Hi I'm Eyal Pinkas - I work at Next-Insurance (we're hiring) and a volunteer at Animals-Now (Formerly Anonymous - we're looking for volunteers :) )."
 * "...I had a good job, but wasn't happy - I decided to dedicate time to activism. This is how I did it.."

2m the challenges, and what does it look like:
  * finding a job
  * keeping in sync with two work-places
  * managing time - work-life-volunteer balance

2m the advantages
  * learn twice as much - 2 domains, 2 cultures, different technologies, etc
  * implement lessons from one domain on the other
  * be loved twice as much
  * Impact on something you care about - more than money can buy
  * flexibility - works for employer as well (elastic developer!)
  * for the employer - employee thinks about work also when he's not around
  * for the employer - Loyalty
  * for the employer - think millennials - this is where the world is going.

title: Technical Roadmap How To Guide (or Tech Debt Is So 2018)
abstract: Companies struggle to keep the balance between happy engineering to advancing business features. Most fail at it, and accumulate large technical debt creating frustrated engineering. This can be done differently when combining Technical Leadership from the CEO combined with a unique strategy for combating Technical Debt. In this lecture I'll explain how the strategy of building a Technical Roadmap composed of Goals and milestones for each, and interweaving it into your ongoing planning cadence, helps you change the way you view Technical Debt and effectively eliminate this concept all together.
outline:
Intro
What is Technical Debt ?
Why approaching it as Debt is spiralling the organization down
The Technical Roadmap strategy - or Interweaving 101
This won't work without Technical Leadership - why?
How to do it at your organization?

title: LANDIS: The stack of the serverless generation
abstract:
The rise of serverless computing platforms is a major force that creates new opportunities (and, of course,  risks). In this talk we will focus on the LANDIS stack which emerges as a dominant pattern for quickly delivering applications and services that are inexpensive but, at the same time, are inherently scalable and reliable.

Specifically, LANDIS stands for:
Lambda
API Gateway
Node
DynamoDB
Identity (Pool)
Static (web-site hosting)

Discussing the various components of this stack, we will cover patterns, practices and pitfalls. For instance, we will explore topics such as: is API Gateway always needed; why is Node the recommended runtime for the backend (Lambda); how to protect yourself from financial exhaustion; codebase structure; and, the elephant in the room: cold starts.
outline:
3m: intro and background
3m: quick overview of the stack
5m: pros and cons (compared to non-serverless stacks)
7m: variations: API Gateway yes/no? why DynamoDB? Can I use python instead of Node?
5m: adjustment to the dev experience that are needed (patterns and practices)
3m: should I worry about cold starts, and what can be done about them

title: Lies, damn lies and statistical thinking
abstract:
Probability and statistics are fundamental fields in our modern world, yet they are not widely thought and often poorly understood and often counterintuitive. As a result, many misconceptions, erroneous beliefs and fallacies have taken root in common thought.
This talk provides examples of such misconceptions and aims to show how we can better understand the world by building our statistical intuition.
outline:
- introduction (2m)
- Individual and series probability (5m)
- Natural variation (5m)
- Significance, confidence and errors (5m)
- Bayes theorem and the base rate fallacy (5m)
- Sampling bias, survivor bias and other biases (5m) 
- Summary (2m)

title: Contributing to Open Source as a 16 year-old Student
abstract: Contributing to open source has become very popular among adult programmers who are already employed and experienced in the field, but many teens and younger people havenâ€™t even heard of the term. I myself first heard about open source 3 years ago, and quickly found myself becoming an active maintainer and contributor to many projects, as well as a much better software developer. In this session Iâ€™ll talk about my own journey through programming and open source, and how more people like me can start contributing themselves. You will leave this session ready to make your first contribution and make a positive impact.
outline:
- 1m Introduction: Who am I and a bit about me.
- 3m My personal story: from first learning to code to the present.
- 3m What I contribute to OSS, how I improved by contributing and why Iâ€™m still doing it.
- 3m How others like me can start contributing to open source, and how maintainers and - adult developers can encourage and help them.

title: A musician in a tech company
abstract: At JoyTunes weâ€™re creating piano courses for self learning users. This talk will open a window to the people responsible for sprinkling the fairy dust - the musicians. From creating new music to cracking the pedagogy suited to all kinds of users. this talk will shortly demonstrate the technology we use in our day-to-day life.
outline:
1 min: Intro - Who am I 
1 min: our day-to-day challenges 
3 min: live demo of creating a track using state-of-the-art sampling software.

title: I want to grab the next 23 minutes and 11 seconds to discuss time estimations
abstract:
Time estimations are an essential part of the software development process. The rise of agile methodologies has even made it easier to come up with more accurate time estimation for engineering tasks. This talk will highlight subtleties, hidden trap doors, and even paradoxes, that await teams that try to over do time estimations. These include:
- time-to-market vs. calendar deadline
- engineering estimation vs. end-to-end estimation
- why is striving to make fully accurate time estimations dangerous to your business?
- are there project types for which time estimations are not as important?
- what is the "black market of time"?
outline:
3m: intro and background
5m: time estimations: the good parts
3m: the importance of slack time
4m: the time-slip paradox: intolerance to time-slips actually encourages delays
4m: the equation of value/time is not that and not that accurate
3m: what are time estimations so inherently inaccurate? (answer: to make precise estimations you need to break it down to discrete tasks but this manifests another problem: estimating the number of tasks)
3m: is there anything practical we can do that is not destructive to the team? 
2m: how to meet real, hard, deadline

title: Blktrace.py transparent block devices
abstract:
Everyone does IO
Everyone cares about performance.
Linux exposes a lot of information about the inner working of its block devices.

But until now, the only way to access this information was to run the blktrace command line utility.

In lightbits.io, we wrote a python library that enables programmatic access to this information.
outline:
2m introduction
3m explain which information is exposed by the library.
3m show example use case
1m summary

title: You donâ€™t have a production environment
abstract:
"We have a problem in production! does it reproduce in staging?" is a sentence often uttered in many companies. Underlying this simple sentence lie implicit assumptions about environments which often turn out to be false in our modern services and applications. Clusters and micro-services complicate matters and make production environments hard to reproduce and model, but when A/B tests, feature toggles and ephemeral containers, serverless functions and multi-tenancy are introduced one must conclude we no longer have a "production environment", but rather "production environments", plural. In a sense, every transaction experiences a unique unreproducible universe.
In this world, what is the value of Staging environments? how does such understanding change our development processes?
outline:
- introduction: 2m
- The old world: prod/stage/testing/dev (5m)
- Clusters and microservices (5m)
- Dev environment in the microservices world - multi tenancy (5m)
- A/B tests and feature toggles (5m)
- Working in a complex world (10m)

title: How to think like an SRE
abstract: SRE - site reliability engineers is the term for proffesionals who deal primarily with handling production incidents. in this talk we will several "light bulb" moments that happened to me, when working with SREs, in which I realized how point of view of an SRE is different than that of a coder.
outline:
Here is a link to the slides (draft):

https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1ZZAhXAEUY6kE8EX0aT3gMH7ifojU1vHNu3ByJj4GLp4/edit

title: Fuzzy Text Search: A Story of Algorithm Optimization
abstract:
This is the easy-to-follow story of the algorithms and optimizations used to write the fuzzysearch Python library.

It starts with the classic linear-programming algorithm for calculating the Levenshtein distance between two strings. From there I'll describe, step by step, the development of the algorithms used to implement efficient fuzzy searching. Optimization is at the heart of this, since the goal is to find fuzzy matches efficiently.

I will describe varied optimization techniques, from low-level bit fiddling in C extensions written manually and with Cython, up to analyzing the problem domain and reducing the search space. There's a surprise twist at the end which had significant impact on the project and is a great take-away, but I won't spoil it here!
outline:
1m: Introducing myself.
2m: The Journey Begins: How the project started.
3m: Introducing the Levenshtein distance: What it is and the classic linear-programming calculation algorithm.
2m: How to Search: Initial discussion of how to go about a fuzzy search, and the first two basic optimizations.
3m: Candidates: A new approach with great benefits.
3m: Generic Search: A generalization of the Levenshtein distance metric.
2m: Backward vs. Forward calculation.
4m: Writing C extensions: In Cython and C.
4m: Plot Twist: The new approach that changed everything.
2m: Benchmarks
1m: Final Notes
3m: Q&A

title: From backend to hundreds of servers in (a few) seconds
abstract:
Taboola services rely heavily on having fresh data. Whether it's campaigns related data, configurations or kill-switches. relevant information must propagate fast reliably way to all services.
delivering fresh information across ~700 frontend servers, spreading over 7 time-zones means you always fight the endless battle of how fresh is your data the load you create by fetching that data. With frontend servers handling over 500k HTTP requests p/s we have very little resources to spare.
As we continue to grow we find ourselves tweaking caches frequently.so we decided to take another path. 
Join us to hear how we leveraged MySql replication with our Kafka know-how. Achieving near real-time data injection from our backend db to ALL services within seconds, with very little load on the services
outline:
2m : introduction about Taboola and the scale + my position @ Taboola

7 min : Presenting taboolaâ€™s conventional way of  metadata at scale :
We use Mysql as a metadata db, with centralized master DB residing within our backend data center. Master db have slaves containing a replicated copy of parts of the data. The replicated dbs spread across the remote data centers. Updates/inserts/deletes are performed only on the master db - ensuring consistency. Reads can be made from any slave or master if it is crucial getting the most up to date data.

We use a few levels of caching above mysql data:
Memcached - keeping projected values of mysql row data
Local Key-Value store (AKA Updatable cache) : Data is loaded on demand, Has various expiration and eviction policies, Can (and 99% of the time) update expired key on the background
Local machine bulk cache: Loading data periodically from mysql, Reads from it cannot trigger a fetch from the db
5 min : Talking about the issues
Why Taboola needs fresh metadata so badly:
Closed/Stopped campaigns are still presented, causing Taboola to lose money
On a large scale system a broken feature flag could cause massive damage, in a matter of minutes if not closed. An extreme issue we had was a new feature that caused such a load on the DB that we got timeouts on reading the configuration that was supposed to close it. Being unable to close the killswitch we had to restart a major part of the frontend services
(Near) Real-time controlling of computational â€œexpansiveâ€ features across an entire DC - depending on traffic
Load on services:
Updating caches on a high scale service is a complicated task. On one side you want to keep the cached value for as little as possible. And on the other hand you want to reduce the load on the service and on the DB. For example : Taboolaâ€™s campaigns cache, has sparse data. raising its TTL of the cache to 10 times of its current value reduces the load by 10% on the FE service!
As a result of trying to reduce the load we often need to increase cache TTLs. causing an inherent delay in getting fresh data
Replication delays: Not all db changes need to propagate fast. Since mysql cannot defer between them a very large amount of updates can cause a replication delay, on all data. Even though we do not mind about getting the overloading data in a delay
Transparency - or the lack of it : You cannot measure on delay of data per table (arrival time of data to the slave - row change/insert/delete time on the master)

3 min : Mysql master-slave quick overview:
A short inroduction about what is MySql binlog
10 min : The solution
Breaking the conventional pattern - bypassing mysql replication: 
A Service listening on master-db binlog file, batching the changes writing it encoded to Kafka on a dedicated topic (protobuff)
Mirroning the messages from the backend kafka to all Frontend kafkas
Consuming the messages from within the service
â€œInjectingâ€ the change directly to the cache
Raising the TTL of connected caches - reducing the load
Why did we choose to go that way ?
DB changes on master-db can come from a large number of points including manual queries. There is no single point in which we could plant a code that sends the data to kafka. We have to â€œhackâ€ the db for that
We already use kafka to transfer huge amounts of data, we have confidence that we can transfer the data with very low latency and no data loss
A single consumer load the server a lot less resources than multiple background threads updating the caches
We get a total delay of less than 4 seconds between the time of change in the db until ALL FE services update the cache (P99)
Showing some graphs of real-time data metrics
3 min : Conclusions and Takes
When should you use it ? this solution has a lot of moving parts, it's here to solve a scale issue caused by reading sparse data from mysql on a busy server. It has a lot of risks but on critical data that freshness is super important, the reward is huge! 
Now that we have all master-db data streamed we can leverage it to more stuff other than service caches - near real-time analysis 
Q&A

title: Logz.io Journey to Self Service Developers
abstract:
Shortly after we began developing at Logz.io, we began to envision a development environment in which developers would be able to develop a feature, end-to-end, without relying on other teams. This vision was, and still is, based on a value of accountability that is part of our culture manifesto.

In this talk, I will unfold the journey we made as a company to the current state of things, where development is 100% self service -- from design to coding, testing, deploying, monitoring and debugging. This story includes Docker, Kubernetes, Apollo (our open source deployment app), Jenkins and processes and methodologies we adopted and enhanced (e.g. The Diamond Model for testing).
outline:
- Intro (1min)
- How we started --> the vision we had in mind: Self service developer, through each development phase (2min)
- Design phase: (2min)
- Code phase: (5min)
- Testing phase: (10min)
- Deployment phase (5min)
- Monitoring phase (5min)

Lecture Video: https://vimeo.com/291350140

title: bigband: lambdas, DBs, deployments and all that serverless jazz.
abstract:
npm/bigband is an open source tool coming out of testim.IO allowing developers to easily assemble multiple AWS resources (Lambda functions, DynamoDB tables, Kinesis streams) into fully functioning services. Main features include:

- a very simple and intuitive command interface

- automatically decides what needs to be deployed

- Manages and updates IAM policies making them essentially hands-free

- Allows reuse of service definitions from other NPM packages


This tool powers all of Testim's Lambda-based applications. It is now offered to the entire open source community.
outline:
1m: intro
2m: the bigband.config.ts file
4m: demo - deploy, run, edit, deploy, run
3m: design at a glance: why typescript, teleporter (the quick deploy sub-component), anatomy of an "instrument"

title: Building Distributed Systems in Distributed Teams
abstract:
Building distributed systems is notoriously hard... building a distributed team, even more so. At Elastic â€” the company behind the open source tools Elasticsearch, Kibana, Beats, and Logstash â€” everything is distributed; the company and our products. This talk dives into the details of how we are thriving on our distributed model:

* How we started to be distributed by design.
* What our shared values are and what we have learned as we progressed and grew to our current size.
* What the day of an Elastician can look like.
* What we are using in terms of tooling.
* How we hire and onboard new employees.
outline:
2min intro: Where are you working today?
2min stats: Current size and distribution in terms of timezones, languages,...
5min how: Distributed by design and how we make it work.
5min values: Our development constitution (public on GitHub).
5min experience: How my personal experience looks like.
5min downsides: What are the pain points of not having an office.
2min tools: How do we collaborate.
2min closing: Conclusion.

Total time: 28min + Q&A

title: Make More than Music with WebMIDI, JavaScript & Tiny Computers
abstract: Did you know thereâ€™s a widely-supported browser API that allows you to interface with a wide variety of hardware, including some you can build yourself? Wonder no more and meet the WebMIDI API! Weâ€™ll look at how MIDI â€” a niche protocol from 1983 designed for electronic musical instruments to talk to one another â€” JavaScript and â€œtiny computersâ€ like the Arduino, Espruino and RasperryPi can be used to build interactive, non-musical experiences that straddle the line between the web and physical world.
outline:
I'm often changing the demos for each talk and try to feature several interactive examples. The outline generally goes as follows, though I've extended and condensed based on available time,  going as short as 15 minutes and long as 90 (!!):

- Brief introduction about me and my talk
- Brief introduction to Espruino and other "tiny" computers via JavaScript.
- Brief talk on the evolution of Node along that same timeline.
- Brief talk about MIDI, what it solved
- Brief talk about why MIDI and the event-driven nature of Node compliment one another.
- A look at some of the packages and projects that make MIDI interfacing easy in Node.
- Why it dovetails nicely with Node and also the Internet of Things
- Why I chose this stack and decided to talk about it: background in music, interesting use for recycled music equipment.
- Examples of IoT projects I've made using this tech stack of Tiny Computer, MIDI and JavaScript (#1)
- Examples of IoT projects I've made using this tech stack of Tiny Computer, MIDI and JavaScript (#2)
- Examples of IoT projects I've made using this tech stack of Tiny Computer, MIDI and JavaScript (#3)
- Examples of IoT projects I've made using this tech stack of Tiny Computer, MIDI and JavaScript (#4)
- Examples of IoT projects I've made using this tech stack of Tiny Computer, MIDI and JavaScript (#5)
- A breakdown of how I'm using this stack to run my presentation and slideshow
- How to create your own version of this stack at home: which versions of Linux to use, packages, etc. 
- Hardware recommendations: adapters, interfaces, which you can take apart and which you can leave as is
- Discuss how this stack makes for a cheap, affordable IoT stack for teaching IoT programming to kids (and in general!)
- List of ideas for other projects and the future of this stack for creative applications
- Discussion of things that could or should be improved
- Other similar tech stacks that blend old and new to explore from here.

title: JavaScript for Artists
abstract:
A bot that sings to you when you're sad? Generative poetry derived from classic literature? Paintings that draw a composite of every person that's ever looked at them? The cutting-edge web technologies that can power these creative applications are easier to use than ever!

Modern JavaScript conventions, browser APIs, AI services and IoT hardware provide a unique platform for artistic expression, exploration and creation. In this talk we'll examine this type of interactive application development and look at the open-source projects, APIs, services, hardware and approaches to creating expressive works through JavaScript â€” audio, visual and otherwise.
outline:
I frequently change the demos but the general outline looks like this:

- Introduction to types of interactive "art projects"
- A very brief history of how technology influences art (and vice-versa)
- A look at the JavaScript artist's palette:
    - Modern Browser APIs (Web Audio, Microphone, Camera, Web MIDI, Geolocation, etc.)
    - JavaScript Libraries (p5.js, processing.js, three.js, etc.)
    - Overview of JavaScript-friendly hardware (Espruino, CHIP, RasperryPi, etc.)
    - Exploring AI and deep-learning-driven services (AWS Rekognition, Lex, Polly, etc.)
- 3-5 Code examples and demos using previously mentioned APIs, libraries and hardware    
- Future APIs, services and creative potential
- How creative exploration makes us better developers (summary)

title: (Math.random()*9)+1 Facts on Random Numbers & JavaScript
abstract: Randomization is an important tool in any developer's toolkit, but do you know how it actually works? Did you know some approaches can be more "random" than others and what those implications are? In this talk we'll take a deep-dive into pseudo-random number generation in JavaScript â€” how they are generated, how to make more cryptographically-sound random numbers with the Web Cryptography API and why we should care. We'll also explore practical and creative applications of randomness in building software.
outline:
The outline looks something like this:


- Introduction
- Brief history of random numbers in computing: what problems they solved, the approaches taken
- Discuss importance of randomness in cryptography & security
- Early Math.random() implementations in JavaScript
- Alternative algorithms for randomness: MWC1616, XorShift128+
- The Web Cryptography API: What it solves, why it exists and when to use it
- *Extremely* alternative algorithms for randomness: atmospheric microphone noise, images, cellular automata, APIs and quantum computing
- Non-cryptographic use-cases for randomness
- Why you, as a developer, should care :)

title: Going the Distance with SVG, Headless & Serverless
abstract: Running apps without servers and browsers without screens sounds a little absurd, but it can be a surprisingly efficient way to solve certain problems. In this talk George will discuss a real-world solution built on top of serverless technologies and Puppeteer â€” the Headless Chrome Node API â€” to work with the SVG DOM on-the-fly and create print-ready documents from GPS routes. The audience will get a firsthand look at how cutting-edge JavaScript technologies and language features were integrated with a preexisting legacy PHP backend and minimal casualties.
outline:
The outline for this talk looks something like this:

- General introduction
- What Puppeteer is and how to get started with it
- Challenges in using serverless architecture and Puppeteer together
- Overview of specific task (Strava API -> GPS routes -> print-ready maps on the fly)
- Challenges in implementation with existing PHP legacy system
- Additional design and workflow challenges (Working with provided pre-existing SVG templates)
- High-Level view of how the final solution was implemented
- How this approach compares to the legacy version
- Why DOM manipulation on the server was chosen over client-side in this scenario
- Future improvements and thoughts on using this stack for other applications

title: Reaching Zen in Your Coordination Layer
abstract: Distributed systems are hard and unfortunately often less perfect than we would hope. This talk shows a concrete example: Elasticsearch's cluster coordination system, called Zen Discovery, got a rewrite in version 7.0. Starting from a formal model, the coordination layer was rebuilt to address multiple issues discovered over the years. We discuss the main improvements of the new implementation: Master elections are much faster, the infamousÂ minimum_master_nodes setting has been removed,Â growing and shrinking clusters becomes safer and easier, and leaves less room to misconfigure the system. Let us join the new, more Zen way of cluster coordination.
outline:
2min intro: About the project and me.
5min problem: Problems of the existing implementation in Zen.
5min restart: Creating a formal problem to have a more sound foundation.
5min implementation: Discussing the most important changes in the implementation.
5min improvements: Showing the main advantages of Zen2.
3min conclusion: Recap and outlook into the future.

Total time: 25min plus Q&A

title: How to Reach the Moon
abstract: What were the main challenges of Beresheet's design, and what surprised us during the voyage to the Moon? What were the rejected versions of the spacecraft and how did we choose the final one? In this talk you will hear for the first time about some of the behind-the-scenes decision making moments that eventually made the mission a huge success

title: The Reversim Story
abstract: How, when and where did the podcast and the conference came to be. Stories behind the scenes and the unwritten (unspoken) history of technical content in Israelâ€™s tech

title: Abstractions All the Way Down
abstract:
Don't you just love creating a good, elegant, juicy abstraction? Extracting the ESSENCE of a problem. Coming up with generalizations. Debating their relative merits of a on social media. It's all so much more fun than solving these pesky bugs that keep coming back from QA. 
We are developers, dammit! Abstractions are what we do!
 
On our day-to-day, we often don't think about the level of abstraction we employ to solve a problem, or how the abstractions we choose affect the kind of solutions we reach. But what if we could think abstractly about abstract thinking? Let's explore the ways the mental model of the ladder of abstraction can help us choose our career path, solve problems, deliver clearer messages and help others grow.
 
very meta. so philosophy. much recursion. wow.
outline: keynote
